webTitle: Last rites for the holy Trinity

fields.headline: Last rites for the holy Trinity
fields.standfirst: Stadium expert Simon Inglis tells why he will lay a wreath today at Aston Villa's much-loved stand
fields.trailText: Stadium expert Simon Inglis tells why he will lay a wreath today at Aston Villa's much-loved stand.
fields.body:
No matter what the score between Aston Villa and champions Manchester United today, I and hundreds of other home fans shall leave Villa Park this evening with heavy hearts. For despite a creditable League placing and, next week, our first Cup Final since 1957, today the final curtain falls for the 76-year-old Trinity Road Stand.

'How can they pull this building down,' demands Hans van Eijden, a disbelieving Dutchman, one of many visitors who regularly come to feast upon the stand's unique red-brick frontage.

Quite easily, is the answer. Frustratingly, the stand has never been listed, despite its apparent pedigree alongside those other listed stands at Arsenal, Fulham and Rangers. (English Heritage claim that there have been too many alterations to justify preservation.) Nor until February, after nearly three years of wrangling between the club, planners and local residents, did most fans realise that the stand would be demolished, rather than extended. Since the penny dropped, other than a few diatribes in fanzines and on the internet, there has been no meaningful protest.

'We're an apathetic lot, us Brummies,' a club official tells me, by way of an explanation.

'The first I heard of the stand being knocked down was when Doug Ellis [the Villa chairman] was interviewed on radio,' says Ian Robathan, a call-centre analyst who launched a belated preservation campaign via his website (www.dougout.ukweb.nu).

'First I was angry,' Robathan explains, 'then resentful, because the club did so little to inform fans exactly what was happening. I was angry not only at the club but angry at myself and the other fans for not doing more to save this final link with our Victorian past.'

Actually the stand is not that old. But before Villa Park was opened in 1897 the site was home to the Aston Lower Grounds, a sort of Victorian theme park with boating lakes, a theatre and gardens. Until 1981 Villa's offices were partly housed in the former aquarium; until 1966 there was even a bowling green in front of the Trinity Road Stand.

Bit by bit, building by building, all traces of that once grand complex have disappeared. Yet amid all this, most fans always assumed that the jewel in the crown - the one Victorian-style feature that made Villa Park so special - would remain sacrosanct.

The Trinity Road Stand and I go back a long way. I first sat there in 1962, aged seven, watching Villa trounce Leicester 8-3. In 1985 I bought my first season ticket on the upper tier, in Block E, Row D, where I have remained ever since, halfway between the centre line and the Holte End. Apart from home, no other place in the world has ever felt so much like home.

But I have other reasons for feeling bereft, as the author who first brought to the public's attention the identity of the stand's designer. I refer to one Archibald Leitch, the now posthumously celebrated Glaswegian engineer whose firm was involved in the design of 27 grounds in Britain between 1900 and 1939.

As I came to realise when writing Villa Park's centenary history, however, the real architect of the stand was the club chairman, Fred Rinder. Rinder masterminded Villa's greatest ever run of success between 1893 and 1914, at the same time as organising the purchase and layout of Villa Park. The Trinity Road Stand was the first phase of his grand scheme to create a final capacity of 104,000.

Unfortunately, by the time the stand was opened by the Duke of York in 1924, its costs had spiralled to nearly £65,000 (at a time when the country's costliest player cost £5,000). Moreover, the 'architectural agitator' as Rinder was dubbed, got rather carried away. To Leitch's original, quite modest design, he added the Oak Room (the first restaurant at a British ground), steam rooms and an X-ray machine. Other Rinder touches, still visible today (if not tomorrow), included leaded windows, curved panelling on the upper tier balcony, gold-leaf mosaics and pavilion-style towers flanking a central stairway. Each would become instantly recognisable hallmarks, rivalled subsequently only by stands at Rangers and then Arsenal in the early Thirties.

Yet other than the stand, not a single memorial to Rinder exists at Villa Park, largely, I assume, because the costs nearly bankrupted the club, leading Rinder to be ousted by angry shareholders only a year after the stand's inauguration (though he was later forgiven and rejoined the board).

Some might say that I deserve scant sympathy in the circumstances. Since the Taylor Report I have expended thousands of words in attempting to soothe the fears of fans at other clubs as their charming but rickety old stands and gloomy terraces have been torn down. Don't fear the future, I have trilled. Modern architecture can be fun!

So now comes my turn to be counselled. 'We have to move on,' I am assured by Mark Ansell, Villa's financial director. 'You can't expect a business, particularly in the service industry, to offer the sort of facilities that are required today in a 76-year-old building.'

I do not doubt him. After a decade of being immersed in such issues, I might have scripted his comments myself. For I concede that the toilets are inadequate, as are the catering outlets. The nine roof columns are an undoubted irritant. By contrast, the new stand (costing £10.5 million) will offer 4,000 more seats, have no restricted views, and will accommodate between 80 and 120 wheelchair users and their helpers, in prime positions, compared with only 39 as at present, all confined to the corners.

Dennis Swain, the new stand's architect, insists that Villa will salvage as much as they can from the old building; the mosaics and the distinctive roof gable in particular, and, I hope, two turnstiles dating back to 1895. Swain knows he's on a hiding to nothing with the new stand, all the same. Too modern and he'll anger traditionalists. Not modern enough and he'll be accused of a loss of nerve. It is a burdensome responsibility, made harder by the club's well-known insistence on value for money.

Naturally I would prefer to hear an altogether different message; that the club will splash out whatever it takes in order to deliver a stand as outstanding for its time as was the Trinity Road Stand in the early Twenties. Instead, I can't help feeling as if a solid old Bentley with leather seats and a walnut dashboard is being sacrificed for a new hatchback. Certainly more comfortable, certainly not unattractive. But hardly distinctive nevertheless.

Of course the Trinity Road Stand is not alone in succumbing to the modernisers. Of the twentieth century's other fine grounds, it will soon be the turn of Wembley's twin towers, two other Leitch landmarks, Craven Cottage and Goodison Park, and almost certainly Highbury too.

Which is why there are possibly hundreds of fans reading this who will sense exactly my unease, and understand why, at three o'clock this afternoon, I will join Ian Robathan in placing a wreath on the Trinity Road Stand's grand central staircase. We expect to be moved on by some jobsworth, but I know we will not be alone in our brooding. After today, Villa Park, and the landscape of English football, will never be the same again.

Simon Inglis's new book, Sightlines - A Stadium Odyssey (Yellow Jersey Press, £18) is published on 25 May

webTitle: Half a century - a whole lot to do

fields.headline: Half a century - a whole lot to do
fields.standfirst: A few checks as you hit 50 will leave you better provided for retirement, writes  Andrew Bibby
fields.trailText: Birthdays are a bit like buses. You wait for ages for them to come when you're a child, only to find later in life that they arrive rapidly, one after the other. Years rush by and suddenly the big five-oh has arrived and you're in your fifties, with retirement around the corner. For many, this is the last chance to get their retirement provisions into shape.
fields.body:
Birthdays are a bit like buses. You wait for ages for them to come when you're a child, only to find later in life that they arrive rapidly, one after the other. Years rush by and suddenly the big five-oh has arrived and you're in your fifties, with retirement around the corner. For many, this is the last chance to get their retirement provisions into shape.

As Donna Bradshaw of adviser Fiona Price and Partners points out, this involves taking a strategic view of your financial affairs. 'Pension planning means looking at more than just pension funds,' she says. 'It includes considering all your other investments, and also whether you can anticipate receiving any inheritance. You have a 10-year period or so to make the most of your investments. But 10 years is a good time scale, offering opportunities for equity investing.'

As well as checking occupational or personal pension arrangements, it is worth remembering the possibility of using Individual Savings Accounts to save for retirement. Unlike pension schemes, Isas do not have tax advantages at the point where contributions are made, but thereafter they are outside the tax net and offer more flexibility than pensions. You should also not forget your state pension.

This is not to say that people in their fifties spend all their time having earnest conversations with financial advisers. In fact, as Denise Knowles, a Relate counsellor, says, this period can be a time of quite radical changes. 'There's a kind of rebellion going on,' she says. 'People in their fifties still have a lot of life ahead, and may be doing things their parents might never have even dreamed of, like backpacking round Australia or buying a motorbike.'

This process may involve re-evaluating work. Choosing to take early retirement and then setting up as an independent consultant is a well-established route - though the pension implications of leaving employment early need to be thoroughly considered.

More radical, and more hazardous, is starting a business in an entirely new area. Even if you feel in retrospect that you chose the wrong career path (you would have preferred life as, say, an organic farmer rather than an actuary), any new business venture inevitably involves considerable financial risk. Buying a retail business needs particular care, as many small shops struggle to remain profitable.

Life-changes may also extend to personal relationships. While the thirties are the time when most marriages break up, divorce rates for the over-50s have been increasing. Women may have particular problems in ensuring that they come out of the divorce with an adequate financial settlement, especially when the man has been the sole breadwinner. 'A large cash settlement may seem a lot of money, but people have to live on this for what may be a very long time,' Bradshaw says.

Pension-sharing on divorce is expected to be introduced for new proceedings from 2001. When this is implemented, the courts will be able to give ex-spouses direct rights to a proportion of their partner's pension.

Pension-sharing is expected to be an important element of divorce settlements, and may offer greater protection to spouses without pension provisions of their own. Spouses in this situation (usually women) could be better off waiting for a change in the law before beginning proceedings.

Case studies

 Anne Tierney's life may be about to change radically. A manager for an IT company in the Thames valley, she turned 50 just over 18 months ago and - with her youngest about to leave university - has begun to emerge from several years of financial stringency. The plan now is to pay off her mortgage, realise the equity and buy a new, cheaper, house near Galway City in Ireland, where her family originally came from.

Anne's personal finances were hit hard when she and her husband divorced in 1996 and she decided to take on the £94,000 mortgage on the family home. 'It was very hard at first,' she says. 'But the hardest thing was getting my two daughters through university. I was pretty broke for three years.'

But now the situation looks more promising. Her Berkshire home has been valued at just under £260,000. She has already identified a house in Ireland, in the countryside north of Galway.

'As you get older, you have to question your quality of life. I've got a career but, to be honest, it's getting me down. I do more hours than I ever did - I'm at work often until 9.30 or 10 at night. I had a day off last week and still worked a 48-hour week,' she says. 'If I had no mortgage, I wouldn't have to earn so much money.'

With relatives and friends in the west of Ireland, Anne already has close links with the area. She's attracted by the quieter pace of life there and, as she points out, with Ireland in the eurozone, the high sterling exchange rate makes this a sensible time to buy in Ireland.

She hopes the deal will go through soon, though Anne does not plan to give up her job immediately . 'If I get the price I want for the house, I'll move into rented accommodation,' she says.

Anne is fortunate to be in a well-funded occupational pension scheme, and has been making additional voluntary contributions for a number of years. The standard retirement age in the scheme is 60.

However, her employer may be prepared to consider early retirement, as part of a redundancy package. Anne intends to wait and see what is on offer.

 Colin Brennan, former director of human resources at TSB, took early retirement after the bank merged with Lloyds, when he was in his mid-fifties. Now 58, he works as a consultant for a number of clients in the banking sector but is also active in the voluntary sector, as a housing association director and as a regional contact for the charity Reach.

Colin is fortunate in receiving a good executive pension - given to him without any actuarial reduction for early retirement. He could afford not to have to think of paid work again. However, he says 58 feels too young for full-time retirement: 'I don't feel retired at all. People in their late fifties still have a lot of energy. You can only play so much golf; you can only go fly-fishing so often.'

The consultancy business developed after he left Lloyds TSB: he was drafted in by executive recruitment agency Morgan & Banks to help a company which was temporarily without a personnel director. He now works primarily from home, using e-mail and fax to communicate with clients.

However he also gives much of his time to Reach, an organisation that matches potential volunteers who have professional expertise or skills with charities in need of assistance. Reach originally worked only with retired people, but as Colin explains, the organisation has recently extended its remit.

'The average age is 56 now. This is partly because people are retiring earlier, but also because Reach now works with people of any age who have time to give,' he says. Taken collectively, Reach volunteers' efforts are worth several million pounds to charities: 'They do make a difference,' he says.

Reach: 020 7582 6543.

fields.headline: Nissan UK risks Micra loss
fields.standfirst: Sunderland plant 'must cut costs by 30% | Jobs under threat | High pound hitting profits
fields.trailText: Nissan is threatening to switch production of its next Micra car away from the UK, raising the spectre of thousands more job losses in the battered motor industry. The Japanese company, like other manafacturers, has found its profits savaged by the high value of the pound.
fields.body:
Nissan is threatening to switch production of its next Micra car away from the UK, raising the spectre of thousands more job losses in the battered motor industry. The Japanese company, like other manafacturers, has found its profits savaged by the high value of the pound.

It revealed the crisis facing its Sunderland plant as Ford announced the end of car production at Dagenham last week and admitted its European operations had lost more than £100 million last year.

The news came as Rover's rescuer, Phoenix, defended its business plan, saying it could develop new models for under half the £1.2 billion BMW spent on its R30 small car.

Nissan's Sunderland plant is Europe's most efficient, but the company has warned that unless there are drastic cost cuts there the next Micra will be built in the French and Spanish factories of its partner Renault from 2003.

Almost half of the 330,000 cars built there this year will be Micras. Unless the model is replaced, up to 2,000 jobs could go, with a further 10,000 at suppliers. A decision is expected in late 2000 or early 2001.

A spokesman for Nissan, which has called on Britain to join the euro, said: 'We have not decided on where we are going to build the next Micra.

'The UK is a good site but it must win the investment, and to do that it has to reduce its costs by 30 per cent.'

Even reaching that target did not guarantee that Micra production would remain.

The Nissan Almera and Primera will continue to be built in Sunderland, but the Micra can easily share a Renauld Clio floorpan , and be produced much more cheaply in the euro zone.

The trade journal Automotive News Europe says Nissan UK chief John Cushnaghan, who has made the firm's calls for Britain to join the single currency, wants fewer platforms used at Sunderland.

However, Nick Scheele, chairman of Ford Europe said that Dagenham had lost its car production business because it was not as flexible or productive as the company's continental factories, where more modern facilities mean that three or four models can be built on the same assembly line.

The industry's gloom was slightly brightened as the Phoenix consortium of businessmen said its plans would slash development costs on new models. Phoenix head and Rover chief executive John Towers said he believed new platforms could be developed for £380m. Investment could double if a partner became involved. Towers said Volkswagen, which had experience of reviving brands and brownfield sites would make sense as a partner.

Details of the consortium's structure are being finalised. Towers has already pledged 35 per cent of the equity to employees. A further 25 per cent has been offered to dealers. Some of the remaining 40 per cent will be set aside for future employees, with the rest going to the four directors, and to suppliers.

Towers said the directors had each put six-figure sums into the venture. They could become very wealthy if the company breaks even.

webTitle: Pounce on accidents waiting to happen

fields.headline: Pounce on accidents waiting to happen
fields.trailText: My son works in a factory where there have been several worrying near-accidents in the year since he started. A month ago, a heavy piece of equipment fell off a ledge a few feet away from where someone was working. Surely the workers have legal rights to ensure that the factory is made safer?
fields.body:
My son works in a factory where there have been several worrying near-accidents in the year since he started. A month ago, a heavy piece of equipment fell off a ledge a few feet away from where someone was working. Surely the workers have legal rights to ensure that the factory is made safer?

FOR every one of the 200,000 work accidents notified to the Health & Safety Executive each year, there are several near-misses. Workers should report dangerous incidents, which must be recorded, in an Accidents Book or some other permanent record, to their personnel departments.

Many employers are negligent, however. In a unionised organisation, the workers have the right to appoint safety representatives, who can monitor safety and investigate accidents and near-misses.

Employers have a legal duty to provide a safe environment. But many fail - there are 20,000 serious accidents a year - and trade unions win millions of pounds in compensation for injured workers. Health and safety is a neglected area of employment law - and most employers are probably in breach of it to some degree.

Trade unions should have extensive information on this area of the law. Your local branch of the Health & Safety Executive could give you more information and tell you what publications it has.

fields.headline: BA woos Dutch once again
fields.trailText: British Airways is in talks with KLM to create a new European airline alliance - and is prepared to invest in the Dutch airline.
fields.body:
British Airways is in talks with KLM to create a new European airline alliance - and is prepared to invest in the Dutch airline.

Both airlines are believed to be keen to revive a partnership deal that almost came to fruition in 1992 but failed in a disagreement over valuations.

Talks this time are not believed to be about a full-blown merger but could involve BA taking a significant stake.

BA is in a race with Swissair to woo KLM after the Amsterdam-based carrier became isolated in Europe following the breakdown of its alliance with Italian flag-carrier Alitalia last month.

BA is also understood to be considering tying up with Air France and Delta Air Lines as its partnership with American Airlines and the so-called Oneworld alliance weakens.

BA would be considered frontrunner to tie up with KLM both because of cordial relations that prevailed despite the failed merger and its strength at Heathrow. American Airlines is also eyeing KLM, which still has a strong partnership with Northwest Airlines of the US.

A source close to the One-world alliance said: 'BA and Swissair and others are taking a very close look at the KLM situation. There is going to be a very big shake-up in the aviation industry and we are moving into an environment that is likely to remain stirred rather than calm for some time.'

BA's new chief executive, Rod Eddington, plans to review the airline's various partnerships in discussion with chairman Lord Marshall, who led merger talks with KLM the first time around.

BA's alliance with American Airlines and the wider grouping of Oneworld, which includes Cathay Pacific and Qantas, is little more than a loose marketing agreement and now looks shaky. American Airlines is understood to be cooling towards BA and is keen on forming relationships with Swissair, its partner Sabena and now KLM.

webTitle: Doctor, doctor: How health screening works

fields.headline: Doctor, doctor: How health screening works
fields.trailText: ACCORDING to Nigel Baker of Lexicon, if you apply for a job with a company that uses health screening, the usual arrangement is that all candidates will be asked to complete a medical questionnaire which will be analysed by a retained medical adviser or occupational health specialist.
fields.body:
ACCORDING to Nigel Baker of Lexicon, if you apply for a job with a company that uses health screening, the usual arrangement is that all candidates will be asked to complete a medical questionnaire which will be analysed by a retained medical adviser or occupational health specialist.

Depending on the findings, some candidates may be asked to undergo a full medical examination. Large organisations often employ in-house occupational health personnel or use an outside independent organisation.

One such company is Barbican Health. Dr Jenny Leeser, assistant medical director of occupational health, regularly carries out medicals for a variety of sectors. She says that confidentiality is the most important element of her job. Medical records are not passed over to the potential employer.

'We only say "fit" or "not fit" for the job.' If, for any reason, a letter has to be written to the employer, Leeser will always tell the individual what she is going to write. 'I am always very cagey about what I put down, describing something as a "chronic condition" rather than going into details.'

fields.headline: How to take a compliment
fields.trailText: ...and watch out for dismissal
fields.body:
1: Understand that even the office ogres are catching on to the touchy-feely trend and will now thank you for your contribution, support, just for being you and so on. In the modern workplace, where positive feedback is becoming increasingly valued by management gurus, you are likely to get more compliments unless you are a real no-hoper.

2: Avoid being so cynical that you dismiss all compliments as fake. Being unable to take pleasure from kind words is a sign of low self-esteem. But look out for the flatterers. 'Nine out of 10 compliments should not be taken at face value,' says former manager Reg. In some sectors, the paying of compliments is so widespread that they cannot be relied upon. In his diaries, Alan Bennett writes of his disillusionment at going to the theatre because of the need to praise the actors afterwards.

3: Watch out for the 'compliment as dismissal'. Former Labour cabinet minister Barbara Castle is frequently gushed over as a plucky octogenarian by New Labour leaders; this is clearly because they do not wish to respond seriously to the points she makes on pensions.

4: Become anxious if you are praised for things that do not need to be said. If you are told, out of the blue, that you are 'unassailable' then you should immediately consider brushing up your CV and start applying for jobs.

5: Understand that it is the job of senior managers to keep the foot soldiers happy and to say jolly things occasionally about individuals. The more authoritarian companies formalise this into awards presentation services. The recipients are being used for propaganda purposes to encourage good performance or sacrifices from others.

6: Recognise that there is often a big difference between public and private compliments. Ask why your boss is praising you in public. Is the purpose genuinely to tell everyone how great you are or is there another motive? Reg, for instance, has seen mavericks publicly lauded so that they will continue working on a lame duck project - to keep them diverted from more serious issues where they could cause trouble.

webTitle: The new way is not quiet desperation is not the way

fields.headline: The new way is not quiet desperation is not the way
fields.standfirst: An extraordinary turnaround is restoring the work-life balance, says  Simon Caulkin
fields.trailText: An extraordinary turnaround is restoring the work-life balance, says Simon Caulkin
fields.body:
A revolt is gathering which would have seemed unthinkable 10 years ago. Then, the idea of 'work-life balance' existed only as a pious ideal, as passé as Victorian values in a world that was speeding in the opposite direction.

Now, however, in an extraordinary turnaround the very forces of competition and globalisation in whose name millions of people have been downsized and de-layered out of employment are quietly reinstating the individual at the heart of the corporate and social debate.

'It's breakpoint or breakthrough,' said Joanna Foster, chair of the National Work Life Forum, introducing a new report, Breakpoint/ Breakthrough , last week.

The stakes are high. On one side lies a hellish spiral in which ever-intensifying work pressures driven by the demands of the capital markets exhaust individuals, destroy relationships and erode the fabric of communities until there's nothing to keep it together.

On the other side is a virtuous circle which, in giving individuals control over their lives, makes the companies they work for more creative and their societies more cohesive and resilient. In short, it reunites management with its own humanity.

It was the American writer Henry David Thoreau who said the mass of men lead lives of quiet desperation. He would have recognised today's conditions, in which Japanese work-related suicides have doubled since 1970; stress is the biggest problem for European companies; and two-thirds of UK managers believe that long hours are harming their health, relationships and productivity.

Over the last 25 years there has been no improvement in people's overall wellbeing, according to Warwick University economist Andrew Oswald, while job satisfaction is declining. Half of all respondents in another survey said they felt they were surviving, not living.

What's changing the rules, though, is a powerful cocktail of demographic and business forces - the latter unleashed by companies on themselves. Their unilateral dismantling of the old employment contract, transferring risk and career responsibility wholesale from firms to individuals, corresponded exactly with the moment when technology was making the individual indispensable as never before.

New technology, points out PricewaterhouseCoopers partner Ed Smith, who led the Forum's strategy group, makes possible the 'ultimate commoditisation' of all goods and services. So the only differentiating factor really is human beings.

Combine this with fuller employment in the US and UK, and the result is that organisations are suddenly confronting the need to live up to all that empowering rhetoric - and sharpish. It may be an exaggeration to say that employees are mad as hell and refusing to put up with it any more, but they are learning their own value fast - and acting on it.

Cue the proliferation of titles such as 'head of diversity and employee support' and 'gender equality and childcare manager' at UK banks. Or the efforts being made by the big consultancies, bellwethers of the digital economy and notorious for their competitive culture, to remake themselves as people-friendly employers.

'The balance of power is shifting,' admits Smith, noting that while the consultancies have an urgent need to build intellectual capital to bring to bear on ever more complex client problems, employee retention is heading in the wrong direction.

Some of the changes PwC is making aim to make the culture less off-putting to women. But 'this is not a women's issue,' insists Peninah Thomson, director of the Change Partnership and another strategy group member. It goes to the heart of strategic leadership for the twenty-first century company, which itself demands a new balance between aiming for short-term effectiveness and putting people first.

Although the forces driving these changes are strong, it would be idle to pretend that work-life is bound to prevail. For a start, what about those lower down the employment scale who are not part of the knowledge economy, demands Melinda Letts, chief executive of pressure group New Ways to Work. She says it is vital to prevent a gulf opening up between privileged work-life 'haves' and excluded 'have-nots' and notes that although work-life is being heavily promoted on the business case, the principles should also apply to public sector organisations which do not judge success by the bottom line.

Even in the business sector, it is likely to be a hard sell. One reason, says Thomson at the Change Partnership, is that the current generation of leaders fought their way up to the top on precisely the head-banging 'I-can-stay-longer-than-you' criteria of commitment which now must be displaced. Another is that most companies' performance measurement systems are firmly based on inputs (hours worked, utilisation) rather than outputs (results from the customer's point of view) - indeed, that is mostly how consultants are paid.

Input measurements are the apparatus of hierarchical command-and-control management systems, points out Smith - inappropriate and even dangerous for running an ideas business. 'But until managers and analysts understand that the underlying drivers of performance aren't the things covered in the quarterly earnings statement but the management of customers, partnerships, R&D and building intellectual capital, progress will be slow.'

In the difficulty lies an opportunity, however. Smith believes that the US mentality, obsessed with short-term earnings and input-driven performance measures, is finding it hard to get to grips with work-life issues.

'There's an opportunity for us to build a healthier model, learning from the good things and avoiding the worst, before the bow-wave of change hits us,' he says. Ultimately, this implies taking a more measured view of profitability - taking companies off the steroids of short-term profit obsession, and rebalancing the regime for long-term fitness.

As both workers and shareholders through pension schemes, we know it makes sense.

fields.headline: Brown still confuses the grey
fields.standfirst: Maria Scott tries to disentangle Labour's plans to give more money to pensioners
fields.trailText: Pensioners are beginning to be recognised for the political clout they can wield. They already account for 18 per cent of the population, and will make up nearly a third later this century.
fields.body:
Pensioners are beginning to be recognised for the political clout they can wield. They already account for 18 per cent of the population, and will make up nearly a third later this century.

Their ability to make or break an election is being acknowledged by the Government in the steps it is taking to placate them over the 75p increase in the basic state pension last month. Anger at the paltry rise - a direct result of low inflation, which determines increases - is thought to be behind Labour's poor results in the recent council elections.

Consequently, last week brought fresh headlines on government plans to help poorer pensioners. But the over-sixties should not celebrate silver power yet. The information was lobbed to the media with the usual Labour spin. Change is afoot, and some pensioners will benefit, but the sums involved and the method of delivery need untangling.

The first of last week's announcements concerned the new pensioners' tax credit. The intention to intro duce this had been announced in the Budget, and last week the Chancellor merely repeated this, but still without details.

The aim will be to improve income for pensioners who have small private pensions that disqualify them from receiving income support, but whose incomes may still be minimal.

It is not clear how the tax credit will be delivered - a consultation document is promised within two months - but the fear is that it will add to the complexity of pensioners' finances. Charity Age Concern is worried that the target will be too narrow. 'A third of older people are too poor to benefit from a tax credit because they don't pay tax.'

Perhaps the worst news for pensioners, however, is that the Chancellor made it clear that the credit would not be introduced until after the next election.

The Government was also reported to be considering an increase in the basic state pension next spring. It was suggested this could rise by £4 to £5, compared with the £2 to £3 expected as a result of inflation-linked uprating.

Age Concern's Rhian Beynon points out that as little as £1 a week may be new money. Nearly two-thirds would have been paid anyway through the annual uprating. Under the rumoured plan the remainder would come by adding the winter fuel allowance and paying it weekly rather than in a lump sum. The allowance is now £150.

One advantage of such a move would be to provide a permanent increase in the basic state pension, even if only a small one. But the Government is continuing to resist calls - led by former Labour Minister Barbara Castle - to restore the link between pension rises and national average earnings.

Beynon argues that a universal increase to pensioners, rather than means-tested assistance, is efficient because 'you know the money is definitely reaching the poorest'.

Age Concern estimates that pensioners need at least £90 a week. At present the state pension for a single person is £67.80, which for those without other private income is topped up to £78.45 through income support. For pensioners, this benefit is now known not as Income Support but as the Minimum Income Guarantee. The rebranding has caused much confusion. Many elderly people believe that it is a basic minimum for all, not just those who qualify for income support.

The Government's aim has been to concentrate on poorer pensioners, by increasing the use of means testing.

Ministers can point to figures that support its claim that many poorer pensioners are better off, but the complexity of delivery means that this is lost on many. Hence the Government's attempt now to focus on the basic state pension, but without committing to the regular earnings-linked rises that many are calling for.

The elderly may be wielding more electoral power, but increasingly they need a calculator, a cold flannel and a degree in maths to work out where they stand.

 The Government is planning a television advertising campaign, from the end of this month, to help improve the take-up of income support by the elderly. Already, it is possible to call a Freephone number (0800 028111) to ask for a claim form to be sent, rather than having to visit a DSS office. From the end of May it will be possible to have the form filled in for you over the telephone.

webTitle: After the party - do some thinking

fields.headline: After the party - do some thinking
fields.trailText: Your mortgage
fields.body:
Your mortgage

If for much of your adult life you have been paying a monthly mortgage, your fifties are when this long process is likely to end. It's a good feeling to own your house outright, but there are some issues to face before you make that last mortgage payment.

First, it may actually not be such a good idea to wipe out your mortgage debt. Bradford and Bingley borrowers should ensure they remain customers until after flotation. (£100 minimum is necessary for voting rights, though smaller loans still qualify for payouts.) Borrowers with other mutual building societies may also want to keep a small mortgage loan outstanding, just in case of future windfalls.

Controversially, when they close a mortgage account, many mortgage lenders levy a 'sealing fee' for the work involved in removing the legal charge. This may seem the ultimate example of greed and bad faith, but if you want to clear the debt you have little option but to pay up.

The alternative is to continue with a small residual loan. The Halifax, for example, offers to freeze the last £125 on a mortgage account on an interest-free basis. This allows you to avoid the responsibility of looking after your own title deeds, since the documents will remain safely stored by the lender. Another possible advantage is that you can subsequently take out a further secured loan against the property at relatively little expense.

However, with the abolition of mortgage interest tax relief this April, there is now no tax advantage for maintaining a mortgage loan unnecessarily.

Trading down

If your children have left home, you may consider moving to a smaller house.

This makes good financial sense if your income is about to be reduced, perhaps through early retirement or redundancy. Household bills are likely to be smaller but, more importantly, you will release some of the capital tied up in your home, which can be reinvested to bring in interest.

If retirement is still some way off, a house is a convenient store for excess capital. Unlike other investments, it is free of any potential capital gains tax liability.

Lump sum investments

This is the stage in life when you can find yourself with a substantial lump sum available to invest. Whether the money is the product of a 25-year savings slog with an endowment policy, a move to a smaller house or the result of an inheritance, the issue is what to do next.

If you want professional financial advice, go to an independent financial adviser rather than a tied representative. You may also want to consider paying for the advice via a fee rather than indirectly through product commission.

The rule is to build a balanced portfolio, spreading your risks. It may be better not to invest a lump sum all at once, but to spread the investment over a period of time - otherwise you risk entering the equity market at a time when the market is peaking and about to fall.

There are other ways to invest a lump sum. One possibility is to buy a second home (perhaps with retirement ultimately in mind). If you are tempted to buy abroad, remember that house prices do not necessarily appreciate in value in the same way as in Britain, and that quaint old farm buildings can be difficult to resell. Unless you plan to retire abroad, you are also taking on an exchange rate risk. In France, make sure you understand the inheritance laws on property.

Second careers and downshifting

The fifties can be years when you feel you are marking time at work, having climbed as far as you will go in your present career. It is certainly not too late to consider something new. However, self-employment or setting up a business do need to be approached with caution.

Take particular care if you are tempted to buy an existing business. Running a village pub or buying a small bookshop may have strong appeal, but will not generate much profit, and you should not assume that a business which is unprofitable has just been poorly managed and can be turned around.

If you establish a business, you have the choice of running it on a self-employed basis or incorporating it as a limited company and paying yourself through a salary and/or dividend payments. There are advantages and pitfalls to both routes, and it is appropriate to take advice. You will be liable to register for VAT if your turnover is £52,000 or above.

Retirement income

With retirement now in the foreseeable future, this may be the last chance to build up adequate arrangements to tide you through the years when you will be surviving on your pension and investment income.

One possibility is to shovel as much spare cash as possible into a pension. For people in occupational pension schemes, additional voluntary contributions (AVCs) made through the company scheme are normally better value than free-standing AVCs, where charges are often substantial.

If you have income from self-employment or from non-pensionable employment, you can contribute up to 30 per cent of these earnings each year to a personal pension between the ages of 51 and 55, or 35 per cent between 55 and 60 (though for high earners, these percentages are capped at an income of £91,800).

Most people are best off maximising pension contributions by back-dating payments, using the complex carry-forward and carry-back rules. With the introduction of stakeholder pensions next year, the rules on earnings will be relaxed.

Building up capital for your retirement is not necessarily restricted to pensions, however. While pension contributions attract tax relief, the capital (whether in a personal pension or AVC) is locked away until you come to retire, and your eventual pension will be subject to income tax.

Isas are more flexible, and should also be considered. Isa contributions (a maximum of £7000 during 2000-1), while made from after-tax income, are afterwards held in a tax-free environment. Isas can also be cashed in at any time (though it is unwise to hold equity-based Isas unless you expect to hold them for a period of several years).

To receive a forecast of your likely state pension, complete form BR19, available from tax and Benefits Agency offices.

Early retirement

If you are taking early retirement, the implications for the pension you will draw for the rest of your life can be significant.

Occupational pensions may be reduced in three different ways: firstly, you will have fewer qualifying years in the scheme. Secondly, in final salary schemes, you are likely to be leaving work on a lower salary than you would otherwise have achieved. Finally, your pension scheme is likely to impose an actuarial reduction on your pension, to acknowledge the fact that you have contributed towards it for a shorter-than-anticipated period, but will be drawing it for longer.

If you take retirement on the grounds of ill health, most of these penalties will not apply. If early retirement is offered as part of a redundancy programme, much will depend on the exact pension terms you manage to negotiate.

For people with personal pensions, Inland Revenue rules normally permit you to purchase your pension annuity and take your cash lump sum from age 50.

The Government recently announced plans to raise the age for drawing on personal and occupational pensions from 50 to 55. This won't affect today's fiftysomethings as the change, if implemented, will be phased in between 2010 and 2020. For fiftysomethings of the future, however, early retirement may be just a dream unless they amass a fortune in earlier life.

It may soon be easier to combine part-time work with a pension - an option that may suit many. At present it is not normally possible to draw a pension and continue working part time with the same employer, but the Inland Revenue is expected to alter this rule.

Even for those who can retire at 50 today, there are practical drawbacks. Few people have enough money to retire comfortably at that age. You will have paid less in contributions and your pension capital will have had less time to grow. You will be drawing a pension for longer, so the annuity you buy will be reduced accordingly. Pension companies may impose penalties if you do not continue a policy until the time you originally intended.

Inheritance planning

This is the time of life when you may be coming to terms with the idea of being a grandparent. Gifts to grandchildren do not have the same tax restrictions which apply when parents make gifts to their own children (where interest over £100 is treated for tax purposes as still being the parents' own income). Gifts which you make out of your normal income - rather than from capital - are outside the inheritance tax (IHT) net, and there is an annual IHT exemption for the first £3,000 worth of gifts. Other gifts could potentially be liable for IHT, but only if you were to die within seven years. (The threshold for IHT on estates is £234,000.)

If you are wealthy enough for inheritance tax to be an issue (only about 4 per cent of estates do incur an IHT liability), there can be advantages in arranging to skip a generation by passing assets directly to your grandchildren. There are a number of ways to achieve through family trusts and if you are in this fortunate position you will probably already have taken professional advice.

Your will

Finally, you should ensure that your will is up to date. Many people first make a will when they start a family; as children grow older, the arrangements may need to be changed.

webTitle: Football to auction TV rights auction

fields.headline: Football to auction TV rights auction
fields.trailText: The Premier League is hinting it may hold a 'mobile phone-style auction' to maximise the amount of money it gets for its Premier League TV rights. The auction would form the second phase of the League's much-hyped TV rights round, which saw the first set of bids submitted by broadcasters last Wednesday.
fields.body:
The Premier League is hinting it may hold a 'mobile phone-style auction' to maximise the amount of money it gets for its Premier League TV rights. The auction would form the second phase of the League's much-hyped TV rights round, which saw the first set of bids submitted by broadcasters last Wednesday.

The chairmen at the 20 Premier League clubs will have to approve the plan, which could see broadcasters such as BSkyB, the cable company NTL and the Carlton-Granada joint venture OnDigital openly bidding against each other.

One league source said club bosses were impressed by the 'big effect of value' achieved by the Government auction, which raised a staggering £22.5 billion for mobile phone spectrum.

An auction is likely or the main package of 66 live games which form the core of the rights. In addition, the league has received initial tenders for rights to highlights, 40 pay per view games and Internet coverage.

Industry insiders expect BSkyB to buy the key 66-game package which includes the pick of the fixture list, with NTL and OnDigital as likely contenders for the pay per view package.

Clubs have estimated that the current bidding round could raise as much as £2bn in revenue, while broadcasters are keen to play down this suggestion. They put final estimates of what they are prepared to pay at around £1.2bn, which is still twice as much as the league raised from Sky and the BBC at the last round four years ago.

 This week BSkyB and OnDigital are expected to open a new round of warfare over digital technology.

OnDigital is rumoured to be announcing new kit to convert existing TVs into digital sets without large decoder boxes.

BSkyB will hit back by dropping installation charges and offering free keypads to new digital customers.

fields.headline: ICC's credibility is sinking fast
fields.trailText: The ICC's credibility is sinking fast.
fields.body:
Some years back a young and beautiful Indian girl in London hit the headlines for her romps with various British MPs and newspaper editors. They were paraded one by one in their grey-headed shame on various front pages.

In India, Pamela Bordes was surprisingly seen as less of a harlot and more of a heroine. "Beauty queen Pamela rocks British Parliament!" screamed one evening paper and the junta cheered. The "rocks" might as well have been "socks" for all the applause she won. Fine work, ol' girl, give it back to the colonialists with scheming Gandhian non violence. They thought you were a curry-in-a-hurry but you're a slow cooked vindaloo with a surprise punch. Hooray.

Alas, there is no such joy in the subcontinent for the sizzling news du jour. "Dalmiya in hot seat as head of ICC!" the papers state ominously. If Pamela threatened to bring down the British government, Dalmiya threatens to bring down ICC's credibility along with himself. And perhaps a whole lot of other not-so-innocent but appearing-to-be-innocent compatriots and colleagues. Colonial seat of power it may be, but ICC represents a sport which for many Indians stands on a pedestal higher than the Empire state building. Thus, this current fiasco brings only a "Good grief, get these Bombay mafia types out of here!"

But who should be shown the door? Bad question, this. A week back we were all asking "and who else is guilty" but as the finger pointing brings up a new name every twelve hours or so it's now "For God's sake if anyone's innocent stand up so we can see you!" It was easy to sniff out a pair of stockinged feet in government corridors, but how on earth do you follow the numerous footprints made from the soft-soled shoes of The Fraternity, the members of which form one happy family and strike deals obscurely behind the side screens? Don't worry old chap, if the spotlight happens to fall on you just deny it in hurt incredulity and we'll provide the chorus of "Leave him alone he couldn't have done it, oh no he couldn't have."

How much longer will we have to wait to see at least one more guilty gentleman being indicted and then one more and another? Is Hansie Cronje going to be the only one nailed to the cross to pay for the sins of his brethren? Yes, he has sinned too, but he confessed and is prepared to carry the burden of isolation for life.

The small fish is netted but the sharks remain on the prowl. A powerful government servant can lose his status easily if proven to have been susceptible to a short skirt, but powerful men in cricket who have been seen with bookies, named as match fixers or are on record to have made dubious television rights deals are allowed to remain virtually undisturbed.

Sujata Prakash is based in Hong Kong. She writes a cricket column for rediff.com.

fields.headline: Round-up
fields.standfirst: Warne ducks the issue
fields.trailText: While Shane Warne waits for the pitches and weather that will suit his leg-spin, his hoped-for impact as a useful lower-order batsman for Hampshire is failing to materialise.
fields.body:
While Shane Warne waits for the pitches and weather that will suit his leg-spin, his hoped-for impact as a useful lower-order batsman for Hampshire is failing to materialise.

The Australian was again dismissed without scoring as Yorkshire bowled out their visitors for 101 at Headingley, Darren Gough taking four for 23. Warne then bowled 12 wicketless overs as Yorkshire raced into a first-innings lead.

Also in the top division, at Chester-le-Street, Glen Chapple took a career-best six for 42 as Durham collapsed from 108 for two to 164 all out. Lancashire then slumped to 128 for seven in their second innings.

In the Second Division, at Sophia Gardens Steve Watkin, with a maiden half-century, and Adrian Shaw, who hit a career-best 88 not out, put on 84 for the last wicket to rescue Glamorgan against Gloucestershire.

webTitle: McGrath struts his stuff after Wilson's century

fields.headline: McGrath struts his stuff after Wilson's century
fields.standfirst: Middlesex 161 & 181 Worcestershire 182 & 50-1
fields.trailText: Middlesex v Worcestershire
fields.body:
There may have been a sombre, muffled peal on the cathedral bells to mark a local bereavement, but matters were less melancholy for Worcestershire on the day Elliott Wilson scored the second hundred of his still brief career and they finished on 50 for one, needing a further 111 to win.

Wilson, 75 overnight, has taken both centuries off Middlesex. He has much self-confidence, shows signs of application when necessary, and has an extravagant sweep of the bat as he goes for his off-drive. There were three of these and two more perky boundaries through mid-wicket as he got to his hundred, with much personal elation, from 193 balls. His partners quickly departed but he remained to carry his bat.

Middlesex were 21 behind on the first innings and it hardly helped their cause when, after an untroubled start - as if to mock the previous day's supposed track demons which led to a visit from an England and Wales Cricket Board pitch liaison officer, though no action was taken - Mark Ramprakash was out to Stuart Lampitt's first delivery.

It is going to be difficult to ignore Glenn McGrath this summer. Historically as a bowler he has a combustible personality, in contrast to his off-field demeanour. The New Road faithful caught the first glimpses of this yesterday.

He appealed with supreme assurance for lbw against Robin Weston. It was bravely turned down by Nigel Cowley, who has just joined the first-class list. McGrath spun round, hands theatrically on hips, to glare at him. An appeal from his next ball was similarly dismissed, and the body language was uncomfortable for the spectators as well as the protagonists.

Middlesex batted badly for 181 in the second innings. McGrath took three wickets, producing several overs which were arguably as fast as any seen on this ground. He displayed more sheer pace than the coltish Imran Khan or, before him, the valiant local speed merchant Reg Perks.

Justin Langer had appeared on the way to rich pickings. It was a captain's innings but it ended as he made a rare false shot, allowing Vikram Solanki to bring off a notable running catch from midwicket. Solanki had earlier, in the slips, held Andrew Strauss, who had again compiled valuable top-order runs. Then Richard Illingworth struck with timely wickets.

Worcestershire were left to score 161; Graeme Hick and Wilson, again, seemed to be pointing them to victory.

It was bravely turned down by Nigel Cowley, who has just joined the first-class list. McGrath spun round, hands theatrically on hips, to glare at him. An appeal from his next ball was similarly dismissed, and the body language was uncomfortable for the spectators as well as the protagonists. Middlesex batted badly for 181 in the second innings. McGrath took three wickets, producing several overs which were arguably as fast as any seen on this ground. He displayed more sheer pace than the coltish Imran Khan or, before him, the valiant local speed merchant Reg Perks. Justin Langer had appeared on the way to rich pickings. It was a captain's innings but it ended as he made a rare false shot, allowing Vikram Solanki to bring off a notable running catch from midwicket. Solanki had earlier, in the slips, held Andrew Strauss, who had again compiled valuable top-order runs. Then Richard Illingworth struck with timely wickets. Worcestershire were left to score 161; Graeme Hick and Wilson, again, seemed to be pointing them to victory.

webTitle: Major plans but no joy for Thorpe

fields.headline: Major plans but no joy for Thorpe
fields.standfirst: Surrey 278-6 v Kent
fields.trailText: Surrey v Kent
fields.body:
It was too early for warm beer at the Oval yesterday but the long shadows were there, as they are over all cricket at present, and so was John Major.

Last month he became Surrey's president, picking up where his Tory leadership had left off three years before with a 253-run defeat at the polls, as the champions lost the first completed county match of his reign by 231 to Durham.

At breakfast time yesterday, in the first public performance of his presidency, he "wunted" to impart better news. There was no soapbox, the usual flannel and even the prospect of flannelled folly outside, where Surrey and Kent, having lost their first day, were limbering in the sun.

They got a full day of little advantage to either side and none to Graham Thorpe, given a last chance to post a score that might get him back in the England reckoning. Kent put Surrey in for no obvious reason; Surrey got themselves out with little excuse.

In four championship innings Thorpe has made 0, 18, 1 and now 11 before he looked unlucky to be given out lbw. He cannot buy a run just now. At least he could but someone would report him to the International Cricket Council.

Major was in the Long Room beneath the board of names of those who died for their country. He had three main things to announce: an £18m redevelopment of the ground; a "unique interactive cricket museum and education unit which will be set up by a new body, the Oval Trust"; and a match on July 29, Asia v the Rest of the World, whose proceeds will go to the trust.

The Oval is the world's oldest test ground and looks it. Planning applications have been lodged with Lambeth borough council to make it "fit for the 21st century". They incorporate a new grandstand alongside the pavilion and rebuilding of the Vauxhall end.

On Desert Island Discs Major said his luxury would be the Oval. Yesterday he had it with him, in model form, and the pleasure showed. Surrey's cabinet may not boast as many trophies as it should but at least it holds no skeletons.

The ground, due for completion in 2004, will hold 25,000, an increase of 6,500. There will be no loss of capacity during the work. It hardly looked a problem anyway. A hamburger van would have housed yesterday's crowd.

Asked whether he thought cricket's present problems made such ambitious plans risky, Major said: "We haven't noticed a knock-on effect. I hope this matter is sorted out comprehensively, finally and speedily." He might have been straight-batting the latest exposé of Tory sleaze. Major, like cricket, has always been too trusting for his own good.

The former prime minister was untroubled at president's question time but he was never too good at spin and always liable to hit his own wicket.

The 50-over match in July is very much his thing, along the lines of one in Dhaka last month. He has got Sachin Tendulkar and Alec Stewart to captain and signed up Mohammad Azharuddin, Wasim Akram and Shane Warne among others to play. "But I can't guarantee 600 runs in the day and a close finish," he said guilelessly. No matter; someone else will.

webTitle: Law has shave as tourists tear hair

fields.headline: Law has shave as tourists tear hair
fields.standfirst: Zimbabweans 143-4 v Essex
fields.trailText: Zimbabweans v Essex
fields.body:
When in Antigua a couple of years back Chris Lewis shaved his head and then went hatless on to the field, he suffered sunstroke. The only danger to Danny Law, however, after he had taken a razor to his head yesterday would have been from acid rain.

There had been play, the first of the match, during the morning, but the afternoon yielded only eight more overs in two brief sessions before the light closed in and the rain tumbled down terminally.

Law, who had begun the day coiffed in bright orange, ran in to bowl as bald as an egg after the first interval and seemed none the worse for it. He will probably be persuaded to grow a beard overnight.

The Zimbabweans, instead, are tearing out their hair in frustration in their last match before the first test. Put in to bat, they lost Trevor Gripper in the second over and were reduced to 69 for four by enthusiastic seam bowling before being rallied by an unbroken stand of 74 between Andy Flower and Neil Johnson.

Until those came together the bowling, by and large, had held its discipline well, never easy in conditions where the bowler's natural tendency is to expect too much too quickly.

Gripper, missed by Nasser Hussain at slip in the first over, drove in the next and was caught at the wicket. After Murray Goodwin and Grant Flower had taken the score to 51, Flower, having spent 52 balls over 10, received a snorter from Law that lifted and left him.

Ricky Anderson then struck twice in an over, ducking one in to the left-handed Campbell to pluck out his middle stump. Four balls later Goodwin, having hit four fours and a six slashed over cover, hooked and Peter Such made an athletic catch at long-leg.

Bowling over-enthusiasm now replaced discipline and the initiative was wrested. Johnson looks in good form, particularly when allowed width, and has hit seven fours.

 Herschelle Gibbs has been fined £1,350, £900 suspended, and given a suspended three-match international ban for night-clubbing in Cape Town after South Africa's team curfew during last month's series against Australia.

webTitle: England in need of replacement therapy

fields.headline: England in need of replacement therapy
fields.trailText: After Nasser Hussain had finished his day's work against the Zimbabwe tourists, the selectors met for the first time this season to discuss the vacancies created by Michael Vaughan's finger injury and the saga of Dean Headley's back.
fields.body:
When the England selectors announced in February their elite group of 12 players to be given central contracts, they were in effect picking their side for the first test three months in advance.

No pundit speculation, no pub arguments, no nudging the selectors: if the contracts had any meaning, here was a group of players who would be backed all down the line. This is England, though, and England players use the resources of the health service as routinely as others do the local supermarket.

Even the best-laid plans are disrupted and so last night in Chelmsford, after Nasser Hussain had finished his day's work against the Zimbabwe tourists, the selectors met for the first time this season to discuss the vacancies created by Michael Vaughan's finger injury and the saga of Dean Headley's back.

The chairman of selectors David Graveney will announce the squad for Lord's on Channel 4's Cricket Roadshow at 10.10 this morning.

The task of finding replacements will have been no easier under changed circumstances. The refined County Championship has done nothing to concentrate the pool of ability into a more manageable size, and the weather during April, with its record rainfall, has seen the large seam on English cricket balls biting into damp, green pitches and making batting the equivalent of playing chicken on the M1.

Survival then is as much a matter of luck as timing and a true assessment of form scarcely possible, for whereas batsmen generally have found life intolerable, seam bowlers are being flattered to an unnatural degree.

It has not stopped Nick Knight and David Sales making their marks. Knight has taken Glamorgan for a double hundred, and Sales - who has hovered around the fringes of the England team with the odd invitation to training camps to keep up his interest - added to his reputation as a player with the capacity to stay in once he gets going, by going on to make 276 for Northamptonshire yesterday. Either has a chance of gaining a middle-order place, and indeed Knight's single test century, scored against Pakistan three years ago, was made from No6.

However, at the top level the Warwickshire opener's technique against the moving ball has been found wanting consistently and the selectors may want to give an early opportunity to Graham Thorpe, despite an indifferent start to his season. Thorpe is a player whom Hussain trusts to re-establish his international credentials after opting out last winter.

On the bowling front, there is a chance that the Lord's pitch at this stage of the season will require a full hand of pace, at the expense of Chris Schofield's wrist-spin, so two additional seamers - one to play and one as cover - need to be found.

Injuries have not helped the cause once again. Chris Silverwood, an obvious replacement, has not bowled this season after a heel injury, and Alan Mullally and Dominic Cork, neither of whom is flavour of the month, are also sidelined.

So where to go? There is a strong argument for an old and reliable horse for this course. Lord's is probably the most difficult ground in the world for bowlers to adjust to because of its lateral slope, particularly from the Pavilion end when a wider line outside off stump is needed.

Angus Fraser knows the lie of the land intimately and as a one-off would let no one down. Equally, Martin Bicknell has been running in nicely for Surrey and Peter Martin for Lancashire. Either player would make a fist of it.

But that would scarcely be forward-looking. This is Zimbabwe, not Australia, and the chance is there to give a grounding to new players and further the experience of those who are improving. Alex Tudor, a hero a year ago, can be quick but had an indifferent winter and needs to find a nasty streak if he is to claw it back.

But Steve Harmison, who came close to going to Australia two winters ago instead of Tudor, has natural pace - real pace - and bounce with it, and surrounded by the experience of Andy Caddick and Darren Gough he should be given his head. If his temperament is suspect, better to find out now. As for the back-up, Ed Giddins had a reasonable debut at the Oval last year, and at least he can get better.

fields.headline: Brown breaks Sussex shackles
fields.standfirst: Sussex 224 Warwickshire 439-6
fields.trailText: Sussex v Warwickshire
fields.body:
Warwickshire, at first edgily and then with dancing feet, batted their way into a commanding position on a sopor-ific second day here. Dougie Brown, who was a member of Adam Hollioake's all-conquering 1997 Sharjah side but who has been ignored by England since, was the day's hero.

He came in at 158 for five and a mini-crisis - Warwickshire had just lost Trevor Penney and Neil Smith within 10 balls - but he soon set about the Sussex attack with aplomb.

He cut, drove and pulled with freedom, hitting Robin Martin-Jenkins for three fours to bring up his 50. He got better as the innings progressed and when, unbeaten on 157, he was applauded off the field, he had bettered his previous highest score by 13 runs.

Brown took his lead from David Hemp, who had stood firm during the morning session when wickets fell. But once the clouds lifted, the bowlers looked bereft of ideas and Hemp's fours started flowing. Mark Robinson, James Kirtley, Martin-Jenkins and Jason Lewry, a motley mix of fast-medium and medium-fast bowlers, kept gamely running in but the pitch was doing them no favours.

A desperate Chris Adams had a few overs himself and tried Michael Bevan and even Toby Peirce and Will House, but to no avail.

The post-tea session was a romp. Brown went to his hundred with the third ball after the break and Ashley Giles picnicked happily on the new ball; their unbeaten partnership of 180 looks like a winner. Sussex are in for a long slog - unless their bowlers can produce something better than this.

webTitle: Will the roof fall in on bad home loan advice?

fields.headline: Will the roof fall in on bad home loan advice?
fields.standfirst: Many people do not receive mortgage compensation after being misled, but that may change reports Richard Colbey
fields.trailText: A High Court decision could force the government to backtrack on intentions to leave advice from home loan brokers outside the scope of the statutory mortgage regulation it plans to introduce in summer 2001.
fields.body:
A High Court decision could force the government to backtrack on intentions to leave advice from home loan brokers outside the scope of the statutory mortgage regulation it plans to introduce in summer 2001.

The judgment may also give a legal remedy to endowment policy holders whose mortgage payments increased because they got poor advice from agents tied to insurance companies.

The case of Martin vs Britannia Life last month could move the line between advice which needs Financial Services Act authorisation such as that on investments including endowments and Isas, and on other recommendations such as home loans.

A court has held that associated transactions must be taken into account as well as those that are specifically regulated.

The decision in January to leave mortgage brokers outside the regulatory net surprised the Council of Mortgage Lenders, which was "disappointed that the government has decided not to rationalise the various different strands of regulation into a single system".

Lenders and brokers say that the absolute certainty over the lines previously drawn between regulated and unregulated advice has disappeared.

Michael Martin brought a claim against Britannia Life, which took over the Life Association of Scotland. In 1991 the LAS's agent, Ivan Sherman had advised Mr Martin to remortgage his family's home with the Bank of Scotland and to take out a new endowment policy with LAS. The mortgage involved was a "low start" one, where relatively low early repayments often led to a devastating accumulation of arrears which had to be repaid later.

When Mr Martin eventually complained, the Britannia was prepared to accept that neither the remortgage nor the endowments were in his best interests. Indeed after some pressure was brought to bear, the company accepted that it had to refund the losses, including interest, Mr Martin suffered as a direct consequence of the endowment.

On the mortgage, however, it did not admit liability. Britannia relied upon events in 1993 after the Insurance Ombudsman (whose role in this is now subsumed by the PIA Ombudsman) had started investigating a complaint against Legal and General about the mis-selling of an endowment policy and mortgage in a similar manner.

Legal and General, backed by most of the major life in surance companies, maintained the Ombudsman's powers did not allow him to investigate such complaints. An eminent QC was called upon to arbitrate and found that Legal and General's position was correct.

However, in hearing Mr Martin's claim, Mr Justice Parker took a different approach. He held that for the purposes of the Financial Services Act 1986 "investment advice" had to include "associated or ancillary transactions", even if they were not directly covered by the Act.

It was artificial, he held, to break down financial advice given in a single session into parts that were and were not "investment business".

The judge did not in fact find for Mr Martin, as the court claim had commenced more than six years after the loss.

This gave Britannia a defence under the Limitation Act, despite Mr Martin's argument that the loss had actually arisen later than that.

The judge, however, had no doubt that the salesman had misled Mr Martin and that the company was otherwise liable for it.

Solicitor and former assistant to the Insurance Ombudsman, Peter Tyldesley, says: "It is inevitable that many complaints to Ombudsmen will not have received the mortgage related compensation to which they are entitled."

Where the Ombudsman has already rejected a claim it is questionable whether he can reopen it.

It may, however, be that in that situation the threat of court proceedings would be enough to make insurance companies pay compensation to anyone who has taken out an over-priced mortgage on the basis of agents' advice.

And the Treasury, which has the final say on financial services regulation, has been left to ponder whether its decision to regulate mortgage information and the provider rather than the sales process complies with existing law.

 Richard Colbey is a barrister

fields.headline: Lacey
fields.standfirst: From the best of times the worst of times
fields.trailText: On the problems still facing the beautiful game.
fields.body:
This time the English football season is likely to end not with a bang but with a whimper. In fact much of the past nine or 10 months has been taken up with whimpering as an assortment of problems has continued to plague the game.

A year ago, amid the euphoria that greeted Manchester United's completion of the treble by winning the European Cup, it was hard to believe that there could be anything wrong with a sport capable of bringing so much joy to so many people. Now, with less to shout about, football can undergo a period of self-examination relatively free from noises off.

Of course it is still important whether Bradford City or Wimbledon go down tomorrow, and whether it will be Leeds United or Liverpool who go straight into next season's Champions League. There may even be those agog to discover if West Ham's Paulo Wanchope will complete a notable double in the Carling Opta statistics by ending the season not only as the player caught offside most times but also as the one who has committed most fouls.

These issues aside, there are a number of more pressing matters to which the Football Association and the leagues need to address themselves. Though the game undoubtedly remains cleaner than it was at the time of its nadir 30 years ago, players' attitudes towards referees and linesmen have deteriorated alarmingly.

This season the customary easing-up in the new year over bookings and sendings-off has been seen by a number of players as a licence to cheat and argue; so much so that the FA is considering charging clubs with misconduct if a team collect more than six yellow cards in any one game.

Already the threat of league points being deducted for the sort of melees seen when Leeds and Tottenham met at Elland Road in February is nearing actuality, though putting it into practice might well end up with clubs taking the FA to the high court. Yet the FA has precedent on its side, having taken two points off Arsenal and one off Manchester United after a mass brawl at Old Trafford in 1990.

Players simply have to learn to accept decisions that go against them. The mobbing of referees is nothing new but the increasing habit of shoving and jostling officials needs to be stamped out. The Professional Footballers' Association can play a part here by agreeing that in certain circumstances its members can be fined more than a fortnight's wages. The referees must also adopt standards of consistency so far unachieved.

Hooliganism, priced out and policed out at Premier League grounds, is once more breaking out in the lower leagues with alarming frequency. The death of a middle-aged man from Swansea who was trampled by a police horse after becoming caught up in street violence in Rotherham last weekend had horrible echoes of the 70s and 80s.

The potential for crowd violence whenever football is played has never gone away. Next month's European Championship will endorse this if the worst fears about extremist groups converging on the Netherlands and Belgium are confirmed. In England the game will brace itself for a rough August should Euro 2000 stoke up the familiar flames of hate.

Yet the overall picture is far from gloomy. Football continues to enjoy an unprecedented boom and has never been so popular across such a wide social stratum. The television companies would not be queueing up to spend between £1bn and £2bn on the next rights contract if this were otherwise.

Should the latest windfall merely send players' salaries and transfer fees soaring even higher, however, there might be a public backlash. Roy Keane's £52,000 a week may still compare poorly with the wage packet of, say, Alessandro del Piero but fans will wear such exorbitant sums only if they are justified by the quality of the football.

Take away Manchester United, Leeds, Arsenal and Liverpool - and Chelsea on their better days - and the overall quality of the Premiership this season has been indifferent. To be sure, Aston Villa's recovery under John Gregory and their appearance in the FA Cup final a week today is to be admired, along with Paolo di Canio's skills at West Ham and the way Kevin Phillips and Niall Quinn have given Sunderland a glimpse of glory, not to mention Bobby Robson's revival of Newcastle United. Since three-quarters of the Premiership teams are concerned merely to stay up it is hard to see this changing. The championship will continue to be contested by the same teams and, so long as Manchester United are predominant, entering the Champions League by finishing second or third will remain an attractive option.

As to hosting the 2006 World Cup, well, England appear to have secured Concacaf's three-man block vote so that should avoid a lost deposit when Fifa counts hands in July. But the Germans, the Germans, always it is the Germans...
