fields.headline: White ' s week
fields.standfirst: You couldn't make it up - and you wouldn't want to:  Jim White on the lessons of Crystal Palace - the soap opera
fields.trailText: On the lessons of Crystal Palace - the soap opera
fields.body:
H ow is it best to assess a season in which your club finished 15th in the First Division, entered administration with debts only marginally smaller than Rover's and conducted year-long skirmishes with a queue of creditors anxious to bring about its demise?

In that perverse way which perhaps only football supporters appreciate, the comedian and Crystal Palace fan Kevin Day pronounces it thus: "It's got to be the best season a Palace fan has ever known in terms of atmosphere at the ground. I have never known a bond like it between the team and the players. And, as for the manager, the reaction to him at the last game of the season said it all: he was fantastic."

It looks as though the lurching comedy of Selhurst Park, a farce worthy of a National Lottery grant to turn it into a Brit-pack movie, may finally be approaching a conclusion.

The plot runs like this: Palace fanatic Mark Goldberg (played with that bemused air of hopelessness by Ricky Butcher, ex-EastEnders) buys the club for far too much money from the previous owner Ron Noades (played by Richard Wilson in full Victor Meldrew mode) and installs Terry Venables (Ray Winstone) as manager, promising funds to take the Eagles back into football's top flight.

But Goldberg has significantly less cash than he imagines, discovers he has no assets since Noades shrewdly did not include the freehold of the ground in the sale and instead of guiding his club to the Premiership steers them into administration. When Venables finds there is not enough to cover his stipend, he declares it all well out of order.

It is at this point that most businesses would collapse - but not a football club. As players are sold round the manager Steve Coppell (Ewan McGregor with baldie wig and bad scouse accent) to cover the bills, he determines his team will not suffer the added indignity of relegation and works like a Trojan on no resources to hold things together. Helpful neighbours Chelsea and Arsenal do their bit by loaning the promising youngsters Mickael Forsell and Ashley Cole to the cause.

Meanwhile the fans set up the Crystal Palace Supporters Trust and raise over £1m - mainly in loans from individual supporters - to help. The trust, by dint of a mass email campaign, convinces the Football Association to lobby on its behalf and persuade Strasbourg and Juventus football clubs, the two most serious creditors who are owed vast sums of unpaid transfer fees, not to foreclose.

But David Mellor (John Hurt after four hours of prosthetic make-up) belittles their efforts, saying they are no more than a naive support organisation for an opportunistic Singaporean syndicate hovering in the shadows. As a result of his intervention, the trust raises even more money by selling the popular "Kick Mellor Out of Football" T-shirts throughout the country.

Then this week, the administrators announce that Crystal Palace is to be sold to a Canadian consortium, led by Mellor's b te noire, the Singapore speculator Jerry Lim. The club's immediate financial future is apparently secure. A happy ending, then, to a season of living through a fiscal blitz.

"Of course I'm thrilled that Crystal Palace Football Club has been saved," says Day. "Absolutely. But," - and he wouldn't be a true football fan without a but - "I do have caveats."

Anxious that this is recorded as his own view rather than that of the Supporters' Trust, of which he is a member, Day worries about the potential strains between the putative new owners and Noades, who still maintains the ground freehold.

"They have been perfectly open that they know nothing about football, have no sentimental attachment to Palace and want to use the club to exploit the under-developed leisure facilities in south-east London," he says. "Which I foresee means a move to a greenfield site near Gatwick, miles away from Selhurst Park, for which I have an idiotic, emotional attachment."

He also worries that the consortium has turned down the trust's offer of its war chest.

"Jerry Lim has been perfectly cordial and open with us," he says. "But he doesn't want the money which, of course, we would only have handed over if it meant some sort of fans' representation on the new board, the kind of insurance we need to ensure Goldberg never happens again."

Whatever twist the saga takes next, however, Day is certain that last season's experience has been beneficial, changing forever the relationship between the club and its fans.

"I think it's altered expectations," he says. "When Ron Noades was around he refused to manage the club in any way other than prudently. We all wanted him out because we wanted the quick fix that Goldberg promised. After Goldberg, obviously now we're all very suspicious of the quick fix and ironically - hypocritically even - wouldn't mind a bit of financial realism. Now it looks like it's over, you might say it's not a bad lesson to learn."

Which is a moral to a tale that applies well beyond the confines of Selhurst Park.

 As the biggest vote since the London mayoral election nears, informed sources within the Football Association are offering an all-or-nothing assessment of England's chances of staging the 2006 World Cup. England will, they reckon, finish either first or last.

If that sounds bizarre, the logic is flawless: the system works in finest knock-out fashion by eliminating the candidate with the fewest votes in each round. Once the loser has departed, the 24 delegates vote again, and again the country with the least friends drops out. And so on until you have a head-to-head final.

Although there has been endless speculation, no one can safely predict exactly who will be voting for whom in that vital first ballot. But most observers say England are virtually every country's second choice. Thus the suggestion is that the bid in which the FA has invested so much will fare better as the contest advances, accruing the support of those delegates who initially favoured another candidate. The problem is, will England have enough first-choice votes to avoid being an embarrassed first faller?

Apparently we can all help on that one. Yesterday, with the financial assistance of Umbro, the FA launched an appeal for mass public support for its bid. All you have to do is log on to a website - www.backthebid.com - to register your enthusiasm.

A huge response, the organisers hope, will help sway the opinions of wavering delegates, convincing them that the nation is four-square behind the idea.

The Germans, incidentally - as swift with a website as they are with a beach towel - have been running a similar scheme for a while, which has attracted a keen following among nationalist MSPs in the Scottish parliament, who fell about with amusement a couple of months ago at the idea of putting their weight behind anyone but England. Which, no doubt, is what a mature democracy is all about.

Unfortunately, when I did my patriotic bit yesterday, my computer crashed as the England site was going through its jazzy graphics - more of a local problem, one hopes, than an omen.

"Well, all I know is it works very well in South Africa, where we're attracting a lot of support," the site's PR man said when I told him of my experience. His name, by the way, is Ciro Castaldo: presumably backing England because his first-choice Italy are not in the running.

webTitle: Scene set for Ronaldo of the north

fields.headline: Scene set for Ronaldo of the north
fields.standfirst: Bolton's Eidur Gudjohnsen is aiming to make up for lost time starting tomorrow against Ipswich Town, reports Oliver Kay
fields.trailText: Bolton's Eidur Gudjohnsen talks about how he is aiming to make up for lost time starting tomorrow against Ipswich Town.
fields.body:
He lets out the deepest of sighs as he is asked yet again to tell the story of what might have been. He must have told it a thousand times, to the point where he hates being reminded of it, but Eidur Gudjohnsen none the less recalls how he was once considered the equal of Ronaldo.

"We were at PSV Eindhoven together," he says, staring out into the middle distance. "I wouldn't say I was necessarily as big a talent as him. Looking back I can say that I have played with the best player in the world, although it didn't seem so special at the time."

Whereas Ronaldo went on to become the most expensive, the highest paid and the most prominent footballer on the planet, his young team-mate left the Netherlands with his dreams in tatters and his career in the balance. Only now, four years later, is Gudjohnsen rediscovering the form that once looked like making him a superstar.

Tomorrow he will enjoy one of his increasingly frequent moments in the spotlight when his Bolton Wanderers team play Ipswich Town in the first leg of the First Division play-off semi-finals at the Reebok stadium, an exact repeat of last year's meeting between the sides at the same stage. Bolton won that tie before losing out to Watford at Wembley. A place in the Premiership is the prize on offer once again, but the growing feeling is that Gudjohnsen will be there sooner rather than later anyway, with or without Bolton.

Three goals in six starts for PSV prompted favourable comparisons with Ronaldo and made Gudjohnsen, however briefly, one of the hottest properties in European football. All was going to plan until a serious ankle injury, sustained while on international duty with Iceland Under-18s in Dublin, brought his career to a shuddering halt.

It is not intended as a slight on Bolton Wanderers, the club who signed him two summers ago when nobody else would go near him, but a fully fit Gudjohnsen would undoubtedly be worthy of a higher stage. He only occasionally hints as much himself, and he is not bitter about events which forced him to rehabilitate in modest Lancashire surroundings.

Not seeking a move

"Bolton is where I'm trying to restart my career," he says. "Everyone knows I've played with some big names and that people back then were expecting a lot, but I can't be the best until I'm completely fit.

"At the moment I'm just enjoying myself and enjoying life. Having gone through what I did, I appreciate what I've got. Who knows what will happen in the future? I could be injured, or just gone, in two or three years."

Again there is a weary sigh when the subject of his future is broached. Derby County tabled a £3m offer for him, and Sam Allardyce's predecessor Colin Todd, an experienced manager who has no doubt the striker he signed two years ago will adapt to the Premiership with ease, also fended off inquiries from Sunderland and Tottenham.

Recent weeks have seen him linked with Newcastle United and Aston Villa, and more tenuously with Liverpool, prompting his manager Allardyce to double an initial transfer valuation of £5m for the 21-year-old.

"My future is that on Sunday I am playing for Bolton in the play-offs against Ipswich," he shrugs. "There has been a lot of speculation lately but that has been going on since the start of the season. I haven't paid much, in fact hardly any, attention to it. I'm certainly not looking for a move."

Whereas doubt persists about how players such as Manchester City's prolific goalscorer Shaun Goater will perform in the Premiership next season, Gudjohnsen's potential is beyond debate. He has been blessed with a tal ent which has set him and his team aside from much of the mediocrity in the First Division.

A stunning goal against Wimbledon in the Worthington Cup just before Christmas was worthy of his more illustrious former PSV team-mate. Picking up the ball on the left-hand touchline he dribbled past four defenders, displaying pace, balance and trickery, before rounding off with the coolest of finishes.

"I'd like to kick Eidur up the backside sometimes," said Allardyce afterwards. "He plays so well in the cup games, I'd like to see him do just as well in the league."

A nod of agreement comes from his father Arnor, who is one of his country's most famous footballers and enjoyed a successful spell with Anderlecht during the 1980s. "I'm not sure he is back to his best yet, but he is getting there," said Gudjohnsen Sr, who still turns out for the Icelandic club Valur at the age of 39.

"He hasn't yet regained the explosive pace he once had, but that too will return as he gets stronger. I'm certain he has a great career ahead of him. Ultimately he may even be a better player than me."

Father and son were expected to play in the same Iceland national team four years ago until injury intervened, denying them a place in footballing history. "I came on for him in a match in Estonia and then we were due to play the next game together," said Eidur.

"I got injured and then we didn't ever play together after that, which is a shame. When I was injured, I heard what other people were saying about me but I tried to ignore it. I knew that I would play again."

It was only after being released by PSV and spending a season with KR Reykjavik that Gudjohnsen was sure he would make a full recovery. Initially he looked sluggish and overweight at Bolton after his arrival on a free transfer, but these days he is known as "Godjohnsen" and has a website dedicated to him by two Dutch admirers.

With every flash of brilliance he shows, the comparisons to Ronaldo are revived. Where once he tip-toed tentatively, now he beats defenders with his unrivalled blend of pace and trickery. But the healing process, he insists, is not yet complete. Heaven help his opponents when it is.

Play-off dates

Semi-finals, first legs: today (all 3pm) Birmingham v Barnsley, Stoke v Gillingham, Millwall v Wigan, Hartlepool v Darlington, Barnet v Peterborough. Tomorrow Bolton v Ipswich (1pm). Second legs: Wednesday (all 7.45) Ipswich v Bolton, Gillingham v Stoke,Wigan v Millwall, Darlington v Hartlepool, Peterborough v Barnet. Thursday Barnsley v Birmingham (7.45).

TV Bolton v Ipswich, Sky Sports 2; Barnsley v Birmingham, Sky Sports 1; Third, Second and First Division finals on May 26, 27, 28, Sky Sports 2.

webTitle: Referees to be given helping hand

fields.headline: Referees to be given helping hand
fields.trailText: Assistant referees will have the power to enter the field of play, under rules proposed for the start of next season.
fields.body:
Assistant referees will have the power to enter the field of play, under rules proposed for the start of next season.

Fifa has announced that the officials formerly known as linesmen are to be given increased responsibilities, starting in this summer's European Championship.

In the most radical move, they will be required to join the referee on the pitch and ensure that the defending team retreat 10 yards at free-kicks.

They will also be asked to stand next to the goalpost when penalties are taken. It will be their task to ensure that the goalkeeper is on the line when the ball is kicked and, as in rugby, to signal whether the kick has been successful.

Under the proposals the fourth official will also be given greater powers. Until now his job has been restricted largely to dealing with substitutions, stoppage-time and, in certain cases, restraining managers. Now he will be able to signal for free-kicks and other incidents from the touchline.

A Fifa spokesman said the changes were designed to ease the pressure on referees. "Euro 2000 will be used as the experiment and, if it goes well, it will definitely be added to Fifa rules for all competitions."

Victory at Perugia tomorrow will secure Juventus's 26th Serie A title, but club officials have suggested that they would prefer to put the celebrations on hold.

Uproar followed the controversial decision to rule out a last-minute header from Parma's Fabio Cannavaro, which allowed Juventus to win 1-0 last Sunday and take a two-point lead over Lazio, and in an attempt to restore some credibility to the title chase Juventus's secretary Antonio Giraudo has declared that he would prefer the Italian championship to be decided by a play-off.

"This way all the insinuations would go away and we can find out who is the better team," he said.

Such a decider will only happen if Juventus draw at Perugia and Lazio win at home to Reggina, meaning the teams finish level on points.

Television evidence backed Cannavaro's claim that the goal should have stood, and the anger at the perceived bias towards the Turin club has led to death threats against the referee's parents, violent street protests by Lazio fans and a very public slanging match.

 Deportivo La Coruna will win the Spanish title for the first time in their 94-year history if they beat Racing Santander tomorrow and Barcelona lose at Real Sociedad.

Deportivo are three points clear with two games to play but will be without their Brazilian playmaker Djalminha, who is suspended after being sent off last week.

 In France, Marseille will be relegated if they lose at Sedan and Nancy, Rennes and Nantes all win; and Bayer Leverkusen will win the Bundesliga if they beat Eintracht Frankfurt and Bayern Munich do not win against Bielefeld.

webTitle: Hooliganism is back with a vengeance

fields.headline: Hooliganism is back with a vengeance
fields.standfirst: The season has shown a significant rise in incidents and serious violence:  Two stabbed in Belgian riots.
fields.trailText: The season has shown a significant rise in incidents and serious violence. And this week two fans were stabbed in Belgian riots.
fields.body:
It was supposed to be the pinnacle of a nine-month campaign and, for Rotherham and Swansea, the chance to enjoy some unaccustomed glory.

With both teams already promoted they were competting for the Third Division championship at Millmoor last Saturday. But, when the referee blew the final whistle, 15 minutes later than expected because of two pitch invasions, there was little to celebrate.

The 1-1 draw ensured Swansea were champions but one of their fans had been killed and the game marred by serious violence, both before and after. The south Wales club later cancelled a planned celebration and the talk over the past few days has focused on trouble, not trophies.

With Millwall, Stoke and Birmingham, three teams at the centre of some of the ugliest incidents this season, competing in the play-offs this weekend, police intelligence agencies warn that football hooliganism has made a comeback and not only the pressure of end-of-season matches is to blame.

Indeed, disturbingly both domestically and in terms of next month's Euro 2000 in the nearby Low Countries, hooliganism has risen significantly here this season not only in the Nationwide's three divisions but also in the Premiership. Clashes have become increasingly organised and vicious.

Mark Steels, spokesman for the National Criminal Intelligence Service, said: "We really don't know why there has been an increase. It's a very hard question to answer because the trend up until now has been for hooliganism to decrease. We are very worried about the situation. There's been violence at every single England Euro 2000 qualifying match and at several league matches throughout the season."

Police said incidents have steadily increased throughout the season. There has been a rise in serious violence and possession of offensive weap-ons, with hooligans becoming more organised, using emails, the internet and mobile phones to arrange clashes.

Steels said: "Weapons have certainly made a comeback... we have had reports of some very nasty incidents. There has been trouble across all four divisions but a lot of it has been away from grounds.

"Hooligans are more organised than ever before and the clashes have become very vicious. Given that there is more intelligence and surveillance, more work goes into organising the violence."

Last season (1998-99) there were 3,341 arrests for football- related offences compared with 3,307 in 1997-98. But that small rise must be seen in the context of an increase in the number of spectators over that period of almost 1m people.

Over the past six years football-related arrests have decreased overall from a peak of 8,000-plus a season in the mid-80s, again while attendances have increased.

The rise this season also exposes claims that it is no longer a Premiership problem and that increased surveillance, all-seat stadiums and higher ticket prices have eradicated trouble. These factors appear to have reduced the risk inside stadiums.

Premiership hooliganism is likely to involve smaller, more organised groups meeting away from grounds. This year 120 Chelsea fans were arrested as they prepared to attack Tottenham fans. A number of weapons - and drugs - were seized as supporters clashed before and after the match. Last month Manchester United and Liverpool fans clashed in central London as they awaited trains home. A pub was wrecked. Police say trouble in transit to games has become a feature of Premiership hooliganism.

One of the most serious outbreaks of violence came last month when Cardiff visited Stoke in the Second Division. About 500 fans from each side clashed intermittently throughout the day, starting at 11am and finishing at 11pm.

This division, containing several clubs with long rivalries, has also seen serious incidents involving Millwall, Burnley, Preston and Wigan.

Tim Crabbe, a lecturer at Sheffield Hallam University who has researched hooliganism, said: "It appears there is a new generation getting involved in football violence. Any trend goes in cycles. There was a time when football violence was considered a bit naff but a newer, younger generation appears to be interested in it."

One month before Euro 2000, there was a massive setback to hopes for a peaceful tournament when football-related rioting in three Belgian cities left two fans with serious knife wounds and led to dozens of arrests.

On the day that new measures were announced as part of a zero-tolerance policy for dealing with offenders, hundreds of police were called to quell the violence that enveloped the final day of Belgium's league season.

In Ghent 32 hooligans were detained after pitched battles with police lasting into yesterday's small hours. Security forces used water cannons and dogs as drunken fans attacked buses and bars.

In Antwerp two fans were in hospital after being stabbed as celebrations for Royal Antwerp's promotion to the First Division turned into an ugly, drunken brawl with extensive damage to bars. Paramedics trying to reach the wounded were also targeted. There were riots in nearby Beveren too.

fields.headline: Dons face £8m make-or-break game
fields.trailText: £8million ways to die for Wimbledon.
fields.body:
Wimbledon's chairman Bjorn Rune Gjelsten insists he has not thought about the financial repercussions of the Dons departing the Premiership tomorrow. Neither has their captain Kenny Cunningham, who bills the game against Southampton at the Dell more important even that his club's FA Cup final date in 1988.

It's just as well both are pleading fiscal ingnorance because the price of relegation from the top flight may well be as much as £8m - enough to make the calmest Norwegian break out in a hot sweat. That's a cool £5m loss in television revenue and £3m in gate revenue.

"It's not an option for us," said Gjelsten yesterday when asked to confront the possibility of dropping out of Eng land's elite after an extraordinary 14-year tenancy.

Cunningham echoes that last determined stand. "To win the FA Cup was a fantastic achievement but maintaining our status in the Premiership is even more important, particularly in the current climate. Everyone is aware of the significance."

"I don't know about the financial implications but I know this is the league players want to play in. We gain great satisfaction from walking into an arena like Old Trafford, Anfield or St James' Park and matching ourselves against some of the world's best players."

Wimbledon's manager Terry Burton, who completed the first half of what could be a 180-minute reign with a last-gasp point against Aston Villa, is demanding a win at Southamp ton, even though, with the Dons' advantage of superior goal difference, the bottom line is that Bradford, entertaining Liverpool, must do better than his own team on the day.

But Burton said: "We have to assume Bradford will beat Liverpool. It's too risky to assume any other scenario." If his side win, it will be Wimbledon's first Premiership success on the road since overcoming Watford on opening day.

Cunningham, who has a long-standing groin problem, is battling to be fit. Burton has already lost the suspended John Hartson, Wimbledon's point-saver last week, and Michael Hughes (broken leg).

Bradford's game with Liverpool may also influence the contest for the third and last Champions League place. But the matter will be taken out of the Merseysiders' hands if Leeds, a point ahead, win at West Ham.

If Leeds lose at Upton Park, a draw for Liverpool will be enough given superior goal difference. But if Leeds draw, the Merseyside team must win. Whoever loses out in the battle for third place will go into the Uefa Cup.

Harry Redknapp is hoping West Ham will wrap up a deal for Frédéric Kanoute this weekend. The club's chairman Terence Brown flew to France yesterday in an attempt to complete the signing of the Lyon striker currently on loan at Upton Park but who is also being pursued by Chelsea.

Redknapp conceded that he would probably have to part with the midfielder Marc Vivien Foe in exchange to raise sufficient money.

fields.headline: Barbados or bust for Scott
fields.trailText: Football Diary
fields.body:
Steven Scott is a striker with Nordstrom Timber in Sunderland's Red C Sunday League Second Division. But he may soon be facing a club v country conflict.

On a recent trip to Barbados to visit his grandmother he popped into the local FA offices and made such an impression at a kick-about with the Under-19s that he has been invited back for a trial. If successful he will be eligible for a World Cup qualifying tie against Cuba.

The problem is that it clashes with Nordstrom's game against Hall Farm in the Chairman's Cup final. Scott's dilemma is clear. After failed stints at Derby and Sunderland, he says: "Playing for Nordstrom got my motivation back. But to take part in the World Cup would be amazing."

 Gary McAllister recovered from long-term injury to top-score for Coventry this season and won the supporters' player of the season award. Unfortunately he had to miss Tuesday's presentation ceremony. He was injured (slipped disc).

 Dry humour. Recent film footage restored by Sunderland FC shows the 1913 FA Cup semi-final against Newcastle, a tie played in relentless snow and rain. At one point the film shows a fan running on to the pitch with a stick in his hand. But it turned out not to be early evidence of hooliganism. The stick was in fact an umbrella which its owner promptly opened and held over the goalkeeper to protect him from the elements.

 Derby's striker Branko Strupar made such an impression playing for Genk last season that each of the Rams' games is religiously attended by 200-300 Belgians. Last Saturday at Newcastle it was known beforehand that he was out injured but the loyalists still turned up.

 Sunderland's chief executive John Fickling thought he was on safe ground when he made a deal with Kevin Phillips last June that he would buy Mrs Phillips a BMW should the England striker score 30 goals.

Goal target now reached, Fickling has coughed up. But instead of taking the £30,000 car, Phillips has given the money to the two children's wards at Sunderland royal hospital, which looked after his daughter Millie when she was rushed to hospital with suspected meningitis 12 months ago.

 Gazza's move to Australia was already in doubt before his manager's intervention when the Boro misfit discovered that "allowed to go walkabout" only referred to trips into the bush.

webTitle: Bar raised as Ipswich make fourth attempt

fields.headline: Bar raised as Ipswich make fourth attempt
fields.trailText: A look at the Nationwide play-offs. What the managers think.
fields.body:
Joe Royle was asked this week for his Manchester City player of the year and the manager did not give it a second's thought. "The Blackburn Rovers crossbar," he replied. "I'm giving it a contract."

If that raised a laugh among the blue half of Manchester, however, it was hardly audible above the gnashing of teeth emanating from East Anglia.

City's players are heading for a day at the races tomorrow while those poor souls at Ipswich attempt to overcome a suffocating bout of deja vu in the First Division play-offs.

After being squeezed out of the automatic promotion places last weekend it will be the fourth successive year their season has come to this. And if previous experiences are anything to go by, the Samaritans should be bracing themselves for a busy few days.

Not once have Ipswich reached the final, and to compound matters Bolton Wanderers, their conquerors in the semi-finals last season, are standing in their way again.

Ipswich finished 11 points and three places above their opponents and, not for the first time, their manager George Burley has cause to rue the end-of-season lottery. "I would have thought we should have been given home advantage in a one-off match but that's not to be," he said.

Birmingham City's fans are also familiar with the feeling of being so near but yet so far. Last season they were eliminated from the play-offs by Watford, and their manager Trevor Francis claims they will be underdogs when they meet Barnsley in the first leg of their semi-final at St Andrews.

Only Manchester United have scored more goals than the Yorkshire team this season, although Birmingham have managed five clean sheets in their past seven games.

"When we have everyone fit we are good as anyone in the First Division, with the exception of Charlton," Francis said. "But we have not had that luxury and I would say that Barnsley are probably favourites to reach Wembley." According to the Barnsley manager Dave Bassett, however, Francis is indulging in "some of that kidology stuff". Bassett is seeking a record eighth promotion as a manager.

Stoke City and Millwall are the two form teams in the Second Division, although it is a fair bet the Metropolitan police will be hoping they both fail to reach Wembley. Stoke host Gillingham in the first leg of their semi-final on the back of an unbeaten 13-match run at the Britannia stadium, while Millwall entertain Wigan Athletic after creeping into sixth place on the last day of the season.

"We have kept the youngsters away from the spotlight," said the Millwall manager Keith Stevens. "If we hype it up too much, we could be our own worst enemies."

The away-goals rule has been scrapped this season - if the teams are level on aggregate after the two games the tie will be decided by penalties - but the Wigan manager John Benson insists they will adopt an adventurous approach at the New Den.

"If we try to defend for 90 minutes it would be very dangerous," he said. "All season we have gone out very positively away from home and this will be no different. We are going there to win."

Barnet face Peterborough and their former manager Barry Fry in the Third Division semi-final first leg at Underhill. The Bees are still uncertain where they will be playing their home games in the long term but feel that promotion could only help their case in negotiations with the Football League.

"We're in the same position as the start of the season," said the assistant manager Tommy Cunningham. "We have nowhere to go so all we can do is get on with it and make it as difficult as we can for people to ignore us. The best way to do that is to get promoted."

The other tie sees Darlington travel to Hartlepool for a local derby which promises not to be for those of a nervous disposition.

"Hartlepool will be on a high after climbing into the play-offs, while we're a bit disappointed to have fallen out of the top three late on," said Darlington's Marco Gabbiadini, who scored one of the goals that took Sunderland to a play-off semi-final victory over Newcastle exactly 10 years ago.

"We have nowhere to go so all we can do is get on with it and make it as difficult as we can for people to ignore us. The best way to do that is to get promoted." The other tie sees Darlington travel to Hartlepool for a local derby which promises not to be for those of a nervous disposition. "Hartlepool will be on a high after climbing into the play-offs, while we're a bit disappointed to have fallen out of the top three late on," said Darlington's Marco Gabbiadini, who scored one of the goals that took Sunderland to a play-off semi-final victory over Newcastle exactly 10 years ago.

webTitle: At the end of a long season it's time to raise a glass to football's most famous son, if you can find him

fields.headline: At the end of a long season it's time to raise a glass to football's most famous son, if you can find him
fields.trailText: Dazza is offered a long'un to get Bestie off the wagon.
fields.body:
Wednesday

Being at the very peak of the footballing pyramid, obviously the name of Darren Tackle very much opens doors in the world of celebrity. Basically if you is organising a premiere, a fashion show, an opening or whatever, you is gagging for names like yours truly's to be very much seen at the top of your invitation list.

Naturally, the Tackle post-bag runs heavy with invites to all and sundry and a cautious approach has to be made about which events to attend. As my old mentor Sir Alex would say: energy is so vital for a professional footballer, it cannot be frittered away at some pants opening where they serves warm white wine, the press ain't interested and the only celeb on parade is Paul Ross.

So, to help with the selection process what inevitably arises from being so in demand, Rodney and I has devised a little rule to decide what invites should be accepted and what shouldn't. We ask the simple question: is there sponds in it?

Generally, experience has taught us that if an organiser is prepared to meet the Tackle fee, then that suggests the event itself has the ambition to match yours truly's expectations. So, therefore, I was fully anticipating that the opening night party for the new George Best movie would very much live up to the predictions of the PR girl what painted a picture of wall-to-wall faces, there to raise a glass to football's most famous son. And Bestie would be there as well as me.

My appetite was particularly raised after Bill, my contact at the People, belled to tell me there'd be a long 'un in it for yours truly if I could aid him in a particular task.

"Listen up, Dazz, there's big money in the first snap of Bestie falling off the wagon," he says. "There's a major league drink in it, mate, if you go up to him with a glass and get him to hold it while my snapper moves into position. You up for it, or what?"

Simple task, no probs.

Thursday

After what happened at training, I is more than happy at the prospect of the Bestie party tonight. When I arrives I discovers that everyone is already horizontal on a Florida beach - Wattsy, Vic, Bob, both Bosnians, the lot - except, of course, Darren Tackle. When I clobbers Old Demo about it, reminding him that there is still a game left in the season and how come everyone else is Mousebound with the Beckhams, his reaction shocks me.

"There's nothing to play for Saturday," he says. "Perfect opportunity to give the senior pros a rest and let the kids and fringe guys have a game."

"So how come I is playing?" I says.

"I just told you," he says.

Sod him, it's down the smoke for the party. Course I gives the film itself a wide berth. Who wants to waste time hearing about a bunch of geezers knocking a ball around back in the mists of old tosserdom? If I wants to know about that sort ofancient history I can just tune in to Old Grandad Mickey Scanlan's anecdotes about the time he played against Gary Lineker.

But when I heads straight to the party I find it's a sweating heave of no-marks. So lacking in class is the entire event, the geezer on the door doesn't even know who I am. There's no one I recognise except him off of the telly with no neck, you know the one, babbling geezer, chat show, goes "er-er-er" all the time, Clive summat.

And all he does when I'm standing next to him at the bar is gives us a long lecture on employment law. Takes me at least half a dozen trips bar-bound before I've located Bestie, standing in a corner on his own, totally unmithered. In fact, you might say, people is deliberately avoiding him.

I'm on a winner here, I'm thinking, as he's already got a bottle of bevvy in his mitts. Takes me another half-hour after that (including four more unscheduled trips to the bar) to find Bill and tell him of my success.

"He's here, is he?" says Bill. "Brilliant news, because the PR girl says he's given it a wide one."

"Follow me, William," I says, picking up a spare bottle from the bar and heading Bestwards. To be honest, geezer looked very relieved someone was paying him some mind. Plus, he's a lot shorter than he looks on telly.

"Poptastic, mate," he says when I hand over the bev. "Absolutely sensational party, mate."

"Sure," I says, and turns round expecting to see the bulbs flashing. Instead I've got Bill whispering in my ear.

"Er, Dazz, how many have you had?"

"Eh, Bill, just the 10, mate, I'm a professional, there's a game Saturday."

"Only, Dazz, that's not Bestie. That's Bruno Brookes."

fields.headline: The supporter
fields.trailText: Julie Stainthorpe, the supporters' club chairman, comes from a family of rugby league supporters with no interest in a cissy game like football. But at 11, in the stubborn manner of girls of that age, she insisted her dad take her to see City.
fields.body:
Julie Stainthorpe, the supporters' club chairman, comes from a family of rugby league supporters with no interest in a cissy game like football. But at 11, in the stubborn manner of girls of that age, she insisted her dad take her to see City.

"It was so foggy that you couldn't see either end of the pitch and that was it as far as my dad was concerned," she says. "He thought it was a complete waste of time. But I went back and I've kept going back for 36 years."

She and her daughter Hannah, 19, whom she indoctrinated at the age of six, have been to every game, home and away, this season. Her husband Michael and son Ben will complete the family support tomorrow.

Stainthorpe has "a strange feeling we're going to do it". And she has the same attitude to those who dread a return to the First Division as the Yorkshiremen from the Monty Python sketch. "Luxury, pure luxury."

When Julie first supported City they were in the Fourth Division and the priority was to avoid re-election or bankruptcy. Even as recently as seven years ago, she says, "you could leave the pub at five to three and be sure of your regular place. Michael used to walk up and down the ground, keeping up with the play.

"Whatever happens, it's been a fantastic season and, if we go down, we'll be back."

fields.headline: The restaurateur
fields.trailText: It is a tradition among fans in many parts of the country to prepare for a big game with a curry and a dozen pints of lager. Even more so in Bradford, a city with more Indian restaurants than Calcutta.
fields.body:
It is a tradition among fans in many parts of the country to prepare for a big game with a curry and a dozen pints of lager. Even more so in Bradford, a city with more Indian restaurants than Calcutta.

Not that the Bombay Brasserie, the best and most stylish in Bradford, is your normal football fan's haunt. "We don't like fans chanting and things like that but we are happy to have them here," says Muhammad Ilyas, who runs the restaurant with his brother.

"A lot more of the young Asians watch Bradford now, too, those who have grown up in this culture. I really hope they stay up."

fields.headline: The player
fields.trailText: Peter Beagrie says he will refrain from performing his back-flips if he scores the winner against Liverpool. "I think I'll be too emotionally drained. I'll settle for a gentle forward roll."
fields.body:
Peter Beagrie says he will refrain from performing his back-flips if he scores the winner against Liverpool. "I think I'll be too emotionally drained. I'll settle for a gentle forward roll."

The fixture is a chance for Beagrie to exorcise his worst footballing memory, when he played in the Manchester City side relegated from the Premiership after a 2-2 draw with Liverpool on the final day four years ago. He can still picture Steve Lomas running the ball down to the corner flag to waste time.In fact, information from the crowd about other scores proved false, which is why Bradford's players will shut their ears tomorrow and simply concentrate on winning.

Although Beagrie, 34, is booked for an operation on his right achilles, he will play without painkillers for the first time in weeks. "I won't need them for this game. The music and the adrenalin will be pumping - and so will the blood."

In their favour, he says, is that Bradford have so many players old enough to get into the Arsenal back four. They have played in much bigger games and faced more scary scenarios.

Beagrie has been unable to kick a ball in training all week, though he has not surrendered a role in the dressing-room mickey-taking. "I've been in the gym all week, doing thousands of miles on the bike," he says. "That's boring enough but much worse when you've got Stuart McCall in there with you, telling you his stories over and over again."

The players are so wary of tempting fate that they have made no formal post-match plans. They have also taken the extraordinary decision to cancel their summer holiday in Magaluf. But Beagrie is fairly sure that a few drinks will be taken tomorrow night among players, he says, who have the best team spirit he has ever encountered.

First thing Monday he must report for his operation. "Let's hope I go under the anaesthetic with a smile on my face," he says. "Mind you, if we're up, I might not need an anaesthetic."

fields.headline: The manager
fields.trailText: If anyone appears to be feeling the strain as the seconds tick away to Bradford's destiny, it is their likeable young manager Paul Jewell. He has visibly aged in this year of living dangerously, which began with the 3-2 victory at Wolves last May that brought their improbable promotion to the Premiership.
fields.body:
If anyone appears to be feeling the strain as the seconds tick away to Bradford's destiny, it is their likeable young manager Paul Jewell. He has visibly aged in this year of living dangerously, which began with the 3-2 victory at Wolves last May that brought their improbable promotion to the Premiership.

Everyone, including the chairman, insists that Jewell has done brilliantly to reach the final game still in touch with survival. But a relegated manager, even one at a club who many thought would be dead and buried by Christmas, cannot escape a feeling of failure and humiliation.

There is a note of desperation in Jewell's voice when he says: "I wish the game were yesterday. It has been a long week and there will be no second chances after Sunday. People keep describing games as the biggest in the club's history but this one really is massive. Everyone at the club worked their socks off to get us in the Premiership and now that we've tasted it we want more."

When the Premiership fixture list appeared last summer, Jewell thought that, fate being what it is, he was destined to play his old club Liverpool in the final game with survival at stake.

"If it were a normal season, I would really want Liverpool to be in the Champions League," he says. "I would love there to be nothing on the game: that Liverpool were already sure of their European place and that we were safe.

"Though they haven't scored in four games, they have got Owen, Fowler, Camara and Heskey to choose from up front, which is a tough choice."

Jewell has been assured his job is not on the line tomorrow but he is too mentally exhausted to think beyond the final whistle. "I've done all I can but I still feel guilty if I manage to get more than two hours' sleep at night. We're still alive and we won't go out without a fight, that's for sure."

fields.headline: The city ranger
fields.trailText: In his days in the police, Chris Brand used to be on duty every other Saturday at Valley Parade. Now he walks about the city in his claret and amber suit directing tourists to places of interest.
fields.body:
In his days in the police, Chris Brand used to be on duty every other Saturday at Valley Parade. Now he walks about the city in his claret and amber suit directing tourists to places of interest.

"Sunday's game is the only thing people have wanted to talk about this week," he says. "I'm an ex-rugby man myself and a big fan of Bradford Bulls. But I shall be watching this one on telly and keeping my fingers crossed. It will be great for the city if they stay up."

fields.headline: The chaplain
fields.trailText: The Reverend Martin Short, Bradford City's chaplain, was not involved with the club on the fateful day of May 11 1985. But it will still evoke painful memories when he leads the minute's silence tomorrow.
fields.body:
The Reverend Martin Short, Bradford City's chaplain, was not involved with the club on the fateful day of May 11 1985. But it will still evoke painful memories when he leads the minute's silence tomorrow.

"I was not based in Bradford at the time but I remember my phone ringing constantly as friends called to tell me they were safe," he says. "And nine months later, when I returned to the city, I discovered that three families in my parish had lost someone in the fire."

Short, 45, has been City chaplain for more than 10 years and has become so close to players and officials that his support for them has overtaken that for his first footballing love, Sheffield Wednesday.

"I wondered how I would feel when we first played Wednesday but I found myself cheering on Bradford and I have every time since," he says. "Even so I was sad when Wednesday went down and it will be a black season for me if Bradford go as well."

His job as chaplain, he says, involves wandering around the corridors of Valley Parade and chatting to whomever he meets. "That way I get to know a lot of people well and I am there if I can ever be of use to them. I see chaplaincy as the church playing away."

Before the game he will say his normal prayer for the club, though he will not be seeking divine intervention for a penalty or a free-kick on the edge of the box. "I always pray that the players come off the pitch knowing that they have given everything, and it is normally answered," he says. "And I happen to think we will win tomorrow and stay up."

fields.headline: The chairman
fields.trailText: Among the usual key rings, mobile phone holders, two-tone wigs and other memorabilia in the Bradford shop (sale now on) is a gem entitled The Season It Rained Goals. Unfortunately it is not a chronicle of their first season in the Premiership but of 1928-29, when Bradford City won the Third Division North.
fields.body:
Among the usual key rings, mobile phone holders, two-tone wigs and other memorabilia in the Bradford shop (sale now on) is a gem entitled The Season It Rained Goals. Unfortunately it is not a chronicle of their first season in the Premiership but of 1928-29, when Bradford City won the Third Division North.

It will be raining only rain on Bradford fans after the roof of the main stand is lifted off to facilitate a £7.5m development to increase Valley Parade's capacity to 25,000. Should Bradford once again be hosting Grimsby and Crystal Palace next season, they are not certain there will be takers for the extra 7,000 seats. But their commitment to the development, as well as a £4m youth academy, reflects their determination to look to the future, whatever happens tomorrow.

"It certainly won't be the end of the world if we are relegated," says the chairman Geoffrey Richmond. "I believe that if you go down financially strong then you have a chance of coming back, as Charlton have done.

"I look to them as an example because they are a similar-sized club to us and they have done things in a similar way. They didn't throw money at the Premiership, which you can do if you get carried away. And they've also spent money developing their ground."

Unlike Barnsley, Bradford did not arrive in the Premiership wearing party hats and carrying autograph books. Richmond says: "We didn't see it as a season-long jolly. I don't understand how people can think you can go to Old Trafford and lose 4-0, as we did, and come back saying you've had a good day out."

The team's fate has been settled on the final day in four of the past five seasons, always in their favour. When Richmond says the mood is apprehensive, it is only because it is not in their own hands. They could win 6-0 and still be relegated if Wimbledon win at Southampton, yet a goalless draw might be enough. Richmond says: "I've a feeling we will do it."

fields.headline: Somewhere in Britain
fields.trailText: Tate Modern | The National Forest | The Millennium Stadium
fields.body:
One lump or two
Then there were twoTate Galleries in London - the original relaunched as Tate Britain; and the Tate Modern, which opened its international contemporary art collection yesterday.

 Open daily, 10am-6pm (10pm Fri/Sat). Free. Millbank, London SW1 (020-7887 8000).

The new green
The National Forest, England's most ambitious environmental project, offers new walks and cycle routes across the Midlands.

 Visitor Centre open daily 10am-6pm. £2.95/£1.95. Moira, near Swadlincote, Derbyshire (01283 21663300).

Up and under
Cardiff's Millennium Stadium, venue for last year's Rugby World Cup and Europe's biggest undercover venue, is open for tours.

 Open daily, 9am-5pm (Suns 10am), £5/£2.50, family £15. Gate 2/3, Westgate Street, Cardiff (0990 582582).

Argyll in bloom
Achara House in Argyll is the latest newcomer to Scotland's Garden Scheme, with a stunning collection of rhododendrons, azaleas and camellias.

 Open Sunday only, 2pm-6pm. £2/child free. A828, just south of Duror of Appin, Argyllshire (0131-229 1870).

Coast show

webTitle: I lost my heart in... a balloon

fields.headline: I lost my heart in... a balloon
fields.standfirst: Richard Branson
fields.trailText: Richard Branson
fields.body:
Why: I am in the very lucky position that I can follow my hobbies to their ultimate conclusion. After successfully setting the records for crossing the Atlantic and the Pacific in a hot-air balloon, I dreamt for many years of capturing the last great aviation record of flying around the world non-stop in a balloon. Now, for many, the prospect of flying in the enclosed capsule of a 1.1 million cubic foot helium and hot-air balloon, propelled only by the whim of a very unpredictable and at times extremely cruel Mother Nature, is their worse nightmare. For Steve, Per and myself, it was a dream come true.

What's the best thing: It's difficult to say. Trying to avoid Iraq had sent us dangerously off course and into China, a country over which we had no permission to fly. I don't think I have ever been so terrified in my life. After this, things could only get better. The next morning we were greeted by the most beautiful dawn you could imagine while flying over Kansia in Japan. Looking out of the capsule to see hundreds of people stop in their tracks to stare at this glorious balloon flying over their heads made my heart soar. It is a memory I will carry with me for the rest of my life.

What triggers the memory: Any balloon, any sunset.

How do I get there? If you are prepared to spend years of your life waiting for the perfect weather, to risk life and limb flying over not only the most dangerous geographical conditions but potentially explosive political situations in the world, not to mention eating stale turkey sandwiches on Christmas Day somewhere over the Pacific, I would advise anyone to give it a go. Oh, and you'll need lots of money as well.

 Richard Branson's Virgin Atlantic starts a non-stop service from London to Las Vegas next month - by plane

fields.headline: Bitter sweet
fields.standfirst: Peter Lennon stays in the villa made famous by Lawrence Durrell in his memoir of the island
fields.trailText: Peter Lennon stays in the villa made famous by Lawrence Durrell in his memoir of the island
fields.body:
When Lawrence Durrell first climbed the steep slope from the mountain village of Bellapais to the villa that was to be called Bitter Lemons, he wrote that the snaky path he negotiated in a rain storm "resembled the bed of a torrent".

It says something about the sluggish tourist development of Northern Cyprus that, when we arrived, the conditions were much the same. The rain had stopped, but the path resembled a dried-up gully, which the taxi refused to negotiate. It halted, appropriately, by the Tree of Idleness, at the centre of Bellapais by the 14th- century Augustinian abbey. The elegant gothic remains, overhang citrus gardens stretching down to the harbour of Girne (Kyrenia).

Durrell came here in 1953 with his two-year-old daughter, Sappho, to begin a new life and write his planned Alexandria Quartet. But within two years, Archbishop Makarios and the guerrilla chief, Colonel Grivas, had begun their war to evict the British.

Durrell had settled into unpolitical village life at Bellapais. But, strapped for cash, he accepted the post of director of information services (spin doctor) for the British. Soon the masons and carpenters who had helped build the villa, the rowdy drinking company and the friendly farmers deserted him. Before the villa was finished, he moved into Nicosia (Lefkosa) and, within a year, retreated in misery to England. But he had completed Justine and out of this experience came Bitter Lemons.

The villa now has a number of additional luxuries that Durrell did not enjoy, including a pool in the leafy courtyard where ripe avocados drop on your head as you dip.

The Republic of Northern Cyprus, set up after the Turkish invasion of 1974, is not recognised by any country apart from Turkey and suffers further isolation under a Greek embargo that forbids flights over Greek airspace. So it takes eight hours to get there from London, via Izmir in Western Turkey. Neither is it the victim of foreign investment (much as it would like to be).

It is not local madness that is turning beautiful coastlines across Europe into frantic rallytracks of mongrelised food houses elbow-to-elbow with rasping discos and tatty trinket stores; it is "international investment" that dictates the density, the style (to pathetically misuse the word) and the decibel environment of a tourist resort.

So when you sit in the little port of Girne watching the boats tilt and bob in the April sun (April, May, September and October are the best months), you have the eerie experience of natural sounds allowed their full value. You hear the waves lap and slap; the birds sing unflustered; the wind is allowed its full silken whisper. For those nurtured on the raucous hubbub of the Costa this and the Cte de that, it must seem like a power failure. (They have nice power failures, too, in Girne, when the world at night assumes a liquid sinuosity by candlelight.)

The prices are soothing too: four quid for a three-course meal; £8 for a gourmet experience. Even Ken Livingstone could not offer a better fare's fair deal: a dolmush (minibus) will take you the 20 miles from Girne to Lefkosa for 60p. As you speed west to the orange and lemon groves around Güzelyhurt, the roads have that old-fashioned, evacuated look.

North Cyprus is a particularily beautiful region; there are the cosy beaches around Girne, well serviced by restaurants, and on the east coast between Gazimagusa (Famagusta) and Bogaz, there is a 15-mile stretch of sandy beach. Famagusta once a great port, the most spectacular victim of the division of the island, contains a ghostly memento of its great commercial days: section of abandoned high-rise hotels.

On our last evening, we went further up our hill to the small restaurant, Guthrie's Bar, run by Deirdre Guthrie whose parents, doctors working in Kuwait, built their summer house here just one year before Durrell arrived. As a teenager, home from boarding school, Deirdre, along with her mother often visited Durrell down the road. "He would talk for hours, but mostly about himself," she recalled. Thirty years ago, a Swedish film maker did a documentary on Bellapais, including interviews with Deirdre's father and mother. She ran the old film for us.

It was curious to see our village unfurl before us in shadowy black and white: the café owners, bread-makers, shopkeepers, acting out their past life around the Tree of Idleness. I tried to match the faces to those I had seen, giving latitude for age. Then I suddenly realised that, of course, this was a totally different population. These were the Greek villagers Durrell knew, replaced abruptly in 1974 by Turks. It was a dramatic reminder of the ravages of politics.

When Deirdre's parents returned three months after the invasion, the village was totally depopulated, plaintive with the sound of abandonded animals.

Now, time has done its work and Bellapais has grown a new history for itself that appears as rooted as the old.

Durrell on Cyprus

First impression of Bellapais and the run-down villa he was to buy and renovate:
"Everywhere grew roses, and the pale clouds of almond and peach bloom; on the balconies grew herbs in window-boxes made from old petrol tins . . . My reverie was interrupted by a moan. A heifer was the cause of the noise. It stood, plaintively chewing something in the front room, tethered to a ring in the wall."

Settling in with the locals:
"The bottle of cognac was low and I now recognised in it, despite its colourless innocence, a formidable adversary which, if taken too lightly, would unhorse me completely. I seized my host's arms . . . and suggested a change to wine. 'Wine,' he said and his voice was charged with professional tenderness."

He comes to collect his belongings:
"As I turned the last corner and came to rest under the belfries of the Abbey, I saw that the whole village was there in the little square. But as the [car] engine fell silent I was aware of some altogether novel factor about the scene. It lacked all animation . . . I walked across to the little café which was crowded but utterly silent. Everybody looked at the ground, awkwardly and with a shy, clumsy disfavour."

Five best restaurants

1 Abbey Tower Bellapais Splendid Turkish cuisine; £10 a head approx, including wine.

2 AGED Bellapais Honest, copious fare for about £6 a head.

3 Le Jardin Three miles east of Girne French restaurant with a high- class reputation, but we kept sneaking back to the Abbey.

4 Courtyard Inn Off the coast road east of Girne Noted for its fillet stuffed with paté and prawns. £10 a head.

5 The harbour cafés in Girne Good for snacks and salads for well under a fiver.

webTitle: Welcome to the new map of the UK

fields.headline: Welcome to the new map of the UK
fields.standfirst: The first 5,000 miles of the National Cycle Network opens next month.  Stuart Jeffries  reports on a mammoth project to make cycling a safe leisure pursuit ands 'test drives' two of the routes
fields.trailText: The first 5,000 miles of the National Cycle Network opens next month. Stuart Jeffries reports on a mammoth project to make cycling a safe leisure pursuit ands 'test drives' two of the routes
fields.body:
The National Cycle Network, chosen as a landmark project to celebrate the millennium, was funded with £42 million of Lottery money and consists of 5,000 miles of both off-road and traffic-calmed routes in Britain and Northern Ireland, as well as unmarked routes along mostly quite lanes. By 2005, a further 4,000 miles will be added and the network will be complete. This network is to do much of the work of making the UK a place in which cycling is something less than insanely dangerous and, hey, even health inducing.

For those of us who daily suck down fumes as we cycle behind buses, waiting only for the moment when some clown in a white van opens his door and projects us into orbit, the growth of this network, though not in itself enough, is no bad thing.

That said, it is inevitable that the National Cycle Network will primarily be a leisure facility. Most of it runs through beautiful rural districts that deserve to be savoured at a relaxed speed. The network has been designed by a small charity called Sustrans, which is short for Sustainable Transport.

Typical is the new 200-mile section opening in early June called the Coast and Castles Cycle Route. It starts in Newcastle, runs along Hadrian's Wall for a stretch, then up the wonderful castly coastline of Northumbria, up and down the Tweed valley before reaching Edinburgh.

This is one of the safe, attractive routes that should ideally be used in conjunction with the integrated public transport system. Which would be nice if there was one. True, many of the routes devised by Sustrans have rail connections. But that is not enough and the cumulative effect of cycle-unfriendliness on the railways is that many people feel obliged to transport their bikes by car, which is no way to carry on.

But that's enough carping. Sustrans' work in negotiating with 400 councils, landowners, businesses and what can only be described as the British Railways Board to push cycle routes through this patchwork quilt of a multi-owner-occupied kingdom deserves a great deal of credit.

Sustrans also deserves praise for setting up a pilot project called Safe Routes to Schools and aimed at doing something about these dreadful figures: 60% of children cycle to school in Denmark compared with 2% in Britain.

Thanks to Sustrans and the city council, it is now a delight to cycle in and around Birmingham, along the industrial-archaelogical sites that line its towpaths. It's even more of a pleasure to roll into Glastonbury along the Willow Walk, a verdant artwork created by Katy Hallett.

The charity has also acquired more than 200 miles of former railway routes and incorporated them into the network. It's heartening to know that a covenant ensures their possible future use as railway corridors, though, if that covenant is taken up, it's hard to know what will become of the millions of us who will be cycling along them in years to come.

All of these former railways have gentle gradients which make them suitable for cycling families with young children, though not exclusively so. When I cycled from Barnstaple to Plymouth last year along the newly-opened cross-Devon route, much of which was along a disused railway, there was purple scabious around my ankles and lilac brushing my cycle helmet. If I had been any more relaxed, I would have crashed into the bushes.

White Rose Route: Hull to Middlesbrough. 123 miles, easy/moderate

Route 65 presses north alongside the Ouse, then through the quiet country lanes of the Vale of York, before rising up into the foothills of the North Yorkshire Moors. There's money in those hills, the kind of cash that demands that pubs in the vicinity have impressive wine lists and patrons who speak in that singular dialect, Yorkshire posh, just like William Hague.

It was a lovely ride, and so well signposted that I barely needed to consult my map.

I picked up the route just north of York railway station last Saturday on a sunny spring morning. Rowers were lifting their craft into a sparkling river and gardeners had emerged from a row of semis to tend the hanging gardens that step down to the Ouse.

I swept on through the water meadows alongside the Ouse and past the leisurely dog walkers of this contented, cycle-friendly little city, and then under the seething outer ring road. Then I left the cycle path that runs through fields and joined a country lane near Skelton, where an evocative weather vane of cyclist and dog marked the transition.

At nearby Shipton, two railway carriages have been fitted up as restaurant and hotel, but I was too busy pedalling off a thumping breakfast to patronise the Sidings Hotel in all but the most notional sense. From York to Easingwold, it's flat terrain, and consequently a little windy for the wobbling cyclist on even the stillest day.

Just on from the Sidings Hotel lies the baroque pile of Beningborough Hall, a nice place for a contemplative wander if you have £3.50 about your person. "Explore Victorian life in the Laundry and Potting Shed," advised the blurb , but instead I roamed the soothing gardens and the collection of more than 100 portraits from the National Portrait Gallery.

They really know when to mow village greens in this part of Yorkshire. Daisies, like white Smarties sprinkled by a god with fine attention to detail, glittered at me from one such green at Newton-on-Ouse. More ruthless gardeners would have cut that green of all such interest.

There was time to consider such details since this was an easy cycle. At Easingwold, though, things changed. Inclines got steeper. I was whisked, thanks to Sustrans' route, into the village's Millfields Park, opened by the mayor only last year, and then through a rinky-dink housing estate, complete with mock-Georgian carriage lamps. The ups and downs of this portion were a surprise to me.

At Newburgh Priory, I saw triangular sign warning of looming ducks. It's so peaceful hereabouts that damp birds are the most prominent of traffic hazards. Mind you, they were quite burly ducks.

At Coxwold, a twee village on a hill, I sank two litres of mineral water, only pausing to emit grateful noisy sighs that seemed to affront the genteel patrons of the adjacent Fauconberg Arms. At this village, Sustrans splits the route in two - a gentle low road direct to Kilburn, and the high road, which I took, that pushes deeper into the hills of the Moors. By the time I reached Byland Abbey, crossing hills and dales, I had sweated most of the water on to my skin surface, thus attracting all of the local insect life.

It was time for lunch. The Abbey Inn, opposite the abbey ruins, is recommended by Egon Ronay and, to a lesser extent, me. It has a restaurant, a good wine list, a delightful garden and a very small bar. I was dehydrated and in urgent need of the sustenance that only a poached salmon sandwich and a pint of Black Sheep bitter can supply.

Fed, watered and abluted, I hit the road again. The White Horse, sculpted into the moorland hills, had long been an uncertain friend, playing peek-a-boo with me as I rose and fell over the hills. At Kilburn, Sustrans offered me another choice: back down into the valley or up into the moors. It was at this point I realised that I urgently needed after-sun lotion, and so headed down towards civilisation. My arms were turning weasel red and so I customised a quick route to Thirsk railway station. I was, nonetheless, very much taken with Sowerby, whose avenues of limes and floral verges were everything they should be.

At Thirsk, it was race day. As I cycled along the road parallel to the the two-furlong marker, a steel band struck up something carnivalesque that spirited me on to the station. Watch out for that right-hand turn into the ticket office, though. It's a doozy. The rail journey from Thirsk to York passed without incident. It's worth recording that all the GNER staff I encountered both on this local service and on the mainline to King's Cross were properly solicitous for me and my bike. In York, I got the attention my arms so needed.

Where to visit: Beningborough Hall, Newburgh Priory (only open on Sunday and Wednesday afternoons), the White Horse at Kilburn, the ruins of Byland Abbey. Where to eat and drink: The Sidings Hotel and restaurant, The Facuonberg Inn, Coxswold. The Abbey Inn, Byland Abbey.

Thames Valley: London to Oxford. 97 miles, easy/moderate

I rode the Thames Valley Cycle Route from Putney Bridge to Windsor. If there were hills, my calves didn't notice them.

This was never, nor was meant to be, a cardiovascular work out. There were herons who sat on the Thames path near Molesey Reservoirs and blocked my way until the last possible moment. They flapped into the air with insolent laziness before settling fatly in my path once more. I felt sure they were the psychic equivalent of sleeping policemen. "Slow down! Slow down! You'll enjoy it more." That is what they would have said if they could have spoken.

Admittedly, I became embroiled in a little altercation near the Ferrari outlet on the Egham by pass, and the one-way systems of places like Kingston, Staines, Weybridge and lots of other identikit towns, jolted me from my reverie back into irksome reality. At these points, where a single slip can mean a 20-mile detour around Slough, the Sustrans map of the cycle route became hot in my hands. It proved very easy to follow, colourful, waterproof, and with smart inserts on how to get through commuter town centres without upset. The only problem with fold-up maps for on-the-go cyclist, to my mind, is that after a little bit of folding and unfolding, a tear always emerges at the vital corner. Much better, surely, to print the maps in little ring binders, as for example they have done with the Hayes London Cycle Guide. If I'd had a ring binder for a map, that whole Egham debacle, I am certain, could have been avoided.

As I cycled these 40-odd miles, I felt protected from the traffic roar all around me. Sustrans has created a route that is a miracle of calm, though north of Windsor there is not yet a quiet path through the dismal jungle of Heathrow buildings and motorways. But even along the Putney to Windsor stretch, 747s are always with us. Only they interrupt the serenity.

From Putney, the route took me along the Thames path for a little while, then nipped through Barnes's interesting collection of Toucan crossings and cycle lanes, before switching, delightfully, into Richmond Park, where it proved necessary to stop for the first of series of unhealthy snacks at Pembroke Lodge. A Toucan crossing, it turns out, is like a Pelican crossing for bikes. The park route forms a by-pass around Richmond. As a result, I missed one more English one-way system and Quinlan Terry's Prince Charles-approved retro riverfront development, for both of which, Sustrans, much thanks.

After Richmond Park, I rejoined the Thames and swept through Teddington, where Magpie was filmed. Then I fringed Hampton Court Park. I hugged the Thames path tight as we swept through the badlands of the commuter belt. I have watched my Ali G, after all, and know that the feud between the West Staines and East Staines massives means that they regularly get medieval on eachothers' bottoms and, perhaps, on those of passing cyclists.

This is an overdetermined corner of England, where heritage history does battle with a frenzied suburban aspiration and just about survives, but only thanks to the suburbanite need to express its collective Englishness through frequenting cream-tea joints and wandering through courtly fields to stately homes.

fields.bodyText: The National Cycle Network, chosen as a landmark project to celebrate the millennium, was funded with £42 million of Lottery money and consists of 5,000 miles of both off-road and traffic-calmed routes in Britain and Northern Ireland, as well as unmarked routes along mostly quite lanes. By 2005, a further 4,000 miles will be added and the network will be complete. This network is to do much of the work of making the UK a place in which cycling is something less than insanely dangerous and, hey, even health inducing. For those of us who daily suck down fumes as we cycle behind buses, waiting only for the moment when some clown in a white van opens his door and projects us into orbit, the growth of this network, though not in itself enough, is no bad thing. That said, it is inevitable that the National Cycle Network will primarily be a leisure facility. Most of it runs through beautiful rural districts that deserve to be savoured at a relaxed speed. The network has been designed by a small charity called Sustrans, which is short for Sustainable Transport. Typical is the new 200-mile section opening in early June called the Coast and Castles Cycle Route. It starts in Newcastle, runs along Hadrian's Wall for a stretch, then up the wonderful castly coastline of Northumbria, up and down the Tweed valley before reaching Edinburgh. This is one of the safe, attractive routes that should ideally be used in conjunction with the integrated public transport system. Which would be nice if there was one. True, many of the routes devised by Sustrans have rail connections. But that is not enough and the cumulative effect of cycle-unfriendliness on the railways is that many people feel obliged to transport their bikes by car, which is no way to carry on. But that's enough carping. Sustrans' work in negotiating with 400 councils, landowners, businesses and what can only be described as the British Railways Board to push cycle routes through this patchwork quilt of a multi-owner-occupied kingdom deserves a great deal of credit. Sustrans also deserves praise for setting up a pilot project called Safe Routes to Schools and aimed at doing something about these dreadful figures: 60% of children cycle to school in Denmark compared with 2% in Britain. Thanks to Sustrans and the city council, it is now a delight to cycle in and around Birmingham, along the industrial-archaelogical sites that line its towpaths. It's even more of a pleasure to roll into Glastonbury along the Willow Walk, a verdant artwork created by Katy Hallett. The charity has also acquired more than 200 miles of former railway routes and incorporated them into the network. It's heartening to know that a covenant ensures their possible future use as railway corridors, though, if that covenant is taken up, it's hard to know what will become of the millions of us who will be cycling along them in years to come. All of these former railways have gentle gradients which make them suitable for cycling families with young children, though not exclusively so. When I cycled from Barnstaple to Plymouth last year along the newly-opened cross-Devon route, much of which was along a disused railway, there was purple scabious around my ankles and lilac brushing my cycle helmet. If I had been any more relaxed, I would have crashed into the bushes. There's money in those hills, the kind of cash that demands that pubs in the vicinity have impressive wine lists and patrons who speak in that singular dialect, Yorkshire posh, just like William Hague. It was a lovely ride, and so well signposted that I barely needed to consult my map. I picked up the route just north of York railway station last Saturday on a sunny spring morning. Rowers were lifting their craft into a sparkling river and gardeners had emerged from a row of semis to tend the hanging gardens that step down to the Ouse. I swept on through the water meadows alongside the Ouse and past the leisurely dog walkers of this contented, cycle-friendly little city, and then under the seething outer ring road. Then I left the cycle path that runs through fields and joined a country lane near Skelton, where an evocative weather vane of cyclist and dog marked the transition. At nearby Shipton, two railway carriages have been fitted up as restaurant and hotel, but I was too busy pedalling off a thumping breakfast to patronise the Sidings Hotel in all but the most notional sense. From York to Easingwold, it's flat terrain, and consequently a little windy for the wobbling cyclist on even the stillest day. Just on from the Sidings Hotel lies the baroque pile of Beningborough Hall, a nice place for a contemplative wander if you have £3.50 about your person. "Explore Victorian life in the Laundry and Potting Shed," advised the blurb , but instead I roamed the soothing gardens and the collection of more than 100 portraits from the National Portrait Gallery. They really know when to mow village greens in this part of Yorkshire. Daisies, like white Smarties sprinkled by a god with fine attention to detail, glittered at me from one such green at Newton-on-Ouse. More ruthless gardeners would have cut that green of all such interest. There was time to consider such details since this was an easy cycle. At Easingwold, though, things changed. Inclines got steeper. I was whisked, thanks to Sustrans' route, into the village's Millfields Park, opened by the mayor only last year, and then through a rinky-dink housing estate, complete with mock-Georgian carriage lamps. The ups and downs of this portion were a surprise to me. At Newburgh Priory, I saw triangular sign warning of looming ducks. It's so peaceful hereabouts that damp birds are the most prominent of traffic hazards. Mind you, they were quite burly ducks. At Coxwold, a twee village on a hill, I sank two litres of mineral water, only pausing to emit grateful noisy sighs that seemed to affront the genteel patrons of the adjacent Fauconberg Arms. At this village, Sustrans splits the route in two - a gentle low road direct to Kilburn, and the high road, which I took, that pushes deeper into the hills of the Moors. By the time I reached Byland Abbey, crossing hills and dales, I had sweated most of the water on to my skin surface, thus attracting all of the local insect life. It was time for lunch. The Abbey Inn, opposite the abbey ruins, is recommended by Egon Ronay and, to a lesser extent, me. It has a restaurant, a good wine list, a delightful garden and a very small bar. I was dehydrated and in urgent need of the sustenance that only a poached salmon sandwich and a pint of Black Sheep bitter can supply. Fed, watered and abluted, I hit the road again. The White Horse, sculpted into the moorland hills, had long been an uncertain friend, playing peek-a-boo with me as I rose and fell over the hills. At Kilburn, Sustrans offered me another choice: back down into the valley or up into the moors. It was at this point I realised that I urgently needed after-sun lotion, and so headed down towards civilisation. My arms were turning weasel red and so I customised a quick route to Thirsk railway station. I was, nonetheless, very much taken with Sowerby, whose avenues of limes and floral verges were everything they should be. At Thirsk, it was race day.
