webTitle: Salary or shares: Can joining a start-up damage your wealth?

fields.headline: Salary or shares: Can joining a start-up damage your wealth?
fields.standfirst: Examine all your options before signing on the dotcom line
fields.trailText: Examine all your options before signing on the dotcom line
fields.body:
Lucky you. You've landed not just one job offer, but two - one with an established employer offering a good salary, the other with a start-up offering less cash but plenty of share options. How do you decide between them?

Consider your pocket and your personality. Accepting a position that doesn't suit you simply because there's a chance of hitting big money could leave you rich but miserable (or broke and miserable).

With all the news about share- option millionaires and internet zillionaires, it's easy to think that options are a guarantee of a big payoff. But those stories make news exactly because they're so unusual.

Truth is, most new businesses fail. Plenty of start-ups that do succeed never go public. And the vast majority of those companies that do go public chug along modestly, paying minimal returns for investors.

Share options are always risky. There is no guarantee that an early-stage company will go public. How, then do you increase the odds of picking a winner? Start by looking for a company that is well-managed, that is well-funded by top venture capital money, that has a strong management team and a solid product-to-market strategy - in other words, look for the things you'd seek in a company whose shares you were buying from the 'outside'.

Be sure to find out what percentage of the company your options represent. Options in a billion-pound company won't make you rich if you only own 10,000 out of 100,000,000 shares.

And understand that stock options are not the same as shares in the company. An option is merely the right to buy shares at a specified price (the 'strike price') after a specified date The right to buy 100,000 shares in the company at £10 each does not equal a £1m bonus. If the stock never sells for more than £10.50 a share, you'll only net £50,000.

Not to be sniffed at, but not enough to retire on either - nor to justify working 20 hours a day for five years when you could make just as much working half as many hours at another company. And if the shares are trading at £9.00, your options are worth less than the paper they're printed on.

A job offer heavily weighted toward share options is basically a pay cheque with a lottery ticket stapled to it. Will you be able to live on the part of your earnings that are guaranteed?

If the offer on the table doesn't include benefits (many start-ups don't) will you have enough money to pay for season tickets, medical insurance and pension contributions on your own? Will you be able to resist spinning out your credit card debt while you wait for an IPO that may bomb?

If the answer to any of these questions is 'No', think very seriously before accepting the share options offer. But if you are guaranteed enough money to cover your minimum expenses, and if the job seems exciting enough, it may be worth a few years of belt-tightening to have a shot at a big winner

if the company does really take off.

Of course, there's more to picking the right job than just going for the gold. And because many share- option packages require that you stay at the company for five years, you could be stuck for half-a-decade waiting to get out. That's why it's important to consider which type of working environment suits you better.

Start-ups involve a lot of late nights and weekends. If you have a very active life outside work - lots of hobbies or commitments that can't be put on hold - this kind of job may not be suitable for you.

And free time is not the only thing that's in short supply at start-ups. Don't look for lots of formal feedback, traditional training programmes or hands-on management at a fledgling company.

If you are looking to develop a solid foundation of skills in a particular area, a more established company may be a better place to do that.

On the other hand, if you're good at handling projects on your own with little or no supervision, and if you want to see a lot of different parts of an organisation, you'll probably enjoy a start-up more. If you like the feeling of being on the edge, and if you think that's romantic, a start up may be right for you.

To make the decision that's wisest for you, spend some time on each of your prospective employers' premises, and ask yourself where you think you would be happier. Talk to as many people as you can at each company. Employees may not be 100% candid with you about their bosses or their jobs, but you'll be able to sense what types of people seem to be happy at each place.

fields.headline: Sixty seconds in: Engineering
fields.standfirst: Frazer Fillingham, engineer with Thames Water, talks to Miles Brignall
fields.trailText: Frazer Fillingham, engineer with Thames Water, talks to Miles Brignall
fields.body:
Although a lot of the sewer network under London was built by the Victorians, it's still in an amazing condition when you consider its age. Until recently engineers working for Thames spent most of their time fixing problems as they developed. But that has all changed and today I'm just as likely to be working on a scheme that will improve the network such as a flood prevention scheme.

When I joined Thames as a graduate site engineer just over a decade ago, the company was undertaking its largest construction project this century - the giant ring main around the capital. I worked in a quality assurance role, which basically meant crawling around under the excavating machines carrying out tests as the miners took their breaks.

Until recently I was responsible for designing several of the large refurbishment projects including the large underground reservoir at Putney Heath. This was built in the 1850s and houses 57m litres of water - enough to supply most of west London and the West End. Obviously we have to manage the work without disrupting the supply, which make the process somewhat more complicated. Other projects I have worked on include the large water holding reservoirs you see as you are about to land at Heathrow airport.

The Thames area stretches from Banbury in the north to near Guildford in the south, and undoubtedly one of the best things about working for the company is the variety of projects we handle. For example at the moment I am overseeing the building of a powerhouse near Dartford. This will take the methane produced by the sewage composters and turn it, via a generator, into 'green' electricity.

One of the big problems the industry faces is how to get the water out of the treated sludge produced by the composting process before it's sent to farms for use as fertiliser. This site will do just that.

Although I am usually working on four or five projects at any one time, I'm only out on site for two days a week. My role today is management orientated and I'm there to make sure the project runs exactly to schedule. While a lot of it is about keeping the 'tension' among those doing the work, most of it is achieved through good planning.

One area that all the utilities are expanding into is working outside the UK. I've already helped design a 60 km bulk supply main in Turkey and the recent earthquake means further work will be coming our way. Although you'd think designing a system for a Turkish hill town would be different, the basic principles are the same as if it were Putney.

fields.headline: Moving on up
fields.standfirst: An ABC guide to harnessing your ambitions
fields.trailText: An ABC guide to harnessing your ambitions
fields.body:
A. Common decency

Although in its naked form ambition can appear threatening and unattractive,

it's something everyone's got, so there's no shame in admitting to it. Acknowledge the nature of yours, then concentrate on dressing it up. Attitudes to ambition are contradictory: a detectable absence is scorned but if it's too prominent, that's not acceptable either. Aspirations that match the world view of those you're trying to impress are always seen as laudable.

B. Well presented

If you feel you have no ambition, you're kidding yourself - what you're after is as easy a life as possible. That's a perfectly reasonable goal but one that needs to be disguised, as does a desire for world domination. Once either of those extremes is detected, others will work to thwart you. Before broadcasting details of your master plan, take care to adapt content to audience. If your overwhelming aim in life is to get home early, take long

holidays or depose your boss, divluge it only to trusted friends.

C. Own goal

The only time you're likely to encounter genuine interest in your goals is at job interviews. Tell them what they want to hear - that you're dynamic but considerate, aware of the value of hard work and experience. It's essential to retain the upper hand and remind your ambitious side that you control it. Be prepared to adapt or tame desires that drive you into a must-win-everything state. Objectives that make you ruthless with yourself and others might not be worth the aggravation.

Own goal The only time you're likely to encounter genuine interest in your goals is at job interviews. Tell them what they want to hear - that you're dynamic but considerate, aware of the value of hard work and experience. It's essential to retain the upper hand and remind your ambitious side that you control it. Be prepared to adapt or tame desires that drive you into a must-win-everything state. Objectives that make you ruthless with yourself and others might not be worth the aggravation.

webTitle: Paying the penalty for a hat-trick of jobs

fields.headline: Paying the penalty for a hat-trick of jobs
fields.standfirst: Does a bulging CV make you less employable?
fields.trailText: Does a bulging CV make you less employable?
fields.body:
There was a time when you could view jobs in a career path like a tower block - ideally the bricks should all be the same colour or, at most, different shades of it. You began and finished your career in the same industry, changing jobs only to move up the ladder. Switching sector or profession was rare.

Conventional wisdom still says you should consolidate your experience to create a 'credible' CV. While it might be acceptable to change career once, two may be pushing it. When you get to three it may seem to prospective employers that you don't know what you want to do or get bored easily.

But does experience in a bunch of disparate industries (on the surface) result in a multi-skilled graduate or a jack-of-all-trades, master of none?

According to Imogen Daniels, an adviser at the Institute of Personnel and Development (IPD), the traditional career-for-life is dying. "People move about more, careers are less prescriptive and it's more acceptable to move around. Today's graduates have more choices compared to people who graduated 10 years ago in the middle of the recession. And as a result they are less concerned about stability and more about jobs which are stimulating and interest them."

Sue Guthrie's career path to her current position is a good example. Sue trained as a vet, then lectured in animal health and was a medical writer before becoming an account director at a pharmaceutical PR/medical education company. "From the age of six I knew that I wanted to be a vet. However, while working as a vet I branched out into research and lectured at an animal college," she explains. So how did the writing come about? "I had always been interested in the arts and languages and while I was working as a vet I did an Open University arts degree. A friend who worked in a medical education agency knew that I was interested in writing and suggested that I send in my CV to the company where she worked. I did and was offered a job."

The biggest transition for Sue was getting used to working in a commercial environment. "I was used to working in either a clinic, a lecture theatre or my own office. Suddenly I was desk bound in an open plan office. It took me at least a year to adjust." After two and a half years as a medical writer, Sue was offered the option to move into PR. "I am always ready for a challenge so I decided to give it a go. This has been quite a transition because I found myself involved in activities that I knew nothing about like organising press conferences.

"Because I've done so many different jobs, I've got a broader range of skills and I can cope better with change. However, if anyone had told me 10 years ago that I would one day work in PR, I would never have believed them."

"I'm sure when most people see my CV, they must think what on earth is going on," says Nina Lee, senior arrivals customer services agent at British Airways. Nina's route to her present role included a masters in clinical laboratory medicine, followed by research, three years working with people with schizophrenia on a care in the community project and a stint in healthcare public relations. All before the age of 27.

Like many graduates, unsure of what to do, Nina fell into her first job and the masters by accident. "During my psychology degree, I did a placement where I carried out research on people with schizophrenia. Based on this I was offered a job and funding to do an masters. Once the project was completed, I was offered project work on a care in the community project."

The short-term contracts and the lack of any nursing or social work qualifications meant that Nina's career opportunities were limited so she decided to move on. "I had always been interested in PR and had done some exhibition work while I was carrying out my research project; because I didn't have any experience, I decided to do a PR course," she explains.

Armed with her PR qualification and a job offer in a PR agency, it seemed that Nina had found her niche. "I went into PR with an open mind but I realised quite soon that it wasn't for me. I spent the first few months writing press materials, which I hated. And I didn't like being stuck at a desk all day.

"PR has a culture of long hours and I felt that all eyes were on me if I left at 5.30pm. Before I quit PR I went through a lot of turmoil, but I knew that my heart wasn't in it. So when I saw an advert for the job at BA, I applied and got offered the job.

"I now know that I've made the right decision. I work shifts and I like the fact that I'm not fighting crowds to get to work in the morning and facing long queues at the bank at lunchtime. Some people thought I was mad when I told them what I was doing, but I knew it was right for me."

"Many people go to university not knowing what they want to do so they study non-vocational subjects," says Ben Williams, an Edinburgh-based chartered corporate psychologist. "They take any job to survive and may move through a succession of jobs until they find the right career for them." He describes an itinerant, promiscuous workforce who will change jobs at the flick of a switch.

He adds: "Since the concept of a job or career for life is becoming obsolete, changing jobs frequently is more acceptable. People aren't loyal to their organisations because of the hire and fire mentality."

Ben Williams' advice to graduates is to "find your vocation and a job where you are happy and content and feel that you are making a useful contribution."

Imogen Daniels' advice to graduates who have moved around a lot is to "focus more on what you have achieved rather than the time spent at the jobs".

For those who are worried about their 'eclectic CV' Imogen has some words of comfort. "Staying with one employer for three years with no promotion or achievements may actually be viewed with suspicion by some employers."

fields.headline: The front line
fields.standfirst: The readers' editor on... a disturbing front-page picture
fields.trailText: The readers' editor on... a disturbing front-page picture
fields.body:
Our front page on Tuesday this week was dominated by a report from Sierra Leone, in particular by a six-column picture, in colour, of one of the civilians shot and killed during the demonstration in Freetown outside the home of the rebel leader, Foday Sankoh. It was a strikingly memorable picture. The head (in profile) and shoulders of the unnamed victim, who was black, were shown in the bottom right corner of the frame. A river of blood came from beneath him, diagonally upwards across the picture, diverging and then converging again in the top left corner.

A number of readers - not a great many, perhaps a dozen - registered strong disapproval at the use of this picture. Readers of the letters page will have had a fairly representative sample of these and of other views (I have also read all the unpublished letters). Several correspondents objected to its use on the front page but would not have minded had we placed it inside the paper. Their argument was that by using it on the front, we denied people the option of quickly avoiding it or keeping it from their children.

One or two accused us of cynically choosing it to sell papers, and expressed this view in the strongest terms, although no one to whom I have spoken here is convinced by the principle implied in this criticism: that images so shocking, or, if you like, so challenging, actually do sell papers. On the contrary, it is thought that they might tend slightly towards the opposite effect.

The most serious questions raised by readers might be summed up like this: would you have used the picture if the dead person had been white? If you would, then why did you not use a similar picture of the dead white farmer murdered in Zimbabwe in the middle of April?

The pictorial options on Tuesday are clearly indicated by a glance at the other papers. The Times and the Telegraph showed the deployment of British paratroopers. The Independent had a picture of a person (a black person), injured when the demonstration was fired upon, being carried away. The picture that appeared on the front page of all editions of the Guardian on Tuesday was available on Monday long before the decision to use it was taken. The picture editor had drawn it to the attention of the newsdesk well before the earliest edition time. At that moment our Africa correspondent, who had been sent to Sierra Leone from his base in Johannesburg, had not surfaced and, without his report, the paper was likely to lead on the British troop deployment, which would be written from London.

There was a discussion about the picture lasting roughly 20 minutes, involving the editor of the paper, the deputy editor (news), the picture editor and the foreign editor. It was decided that the picture would not be used unless the Africa correspondent came through and then only if his dispatch provided an appropriate context. When he did file his eyewitness account of events in Freetown, he made one point very strongly, that the option of leaving offered to the small number of (mainly white) foreigners by the British military operation was not open to the mass of (black) Sierra Leoneans. [The parentheses are mine.] His second paragraph read, "Foreigners may scan the skies for rescue helicopters, but there is nowhere for Sierra Leoneans to run... Four died and a city was left in terror of the consequences."

Particular care was taken that the headline addressed both the report and the picture. It said, "Amid the chaos of Sierra Leone, those who can are fleeing". The paper felt that it was thus accurately and at the right moment - during the military operation to lift out foreigners - interposing a strong reminder that it was Sierra Leoneans who were suffering and dying. Some of those who registered their response saw it that way too, and so did I. Black colleagues and correspondents, though they may applaud the intention, nevertheless believe a radical shift of perception is needed.

They point out that the dead white farmer in Zimbabwe, used on the front page on April 19, was named and that the body was covered by a tarpaulin. The dead black person was anonymous and exposed to our gaze. They say that the paper seems to consider the possible feelings of relatives when the picture is of a dead white person, while apparently overlooking them when the dead person is black. (The possibility of someone recognising the person in Tuesday's picture was not entirely remote. There are about 50,000 Sierra Leoneans living in Britain).

Another objection registered by a couple of readers was the careful framing of the picture, the "art" in it. This also, they felt, suggested a cynical disregard for human dignity. I do not believe that. Indeed if the photographer told me he was not engaged I would not believe him either. He was. The picture says so, and on this occasion I think the decision to use it was justified.

fields.headline: Eye of the tiger
fields.standfirst: He's the reformed Essex bad boy who, English cricket hopes, will bring back success, starting with Thursday's Test match at Lord's. But,  Stephen Moss reports, the England captain's Anglo-Indian background plus his New-British swagger and steely drive also mark a much-needed cultural shift for a struggling sport
fields.trailText: He's the reformed Essex bad boy who, English cricket hopes, will bring back success, starting with Thursday's Test match at Lord's. But, Stephen Moss reports, the England captain's Anglo-Indian background plus his New-British swagger and steely drive also mark a much-needed cultural shift for a struggling sport
fields.body:
Nasser Hussain was not happy. He looked at the umpire who had just given him out leg-before wicket with dismay and paused for a moment, reluctant to leave the crease, before tucking his bat under his arm and stalking off towards the pavilion, his body language speaking eloquently of his disbelief. We were warned not to approach him for half an hour. He was still in a foul temper when we finally made contact and he was initially unwilling to pose for photographs. But he relented and eventually apologised for being "in a mood". "My whole day today has been geared towards getting runs for Essex. You get a bad decision and your day has gone. It pisses you off but you have to get on with it."

In a way it is a compliment to Hussain, the England cricket captain, that a week before the first Test he is so worked up about getting out in a second division county championship match between Essex and Nottinghamshire in front of a couple of hundred diehards at sleepy Chelmsford. Hussain's urge to score runs and to succeed, the steely competitiveness that characterises his game, is apparent whatever the arena; it is why he was chosen as captain and why cricket followers believe he has what it takes to lift cricket out of the doldrums.

The game in England is facing unprecedented challenges. The Test team had a dismal record in the 90s, and Hussain took over last year when Alec Stewart was sacked after England's humiliating exit in the first round of the world cup. The overall quality of the game has also come under attack from critics who say there are too many full-time players performing at a mediocre level that is a world away from the rigours of international cricket. Peaceful days in the sun at Worcester or Guildford, it is argued, have no place in our fiercely competitive global age.

English cricketing failure in the 90s, sitting starkly beside the rapid rise of Premiership soccer, left the sport looking feeble: it has struggled for media attention, is having trouble attracting sponsors, and currently lacks players with the punch of Ian Botham or the panache of David Gower. England had limited success for much of the 80s too, and were routinely annihilated by the all-conquering West Indians, but with Botham, Gower, Lamb and Gooch, it was possible to lose with elan, to feel pride in defeat. The 90s were just drab and pitiful.

The threat now is that soccer will change its calendar and, in line with a Fifa initiative, be played from February until November. If football changes its season, our traditional summer sport would be in danger of being dismissed. All of which demands that the 32-year-old Hussain, as well as being England's captain and key batsman, should also be the miracle worker who remakes cricket for the modern age.

Part of that miracle has to be cultural, and Hussain - who has an Indian father and an English mother and was born in Madras - is uniquely placed to work it. Cricket in England has been emasculated by class and deference; strangled by the old school tie. Captains were supposed to be pukka gents like Peter May or no-nonsense northern types like Raymond Illingworth (Botham and Mike Gatting were earthy - and short-lived - exceptions). The game itself has been locked in some Majorite dream-world of village greens, public schools and hearty parsons: no wonder soccer, adapting its class base and connecting the media and sport, pop and Posh, has been making all the running.

When Hussain became England captain last June, his former team-mate at Essex, Derek Pringle, now cricket correspondent of the Independent, wrote of the change - both practical and symbolic - that his appointment would make. "Hussain is a shrewd, passionate cricketer whose desire to succeed is just what English cricket needs, as it looks to step into the new millennium. Rumours emanating from HQ were that the occasional bout of temper made him something of a liability in the genteel world of Victorian mores by which the game in this country still judges itself. Yet like it or not, he is very much a product of modern Britain, and as such should not be precluded from shaping its future."

"He is a good choice as captain and a very important figure," says Rob Steen, editor of The New Ball, which showcases new cricket writing. "He should have been blooded earlier, but the selectors were scared of him. He had said in one interview that we had to get nastier and the establishment hated that. He represents a break with the past, and making him captain was as significant as making Len Hutton the first professional captain in the 50s. He's not from the usual background; he's from a talented Anglo-Indian family who love the game."

Mihir Bose, author of The Sporting Alien, says Hussain is very different from other Indians and Anglo-Indians who have played in English cricket. "There is a long tradition of Indians playing in English cricket, but they tended to be from the gentlemanly or princely class and above the battle," says Bose. "In the early part of his career, Nasser made a point of being different - he was bolshie, a streetfighter. He is very much a product of the late 20th century and his captaincy marks a change in cricket. I don't know whether it is conscious or not, but there appears to be a desire to be more populist. He is certainly more populist - like a character from Men Behaving Badly - and aware of modern susceptibilities and of his dual identity."

Cricket has always been central to Hussain's life. He was born in Madras in 1968 to an Indian father, the cricket-playing Jawad (anglicised to Joe), and an English mother, Shireen. They had met when Joe, who had an electronics business in India, was visiting the UK. His two older brothers, Mel and Abbas, were fine cricketers, and Nasser's early years were spent on the boundary's edge at the Chepauk stadium in Madras watching his father play and having members of visiting Test teams bowl underarm to him.

The family moved to Ilford when Nasser was six and all three sons continued to play cricket. Nasser, who was very small as a boy, was an excellent leg-spin bowler, but Mel was reckoned to be the more promising player ("10 times better than Nasser at the same age," according to their father). Ironically, Mel went on to play a few seasons for Hampshire, while Nasser scaled the heights of international cricket.

When he was 14, Nasser suddenly grew and, as he got taller, lost the ability to bowl leg- spinners. "He must have been crying in his bed," says his father. "But he was determined to play professional cricket, was hungry to play for Essex, and turned himself into a batsman. Mel didn't have the patience, but Nasser was determined to succeed. At 17, I knew Nasser would make it to the professional game, but I didn't know he would play Test cricket at 21."

Living next door to the Hussains in Ilford must have been a noisy experience: one neighbour recalls the endless thump of cricket balls against the wall. Joe Hussain would also take his three boys down to the nets at the Ilford cricket school (which he later bought and now runs), where they would hire a net and practise for hours on end. Ilford is a buoyant catchment area for young cricketers - former Essex and England captain Graham Gooch comes from near here - and an evening at the school demonstrates that there is life in the game yet.

Hussain's characteristics - steeliness, directness, testiness, an unwillingness to give a sucker an even break - might be thought of as typical Australian virtues, and they did not endear him to the cricketing establishment in his early days. He was seen as a rebel, accused of aloofness and arrogance, and his career has been punctuated by disciplinary infringements which led to one- or two-match suspensions.

His father says the competitiveness is hereditary. "I play cricket the hard way; I play to win. If I see a boy with the fighting spirit, I don't dampen it, I just have a quiet word. You've got to have it: look at the Aussies, look at the way Steve Waugh [the Australian captain] talks to batsmen at the end of an over. You can't play cricket with one hand tied behind your back. Nasser went over the top once or twice, but nothing much. He always wanted to do well and to win. If those qualities hadn't been there, Nasser wouldn't be what he is today."

Early in his career at Essex, Hussain was involved in two incidents that dogged him for years afterwards. Once, when he was yorked [bowled by a ball that hits the base of the stumps without bouncing] in a match against Surrey, he went back to the dressing room and rounded on the Essex bowlers for their inability to produce such effective deliveries. Gooch, then Essex captain, did not take kindly to an upstart denting team morale and suspended him for one game. Worse, in another match for Essex, he gave the team's senior bowler, Neil Foster, some unwanted advice and was publicly reprimanded. Back in the dressing room, he kicked over a case containing cricket equipment, which fell on the foot of another Essex bowler, Mark Ilott, injuring his toe. He refused to apologise, and he and Ilott almost came to blows.

Hussain was banned for two games after that altercation and was on the way to getting a reputation for truculence that at one stage seemed likely to deny him the England captaincy. He was passed over when Michael Atherton resigned in 1998 (Hussain was vice-captain but Alec Stewart was given the job), and there were dark rumours that Lord MacLaurin, chairman of the England and Wales Cricket Board, was vehemently opposed to Hussain becoming captain. But the débcle of the world cup appears to have convinced the cricketing authorities that England needed some of his bloody-mindedness.

When he was made captain, his long-time England team-mate Michael Atherton said that Hussain would have to temper his steeliness. "It is in the dressing room that he may have to work the hardest," said Atherton, who captained England in a record 52 Tests. "He is regarded by some as self-centred, good for a batsman but not for a captain, and has the endearing ability to rub people up the wrong way with no apparent effort. So much so that last winter two of England's bowlers were heard to mutter that if he ever became captain he would have to find two more bowlers."

"I've always had a short fuse," Hussain admits. "That's just the way I am. But the reputation came from one or two things that made the press. I was only left out for one or two games by Essex, and disciplined for a heated argument in the dressing room, but after that you are portrayed as a bad boy. It's very difficult to get away from that, and in your mind you almost start to live up to it. That's why I understand players like that, and like to have them in my side, because you can see them doing what you've done in the past."

"What underpins everything is his burning desire to succeed," says Gooch, who has known Hussain since he was eight. "He has a passion that has sometimes led him to boil over. He still has that fire in the belly, but he has learned to control his emotions. He always had his own ideas about how things should be done, and we had our moments when I was captain, but that all helped to make him a more rounded character."

"He does explode on occasions," says Keith Fletcher, the former England captain and coach, and now eminence grise at Essex. "But he handled the long tour of South Africa well, and has grown with the responsibility of being England captain. He knows he can't explode now because the press would be down on him. He's not stupid."

He had attended the very sporty Forest School in Snaresbrook, accumulating 10 O levels and three A levels (ropey grades, he says modestly), as well as a mountain of runs. fields.bodyText: Nasser Hussain was not happy. He looked at the umpire who had just given him out leg-before wicket with dismay and paused for a moment, reluctant to leave the crease, before tucking his bat under his arm and stalking off towards the pavilion, his body language speaking eloquently of his disbelief. We were warned not to approach him for half an hour. He was still in a foul temper when we finally made contact and he was initially unwilling to pose for photographs. But he relented and eventually apologised for being "in a mood". "My whole day today has been geared towards getting runs for Essex. You get a bad decision and your day has gone. It pisses you off but you have to get on with it." In a way it is a compliment to Hussain, the England cricket captain, that a week before the first Test he is so worked up about getting out in a second division county championship match between Essex and Nottinghamshire in front of a couple of hundred diehards at sleepy Chelmsford. Hussain's urge to score runs and to succeed, the steely competitiveness that characterises his game, is apparent whatever the arena; it is why he was chosen as captain and why cricket followers believe he has what it takes to lift cricket out of the doldrums. The game in England is facing unprecedented challenges. The Test team had a dismal record in the 90s, and Hussain took over last year when Alec Stewart was sacked after England's humiliating exit in the first round of the world cup. The overall quality of the game has also come under attack from critics who say there are too many full-time players performing at a mediocre level that is a world away from the rigours of international cricket. Peaceful days in the sun at Worcester or Guildford, it is argued, have no place in our fiercely competitive global age. English cricketing failure in the 90s, sitting starkly beside the rapid rise of Premiership soccer, left the sport looking feeble: it has struggled for media attention, is having trouble attracting sponsors, and currently lacks players with the punch of Ian Botham or the panache of David Gower. England had limited success for much of the 80s too, and were routinely annihilated by the all-conquering West Indians, but with Botham, Gower, Lamb and Gooch, it was possible to lose with elan, to feel pride in defeat. The 90s were just drab and pitiful. The threat now is that soccer will change its calendar and, in line with a Fifa initiative, be played from February until November. If football changes its season, our traditional summer sport would be in danger of being dismissed. All of which demands that the 32-year-old Hussain, as well as being England's captain and key batsman, should also be the miracle worker who remakes cricket for the modern age. Part of that miracle has to be cultural, and Hussain - who has an Indian father and an English mother and was born in Madras - is uniquely placed to work it. Cricket in England has been emasculated by class and deference; strangled by the old school tie. Captains were supposed to be pukka gents like Peter May or no-nonsense northern types like Raymond Illingworth (Botham and Mike Gatting were earthy - and short-lived - exceptions). The game itself has been locked in some Majorite dream-world of village greens, public schools and hearty parsons: no wonder soccer, adapting its class base and connecting the media and sport, pop and Posh, has been making all the running. When Hussain became England captain last June, his former team-mate at Essex, Derek Pringle, now cricket correspondent of the Independent, wrote of the change - both practical and symbolic - that his appointment would make. "Hussain is a shrewd, passionate cricketer whose desire to succeed is just what English cricket needs, as it looks to step into the new millennium. Rumours emanating from HQ were that the occasional bout of temper made him something of a liability in the genteel world of Victorian mores by which the game in this country still judges itself. Yet like it or not, he is very much a product of modern Britain, and as such should not be precluded from shaping its future." "He is a good choice as captain and a very important figure," says Rob Steen, editor of The New Ball, which showcases new cricket writing. "He should have been blooded earlier, but the selectors were scared of him. He had said in one interview that we had to get nastier and the establishment hated that. He represents a break with the past, and making him captain was as significant as making Len Hutton the first professional captain in the 50s. He's not from the usual background; he's from a talented Anglo-Indian family who love the game." Mihir Bose, author of The Sporting Alien, says Hussain is very different from other Indians and Anglo-Indians who have played in English cricket. "There is a long tradition of Indians playing in English cricket, but they tended to be from the gentlemanly or princely class and above the battle," says Bose. "In the early part of his career, Nasser made a point of being different - he was bolshie, a streetfighter. He is very much a product of the late 20th century and his captaincy marks a change in cricket. I don't know whether it is conscious or not, but there appears to be a desire to be more populist. He is certainly more populist - like a character from Men Behaving Badly - and aware of modern susceptibilities and of his dual identity." Cricket has always been central to Hussain's life. He was born in Madras in 1968 to an Indian father, the cricket-playing Jawad (anglicised to Joe), and an English mother, Shireen. They had met when Joe, who had an electronics business in India, was visiting the UK. His two older brothers, Mel and Abbas, were fine cricketers, and Nasser's early years were spent on the boundary's edge at the Chepauk stadium in Madras watching his father play and having members of visiting Test teams bowl underarm to him. Nasser, who was very small as a boy, was an excellent leg-spin bowler, but Mel was reckoned to be the more promising player ("10 times better than Nasser at the same age," according to their father). Ironically, Mel went on to play a few seasons for Hampshire, while Nasser scaled the heights of international cricket. "I've been fortunate because I came in at rock bottom," he says. "We were out of the world cup, our Test results hadn't been great, and everyone was thinking that anything from here was a bonus. Everyone was expecting us to lose four- or five-nil in South Africa, and we didn't so people view it as a success, but I personally don't because we lost the Test series. There's been a lot of praise heaped on me, but the two series I've been in charge we've lost. "The only thing that will lift English cricket is winning, and people seeing us doing well and enjoying it. We should beat Zimbabwe and, if we play like we can, we should beat West Indies. But Zimbabwe like to prove a point and West Indies are still dangerous ." The real test, though, comes next summer when England play Australia for the Ashes, the series which will define the success or failure of Hussain's tenure as captain. "He likes the way the Australians play cricket but he believes we have the talent to take them on," says Joe Hussain. "His biggest ambition in life is to beat them." If he succeeds, Hussain will have given English cricket its biggest boost since Ian Botham's heroics at Headingley in 1981, the future will look incomparably brighter, and the sport's rebellious son will have become its saviour.

webTitle: Weak euro blamed on excessive protection

fields.headline: Weak euro blamed on excessive protection
fields.standfirst:
ECB's top economist calls for Thatcherite market reforms

Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: The European Central Bank's most senior economist yesterday called for a radical programme of US-style deregulation and liberalisation to bolster the performance of the euro zone and its ailing single currency.
fields.byline: Andrew Osborn  in Brussels and  Charlotte Denny
fields.body:
The European Central Bank's most senior economist yesterday called for a radical programme of US-style deregulation and liberalisation to bolster the performance of the euro zone and its ailing single currency.

In a speech delivered on his behalf in Brussels, Professor Otmar Issing lashed out at inflexible rules which hamstring Europe's economy and came down firmly in favour of a neo-liberal, almost Thatcherite approach to economic management.

Many analysts blame the perception that European policymakers are dragging their feet over economic reform for the euro's 18-month slide on the foreign exchanges.

Much of his criticism, although he did not say so directly, seemed to be aimed at France where the government has reduced the working week to 35 hours despite opposition from business.

Professor Issing railed against "the adverse impacts of minimum wage and employment protection legislation" and called for a "comprehensive programme of structural reform".

He argued that the role of national governments in running Europe's economy needs to be reduced, taxes lowered and labour markets made more flexible.

Several structural rigidities are, he added, holding Europe back and the regulatory environment is "much less favourable to entrepreneurial activity than in the case of the US".

"The key to improving the growth performance of the euro area lies in the field of structural reform in goods, and particularly, in labour markets." Financial markets in Europe were also not as well equipped as their American counterparts to raise risk capital for new businesses.

Although Prof Issing said US economic performance had been remarkable he also suggested luck may have been a factor behind the record breaking nine-year American expansion.

Weak oil and commodity prices and a strong dollar throughout the 1990s were, he said, a fortuitous combination.

Prof Issing suggested that the European economy could repeat the US economic miracle if policymakers were prepared to undertake the necessary structural reforms.

The ECB's role was to pursue a medium-term monetary policy oriented towards price stability and not take any radical risks.

"Central bank credibility can only be built up over a period of time on the basis of a proven record of stability-orientated policies. Once lost, the reputation of a new central bank such as the ECB, without an established track record of its own, is in no position to take such risks."

Prof Issing's remarks were taken by the markets as a sign that the ECB is in hawkish mood. The euro rallied through 91 cents on the back of his comments .

According to Michael Metcalfe, currency analyst at NatWest GFM, Issing's suggestion that the euro system's monetary policy "would no way be an impediment to faster growth", was widely interpreted as an indication that he regards policy still to be accommodative.

"It looks suspiciously like central-bank speak for 'we think monetary policy is still too easy'," Mr Metcalfe said.

webTitle: Cyprus hosts rise and fall of Miss Aphrodite

fields.headline: Cyprus hosts rise and fall of Miss Aphrodite
fields.standfirst: Beauty pageant sparks heated church protest but leaves public cold
fields.trailText: Beauty pageant sparks heated church protest but leaves public cold
fields.body:
For all its efforts to reinvent itself as a modern, non-sexist, event, Miss Universe has run into trouble again: this time in the form of Orthodox priests protesting against the "pernicious" pageant being held in Cyprus - the island that has long prided itself as the birthplace of Aphrodite, the world's first beauty queen.

Last night, as 79 delegates competed for the new millennium's first Miss Universe crown, strutting before judges in bikinis and ballgowns, the church was doing what it does best - leading its flock in prayer.

At an all-night vigil timed to coincide with the contest's 4am finale (for the benefit of viewers across the Atlantic), the church admonished the contest for its "evil, soul-destroying ways".

Miss Universe, the conservative Greek Orthodox church says, is the sort of thing that demeans women, destroys marriages and, in seeking "to satisfy the pleasure of the senses", encourages drug-taking, Aids and sexual crime.

Even worse, protesters argue, the event is being held in Nicosia's main sports stadium, within walking distance of an ancient orthodox monastery dedicated to the Holy Virgin and All-Innocent Mother of Our Saviour.

"When we believe something is very wrong we react with a vigil and prayer," said Father Marios of the synod, the church's governing board.

What, he asked, are innocent villagers meant to think when they see girls with legs up to their armpits parading in a state of semi-dress?

"How can an island that has been partitioned by war, that has missing people and mothers who cry themselves to sleep, so happily promote half-naked women?

"It is a schizophrenic state of affairs and an affront to Christianity."

Affront or not, the Greek Cypriot government has poured nearly £5m of taxpayers' money into the pageant. For the past three weeks the delegates have been wined and dined across the former British colony.

Miss Universe 2000 is the 49th beauty contest to be held since it was first held a year after the British invented the Miss World title in 1951.

Three thousand years after Aphrodite, the goddess of love, rose "out of the soft, sea foam", according to Homer, officials had hoped the "event of the new millennium" would lure visitors to the tourist-dependent island.

"This is something we have been striving to do for years," said the island's commerce and tourism minister, Nicos Rolandis, who married a former Cypriot beauty queen.

"Who said anything about culture? This is not culture. This is entertainment, pure and simple."

Not everyone on Cyprus would agree. For all of its "gawp value", the visual feast has left most Cypriots cold. Last week's preliminary pageant was held in a half-empty stadium.

For the finale - beamed via the US to more than 120 countries - the organisers have been forced to slash ticket prices by more than 60%.

"It's been a case of overkill," said one Cypriot male. "You turn on the television and these girls just seem to be everywhere."

In the five years since the US tycoon Donald Trump bought the company, Miss Universe has, like other pageants, been increasingly derided, even by the delegates.

Even by the controversial standards of Miss Universe, this year's event has been problematic.

The Cyprus government caused consternation in Paris by demanding that the Louvre lend the island the Venus de Milo statue, the quintessential Aphrodite, for the duration of the show.

Once the contestants arrived nerves were frayed further when Turkey announced that it would not be sending a delegate to the island it invaded in 1974, and China fumed over a competitor who presented herself as "Miss Taiwan".

For the Orthodox church the fall-out is proof that the government is already paying for its sins.

webTitle: They put my kids on the cheapest bus

fields.headline: They put my kids on the cheapest bus
fields.standfirst:
The transport guidelines for schools put our children at risk

Transport in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: On the first day of the public inquiry into the Paddington rail disaster, a relative of one of the dead complained that Britain presented itself as a leading industrial nation but had the transport policy of a trailing industrial nation. Whether or not the inquiry eventually nods in agreement, I did.
fields.body:
On the first day of the public inquiry into the Paddington rail disaster, a relative of one of the dead complained that Britain presented itself as a leading industrial nation but had the transport policy of a trailing industrial nation. Whether or not the inquiry eventually nods in agreement, I did.

My children attend a school in Northamptonshire. They used a bus provided by the county. The vehicle would never have done service as Tony Blair's campaign battle bus but had seat-belts and an adult escort and a driver who understood that a cargo of children (some as young as four) involved more responsibilities than transporting shoppers. Recently (when the company which provides the vehicles gave up the contract) rival bids were, in the modern way of things, invited. A tender from Stagecoach United Counties - believed to be the lowest - was accepted.

On the first day of the new service, the children sat down and found themselves doing a mime long before they got to their dance and drama lesson. Their hands flapped out the pretence of tying an imaginary seat-belt. They might in other circumstances have asked their escort for guidance but she had left at Easter and the county had been unable to replace her. It would be wrong, however, to say that no adult assistance was at hand. They could have asked for help from any of the complete strangers who got on and sat beside them. For the route had been turned into a public service which is apparently another way of defraying the costs of a school bus.

By the next day, the public had the school bus pretty much to themselves. There were letters to the county council, phone calls to the relevant MP, petitions, photos in the local paper. The anger of the parents was reduced by the assumption that this must be some bureaucratic blunder. In an educational culture in which children are regularly sent home with leaflets about sunblock and nutrition and the numbers of various helplines, it seemed unlikely that their daily journey to school could contain so much danger. We were wrong. Although letters and phone calls continue, it is apparently the case that there is no legal requirement for children on school buses to be restrained, accompanied or self-contained.

And yet, strangely, the Department for Education recently sent guidance to headteachers on the "Health and safety of pupils on educational visits". This document - relating to the occasional outing to museums or theme parks - requires a school to complete a risk assessment form before heading for the Millennium Dome or the British Museum. Page 23, paragraph 126 states: "All minibuses and coaches which carry groups of three or more children aged between three and 15 years inclusive must be fitted with a seat-belt for each child. The seats must face forward and seat restraints must comply with legal requirements." A later clause warns that the driver of this vehicle can not be solely responsible for the safety of the passengers. Separate advice suggests that adults who accompany pupils on such ventures should be prepared to have their name checked against paedophile registers and police records.

You can understand how this disparity - high-security annual outings, low-security daily journeys - happened. Pupils on treat trips are being driven much longer distances and frequently on motorways. But local roads are not necessarily safe. A long and winding stretch towards my children's school is not on the council's list for winter gritting.

And there are other paradoxes which are incomprehensible. If, in the cars we now use to transport the children while boycotting the bus, we failed to use seat-belts, we would be breaking the law. And imagine the reaction of the driver of a public bus service if a four-year-old got on unaccompanied at a stop. And yet the reverses of these situations are apparently legal.

The logic of this position would be hilarious if so many potential tears did not lie at the end of the road. The education authorities are determined to minimise the risk of any child being molested, abducted or hurled through a windscreen while on an educational visit - presumably because these would interrupt an annual treat. Yet during their up to 10 potential weekly visits to and from their education, these risks must not be assessed.

Although this policy is made locally, it is apparently permitted by Department for Education guidelines. Yet given that no parents with access to a car could accept these arrangements, the result of this small saving on the transport budget is to force dozens more cars into the already cruelly polluting school run. The provision of vehicles for schoolchildren is historically an emotive subject; this example from Middle England is bussing as muddle and fudge. No local politician actually intends the consequences which might result and any wreaths sent in that eventuality would be quite sincere. But the danger of applying competitive tender to areas in which lives are at stake is a more general lesson for politicians.

Northamptonshire council still insists all this is normal but we are not listening. Belt up, as Sir Jimmy Savile used to say in those advertisements. Belt up.

fields.headline: Inquiry into slap by teacher
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The Department for Education is investigating the circumstances that led to a teacher receiving a formal police caution for common assault after she allegedly slapped a pupil for a mistake during a Welsh lesson.
fields.body:
The Department for Education is investigating the circumstances that led to a teacher receiving a formal police caution for common assault after she allegedly slapped a pupil for a mistake during a Welsh lesson.

James Parry, 13, claims he was slapped across the face because he pronounced a sentence wrongly at Syr Thomas Jones comprehensive school at Amlwch, Anglesey, in January.

The teacher is also said to have poked him on the chest while making him say the sentence correctly five times.

Anglesey education authority confirmed yesterday that details of the alleged incident and the caution had been forwarded to officials at the Department for Education.

The teacher is understood to have been cautioned by police last month following a complaint by the boy's family.

James's mother, Samantha Parry, who works as a lunchtime supervisor at the school has met the teacher, Linda Jones, and the school's headteacher but is refusing to accept a personal apology. "The teacher should be sacked," Mrs Parry said last night.

Anglesey education authority said that it was waiting to hear from the DfEE before deciding on any disciplinary measures.

webTitle: Teachers' sick leave adds up to 2.5m days lost

fields.headline: Teachers' sick leave adds up to 2.5m days lost
fields.trailText: More than half the teachers in England took sick leave last year at an estimated overall cost of £300m to the public purse, official figures released yesterday show.
fields.body:
More than half the teachers in England took sick leave last year at an estimated overall cost of £300m to the public purse, official figures released yesterday show.

Over 2.5m working days were lost. The average teacher took nine days off, according to a survey by the education department.

The schools minister, Estelle Morris, yesterday issued new guidance on occupational health for teachers, designed to help reach the target set by the education secretary, David Blunkett, of a 30% fall in teachers' sick leave by 2002.

The 55% of teachers taking sick leave comprises 60% of full-time teachers and 35% of part-timers. Of those, 44% were absences of 20 days or more.

But the average of nine days per year is the same as for employees in firms of 500 or more, according to the CBI.

fields.headline: Schoolgirls attack PE coaches
fields.trailText: Two teachers were recovering yesterday after they were attacked by a gang of girls.
fields.body:
Two teachers were recovering yesterday after they were attacked by a gang of girls.

The PE teachers, both women, were punched and kicked and had clumps of hair pulled out during the assault at Salendine Nook high school in Huddersfield, West Yorkshire, on Wednesday.

The five girls, aged between 15 and 16, who attend nearby Royds Hall high school, roamed on to Salendine Nook's playing fields during an athletics practice. The two teachers asked them to leave when they began wandering in front of the javelins.

But the teachers were met by a torrent of abuse and one of the girls picked up a javelin and threatened to throw it at one of the women. When the teachers repeated their request for the girls to leave they were attacked.

Christine Spencer, headteacher at the 1,400-pupil Salendine Nook school, said she was extremely upset about the attack.

It is understood that the girls involved have been suspended by their school. No one was available for comment at Royds Hall.

A West Yorkshire police spokeswoman said last night a 15-year-old girl had been arrested in connection with the assault and released on bail.
Press Association

fields.headline: Girl, 15, runs away with teacher
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Police are searching for a schoolgirl aged 15 who went missing with her maths teacher.
fields.body:
Police are searching for a schoolgirl aged 15 who went missing with her maths teacher.

The girl, who has not been named, disappeared on Monday with Micha Gray, head of year 11 at Leftwich high school in Northwich, Cheshire.

It is thought the couple may be heading for Germany, where Mr Gray has relatives.

The police were called in by her parents when she did not return home from school.

It emerged that the girl had told friends that she had been having a relationship with Mr Gray, 28, who is divorced.

The girl, described as quiet, well-behaved and popular, was last seen shortly after school registration on Monday. Mr Gray did not turn up for school that day.

The teenager has twice contacted her parents from France to let them know that she is safe and well, but the police still want to speak with her.

A spokesman for the Cheshire education authority said: "We are aware that a 15-year-old girl has been reported missing and the matter is being investigated by police. Her family and friends are going through anguish, and we can only hope for a safe and early return."

webTitle: A hot dog please. Oh, and $90m

fields.headline: A hot dog please. Oh, and $90m
fields.trailText: A swimming pool installer who paid for a hot dog with a $100 bill and spent the change on 98 lottery tickets stepped forward yesterday to claim his half of a record-breaking $363m (£237m) jackpot.
fields.body:
A swimming pool installer who paid for a hot dog with a $100 bill and spent the change on 98 lottery tickets stepped forward yesterday to claim his half of a record-breaking $363m (£237m) jackpot.

"I guess I'd like to start a new job playing golf," said Larry Ross, a 47-year-old occasional lottery player accustomed to working 80 to 100 hours a week in the summer. "We haven't had a summer vacation in 13 years."

Mr Ross and his wife, Nancy, will take their share of the bounty in a one-time payment of about $90m before tax. They could have elected to take the full $181.5m in 26 annual installments.

The $363m Big Game jackpot was the richest in US history, but the biggest individual payout is still the $197m awarded last year to a Massachusetts woman.

Mr Ross bought his ticket to Tuesday's draw at Mr K's Party Shoppe near Utica, 20 miles north of Detroit. He had stopped to buy a hot dog, and all he had was a $100 bill. At his wife's urging, "I asked the guy to give me change in lotto tickets," he said.

Mr Ross said he wrote down the winning numbers incorrectly on Tuesday night and didn't realise one of his computer-selected tickets was a winner until he saw it on television the next morning.

Now he is looking to retire and buy a boat, a house and maybe that purple Jaguar his wife has always wanted.

webTitle: Minister joins row on waste plant

fields.headline: Minister joins row on waste plant
fields.trailText: The row over government plans to increase incinerator capacity in Britain took a new turn yesterday when a cabinet minister sought assurances over the safety of an "energy from waste" plant in his constituency.
fields.body:
The row over government plans to increase incinerator capacity in Britain took a new turn yesterday when a cabinet minister sought assurances over the safety of an "energy from waste" plant in his constituency.

Nick Brown, the agriculture minister, has demanded assurances from the environment agency, Newcastle upon Tyne council and the local health authority that the Byker waste plant poses no public health risk.

His intervention yesterday came after Newcastle council ordered the removal of 2,000 tonnes of poisoned ash, which has been found to have high levels of mercury, cadmium and lead, from footpaths and allotments. It ruled that no children under the age of two should play in the 27 affected allotments.

The waste plant is already the centre of controversy as its operator wants to double its capacity. The plan includes burning tyres which are known to include heavy pollutants.

Mr Brown wrote to all three authorities saying: "Can I have your view as to whether the operations carried out at the plant pose a real threat to human health?"

His intervention comes as the government delayed publishing its national waste strategy after Downing Street intervened in the controversy over landfill tax scams revealed by the Guardian and Channel 4's Dispatches.

webTitle: Brothers win damages for killings claim

fields.headline: Brothers win damages for killings claim
fields.trailText: Two brothers from Northern Ireland have won more than £600,000 damages after a book published in the US claimed they were part of a committee which ordered political assassinations in the province.
fields.body:
Two brothers from Northern Ireland have won more than £600,000 damages after a book published in the US claimed they were part of a committee which ordered political assassinations in the province.

David and Albert Prentice won the settlement following a lawsuit taken out in Washington. Damages are thought to be around $1m (£630,000).

They brought the case against journalist Sean McPhileny and Roberts Rhinhart, publishers of the book The committee: political assassinations in Northern Ireland. Mr McPhileny and Roberts Rhinehart said in a statement they accepted that the Prentice brothers had not been involved in the activities described in the book.

"Sean McPhileny and Roberts Rhinehart sincerely regret the embarrassment and offence caused to Albert and David Prentice by the books."

A spokesman for the brothers said they were delighted at the settlement and that their name had been cleared from the "ludicrous allegations in the book".

Their US lawyer, Bill Taylor, also welcomed the settlement. "We are very happy with the amount of damages."

The book was on sale in the US, but not in Britain.

fields.headline: Strawberry Fields loses its gates
fields.trailText: The gates immortalised in the Beatles song Strawberry Fields, written by John Lennon and inspired by his childhood listening to the Salvation Army band playing at a children's home, have been stolen in a daylight theft.
fields.body:
The gates immortalised in the Beatles song Strawberry Fields, written by John Lennon and inspired by his childhood listening to the Salvation Army band playing at a children's home, have been stolen in a daylight theft.

The gates at the entrance to the Strawberry Fields children's home in Liverpool were surrounded by grafitti scrawled by Beatles fans on the gateposts.

Shortly before lunch yesterday two men armed with saws pulled up in a blue Transit van. They hacked through the 10ft square gates and hauled them into the van before driving off.

Edwina Willis, a Beatles tour guide in Liverpool, said she could not believe that the gates had been stolen. "The gates are known the world over," she said. "They are absolutely unique and we want them back. We have people on tours who are on pilgrimages to the city.

"They do not know some of these locations in the songs actually exist and so when they see places like Strawberry Fields they break down and cry."

Paul McCartney's brother Mike said: "This is awful - I hope these people's conscience gets the better of them and they put them back."

fields.headline: Digital TV adopts sign language
fields.trailText: Once confined to regional news programmes, sign language for deaf television viewers will soon be screened on game shows, dramas, and even ad breaks.
fields.body:
Once confined to regional news programmes, sign language for deaf television viewers will soon be screened on game shows, dramas, and even ad breaks.

From Monday, minimum standards for sign language interpretation come into force for digital TV services, and the government is being lobbied to extend quotas to cover advertisements as well as the programmes.

One firm claiming to provide innovative ways of making the "signer" less intrusive for non-deaf viewers said yesterday that it was close to a deal with a "major international conglomerate" to sign its advertisements.

The new signing will be also be more sophisticated. In a trial advert for the cat food Go-Kat, for instance, when the cat jumps over the screen, the signer ducks to avoid him. And signers in, for example, car ads would be as glamorous as the products they promote.

Introduction of the targets had been delayed as broadcasters attempted to find a way of displaying the signer only to those viewers who wanted to watch the service, it was explained. However, that proved too complicated.

Sylvia Sheridan, chief executive of Independent Media Support, a company specialising in subtitling and signing of programmes and ads, said that developments in signing technique would make the rules more palatable for the majority while providing a valuable service for deaf consumers.

"I told one client, BSkyB, that if we had an Ulrika Jonsson signer in a wet T-shirt, I'm sure that wouldn't turn people off. Obviously we are not going down that route, but I think they took the point."

From next week, 10% of programmes on digital terrestrial television channels must be subtitled, 1% must be signed, and 2% must be audio described. Audio description technology is in its infancy, but blind viewers who sign up for the relevant equipment hear the on-screen action described to them.

These limits will increase considerably over the next few years.

webTitle: Police rewrote 'confession' of accountant wrongly jailed

fields.headline: Police rewrote 'confession' of accountant wrongly jailed
fields.trailText: An accountant who was convicted of prejudicing a police investigation has had his conviction quashed by the court of appeal after it was ruled that part of his confession had been rewritten by a police officer.
fields.body:
An accountant who was convicted of prejudicing a police investigation has had his conviction quashed by the court of appeal after it was ruled that part of his confession had been rewritten by a police officer.

Mohammed Yusef Patel was sentenced to four years at Snaresbrook crown court in 1987 for allegedly prejudicing an international drugs investigation. He served 28 months in prison before being released in April 1990.

But yesterday, 13 years after his original conviction, the court of appeal ruled that it was unsafe. Lord Justice Pill said that in the light of fresh evidence there was no substantial basis to support the main allegation against him.

After hearing that his con viction had been quashed, the 44-year-old former Muslim Commercial Bank accountant said he would be seeking compensation. He said no amount of money could make up for the damage caused to his life during 13 "devastating" years.

"This is total vindication for me," he said. "I had 13 years of pain and anguish. It ruined my life. But this is very good news for me and my family."

Mr Patel, who is now on medication for stress, said he would be seeking damages against the Metropolitan police. He said that since he was released from prison he had been unable to re-build his life.

"I am now very forgetful and unable to work. I will never be the same person again."

His problems began in 1987 when he visited the house of a client, Ramjamadi Mo hammed Ali. Police were raiding Ali's house at the time and discovered 5kg of heroin.

Mr Patel insisted that he knew nothing about the drugs but the police issued an order banning him from communicating with a number of his clients in Portugal who were under suspicion of international drug trafficking.

The prosecution claimed he had compromised the case by contacting those clients.

Ali was sentenced to 16 years in prison for the possession of £1m of heroin with intent to supply.

Mr Patel, from Stamford Hill, north London, always maintained his innocence. Yesterday the court of appeal heard that scientific analysis of an alleged confession statement showed that part of it had been re-written.

webTitle: Rescued Britons relive ordeal in the bush

fields.headline: Rescued Britons relive ordeal in the bush
fields.standfirst: Villagers risked their lives to help exhausted soldiers to safety
fields.trailText: Villagers in a rebel-held area of Sierra Leone risked their lives to save a group of British soldiers who were so exhausted from days in the bush that they were hallucinating and barely able to walk. The men were fleeing the clutches of the Revolutionary United Front (RUF).
fields.body:
Villagers in a rebel-held area of Sierra Leone risked their lives to save a group of British soldiers who were so exhausted from days in the bush that they were hallucinating and barely able to walk. The men were fleeing the clutches of the Revolutionary United Front (RUF).

"If it hadn't been for them, we'd still be there now," said Major Phil Ashby, 30, a Royal Marines commando. "We were averaging less than a kilometre a day. Our bodies were physically degrading. We can't thank them highly enough because of the risk they took for us. We had political value as hostages but they would have been shot at best, or something worse, if we had been caught."

The four men - three British officers, including a nuclear scientist, and a New Zealand major - were operating as unarmed UN observers in Makeni, the rebel headquarters, where they shared a compound with more than 100 Kenyan peacekeepers.

Trouble started a fortnight ago after a group of RUF fighters surrendered their weapons at the UN demobilisation camp in Makeni. Rebel commanders called the men deserters and demanded that they be handed over. The British observers suspected a ploy to create a confrontation.

The UN compound was surrounded by about 2,000 rebels armed with grenades and mortars. Three people were killed as the Kenyans resisted an RUF assault, but the rebels' rhetoric was mostly directed at the British soldiers.

"The RUF are quite good in psychological warfare, in scaring people into either running away or disarming," Maj Ashby said. "Rebels would regularly come up to the gate wearing UN uniforms."

He quoted one as saying: "I have just killed the man who was wearing this uniform. In 15 minutes, I am coming back to do the same to you."

With no means to defend themselves, Maj Ashby and his colleagues - fellow Britons Lieutenant-Commander Paul Rowland and Major Andrew Samsonoff, and Major David Linguard from New Zealand - opted to break out at the weekend. Using an old map they plotted a 50-mile route to safety.

Maj Ashby, a six-footer with cropped fair hair, persuaded the Kenyans to provide covering fire if the escapees were spotted by the RUF.

"In the middle of the night we jumped over the wall, which sounds easy but in practice when you can hear your heart beating and every noise seems to echo and go round and round, the time seems to go on for an eternity. You feel very naked, very exposed," he said.

The men set off at a "panicky sprint" until Maj Ashby ran into a barbed wire fence. The group walked through the night and at first light hid in thick bush.

"It was a good position, not near any paths. However, after daybreak we found we were only 30 metres from a mango tree. It is now the mango season and throughout the day there were people getting mangos from the tree which meant we could afford no movement. We had to lie in the sun all day with no water," he said.

When no one was near the mango tree, they listened to Chelsea lose to Arsenal on the BBC World Service. It ruined Maj Ashby's day.

The group moved deeper into the bush, hacking their way through thick vegetation while trying not to draw attention to themselves. The going was slow. They had only one loaf of bread each, and a tin of baked beans between four of them. But after two days and nights on the move it was lack of sleep and water that took the worst toll.

"We stopped that night when the hallucinations became more regular than the gaps between," the major said. "We were forced to drink from a stagnant pond that had more organic matter than water. It was just enough in the short term to have more benefit than negative effect."

Maj Ashby was carrying a satellite telephone. He had used it to alert the UN to their escape and decided to call for a rescue team, but the battery was flat. The major had used the phone as a pillow and accidentally turned it on until the power was exhausted.

"We considered that if we kept moving at night, assuming everyone was a potential RUF soldier, we would still be there in a year. We took a decision that we would approach the locals," he said. "We got to a village where someone spoke English. The whole village was incredibly helpful. It was hardly surprising. There was no love lost because the only thing the RUF had done was burn, rape, loot and kill most of the young men. They are not keen on the RUF but they will not attack them."

The villagers provided a guide to lead the men to safety at considerable risk. If the RUF found out, the village chief - and quite possibly everyone else - would have been killed.

With a young man who knew the terrain the soldiers moved fast, refilling water bottles at villages along the way. Within a day they crossed into friendly territory and the protection of the Kamajor pro-government militia.

"We were pampered and treated like kings, fed and given flip-flops. It was a huge relief. We were psychologically and physically protected by a bunch of menacing looking guys," he said.

A courier with a bicycle was found to carry a note and Maj Ashby's dog tag to the nearest UN post several hours away. Eventually an SAS unit arrived by Land Rover, and a helicopter airlifted the four soldiers out.

A couple of days later, the Kenyan peacekeepers fought their way out of the Makeni compound and made it to Freetown, but not without "significant casualties".

Maj Ashby must wait to show his gratitude to his saviours. The village remains in RUF hands.

webTitle: Annan disparages UN efforts in Sierra Leone

fields.headline: Annan disparages UN efforts in Sierra Leone
fields.trailText: The UN secretary general, Kofi Annan, yesterday damned his peacekeeping force in Sierra Leone as "badly trained and badly equipped".
fields.byline: Michael Ellison  in New York and Ewen MacAskill
fields.body:
The UN secretary general, Kofi Annan, yesterday damned his peacekeeping force in Sierra Leone as "badly trained and badly equipped".

Mr Annan, who is desperate to make a success of UN intervention, said: "Obviously I am disappointed, very disappointed. I'm not alone in this. Anyone who believes, or says they believe, in multilateral affairs must be disappointed."

The criticism added to a growing sense of confusion at UN headquarters. There was debate about whether the UN mandate should be toughened up. But some of the countries involved, such as India, were reluctant, concerned about the safety of their troops.

The UN force of almost 9,000 has suffered a series of humiliations in Sierra Leone over the last fortnight. Around 500 of its troops are being detained by rebel forces.

Mr Annan protested: "You know that countries which supplied us with soldiers were supposed to equip them fully and train them well. That was not entirely the case here. Some soldiers arrived without even a uniform."

Some peacekeepers had inadequate communications equipment and some even had the wrong maps.

The UN force has yet to reach its full strength of 11,000. A Jordanian contingent arrived yesterday and battalions from India and Bangladesh are due in the next few days.

The Jordanians, Indians and Bangladeshis are regarded as serious soldiers by western diplomats who are privately scathing about the standards of training and equipment of the Zambians, Guineans and other nationalities serving with the UN force.

Mr Annan told a meeting of the security council: "Let us not fail Sierra Leone. Let us not fail Africa. This time, in this crisis, let us back words with deeds and mandates with the resources that work."

fields.headline: She's the big one
fields.standfirst:
The Queen has proved herself indestructible by concentrating on what she does best

The future of the monarchy: special report
fields.trailText: Well, who would have thought it? Three years ago, the idea that it would be the Queen opening the Tate Modern and exchanging a few regal pleasantries with Bridget Riley would have seemed incredible, even illogical. The fusty old Queen turn up in her fruit-gum green outfit to cut the ribbon at the temple of the new Britain? All the high priests of Cool Britannia pay homage to royalty? Not a chance.
