fields.headline: From alternative origins
fields.standfirst: Boots
fields.trailText: John Boot, the founder of what is now Boots the Chemist, died an exhausted man at the age of 45. His herbal medicine business had no cure for overwork.
fields.body:
John Boot, the founder of what is now Boots the Chemist, died an exhausted man at the age of 45. His herbal medicine business had no cure for overwork.

He was an unlikely businessman, who combined trade with a religious zeal to improve the living standards and social conditions of the poor.

He was all too well aware of how hard life could be for those at the bottom of the social ladder.

He was born in 1815 - the year of Waterloo -and spent his early years as a farm labourer, travelling into Nottingham for services at the Weslyan chapels before moving into the city to live in one of its poorest areas.

Drawn into community life, he started a shop in 1849 to provide herbal medicines for those too poor to afford a doctor. It went by the grand title of the British and American Botanic Establishment.

The business got off the ground with the financial support of his father in law and local Methodists, and the herbal expertise of his mother.

Boots today probably dispenses more prescriptions for modern medicines than any other company in the UK. But its roots were firmly based in alternative medicines.

When John died in 1860, his wife took over the running of the business, helped by Jesse, their son, aged 10.

Jesse was to become the driving force which turned one shop into a national business. Initially he opened other shops in run-down areas of the city, and upset rivals by cutting costs and advertising widely.

He improved what the modern businessman would call cash flow by asking for cash rather than offering credit. He also outflanked rivals who criticised his remedies by employing his own qualified pharmacist in 1884.

Five years' later, Jesse took a holiday in Jersey where he met Florence Rowe, a bookseller 's daughter. After they married, Florence's influence on the business soon became evident as its product range was expanded to cover books, stationery, and artists' materials.

Florence was behind the launch of the Boots subscription library which was to last until 1965. She was also credited with introducing stylish cafes into larger stores to attract middle class shopper.

Her husband continued to expand manufacturing - to keep control of quality and margins.

The factories were used during both world wars to make everything from sterlizers to gas masks. During the 1939-45 conflict they produced the equivalent in saccharin of 731,000 tons of sugar.

In 1920, Jesse, plagued by arthritis and anticipating tough times ahead, sold his company to Louis Liggett, head a large US pharmaceutical company, for £2.25m. His son John continued to work for the company.

Liggett's company went bust during the 1929 Depression, and Boots was sold to a group of British financiers for £6m. John Boot emerged as chairman and managing director.

During the 1930s Boots expanded into horticultural and veterinary products and launched its No7 cosmetics range in distinctive art deco packaging.

In 1987 a new Boots label appeared, Boots Opticians. This has proved more successful than the group's foray into DIY through Do It All, which was sold off in 1998 after costing £400m over nine painful years.

The group also owns Halfords, the car and cycle parts and accessories business which is now expanding from the high street into a variety of new locations.

This week Boots announced its latest development: a pilot scheme of laser hair removal centres. A scheme that takes the company a long way from poverty and herbal medicines.

 Halfords.co.uk

webTitle: Raider ups stakes in Nabisco battle

fields.headline: Raider ups stakes in Nabisco battle
fields.trailText: Corporate raider Carl Icahn has upped the stakes in his fight for Nabisco, producers of Oreo biscuits and Ritz crackers, with regulatory filings in the US showing he has offered to pay $22 (£13) per share.
fields.body:
Corporate raider Carl Icahn has upped the stakes in his fight for Nabisco, producers of Oreo biscuits and Ritz crackers, with regulatory filings in the US showing he has offered to pay $22 (£13) per share.

Mr Icahn, who has been stalking the company, formerly known as RJR Nabisco, for several years, is thought to have pitched earlier deals in the region of $16 per share, valuing the company at $5.2bn.

His assault is on Nabisco Group Holdings, which owns 90% of the snack food maker Nabisco Holdings Corp, its only asset. Mr Icahn, who earned his status as a corporate raider during a series of battles in the 1980s, owns 9.6% of Nabisco Group Holdings, which put itself up for sale last month after he made an unwanted bid for company.

Nabisco is thought to have set a deadline of Monday for bids, which would explain the timing of yesterday's submission contained a filing to the securities and exchange commission in the US. The group has not confirmed that is has set a deadline for bidders.

One of the potential deterrents for bidders is the risk of tobacco litigants in the US against the RJ Reynolds tobacco group which Nabisco Group Holdings used to own.

According to the filings, Mr Icahn and his shareholder group, High River, would give shareholders $19 in cash and a two-year note with a principal amount of $3 for each Nabisco Group Holding shares.

News of the offer helped to buoy shares in both Nabisco companies on the New York stock exchange in early trading.

Meanwhile, the war for loyal customers among Britain's supermarkets took another twist yesterday when Tesco tried to lure any defections from Safeway with the promise of 250 points when they sign up for its loyalty card.

The move follows Safeway's decision to ditch its loyalty card in favour of a lower price promotion. Tesco said more than 65,000 customers had signed up for its Club Card since Safeway's decision last week. Sainsbury is also trying to win Safeway customers with deals on its loyalty card.

fields.headline: Lemsip and flu boost Reckitt
fields.trailText: Surging sales of Lemsip during the recent winter flu epidemic helped to put Reckitt Benckiser, the household products group, back on track, following its merger last year.
fields.body:
Surging sales of Lemsip during the recent winter flu epidemic helped to put Reckitt Benckiser, the household products group, back on track, following its merger last year.

The company's first quarter profits were up 20% to £67m, although this compared to a particularly lacklustre performance from Reckitt & Colman last year.

Chief executive Bart Becht declared that the figures vindicated his new strategy of concentrating investment on a smaller number of global brands.

He described the results as "a major credit to the new Reckitt Benckiser team as they were achieved despite the many issues and distractions associated with merging two companies".

Among the brands which did particularly well were Lemsip - which achieved a record market share - and the US disinfectant Lysol.

These benefited from a 10% increase in the group's spending on media advertising and promotions.

The merger has yielded savings of £11m so far, partly due to benefits from larger scale purchasing, although after the extra media investment, the contribution to profits was only £4m.

Mr Becht said he was confident of achieving the group's target of £38m savings this year.

Reckitt said other good performers included hair removal products, air fresheners and Resolve carpet cleaner.

New products being introduced include an insecticide spray which attracts flies and a controlled release dishwasher tablet that responds to the different stages in the wash cycle.

Analysts described the results as encouraging, but stressed that the company still had a lot to prove.

Mark Lynch of SBC Warburg said: "These were solid, reassuring numbers, while the company reaffirmed its targets for the year."

webTitle: We are right to be there

fields.headline: We are right to be there
fields.standfirst:
It is hazardous, but the British are needed

Sierra Leone: special report
Interactive: what is happening in Sierra Leone?
fields.trailText: First things first. The government was right to intervene militarily in Sierra Leone. The deployment of British troops has already helped stave off another UN peacekeeping disaster. It has been welcomed by the Sierra Leone government and its people, who want Britain to do even more, and by neighbouring West African states. The intervention followed stated Labour policy, as set out last January by foreign secretary Robin Cook: "When faced with an overwhelming humanitarian catastrophe and a government that has demonstrated itself unwilling or unable to prevent it, the international community should act."
fields.body:
First things first. The government was right to intervene militarily in Sierra Leone. The deployment of British troops has already helped stave off another UN peacekeeping disaster. It has been welcomed by the Sierra Leone government and its people, who want Britain to do even more, and by neighbouring West African states. The intervention followed stated Labour policy, as set out last January by foreign secretary Robin Cook: "When faced with an overwhelming humanitarian catastrophe and a government that has demonstrated itself unwilling or unable to prevent it, the international community should act."

The deployment serves Britain's national interest, in upholding the authority of the UN and democratic values. It fulfils Britain's responsibility as the former colonial power, largest aid donor, and joint mediator of last year's Sierra Leone peace accord. Most of all, the intervention is the duty owed by a wealthy and powerful nation to, in this case, one of the world's poorest countries. The hazardous nature of this undertaking is not in dispute. Nor is it, or can it, be clear how long and how deep Britain's involvement in such a chaotic situation will go: those demanding timetables and watertight guarantees understand neither war nor politics. It may ultimately cost blood as well as money. It may hurt. But it is the right thing to do.

Britain's action once again begs a much broader question - about the principle of intervention in the affairs of another state and "global governance" through the agency of the UN. These issues pose a problem for the political left with its visceral dislike of big, rich countries apparently telling smaller, weaker ones what to do. In Africa, this dilemma is exacerbated by the legacy of European colonisation and misrule. On the political right, UN intervention is opposed for ideological reasons. This tendency has gained fullest expression most recently in the US, where a conservative congress and a president who lacks strong convictions have often combined, as now, to give a distinctly disengaged flavour to American foreign policy.

Interventions like that in West Africa also raise issues of consistency which trouble people right across the political spectrum. If in Sierra Leone, then why not in Sri Lanka, another former British colony where an appalling civil war rages unchecked? Or Chechnya or Tibet? In the case of Sri Lanka, there is no obvious or satisfactory answer. When it comes to territory controlled by nuclear-armed states which also have UN security council vetoes, like Russia and China, brute political and military reality trumps any amount of humanitarian concern.

Intervention, both in theory and practice, is plainly an imperfect science. But progress is discernible. The self-serving opposition of Moscow and Beijing to any infringement of sovereign borders gives solace to a few undemocratic, renegade regimes, such as Serbia and Iraq. Increasingly, however, the principle of UN-approved intervention is accepted, as shown by the speech of Kofi Annan, the UN secretary-general, to the UN general assembly last autumn and, for example, positions taken by the last Organisation of African Unity summit. But if the end is largely agreed, the means remain controversial and fiendishly difficult.

The UN-sanctioned intervention in East Timor last year worked because one regional power, Australia, was prepared to show a lead and commit ground troops. Kosovo remains much more problematical because it lacked the UN's prior blessing. The US-led air war did not by itself bring the Serbs to heel and Kosovo, too, ultimately required a (British-led) ground occupation and UN follow-up to secure its objectives. Likewise, the Bosnian war ended only after an Anglo-French rapid reaction force came to the aid of the UN and forced the Bosnian Serbs to come to terms. In contrast, other UN interventions, in Angola and Rwanda to name but two, failed miserably for lack of international support and, crucially, because no regional or western power was able or prepared to get involved physically as the designated international military trouble-shooter.

There is a pattern here which looks like being repeated in Sierra Leone. Britain, like it or not, is already spearheading the military effort and the British commander is expected in effect to assume overall direction of Nigerian and other troops officially under UN command. As this stabilising force extends its influence, the aim will be to persuade the RUF rebels, the Sierra Leone army, and the militias that a return to the Togo peace process is their best bet. The UN mission should then be able to revert to the business of peacekeeping.

In an ideal world, Sierra Leone would have been able to sort out its problems by itself. But in nine years of war, it has become the archetypal "failed state". Ideally, the Nigerian-led, West African force which preceded the UN would have been better supported and funded by the west; and UN peacekeeping missions would generally be better trained and financed. In an ideal world, as Mr Cook said this week, the underlying causes of such conflicts - poverty, debt, ignorance - would be more energetically and selflessly addressed; the rackets which rob Africa of its precious natural resources, like the trade in uncut diamonds which funds the RUF, would be halted; and political mavericks like the rulers of Libya and Liberia would stop using conflicts like Sierra Leone to further their pseudo-ideological and material interests. Ideally, the international criminal court would be ready to prosecute those responsible for Sierra Leone's agony. It is not.

There can be no general rule of intervention; each case is different. But the fact that there have been so many failures in the past does not negate attempts to do better now and in the future. That is what progress is all about. In Sierra Leone, as elsewhere, Britain is right simply to try to do what it can, where it can, when it can, within the limits of its power and self-responsibility.

webTitle: MPs try to 'flush out' Blair on law to ban fox hunting

fields.headline: MPs try to 'flush out' Blair on law to ban fox hunting
fields.standfirst: The hunting debate: special report
fields.trailText: A group of Labour MPs will attempt to get Tony Blair to throw his weight behind a ban on fox hunting by next week tabling an amendment that would outlaw the practice.
fields.body:
A group of Labour MPs will attempt to get Tony Blair to throw his weight behind a ban on fox hunting by next week tabling an amendment that would outlaw the practice.

Angered by the prime minister's refusal to introduce an anti-hunting bill, the MPs aim to "flush out" Mr Blair's position with their amendment to the government's countryside and rights of way bill that legislates for the right to roam. Gordon Prentice, MP for Pendle, will table the amendment on Monday.

Yesterday he said that Labour MPs were fed up with the government's foot-dragging: "We want the prime minister to embrace our amendment, or to say the government will introduce its own bill to ban fox hunting.

"We want to put pressure on the government to flush out its position."

His remarks highlight the growing frustration among Labour MPs who voted overwhelmingly in favour of a fox- hunting ban in 1997 when they supported a private member's bill introduced by Michael Foster.

Mr Blair has said that he personally favours a ban, but he has refused to introduce a government bill amid fears that such a move could alienate Middle England voters in the run-up to the election. As a compromise the prime minister set up an inquiry into hunting, under the former Treasury permanent secretary, Lord Burns.

The inquiry is due to publish its findings on May 31 and there has been speculation that the home secretary, Jack Straw, could introduce a "multiple choice" bill before the election. This would give the MPs a chance to vote on options ranging from an outright ban to leaving the law unchanged.

Mr Prentice said he would welcome such a bill, and that his amendment was designed to maintain the pressure to introduce the measure.

"People are fed up with the fancy footwork and procrastination," he said. "The government must come forward with its own bill, because a private members' bill would be torpedoed. We must stop looking over our shoulders on this issue. It would be fatal for the government to drag this out."

The suspicions of Labour MPs were increased yesterday when the Guardian reported that Robin Cook and Baroness Jay had been praised by the Countryside Alliance for secretly undermining attempts by Labour backbenchers to ban fox hunting. Confidential letters reveal that the foreign secretary and the leader of the Lords have been thanked for their work. Mr Cook is singled out for his efforts in ensuring that a pledge is kept out of Labour's manifesto.

In his amendment Mr Prentice will attempt to meet the concerns of some rural lobbyists who have said that a ban on hunting could penalise innocent dog owners whose pets kill a fox.

Mr Prentice said: "My amendment will say that a person would commit an offence if they intentionally hunted a mammal with a hound. There is therefore no question of someone being convicted if their dog slips the lead and kills a fox. The intention is there up front."

Mr Prentice's attempt to step up the pressure on the government will be helped on Monday when the RSPCA publishes its "model" parliamentary bill to ban fox hunting. An RSPCA spokesman said: "The legislation will need to be clear and categorical, with any exemptions worded so as not to permit hunting to continue by default."

The RSPCA will call for:

 the police to be given sufficient powers of enforcement, along with powers to act swiftly where an offence is committed;

 the "deplorable" practice by hunt kennels of killing hounds at six years to be replaced by an early and complete end to breeding within packs;

 no compensation payments to follow a ban.

webTitle: Rivals can challenge '£2m a day' leeway for Vodafone

fields.headline: Rivals can challenge '£2m a day' leeway for Vodafone
fields.trailText: British Telecom and its rival, the One2One mobile phone service, were yesterday given the green light to seek a judicial review of what they claim are favourable payment terms granted for their licences to operate third-generation mobile telephones.
fields.body:
British Telecom and its rival, the One2One mobile phone service, were yesterday given the green light to seek a judicial review of what they claim are favourable payment terms granted for their licences to operate third-generation mobile telephones.

BT and One2One claim the Government is giving Vodafone Airtouch, a third competitor in the British communications industry, and Orange, which is currently owned by Vodafone, preferential treatment by allowing the companies an extra 180 days to pay up the £10bn total they owe the Treasury. BT says this concession is worth £2m a day in interest payments, or £360m all told.

Vodafone bid about £6bn in its own right for a third-generation licence and Orange bid £4bn.

The government has deferred payment by the two companies to give Vodafone time to sell Orange, which it acquired when it bought the German telecoms group, Mannesmann.

The sale of Orange was a condition set by regulators for approval of the monster bid, and the government accepts it is fair to allow Vodafone and Orange to untangle themselves before having to pay.

BT and One2One have claimed the interest gain for both companies is unfair and that BT and One2One ought to be compensated by the government for the interest they themselves will have foregone by paying on the nail.

In the high court yesterday , Mr Justice Morrison expressed scepticism about the BT and One2One challenge, saying that it "lacked merit", but granted leave to seek judicial review because the Department of Trade and Industry was actively supporting the move in order to obtain a firm ruling.

He was not, however, prepared to grant an injunction invalidating the auction.

Both sides will now present arguments in October.

The auction last month of third-generation franchises has brought £22.5bn into the public coffers, with five winners: BT, One2One, Vodafone, Orange and Tiw-Umts, a joint venture between Canada's Telesystem International Wireless and Hong Kong's Hutchison Whampoa.

Judge Morrison said that, at first glance, he believed the challenge was unlikely to succeed. "I find myself in this difficulty, that having prepared this case with care, my preliminary view was that this was not a case where leave or permission should be granted," he said.

But he added that: "If the applicants succeed, they will have been required to pay out money earlier than they would have done and they can be compensated for that loss."

webTitle: One more dance brings WPP to the altar with Young & Rubicam

fields.headline: One more dance brings WPP to the altar with Young & Rubicam
fields.standfirst: Sorrell and Bell tie the knot for £3.1bn.
fields.trailText: WPP finally sealed a £3.1bn merger with the US advertising group Young & Rubicam yesterday, after three months of negotiations dragged out by a series of acrimonious walk-outs.
fields.body:
WPP finally sealed a £3.1bn merger with the US advertising group Young & Rubicam yesterday, after three months of negotiations dragged out by a series of acrimonious walk-outs.

The deal creates the world's largest media buying agency, with leading positions in public relations, direct marketing and market research. WPP's chief executive Sir Martin Sorrell, who will run the combined organisation, said: "This is a combination for the 21st century."

However, Young & Rubicam's chief executive Thomas Bell will not be staying to see it through.

He becomes chairman of Young & Rubicam within WPP but he revealed he would be leaving "at an appropriate time in the future", explaining: "Two cooks spoil the broth."

Insiders said Mr Bell had turned down a job as chairman of the combined company. He was one of the main opponents of a merger, only agreeing to proceed after concerted pressure from boardroom colleagues.

Under the terms of the tie-up, WPP will buy Young & Rubicam for £2.4bn in an all-paper transaction. Young & Rubicam's investors will get 4.175 WPP shares for each share they own.

The two groups said that they needed size to cater for the needs of multinational clients - among the top accounts they hold between them are several transnational corporations such as Ford, IBM and American Express.

WPP owns the advertising agency Ogilvy & Mather, while Young & Rubicam owns J Walter Thompson. Mr Bell admitted negotiations had been tough: "We'd part for a while and always come back and do one more dance.

"We both knew that if we kept at it, there would be a meeting of minds."

Among the sticking points was the thorny issue of "golden parachute" allowances, which entitled the US company's executives to payoffs of up to $60m in the event of a change in control. These have been dropped, in exchange for employment contracts within the combined group.

Talks broke down again last month, when Young & Rubicam tried to insert a clause giving it autonomy for a year following the merger. However, eventually this demand was also dropped. Sir Martin said: "There was compromise on both sides."

The two companies said the tie-up would yield annual cost savings of £20m by the end of next year. However, WPP's shares fell 42p to 803p, reflecting the potential dilution caused by the deal.

David Forster, an analyst at Salomon Smith Barney, said: "More and more clients do require agencies capable of servicing their needs internationally. I think we'll see further deals like this."

webTitle: ITC to raise ad share for TV firms

fields.headline: ITC to raise ad share for TV firms
fields.trailText: The independent television commission indicated yesterday that it is ready to consider raising the limits governing the share of the advertising market held by Indepenent Television Companies.
fields.body:
The independent television commission indicated yesterday that it is ready to consider raising the limits governing the share of the advertising market held by Indepenent Television Companies.

At the moment, no one ITV group may control more than 25% of advertising revenue. But the proposed merger between Carlton Communications and United News and Media, plus the planned counterbid for one of the two companies by Granada, has forced the ITC to reconsider the issue.

The acquisition of either Carlton or United by Granada would breach the statutory audience share limit of 15%, the commission said. Granada has indicated that it is prepared to divest it's other interests to comply with the rule, but that would still leave the group controlling LWT, Yorkshire, Tyne Tees as well as the Granada franchise.

Together these companies control 30% of the total advertising revenue.

Assuming the 5% raise would be permitted, responsibility for selling 10%-12% of advertising revenue would need to be transferred to another company, the commission said. "This may not be objectionable in itself," the ITC noted, although smaller ITV companies would have to be protected.

The ITC also expressed concern that the proposed acquisition of Carlton or United by Granada would undermine the regional bias of the ITV companies' programmes and raise serious competition issues. Carlton owns Central and Westcountry, while United controls Meridian, Anglia and HTV.

A final decision to change the rules on advertising revenue share would have to be taken by the competition commission.

webTitle: No snub to Queen Mother says BBC

fields.headline: No snub to Queen Mother says BBC
fields.standfirst:
Live coverage of parade ruled out in £1m birthday celebrations

The future of the monarchy: special report
fields.trailText: The BBC mounted a strong defence yesterday of its decision not to broadcast live a parade of soldiers and civilians to mark the Queen Mother's 100th birthday.
fields.body:
The BBC mounted a strong defence yesterday of its decision not to broadcast live a parade of soldiers and civilians to mark the Queen Mother's 100th birthday.

Rejecting allegations that it was snubbing the royal family, the corporation said it had committed £1m to the coverage of the Queen Mother's centenary on BBC1 alone.

The BBC had been in discussions to show the event, two weeks before her birthday on August 4, but "on balance" decided not to go ahead. It said a suggestion that it refused to cover it live because it clashed with the early evening soap, Neighbours, was nonsense. In fact the event was originally to start at 6pm, not 5pm.

The Daily Mail highlighted the BBC's decision in a front page story yesterday headlined: "How dare the BBC snub the Queen Mother".

Inside, the paper accused the corporation of nurturing republican elements, and said of the decision: "It not only affronts the millions of viewers who would have enjoyed the hour-long spectacular, but reveals a depth of journalistic incompetence unforgivable in a publicly funded organisation."

BBC executives were furious at the allegation. One source said: "If we constructed our schedules with one eye on what the Daily Mail says, nobody would watch our programmes."

A spokesman said: "Under no circumstances or by any stretch of the imagination can we be accused of snubbing Her Majesty. We are spending £1m on commemorating a great occasion."

The BBC is to screen live a service of thanksgiving for the Queen Mother in St Paul's cathedral, which will be attended by the Queen, Tony Blair and politicians and royalty from around the world.

On August 4 it will mount a two-hour outside broadcast, taking in events from all around Britain, presented by David Dimbleby.

In the run-up, there will be documentaries, celebrations, music programmes on Radios 2 and 3 and broadcasts on Radio 4.

On the Sunday before the birthday, Sally Magnusson will present a special edition of BBC1's Songs of Praise from the Queen Mother's birthplace, Glamis Castle. "This will be the people's tribute," the spokesman said.

BBC cameras will be at the parade in question, which will feature a pageant of 5,000 people from the charities of which the Queen Mother is patron and a military parade of 1,000 members from all her regiments in Britain and the Commonwealth. Dame Vera Lynn will lead 700 children in the parade, and there will be a flypast by second world war aircraft.

The event, headed by Major General Evelyn Webb-Carter, general officer commanding, of the army's London district, will be covered in the BBC's main evening news bulletins.

But Conservative MPs were still furious. Gerald Howarth, MP for Aldershot, said: "It is a monstrous decision when one considers the tremendous affection in which the Queen Mother is held by the people of this country.

It is also an insult to all the organisations taking part. If the BBC will not cover this, why should they be allowed to cover other state events?"

Buckingham Palace was reluctant to be drawn into the row.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Dairy Crest wins milk battle
fields.body:
Dairy Crest wins milk battle

Dairy Crest emerged victorious from the battle for control of Unigate's milk and cheese operations yesterday, after rival bidder Robert Wiseman Dairies threw in the towel.

Dairy Crest is paying £250m for the operations, which will almost double the size of its business, giving it a turnover of £1.5bn.

Robert Wiseman confirmed it had decided against raising the £140m offer it made last week. Finance director Billy Keane said: "Enough's enough. We gave it our best shot."

Following the transaction, Dairy Crest will have 22% of the milk market, second only to Express Dairies which has 29%.

US factory gate prices slip

Producer prices in America fell for the first time in three months in April, the government said yesterday. But analysts said the figures would not deter the Federal Reserve from raising interest rates on Tuesday.

A 4.1% slide in energy prices helped push the producer price index down by 0.3% last month, its biggest drop since February 1999, the Labour Department reported.

"It's basically in line with expectations and I don't think it changes the outlook for the Fed meeting on Tuesday," said Jeff Palma, economist at UBS Warburg in Stamford, Connecticut. "I think they're still very much in line to [raise interest rates by] 50 basis points given the strong growth and other inflation pressures we've seen."

Motor insurer Drake scuttled

Drake Insurance, the specialised motor insurer that earlier this week was ordered to cease writing new policies, went into provisional liquidation yesterday . The company was damaged fatally by a recent price war in the car insurance market.

Jamie Smith and Steve Akers of accountants Deloitte & Touche, have been appointed provisional liquidators. They advised all 180,000 policyholders to contact their insurance brokers or agents to ensure they are still covered.

Drake is based in Brighton and employs 170 people. It specialised in certain types of cover, including "hard to insure" motorists such as younger drivers and people with a poor claims history. Liquidators have set up a helpline for policyholders, on 01273 565356.

Japan upbeat on economy

The Japanese government yesterday gave an upbeat assessment of its economy, and dismissed fears about recent stock market falls.

The economic planning agency said the boost to corporate profits and investment would mean the economy ended the year in positive territory despite continuing weakness in consumer spending.

Taichi Sakaiya, economic planning minister, said economic fundamentals were not bad and that the government was "absolutely not considering" steps to boost share prices.

Dell computer sales leap

Computer maker Dell saw its sales rise by nearly a third in the first three months of this year.

The profits topped expectations as the world's second largest personal computer maker returned to form after two shaky quarters.

Its net income rose to $525m (£344m) from $434m a year ago. Its sales rose to $7.28bn from $5.54bn in the same period in 1999.

fields.headline: Capital letters
fields.standfirst: Russia's new strongman puts Stalin back on a pedestal
fields.trailText: Russia's new strongman puts Stalin back on a pedestal
fields.body:
First there was May Day, the holiest holiday in the communist calendar. Then there was the Orthodox Easter, the most sacred feast for religious Russians. Next came Victory Day, another long weekend of partying on what is the most important national holiday - marking the conquest of Nazi Germany in a country that otherwise has little to celebrate these days.

Moscow is nursing a gigantic hangover after three long weekends that inevitably merge into each other. Workers marching under the red flag blur into processions of long-bearded priests who morph into military parades. Into the middle of the carousing came the inauguration of the new president, Vladimir Putin, making May 2000 the bumper party season for the New Russia.

This profusion of ritual provides symbols and portents that offer clues as to who the New Russians think they are. Memorials unveiled. New coins minted. Flags raised and songs sung.

Poring over the rites of the New Russia, however, is confusing and contradictory. Take the national anthem, for example. The old Soviet anthem which replaced the Internationale in 1943 on Stalin's orders was ditched when the Soviet Union collapsed in 1991. Boris Yeltsin's choirmasters came up with a 19th century tune, The Patriotic Song of Glinka.

Standing among the old soldiers on Red Square the other day as the band struck up, I half expected the veterans to burst into song, but they did not, of course, because it's an anthem without words - for the simple reason that no one can agree on what it should say.

There have been 500 text submissions during the 1990s, but every suggestion has offended someone, so putting words to the music has been put off. Besides, the parliament, until recently dominated by communists, has refused to accept the Glinka, just as it threw out the white, blue, and red tricolour as Russia's national flag, and the heraldic double-headed golden eagle. Too Tsarist, you see.

If words and flags are too divisive, one figure has emerged as the unlikeliest of healing symbols - Stalin. The dictator, it seems, is proving useful to Mr Putin. He opened his Red Square address to the war veterans with exactly the same words Stalin used in 1945.

Mr Putin unveiled a Kremlin plaque dedicated to 17 war heroes - top of the list was Stalin. A couple of days before that the central bank issued commemorative coins for the holiday featuring Stalin alongside Churchill and Truman.

A new bronze bust of Stalin is planned for Russia's main war memorial. And two days ago, Mr Putin became the first Russian leader in decades to hold a meeting at the Volynskoye dacha outside Moscow where Stalin lived and died.

fields.headline: Maxwell's troubled Telemonde in profit
fields.trailText: Kevin Maxwell's troubled Telemonde communications company has swung round into profit in the three months to the end of March, despite problems with US regulators and protracted negotiations over £76m of supply credit.
fields.body:
Kevin Maxwell's troubled Telemonde communications company has swung round into profit in the three months to the end of March, despite problems with US regulators and protracted negotiations over £76m of supply credit.

The US company turned a loss of $600,000 in the first quarter of 1999 into an operating profit of $1.2m.

Mr Maxwell, co-founder of Telemonde and son of the late publisher Robert Maxwell, said the turn-around was "very significant", given Telemonde was now hitting "vital" sales and profit targets.

The company remains de-listed in the US because of outstanding questions raised by the financial regulator, the Securities and Exchange Commission, concerning accounting policies.

It is thought Telemonde believes these queries, which were raised last November, will be sorted out in the near future, allowing the company to return to the Nasdaq stock exchange.

Telemonde's recent difficulties have arisen from supply contracts with suppliers under which the company is required to buy specific quantities of supplies over set periods.

In November, Mr Maxwell notified the SEC that the company had not been able to generate sufficient cash to meet these requirements, so was in danger of default. One contract has been renegotiated, and two are still subject to discussions.

The company aims to cable up the developing world, bringing poorer countries the benefits of high-quality, low-cost telecoms links.

Although co-founder Adam Bishop said much of first-quarter revenue had come from transatlantic traffic, Mr Maxwell said that for the first time a significant contribution was coming from the Middle East.

Financial chief Paul Donofrio said there was "still much work to be done," in particular to secure adequate working capital to fuel Telemonde's continued strong growth.

webTitle: Doctors' caring image struggles to survive

fields.headline: Doctors' caring image struggles to survive
fields.standfirst:
The medical profession has come under attack this week for perceived remoteness in dealing with patients. Today we assess whether a culture of arrogance has taken root in the health service

The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: Paul and Valmai Bradley found the funeral of their daughter Bethan, six, who died after heart surgery in Bristol, almost impossible to bear. In March, six years on, they discovered they had not buried all of her. Shocked and distressed to find that organs had been removed from her body without their knowledge, they feel that their child has been treated with contempt.
fields.body:
Paul and Valmai Bradley found the funeral of their daughter Bethan, six, who died after heart surgery in Bristol, almost impossible to bear. In March, six years on, they discovered they had not buried all of her. Shocked and distressed to find that organs had been removed from her body without their knowledge, they feel that their child has been treated with contempt.

"There are no words to describe the feeling," Mr Bradley told the inquiry into the deaths of child heart patients at the Bristol Royal infirmary. "It might be considered over the top, but we cannot help how we feel: we felt it was criminal, what was done - that it was contemptuous to the dignity of our child, that her body had been, as we see it, invaded and body parts stolen."

Ian Kennedy QC, who is chairing the inquiry into Bristol heart surgery, this week condemned the "arrogance born of indifference" of doctors who, with the best of motives, removed organs from children's bodies without telling parents what they intended to do or what they had done.

The inquiry had heard evidence relating to what took place in Bristol before 1995. Professor Kennedy's words drew fierce protests from the British Medical Association.

"I am not defending practice that has been obviously indefensible, but this idea of non-sympathetic doctors is deeply damaging to the profession and therefore deeply damaging to patient care," said Ian Bogle, chairman of the BMA council.

It was the second body blow to the caring image of the profession in a week. On Monday doctors at North Staffordshire hospital were condemned by a report from the Griffiths inquiry for failing to give parents proper explanations before putting their premature babies into trials for a new type of ventilator. Allegations that consent forms were forged have gone to the General Medical Council.

The image of remoteness, a doctrine of arrogance, was further fostered by this week's disclosures about Steven Harley, who had to endure 22 examinations by 12 different doctors before he was correctly diagnosed as having tongue cancer - too late for surgery.

One doctor allegedly told Mr Harley, after a six-hour wait in casualty at Barnsley district general hospital on New Year's Day, that he should "go home and get a life". The hospital has refused to apologise for the remark, saying it was an epithet meant to reassure him.

But according to the medical institutions - the royal colleges, the BMA and the GMC - the patrician doctor is an endangered species, flushed out of his ivory tower by scandals such as the one at Bristol.

The government has used Bristol as a stick to beat the profession with. Doctors' organisations have embraced changes such as appraisal, inspection and a new consumer-led NHS culture. They say arrogance may linger on in the odd cobwebby corner but is largely a thing of the past.

But Joyce Robins, who with Roger Goss runs the independent pressure group Patient Concern, said: "The one thing that comes through all the time from patients who are complaining is the arrogance of doctors. They will put up with waiting for hours, but let the doctor make them think they are two inches tall and that really gets them going.

"Guidelines are fine, but what is practice in the consulting room is a very different matter. We have people saying all the time I never signed that [consent form]. We hear of people signing consent forms on the trolley after a pre-med. I have never heard of anyone being given a copy of their consent form. It is the only legal document like that."

Recently she was a guest on a television programme. "A patient told a sad story of something that happened to her when her son died and how the doctors behaved. A surgeon from a top teaching hospital said he did not believe a word of it." Afterwards Ms Robins told the surgeon she had heard many such stories and could not disbelieve them all. He replied, she said: "That's because you are a silly woman representing a stupid, ignorant section of society."

On another occasion, she went to a consultation with a friend diagnosed with cancer. "She said to the consultant: 'What symptoms have I got to expect in the short term?' He said: 'I won't tell you because you will start imagining them.' This is a professional woman, perfectly capable of taking it in."

In the British Medical Journal last month, Shah Ebrahim, professor of the epidemiology of ageing at Bristol University, wrote of the profession's continuing disrespect for age: "Our attempts over the past three decades to produce humane doctors and nurses, capable of responding to patients' needs regardless of age, have not been rewarded. Medical students still rejoice in their stereotypes of 'geriatric crumble' and 'gomer' [get out of my emergency room] patients."

The Downs' Syndrome Association recognises that attitude. Its complaints about treatment of patients and parents at the hands of doctors at the Royal Brompton hospital are being investigated.

Families are devastated by unfeeling comments from medical staff. "We won't bother with glasses as he is not what you would call university material," said an ophthalmologist of Tom, 13, according to an association report last year. Another told the parent of Stephen, 11: "The problem with these children is they are either hyperactive or pathetic." Some children have been denied medical treatment such as heart surgery which might give them a longer life.

Peter Hawker, chairman of the BMA consultants committee, is part of a generation brought up in the 1960s and 1970s which does not have the patrician attitudes he accepts linger on among the older generation. "I feel quite passionately that we have seen and are seeing an almost sea-change," he said. His generation was "much more attuned to looking after patients". "I talk about people, not patients," he said. "I don't treat disease, I look after people who have illnesses.

"Some attitudes do come across as a little bit of arrogance. Sometimes it is from the best of motives. Some of my colleagues do feel that they have to try to protect their patients. I think that is going, because people do come in and want to know."

Dr Hawker is a gastroenterologist at Warwick hospital with a special interest in the palliative care of oesophagal cancer. Two or three times a week he may have to tell a patient that he or she has cancer.

"I'm often talking to an elderly couple," he said. "Everything they have worked for and the retirement time they were planning together: you are leading them to accept that it is not going to happen. The day I find it easy to have those conversations I am going to stop having them, but there comes a time when you have to put in a bit of a distance or you would break down yourself, and that doesn't help anyone."

The distress caused at Bristol and the other 42 hospitals that have removed organs without discussion, and at North Staffordshire, where procedures for obtaining consent were inadequate, will lead to guidelines and possibly a change in the law on clinical trials. But it may take a few more years before the last of the old school of doctors has retired and the modern doctor-patient relationship prevails.

fields.headline: York deals blow to Labour
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Elections 2000

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Labour yesterday lost overall control of a flagship authority which has pioneered Blairite town hall reforms and efficiency measures.
fields.body:
Labour yesterday lost overall control of a flagship authority which has pioneered Blairite town hall reforms and efficiency measures.

In spite of campaign visits this week by a string of ministers, including John Prescott, the party suffered the humiliation of losing York city council on a 25% swing to the Liberal Democrats in a crucial byelection.

Although Labour has lost 17 councils and more than 500 seats in the past eight days, the latest reversal in one of its safest wards in York is a severe blow in a city that has won awards for the quality of its council services.

Labour will find it harder to blame defeat on traditional supporters refusing to vote, because the 35% turnout was relatively high by local election standards.

To make matters worse for the party, Tony Blair's plea this week for voters to be patient while reforms filter through was clearly rejected in a city that embraces old working-class areas and swaths of middle England.

Rod Hills, the council's Labour leader, said he found it hard to understand how a "model New Labour council" could lose ground on its record. It will shortly be praised by Ofsted for the quality of its education service. "But local elections are won or lost on how popular the government is, and the truth of the matter is we couldn't get our vote out."

He said the party had been particularly badly hit by criticism of the 75p rise in the basic state pension. "The message has not got through how much we have put into education and, more importantly, into health."

Steve Galloway, the Lib Dem leader, said: "While there is an element of mid-term unpopularity with the government, Labour has also taken some very unpopular measures locally, like increased charges for home care and meals on wheels."

The byelection means Labour now has 25 seats on the council to the Lib Dems' 23. The Tories have three and independents one. Next week, in another byelection, Labour is likely to lose another seat.

webTitle: Eat, drink and yell your head off

fields.headline: Eat, drink and yell your head off
fields.standfirst: Restaurant noise reaches levels which threaten health
fields.trailText: Friday lunchtime in a packed gastro-pub in Soho, central London, and a gaggle of women are shouting to make themselves heard.
fields.body:
Friday lunchtime in a packed gastro-pub in Soho, central London, and a gaggle of women are shouting to make themselves heard.

Fuelled by Chardonnay, their voices become more raucous as they compete with the thocks of table football, the clatter of kitten heels on the wooden floor, and Gabrielle blaring over the sound system.

"Sometimes we decide not to come here after work because we can't handle the noise," admits Fiona Fovargue, a 30-year-old advertising account manager, as she strains to be heard over a screech of laughter.

It is a scenario with which many diners are becoming increasingly familiar.

But a survey published by New Scientist magazine this week suggests that noise levels in such establishments regularly exceed industrial safety regulations.

Indeed, in almost half the venues, the average noise level was 88 decibels - higher than the 85 at which there is a risk of hearing damage.

The survey also discovered that bars and restaurants that follow the vogue of bare floors, walls and pillars were the noisiest, since sound is reflected back and not absorbed.

In one unnamed West End restaurant, a peak level of 97 was measured.

Prolonged conversation at such a pitch can lead to laryngitis, and the magazine warned that staff subjected to such conditions "ought to consider donning industrial ear muffs to protect them from possible hearing loss".

Armed with a decibel meter and an environmental health officer, the Guardian conducted its own straw poll in London and Manchester.

In six of the 10 restaurants and bars peak levels over 85 decibels were recorded - a level above that at which employers are legally required to take action if workers are exposed to it for eight hours a day.

At the Slug and Lettuce in Soho, where Ms Fovargue and her five colleagues were struggling to be heard, the highest level was 94; at a Pizza Express in Manchester, the highest level was 90.

Customers tended to admit they wished sound levels were lower, and often criticised the music - largely credited with driving up noise levels, according to Dani Fiumicelli, the acoustician taking the readings.

"The noise of people talking means it is hard enough to make oneself heard without this drivel," complained Caroline Thornton, a 24-year-old administrator, as Frank Sinatra pushed levels in Leicester Square's All Bar One to 89 decibels. But venues without music could also be deafening. At the Eagle, a gastro-pub in Farringdon Road, London, with bare boards and a kitchen open along the length of the bar, the decibels soared to 89.7 - just short of a thundering heavy goods lorry.

Mr Fiumicelli, an acoustician with a London borough council, insisted that customers were unlikely to be damaged by the levels, since they were unlikely to be subjected to such levels for eight hours daily. But he stressed that more traditional venues with carpets, bolstered furnishings and plants, were gentler to ears.

The New Scientist had also surveyed such establishments and found none exceeded the 75 decibel level.

But did this mean having to revert to flock wallpapered establishments, anathema to hip urban living?

Not necessarily. Cafe Med, a terracotta-decorated Soho brasserie with dark wood floors and deep leather armchairs, noise levels averaged 75 decibels.

Andrew Tyldesley, a property developer, explained why he had booked the restaurant. "I knew we had to talk, and it is nice to be able to hear yourself doing so."

Decibel count Where shouting drowns out music

 Pizza Express South King Street, Manchester

Three-floor branch of high-street chain with steel and glass interior

Maximum decibels 90.1

Noise Waitress can't hear orders, babies' screams and jazz music drowned out by shouting and clatter of plates

 Mash and Air Chorlton Street, Manchester

Conran-style minimalist restaurant and bar

Maximum decibels 80.5

Noise Pans crashing in the open-plan kitchen, loud acid house music

 The Living Room Deansgate, Manchester

Art house lounge brasserie "designed to feel like home"

Maximum decibels 87.6

Noise Grace Jones and shouting

 Cafe Med Dean Street, London

Mediterranean Bar grill, wooden floors, open kitchen

Maximum decibels 83

Noise Unobtrusive jazz broadcast, hum of conversation

 The Eagle Farringdon Road, London

Gastro pub with open kitchen, bare floors and walls

Maximum decibels 89.7 Noise Food frying, clatter of utensils, drone of traffic from adjoining busy road

 Slug and Lettuce Wardour Street, London

Chain bar with bare floors and walls

Maximum decibels 94

Noise Table football, pop music, lots of laughter

 McDonald's Leicester Square, London

Fast-food outlet packed with mothers with young children, foreign tourists, and teenagers

Maximum decibels 80

Noise Quiet pop music, the ring of cash machines and cry of children

The New Scientist had also surveyed such establishments and found none exceeded the 75 decibel level. But did this mean having to revert to flock wallpapered establishments, anathema to hip urban living? Not necessarily. Cafe Med, a terracotta-decorated Soho brasserie with dark wood floors and deep leather armchairs, noise levels averaged 75 decibels. Andrew Tyldesley, a property developer, explained why he had booked the restaurant. "I knew we had to talk, and it is nice to be able to hear yourself doing so." webTitle: Getting customers to keep the faith

fields.headline: Getting customers to keep the faith
fields.standfirst: Supermarket loyalty schemes are becoming a thing of the past but it is still too early to mourn their complete demise. Matthew Hooper reports
fields.trailText: Safeway last week abandoned its "abc " loyalty card and immediately saw its share price jump 21p to 229p. Does this herald the retailers' return to price wars and the demise of the plastic wallet fillers that have found their way into our hip pockets and purses?
fields.body:
Safeway last week abandoned its "abc " loyalty card and immediately saw its share price jump 21p to 229p. Does this herald the retailers' return to price wars and the demise of the plastic wallet fillers that have found their way into our hip pockets and purses?

Safeway's decision should come as no surprise, as the number of these schemes in the US - birthplace of "loyalty " - has fallen dramatically over the last few years because customer uptake has dropped, and they are no longer commercially viable.

Loyalty may have had its day, but the same can be said of most management principles - downsizing, outsourcing, etc. - and yet most enjoy a phoenix-like return under a different name. So it's probably not wise to write off the principle just yet.

Most loyalty schemes are born as a reaction to competitive activity. But such schemes smack of cosmetic sincerity and fake customer concern. These plastic point collecting solutions are similar to (and arguably less effective than) the piecemeal promotions they replace, and have less brand and customer focus than their proprietors would have us believe. Undeniably, the efficacy of most point-based loyalty schemes has clearly diminished when their origins do not offer meaningful customer focused rewards.

The "first to market" scenario is a compelling theory, because of the added value and point of differentiation aspects, but such gains can diminish quickly unless the scheme is continuously re-invigorated and its effectiveness monitored.

And what are loyalty schemes meant to achieve? If loyalty is the desire to counteract "promiscuity", shouldn't we be asking what is making the customer promiscuous in the first place? And are these not the areas a loyalty scheme should address?

People are loyal for many reasons. A 1% or 2% discount is not a huge incentive, although the cost to a corporation can be extremely large. That money could, arguably, be better spent on other areas such as improving the buying environment, raising staff service standards and generating a better understanding of what customers really want, which could be practical things such as secure parking or baby-changing facilities. What companies need to appreciate is that what makes customers loyal is never just one aspect of the brand.

Loyalty is therefore clearly a management issue and one that transcends all levels in terms of audiences - consumer, staff and suppliers. But just as it is a notion that is applicable to all audiences, so too do its tentacles extend to all areas of a business. There is no loyalty panacea, no single formula. Schemes that are not "bought into" by those who actually interface with the customer will fail. Schemes that do not receive commitment from the very top will fail. Schemes that embrace singular sections of a business rather than the multiple picture will fail. Schemes dictated from the boardroom instead of the shop floor will fail.

Like downsizing and outsourcing, loyalty has a place on the boardroom agenda. But like the former two, the principle of loyalty's place depends on the brand, the company and the sector in which it operates. Such schemes must have clear and attainable commercial objectives. They should consider all in fluencing aspects of the business, and their components should be founded in a focus that is customer-led.

That said, there are many admirable schemes which go under the title of "loyalty", but are in fact effective and tactical traffic building exercises. These too have a place, but again the prerequisite is the commercial goal.

One distinct advantage that a well-run loyalty scheme can offer is its database, which, if utilised to its full potential can unlock the secret of customers' buying patterns, choices, motivations etc. However, it is a common oversight on the part of many schemes that such material is neither correctly gathered or analysed and identification of the brand's core customers remains a classified secret.

One well-run scheme is Selfridges', which has established opportunities to offer customers different things that tie them back into the store, so the incentives and rewards are store- rather than money-based.

Also, the scheme operates a tier system, so that it rewards the most loyal and simultaneously encourages the migration of lower tier customers to the higher echelons of the top tier and so actively encourages profitable customer behaviour.

Unlike in the physics of energy, loyalty can be both created AND destroyed. But applying this science means it can also be passed from one form to another, and you don't have to be Einstein to work out how: just a good manager.

 Matthew Hooper is managing director of Interfocus.

webTitle: 'Betrayed' Ford workers ponder strike as axe falls

fields.headline: 'Betrayed' Ford workers ponder strike as axe falls
fields.standfirst: Special report: Ford at Dagenham
fields.trailText: The day began with a touch of gallows humour - a handwritten sign tied to railings above the main entrance read: "To let, £10 o.n.o."
fields.body:
The day began with a touch of gallows humour - a handwritten sign tied to railings above the main entrance read: "To let, £10 o.n.o."

But that ironic reference to the resurrection of Longbridge, bought from BMW for a symbolic £10, was the last time anyone was in the mood for jokes. As the shift spilled out of the Dagenham assembly plant in east London at lunchtime, clutching redundancy letters handed to them minutes before, they spoke of a bitter rift between winners and losers under the deal.

Union officials warned of industrial action, saying a meeting had been called for Monday to urge a strike ballot. Peter Singh, 40, a Transport and General Workers Union shop steward, said Ford had broken its 1997 promise to maintain production. "The men are very agitated. They feel let down."

Some found themselves entitled to generous packages: a supervisor in his mid-50s with 30 years service could expect to get a £51,800 payout on top of his £16,400 pension. Others were not so fortunate.

Steve Johnston, 42, an electrician, said: "I've been here for 18 years but I am not old enough to get a pension, and I am devastated.

"I would like to know: why Dagenham? We are expected to be more efficient and we are cheaper to employ than the German worker.

"Some people are jubilant and only want to go. Others in my situation feel sickened. I have got a £500 a month mortgage, and three children. There are no jobs around here."

If Mr Johnston were to have been 45 in 2002, when the plant will finally close, he would be eligible for a package in which the pension is deferred until 50, on top of a lump sum payout.

As it is, he will take away little more than a year's wages. "In 2002 I will 44 years and one month. At my age I can only take voluntary redundancy and all I am offered is £37,000."

Dain Wilsher, 25, an assembly line worker, has been offered £25,000 after five years' service. "I was quite upset," he said. "I was hearing things on the radio before they told me. We always seem to be the last to know.

"The mood is terrible in there. Tempers are going all the time. No one knew what was happening.

"We feel betrayed. I was expecting a steady job for life. There are not that many good jobs out there unless you have got qualifications and experience which I don't have."

Women in the canteen, not employed by Ford but by a contractor, also face the end but stand to receive meagre payouts. Pamela North, 56, a cashier, said she would get a week's pay for each of 16 years' service.

As the morning shift filed out at 1pm no new shift came in to replace them. For nine months, Fridays have been a single shift due to low demand for Fiestas.

Four hundred of the 1,900 offered redundancy can instead take the chance of new jobs in Dagenham's engine plant, or move to plants in Southampton, Swansea, or Bridgend.

But Gengiz Osman, 36, with a Spurs scarf wrapped around his neck, said: "Why would I want to go to Southampton? My wife won't move there, and I don't want to take the kids there."

webTitle: From feet of clay to pots of cash

fields.headline: From feet of clay to pots of cash
fields.standfirst: Over the past decade Clarice Cliff ceramics have soared in value. Stewart Dalby looks at more potters whose time may have come
fields.trailText: Few dealers or auctioneers can explain the craze for the Art Deco and jazz-age ceramics of Clarice Cliff. In the past 10 years prices for her wares, made largely in the 20s, have rocketed to thousands of pounds per item.
fields.body:
Few dealers or auctioneers can explain the craze for the Art Deco and jazz-age ceramics of Clarice Cliff. In the past 10 years prices for her wares, made largely in the 20s, have rocketed to thousands of pounds per item.

She has become a cult figure. The auction houses have dedicated sales of her works, always well attended. Yet in the 60s she was very much out of fashion and you could pick up her pieces for a few pounds. Her reputation began to revive following a major retrospective exhibition of her work in Brighton in 1972. She was, moreover, an industrial potter; her work was mass-produced.

If Clarice Cliff has now become too expensive for you, are there other quite well-known potters that have been overlooked and may be due for a revival? One such group could be the pieces of the Poole Potters. Poole Pottery is a cross between studio pottery and industrial ceramics, as the pottery in Dorset attracted various artists whose designs were produced in limited and unlimited editions.

The pottery is still going. In 1992 a venture capital-backed management buyout from parent Thomas Tilling brought in fresh capital. Last August Poole experienced a 99% eclipse of the sun. To mark the occasion a plate and charger, a large decorative wall plate, were produced in a limited edition of 2,000.

The Poole Pottery was set up in the 1850s and became firmly established in 1873 when it was taken over by Jesse Carter and his sons Charles and Owen, and became host to artists with emerging and changing styles.

William de Morgan, who became well known had been buying blanks from the Carters from the 1870s. In 1900 he began buying bowls. John Radley Young introduced new lines during the first world war and Roger Fry, the Bloomsbury designer, visited Poole between 1914 and 1917 to produce wares for his Omega workshops.

Resident designers in the last century included Truda Carter, John Adams, Harold and Phoebe Stabler and visiting artists such as Edward Barra and Dora Batty. Later designers were Ruth Paveley in the 20s.

The range extends from early plain and encaustic tiles through various experiments to the decorative domestic wares up until the 50s.

The wares produced throughout the 20th century reflected the changing tastes of various decades. There were bright Art Deco items during the 20s and 30s and more restrained items in the 40s. In the 50s there were the free-form styles often made for Liberty. They were called Freeform because they were hand-thrown using traditional hand potting techniques, making each one slightly different. By the 60s came the Delphis range, with bright psychedelic colours and abstract designs.

The Delphis wares were launched in 1963 at Heal's, the designer store. The same year Tony Morris, a former student at Newport School of Art, joined Poole and over the next two years he and Robert Jefferson developed the range. The lines were continued until 1980.

Today, after a period in the doldrums, Poole pottery is beginning to perform well at auctions. Christie's South Kensington has two auctions a year where it sells Poole Pottery along with Chintz and Carlton Ware.

The most sought-after items are the traditional ware, the pieces made early in the century by the Carter-Adams-Stabler team, and the Delphis range. The traditional items are usually earthenware pieces with an off-white glaze and either geometric or spare floral or bird designs.

Poole Pottery is still very cheap. In flea markets in Brighton and Lewes in Sussex recently I saw several pieces, mostly plates or chargers, going for £15 to £20 and a large jug and bowl for £68. At the next Christie's auction on August 25 there are two chargers from the Delphis range, and associated with Tony Morris estimated at between £300 and £500. Occasionally a piece reaches a four-figure sum.

If Clarice Cliff can take off, why not the Poole Potters, particularly the Delphis wares?

Joy McCall at Bonham's says: "I suppose you would have to say that Clarice Cliff is probably more distinctive in shape and design. The countryside and floral patterns are very intricate, the Delphis pieces have abstract designs. But they are not inferior as products."

For further information telephone Christie's, South Kensington, 020-7581-7611, www.christies.com or Bonham's 020-7393-3900 www.bonhams.com.

webTitle: US faces its biggest anti-gun march as moms say 'no more'

fields.headline: US faces its biggest anti-gun march as moms say 'no more'
fields.standfirst: Gun violence in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Every day in the United States about 12 mothers find out what it feels like to be Jaquie Algee - to lose your child to the random, ricocheting violence of gunfire.
fields.body:
Every day in the United States about 12 mothers find out what it feels like to be Jaquie Algee - to lose your child to the random, ricocheting violence of gunfire.

In a country with more guns than adult citizens, the bullet can come from anywhere.

Ms Algee's 19-year-old son Kenneth was not a gang member. In fact, his mother had sent him away to college in Maryland partly to shield him from the gun-infested south side of Chicago.

But on November 6 1995, he was home for the holidays helping a friend move house when a bullet found him.

"He was coming out of the door carrying a TV, when these kids came round a corner shooting. It hit him in the head," Ms Algee said.

They apparently did not like strangers on their territory, but she will probably never know for sure.

The bullet was of a type that fragments and cannot be traced. No one has ever been charged with the killing.

For more than four years, Ms Algee has had to live without the comfort of justice. There was no shortage of sympathetic relatives but, as she points out: "They're not helpful at 3 o'clock in the morning when you can't sleep and all you want is to hear his voice."

She became a foot-soldier in America's silent civil war over guns, which will break into open battle this weekend with the Million Mom March, a mass protest in support of gun control to be staged tomorrow, Mother's Day, in Washington and cities across the country.

The aim is to put the issue where it has never been before, at the centre of the political agenda as the 2000 election campaign enters its final months.

In a country where handguns are subject to fewer federal regulations than electric toasters or teddy bears, the marchers will demand built-in safety locks, "cooling off" periods between ordering a gun and receiving it, and purchase limits of one gun per person per month.

To European eyes, it is hardly a radical programme. But similar measures have been stuck in Congress for the past year, blocked by well-funded and well-organised opposition from the gun lobby, the National Rifle Association (NRA), which is ploughing millions of dollars into a campaign to stifle the momentum of the Million Mom March.

Advertisements are being broadcast around the country, in which the NRA's figurehead, the aging film legend Charlton Heston, offers to spend $1m on a programme to teach children to handle guns safely.

The NRA has also launched a spoiler to the Million Mom March called the Armed Informed Mothers' March.

It will be fronted by an NRA women's subsidiary calling itself the Second Amendment Sisters, in reference to the constitutional clause guaranteeing Americans the right to bear arms.

The winners and losers in tomorrow's battle will be determined by turnout.

Gun-control campaigners are optimistic they can bring up to 300,000 marchers together in Washington, and make up the rest of the million in other cities.

If they succeed, it will be the biggest anti-gun demonstration in US history.

The movement has been fuelled by a string of highly publicised school shootings - such as the 1999 massacre at Columbine high school in Colorado - which have spread anxiety about guns to white middle-class suburbs, particularly to suburban mothers.

A Gallup poll yesterday found that 58% of US women were in favour of new gun laws, compared to 30% of men.

"In most of the southern cities, it cuts across race lines, and it goes across class lines," said Ben Bycel, an anti-gun activist who is helping to coordinate the march in the south.

"I haven't seen anything like this since the 1960s. There is a groundswell here."

Ms Algee now lives in Atlanta. There, she says, outrage at guns is no longer just a black issue. Several of her fellow organisers are relatively affluent whites.

"If it doesn't affect you directly, you feel sad about it, but you don't do anything about it," she said. "But with guns, there are no guarantees. It's no respecter of persons or backgrounds."

Two years ago, the Jaskolkas, a conservative, gun-owning family from Delaware, discovered just how random gun violence can be.

Gregory, Brenda and their 11-year-old son Joseph were at a New Year's Eve street party when a bullet fell from the sky and struck Joseph in the head.

Somebody had decided to mark the occasion by letting off a few rounds, a relatively common form of celebration in a country where many still see themselves as roughneck pioneers.

Incredibly, Joseph survived with a bullet lodged in his brain. But the Jaskolkas' lives were changed forever. Their son, now 13, can walk only with extreme difficulty and spends most of his time confined to their home.

Brenda works nights at a shipping company and Gregory works shifts at an oil refinery to provide for their son's needs. Together, Mr Jaskolka said, "we can just about wing it".

"It is very difficult. It consumes you," Mrs Jaskolka said. "I get home and I sleep for two hours and then I have to get up, when he has to go to the hospital.

"Then I sleep for another two hours before I have to go to collect him, and then it's time to go to work."

A former policeman, Mr Jaskolka, was a card-carrying NRA member and gun enthusiast for much of his life. Not any longer.

Tomorrow the family will be at the Washington march, where Joseph will ring a bell for child victims of gun violence who did not survive.

"We don't want to disarm the public," Mr Jaskolka said. "We just want some responsibility. We regulate how chickens lay eggs. But there is no regulation on guns.

"They regulate how we grow celery, but there is no regulation on ammunition. We need some regulation. There is none."
