She became a foot-soldier in America's silent civil war over guns, which will break into open battle this weekend with the Million Mom March, a mass protest in support of gun control to be staged tomorrow, Mother's Day, in Washington and cities across the country. The aim is to put the issue where it has never been before, at the centre of the political agenda as the 2000 election campaign enters its final months. In a country where handguns are subject to fewer federal regulations than electric toasters or teddy bears, the marchers will demand built-in safety locks, "cooling off" periods between ordering a gun and receiving it, and purchase limits of one gun per person per month. To European eyes, it is hardly a radical programme. But similar measures have been stuck in Congress for the past year, blocked by well-funded and well-organised opposition from the gun lobby, the National Rifle Association (NRA), which is ploughing millions of dollars into a campaign to stifle the momentum of the Million Mom March. Advertisements are being broadcast around the country, in which the NRA's figurehead, the aging film legend Charlton Heston, offers to spend $1m on a programme to teach children to handle guns safely. The NRA has also launched a spoiler to the Million Mom March called the Armed Informed Mothers' March. It will be fronted by an NRA women's subsidiary calling itself the Second Amendment Sisters, in reference to the constitutional clause guaranteeing Americans the right to bear arms. The winners and losers in tomorrow's battle will be determined by turnout. Gun-control campaigners are optimistic they can bring up to 300,000 marchers together in Washington, and make up the rest of the million in other cities. If they succeed, it will be the biggest anti-gun demonstration in US history. The movement has been fuelled by a string of highly publicised school shootings - such as the 1999 massacre at Columbine high school in Colorado - which have spread anxiety about guns to white middle-class suburbs, particularly to suburban mothers. A Gallup poll yesterday found that 58% of US women were in favour of new gun laws, compared to 30% of men. "In most of the southern cities, it cuts across race lines, and it goes across class lines," said Ben Bycel, an anti-gun activist who is helping to coordinate the march in the south. "I haven't seen anything like this since the 1960s. There is a groundswell here." Ms Algee now lives in Atlanta. There, she says, outrage at guns is no longer just a black issue. Several of her fellow organisers are relatively affluent whites. "If it doesn't affect you directly, you feel sad about it, but you don't do anything about it," she said. "But with guns, there are no guarantees. It's no respecter of persons or backgrounds." Two years ago, the Jaskolkas, a conservative, gun-owning family from Delaware, discovered just how random gun violence can be. Gregory, Brenda and their 11-year-old son Joseph were at a New Year's Eve street party when a bullet fell from the sky and struck Joseph in the head. Somebody had decided to mark the occasion by letting off a few rounds, a relatively common form of celebration in a country where many still see themselves as roughneck pioneers. Incredibly, Joseph survived with a bullet lodged in his brain. But the Jaskolkas' lives were changed forever. Their son, now 13, can walk only with extreme difficulty and spends most of his time confined to their home. Brenda works nights at a shipping company and Gregory works shifts at an oil refinery to provide for their son's needs. Together, Mr Jaskolka said, "we can just about wing it". "It is very difficult. It consumes you," Mrs Jaskolka said. "I get home and I sleep for two hours and then I have to get up, when he has to go to the hospital. "Then I sleep for another two hours before I have to go to collect him, and then it's time to go to work." A former policeman, Mr Jaskolka, was a card-carrying NRA member and gun enthusiast for much of his life. Not any longer. Tomorrow the family will be at the Washington march, where Joseph will ring a bell for child victims of gun violence who did not survive. "We don't want to disarm the public," Mr Jaskolka said. "We just want some responsibility. We regulate how chickens lay eggs. But there is no regulation on guns. "They regulate how we grow celery, but there is no regulation on ammunition. We need some regulation. There is none."

fields.headline: Shooting angers Israeli Arabs
fields.standfirst: Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: The shooting of an Arab motorist by police yesterday threatened to ignite rising frustrations in a community that accounts for 1m Israeli citizens, yet faces systematic discrimination.
fields.body:
The shooting of an Arab motorist by police yesterday threatened to ignite rising frustrations in a community that accounts for 1m Israeli citizens, yet faces systematic discrimination.

Israeli Arab leaders called for Alik Ron, police chief of the northern Galilee region, to be stripped of his duties and face trial for attempted murder after he shot and wounded the speeding driver on Thursday.

"His decision to use weapons and to chase him down in such a dangerous way can only be seen as murderous," said Mohammed Zeidan, chairman of the Supreme Monitoring Committee of Israeli Arabs and mayor of Kafr Manda, the hometown of the wounded motorist.

"We see this as an act of provocation against the Arab people by a man who has a history of being prejudiced against Arab people."

Israeli Arabs, who account for one-sixth of Israel's 6m citizens, face discrimination in civil rights, jobs and housing. "In the situation now, it as if we are living under military rule," Mr Zeidan said.

Yesterday he led a protest of several thousand in Kafr Manda and says strikes and demonstrations are planned across Israel. They follow clashes between Arab and Jewish students at universities in Haifa and Jerusalem last month, the worst campus unrest in a decade.

A protest in the Arab town of Shfaram against official events to mark Israel's independence day earlier this week turned into a riot in which dozens of Arabs and five policemen were wounded.

"We are not against Israel, but we are against what is happening to the Arab community in Israel," said Nakad Nakad, who was hit by rubber bullets during the Shfaram protest.

He said the younger generation of Israeli Arabs was bitterly disappointed with the prime minister, Ehud Barak, for failing to honour campaign promises he made a year ago to improve their lot.

"Ninety-nine per cent of Israeli Arabs voted for Barak, but now we do not see any difference," Mr Nakad said.

webTitle: Put an end to capital  punishment

fields.headline: Put an end to capital  punishment
fields.standfirst: Could you put up with a train journey requiring you to stand for its entirety every day? And even if you could, is it worth it to escape the ever soaring cost of living in London? As more and more people decide to pack up and move out Elizabeth Langton weighs up the pros and cons
fields.trailText: Soaring property prices have put owning a home in London out of the reach of thousands of workers. But does it save you money to buy a cheaper house in commuterland and pay train fares - which can add up to as much as £5,000-£6,000 a year - to work in the capital?
fields.body:
Soaring property prices have put owning a home in London out of the reach of thousands of workers. But does it save you money to buy a cheaper house in commuterland and pay train fares - which can add up to as much as £5,000-£6,000 a year - to work in the capital?

The number of passengers using the train to commute into London is up for the third consecutive year, according to official figures. Last year an extra 12,919 passengers chose to take the train to work, bringing the total number of peak-hour travellers to 455,290.

But does it pay to travel so far to work? It's certainly far cheaper to buy property outside London. The average cost of a semi-detached family home in Norwich, East Anglia is £64,225. The cost of a semi in the London borough of Croydon is an average of £141,644, while in trendy Islington the same semi would cost a whacking £339,240.

A mortgage for 90% of the value of the Norwich home at a standard variable rate of 7.75% will cost buyers £5,299 a year. Add to that the cost of a season ticket, £4,400 for the 1 hour 40 minute journey and the annual cost of living in Norwich, and travelling to London comes to the grand total of £9,699.

That £9,699 would, according to Halifax, pay for a mortgage of nearly £106,000 (equal to a house purchase of £117,600 assuming a 10% deposit) which would still not be enough to buy the average semi in London, so the Norwich commuter is quids in.

Russell Taylor is one of a growing band of commuters who want to have their cake and eat it. After 15 years in London, Mr Taylor, who runs FPD Savills' Docklands estate agency office, went in search of a better quality of life. Last October he and his family took the plunge and moved to the pretty Hampshire city of Winchester. They are currently renting while looking for somewhere to buy.

A cathedral, good state and private schools, the countryside and the Solent entice many Londoners to wave farewell to the smoke and move to Winchester, says Stephen Cross of FPD Savills' Winchester Office. Mr Cross has noticed a marked increase in the number of people looking to live in the area but work in London.

"Easily 50% of the people we sell to are commuting to London. They either live here already and commute or are moving out of London," says Mr Cross. "It's a fast train to London. The road links are very good too. The M3 connects to the M27, the A34 to the M4 and the A303 to Exeter. The ferry ports are also in easy reach," he explains.

Mr Taylor says his journey is far from arduous and has rekindled an interest in reading during the 55 minute trip: "I step on the Winchester to Waterloo, get engrossed in a book and I'm there before I know it. I keep a scooter at Waterloo and can be in the office in 10 minutes.

"Door-to-door it takes an hour and 20 minutes. And 55 minutes of that is sitting down reading," he adds. The average price of a semi in Winchester is £130,386 and the cost of an annual season ticket for the 55-minute journey to Waterloo is £2,936. A four-bedroom family home can cost between £375,000 - £450,000. It's easy to understand why people move out, says Mr Cross. "If you can swap your £400,000 terraced house in London for a detached or semi-detached home in Winchester, you're going to do it, aren't you?"

Elaine Stratford, sales director of Banner Homes, certainly believes you will. She says: "There is no doubt that the area from which people are prepared to commute has greatly expanded." There are plenty of commuters applying to buy Banner's properties in Winchester and Cambridge. The remaining two duplexes overlooking a courtyard in the company's Winchester development are selling from £264,950. Another development is planned soon.

Demand is high, says Ms Stratford. "The hunt for good schools is one factor that drives people to search for new areas to commute from," she says. "House-hunters in Winchester can buy into the rural element and send their children to a nice village primary school but still be in Waterloo in under an hour."

As well as having a thriving business community, East Anglia and Cambridge are attracting increasing numbers of London commuters in search of value for money. Stuart Chipchase of FPD Savills' Cambridge office says houses in the area are two-thirds of the price of the equivalent London home. "Buyers can get an old farmhouse with half to a couple of acres - not too big to mow - for the same price as some London terraces," says Mr Chipchase. The company is currently marketing a house on a hill, standing in 10 acres, for £950,000.

Residents of the villages around nearby Huntingdon can cycle leisurely to the station, jump on a train and be in King's Cross within an hour, he says.

But as any seasoned commuter hanging on until their arms are numb will testify, travelling long distances by train has its downside. Last year's figures show passengers experienced severe overcrowding on trains on routes run by four of the 10 train companies that serve the capital. Thameslink, Connex South Central, South West Trains and Chiltern all exceeded the guidelines for maximum numbers of passengers standing.

In some cases the problems were caused by the increase in the number of passengers following improvements to the services.

The train companies promise to keep pace with the increasing demand. As part of the upgrade of the west coast main line Virgin trains is cutting journey times on intercity services. Birmingham to London (currently 1 hour 30 minutes) will take only 1 hour and 10 minutes by 2005. Likewise Manchester to London (now 2 hours 30 minutes) will take only 1 hour and 50 minutes in five years' time.

Of course, making the decision to move out but continue working in London can be risky unless you have friends and family in the area. Some property websites can help with pre-move research. www.upmystreet.com provides local information including the cost of council tax, details of local schools and their league table results.

webTitle: Province greets the ceasefire warily after decades of violence

fields.headline: Province greets the ceasefire warily after decades of violence
fields.standfirst: Indonesia and East Timor: special report
fields.trailText: Euphoria was not the prevalent emotion in Aceh yesterday when the news filtered through that the Indonesian government and separatist rebels in the province had signed a three-month ceasefire.
fields.body:
Euphoria was not the prevalent emotion in Aceh yesterday when the news filtered through that the Indonesian government and separatist rebels in the province had signed a three-month ceasefire.

Even describing it as relief would be putting it too strongly. In the last two years there have been so many initiatives to end decades of conflict in north Sumatra that people have given up believing in anything smacking of peace.

"Everyone is hopeful and we've got nothing to lose by trying it," a human rights lawyer, Humam Hamid, said in the provincial capital, Banda Aceh. "But you should not underestimate the problems involved."

Topping the list is that neither the rebels nor the government have conceded ground on their key objectives.

Jakarta is determined to crush the rebels and ensure that Aceh does not follow East Timor down the road to independence, while the Free Aceh movement sees the current development as merely a stepping stone on its path to freedom.

Violence is part of everyday life for the 4.3m Acehnese. Murder, beatings, intimidation and house burnings continue unabated and no one expects a speedy restoration of law and order.

Analysts view the deal more as an opportunity to obtain answers to a multitude of nagging questions.

Are both sides really committed to peace? Are the Aceh-based separatists on the same wavelength as their counterparts in Malaysia? Who is the mysterious "third force" everyone has been blaming for the majority of violence in the last year?

Many believe that the rebels, who have been under severe military pressure in recent months, will merely use the break to regroup and rearm. The Indonesian military, which is still suffering for its continuing human rights abuses but is showing few signs of wanting to withdraw, is equally keen for a breather.

The Aceh deal should also illuminate the murky political scene in the Indonesian capital. This is becoming increasingly confused as the over-optimistic expectations of immediate stability and economic recovery that greeted the election of President Abdurrahman Wahid last October have been replaced by a grudging realisation that it will take years to implement fundamental reform.

Mr Wahid is facing hostile fire on several fronts. Doubts remain about his control over the once all-powerful military, even though he has removed the former armed forces chief, General Wiranto, and many of his closest allies.

Intensifying army operations in Indonesia's easternmost province, Irian Jaya, are the latest proof that elements of the military continue to pursue their own agendas in the sprawling archipelago.

Similar concerns exist about the respect the current armed forces chief, Admiral Widodo, commands among the upper echelons of the army.

Party political in-fighting has also taken its toll on Mr Wahid's compromise cabinet. The president recently dismissed two ministers for alleged corruption, which did not endear him to his vice-president, Megawati Sukarnoputri, as one of the sacked ministers was a senior lieutenant of hers.

Ms Megawati is often at loggerheads with Mr Wahid after failing to clinch the presidency, despite her party winning more parliamentary seats than any of its rivals.

Economic reform, or rather the lack of it, is proving the other major stumbling block. Mr Wahid used up what was seen as his last available excuse for not implementing promised major changes last month and the financial community has run out of patience. The rupiah is starting to slide again and the stock market is heading in the same direction.

But despite the bleak short-term outlook, few people predict total chaos or national disintegration.

"There is not going to be anarchy in the streets and the country is not going to fall apart," a western diplomat said yesterday. "The country will probably just continue to muddle through at the same level of ineptitude as it has for ages."

webTitle: Cardinal tells Catholics way to God is to line church's coffers

fields.headline: Cardinal tells Catholics way to God is to line church's coffers
fields.trailText: A leading contender to succeed the Pope has astounded theologians by insisting that poverty is a virtue - but not for the Catholic church.
fields.body:
A leading contender to succeed the Pope has astounded theologians by insisting that poverty is a virtue - but not for the Catholic church.

Cardinal Giacomo Biffi, 71, said Catholics should follow Christ's example of poverty by donating all their wealth to the church, which should, in turn, be exceedingly rich.

Bishops, priests and parishioners who feel queasy about the Vatican's stupendous wealth are suffering from a bourgeois guilt complex, according to the cardinal, whose comments have sent him charging headlong into an agonised 2,000-year-old debate.

Generations of hand-wringing over justifying Renaissance treasures, bank accounts and prime real estate would be swept away if conservatives succeeded in installing the cardinal as successor to the ailing Pope John Paul II.

The faithful should not be infected by the fretting of middle-class clergy, he said.

"That is a class that knows how to keep its own wealth and has all the best furniture in its homes but, to placate its guilt, proposes that the church should be more austere.

"Ordinary people are not attracted by this ideology," he said. "It's a bourgeois thing."

Christ may have been a carpenter with a frugal lifestyle who attacked money changers in the temple, but that was no reason for the church to renounce wealth, Cardinal Biffi said.

His denunciations of feminism, pacifism and gay rights have won the support of bureaucrats inside the Curia - the papal court and government - and conservative groups such as Opus Dei. Liberal critics concede only that he is intelligent.

The accumulation of church wealth, especially by popes, has been a sensitive subject, especially since Alexander VI's gloating at his election: "Now that we have the papacy, let us at least enjoy it."

But Cardinal Biffi insisted that true Catholics were entitled to regard the church's riches as their own to share. Speaking at an exhibition of sacred artworks in Bologna, where he is archbishop, the cardinal recalled how his father - a factory worker - had marvelled at the cathedral in Milan, adding: "That was our only wealth."

Two months ago he caused a minor sensation by saying the Antichrist was already on earth in the guise of a vegetarian philanthropist whose concern for human rights and the environment masked his desire to destroy Christianity.

His target appeared to be the substitution of causes such as ecology and humanitarian aid for Catholicism, rather than any individual.

Perhaps sensing a similar outcry to his latest pronouncement, he hinted he was not alone.

"This is my opinion. I don't know if it is also that of my colleagues. Perhaps yes, but they don't say it."

It was not the opinion of Nicholas Lash, a retired Cambridge theology professor.

"What utter nonsense. He's distinguishing between an abstract called the church and God's people, but there is nothing in scripture that makes that distinction.

"Ever since the letters of St Paul, poverty has been held up as an ideal we should aspire to."

Speaking at an exhibition of sacred artworks in Bologna, where he is archbishop, the cardinal recalled how his father - a factory worker - had marvelled at the cathedral in Milan, adding: "That was our only wealth." Two months ago he caused a minor sensation by saying the Antichrist was already on earth in the guise of a vegetarian philanthropist whose concern for human rights and the environment masked his desire to destroy Christianity. His target appeared to be the substitution of causes such as ecology and humanitarian aid for Catholicism, rather than any individual. Perhaps sensing a similar outcry to his latest pronouncement, he hinted he was not alone. "This is my opinion. I don't know if it is also that of my colleagues. Perhaps yes, but they don't say it." It was not the opinion of Nicholas Lash, a retired Cambridge theology professor. "What utter nonsense. He's distinguishing between an abstract called the church and God's people, but there is nothing in scripture that makes that distinction. "Ever since the letters of St Paul, poverty has been held up as an ideal we should aspire to."

webTitle: Germany's rustbelt seeks fresh start as voters head for the polls

fields.headline: Germany's rustbelt seeks fresh start as voters head for the polls
fields.trailText: Wuppertal is one of Germany's oldest industrial centres. It was the birthplace of Friedrich Engels and of Friedrich Bayer, the founder of the pharmaceutical empire. Even today, there are few places in the city from which you cannot see a tapering smokestack.
fields.body:
Wuppertal is one of Germany's oldest industrial centres. It was the birthplace of Friedrich Engels and of Friedrich Bayer, the founder of the pharmaceutical empire. Even today, there are few places in the city from which you cannot see a tapering smokestack.

Its 385,000 inhabitants represent a cross-section of the nearly 18m Germans who live in Europe's most populous administrative region, North Rhine-Westphalia.

Tomorrow, the voters of this archetypal "rustbelt" territory are to elect a new assembly and administration, after a campaign dominated by the issue of whether Germany can bring about the industrial rebirth so badly needed by cities such as Wuppertal.

Earlier this year, the federal government, led by the Social Democrats, said that it would offer thousands of special immigration permits to foreigners qualified to fill vacancies in the information technology sector. Most recruits are likely to come from India.

Jürgen Rüttgers, the Christian Democrat candidate to lead the administration in North Rhine-Westphalia, attacked the plans, reportedly saying that priority should be given to Kinder statt Inder -children instead of Indians.

His approach - he denied using the exact words - was denounced as racist by opponents, amid Europe-wide concern about the rise of Austria's extreme rightwing Freedom party under its former leader, Jörg Haider.

Mr Rüttgers, whose stance is unlikely to bring him victory in tomorrow's poll in a region which has been run by the Social Democrats for more than 30 years, has been branded a "Haider on the Rhine". But that is not how things look from Wuppertal, where he has raised an issue of concern.

"Here, the change from an industrial to a post-industrial economy has yet to be fully accomplished," said Michael-Georg von Wenczowsky, the Christian Democrat candidate for one of the city's three seats in the regional assembly.

Around 35% of Wuppertal's workers are still employed in traditional sectors such as textiles, chemicals, toolmaking and the manufacture of motor spares. "The textile industry is in rapid decline and the jobs that are being lost are going to have to be replaced," he said.

Wuppertal is a quirky place, whose inhabitants pride themselves on their sophisticated humour. The city claims the world's largest flea market, and boasts a suspended railway - the Schwebebahn - which still looks futuristic 100 years after its inauguration.

Christian Boros, who runs a local advertising firm, has a theory that the city is "so ugly that it encourages creativity". Whatever the reason, several hundred small new media enterprises have sprung up in Wuppertal - one of the reasons why, despite its problems, the local unemployment rate, at 11.1%, is only fractionally higher than the regional average.

But creating jobs is only half the battle - the people of Wuppertal and Germany's other rustbelt cities need to be qualified to fill them. Even the Social Democrat mayor of Wuppertal, Hans Kremendahl, agrees that there is a problem.

"It is twofold," he said. "The equipment of schools has got to be improved, though Wuppertal is in the lead within North Rhine-Westphalia because we have our own supplementary city programme. In addition though, a gap has got to be closed between the needs of industry and the quantity and quality of information technologists being produced."

For Esther Königes, who is setting up a subsidiary of Mr Boros's advertising company to create websites for firms, that gap is a daily preoccupation.

"We are starting to look for people, but we are finding it difficult," she said.

Though Wuppertal has an excellent university, with departments specialising in graphic design and computer science, in the increasingly crucial area of website creation, it has turned out graduates who are too specialised.

"It is very difficult to find generalists. You can find designers and programmers, but not people who can put it all together," said Ms Königes. "I am sure that these people can do a good job for, say, Siemens. But what Germany needs is new ideas to develop new business."

When the government first announced its initiative to bring in IT specialists, a magazine asked on its cover: "Are Germans too stupid for computers?" The question is, of course, absurd: in the south of the country, particularly, Germans have been running a successful, computer-based economy since the 1980s.

But the struggle for power in what was once Germany's industrial heartland has highlighted the issue of whether the country's highly structured, rigorously planned but often inflexible way of doing things might not be inimical to the latest technologies.

webTitle: Jakarta and Aceh rebels sign truce

fields.headline: Jakarta and Aceh rebels sign truce
fields.standfirst: Indonesia and East Timor: special report
fields.trailText: The Indonesian government and separatist rebels yesterday signed a three-month ceasefire aimed at ending more than two decades of violence in the resource-rich north-western Aceh province.
fields.body:
The Indonesian government and separatist rebels yesterday signed a three-month ceasefire aimed at ending more than two decades of violence in the resource-rich north-western Aceh province.

But while both sides welcomed the deal as a key step towards peace in north Sumatra, the rebels vowed to continue their push for independence, and Jakarta ruled out recognition for the separatists.

The government said the truce, signed in Geneva, would begin on June 2 and would be regularly reviewed.

"This joint understanding is an early step of a hundred-step journey in the efforts to find a final solution to the Aceh problem," Indonesia's ambassador to the United Nations in Geneva, Hassan Wirajuda, said in a statement after signing the deal with the Free Aceh movement's health minister, Zaini Abdullah.

The rebels said that their goal remained independence.

"The meetings in Geneva to stop the violence in Aceh... do not mean that the Free Aceh movement is becoming weaker in its struggle for the independence of Aceh, the rebels said in a statement. "The commitments to achieve its solemn goal remain intact."

The deal followed repeated assertions by Indonesia's president, Abdurrahman Wahid, that the government would not bow to the rebels' demand for independence.

"This deal is called a humanitarian pause. So there is no business about giving recognition to anyone by anyone," Mr Wahid said before the ceasefire was signed.

He is giving the provinces more autonomy and a greater share of their own wealth in an effort to appease anti-Jakarta feelings. Demands for an East Timor-style independence ballot are mounting in Aceh, fuelled by widespread human rights abuses by soldiers and police and resentment at what is seen as Jakarta siphoning off Aceh's resources.

Violence this month has killed dozens and destroyed hundreds of homes in Aceh province.

Reuters

fields.headline: Berlin minister's federal EU vision
fields.trailText: Germany must work with France to bring about political integration in Europe and push through enlargement of the EU, the foreign minister, Joschka Fischer, said yesterday.
fields.body:
Germany must work with France to bring about political integration in Europe and push through enlargement of the EU, the foreign minister, Joschka Fischer, said yesterday.

Mr Fischer said that Europe needed Berlin and Paris to work more closely together - a clear response to recent criticism that the old motor of the EU has sputtered and died.

"One thing is sure. Without the closest German-French co-operation, no future European project will succeed," Mr Fischer said

A passionate integrationist, he said he was aware that his "personal vision" might provoke Eurosceptic headlines, particularly in Britain, but his ideas were a long-term view that nobody should fear.

Britain's Conservatives reacted on cue. "Joschka Fischer has spectacularly blown the lid off Europe's superstate agenda," said Francis Maude, the shadow foreign secretary. "Unlike Tony Blair, Fischer is honest about the direction in which Europe is heading." Michael Portillo, the shadow chancellor, said the speech was "further proof that the vast majority of politicians in Europe want EMU [European monetary union] to lead to full political union and a new country called Europe."

Mr Fischer also suggested that if a majority of EU states did not agree to the founding of a European federation, then a smaller core group of europhile countries could lead the way.

British officials say they fear France will use its forthcoming EU presidency, starting in July, to seek to work more closely with Germany.

London already feels excluded from the euro-11 group of finance ministers who participate in the single currency.

Mr Fischer told an audience at Humboldt University that the first step towards a federal Europe would be closer cooperation between the euro-zone countries, particularly in economic policy.

He added that while his vision would eventually require a new constitution and direct elections for a European government, a federal Europe should not mean abandoning the nation state.

"Even in the ultimate federal model, the nation state, with its cultural and democratic traditions, will be irreplaceable in order to have a union of citizens and states that wins public legitimacy," he said.

"I say this with one eye on our friends in Britain, because I know that the word federation irritates many Britons. But I can find no other word. It shouldn't irritate anybody."

Mr Fischer said that Berlin wanted the EU to complete urgently needed internal reforms to allow the speedy admission of countries from central and eastern Europe.

Poland, the largest of the candidate countries, is concerned that the timetable for accession is slipping.

fields.headline: Word play
fields.trailText: Matthew Engel (Standing up against the unspeakable, May 9) articulated the disgust many of us feel about imported Americanisms (without mentioning two of the worst offenders, "regular" and "fries", which, of course, are often uttered in the same sentence).
fields.body:
Matthew Engel (Standing up against the unspeakable, May 9) articulated the disgust many of us feel about imported Americanisms (without mentioning two of the worst offenders, "regular" and "fries", which, of course, are often uttered in the same sentence).

He points out that "rookie" would "never ever be spoken in any British conversation". I might add that you never hear anyone saying that they are just going down to the "store" for a pint of milk, or that something or other should be "curbed".
Jim Grozier,
Brighton

 In response to your article about intimate messages sent by email (Our emails met across a crowded room, May 11), I was once told by a female acquaintance that she found that men who wrote well made love well.

She particularly admired men who could handle long sentences successfully, since it often demonstrated they could sustain something over a long period of time and still reach a successful conclusion. I have attempted ever since to cultivate this skill, whether with pen or email.
AJ Martins,
Norwich
adrianmartins@hotmail.com

 How much longer can the political parties keep their present names? Blairite Labour cannot keep calling itself "new" because it is getting "old", and the Liberal Democrats could become the Democratic party. The Tories can call themselves whatever they like -I have a name for them, but it not printable.
H Lawless,
Huddersfield

fields.headline: Return of the repressed
fields.trailText: An unfortunate corollary of the increased tolerance of pornography (ie the erotica of one's intellectual inferiors), of which Jonathan Freedland complains (Comment, May 10), is the parallel increase in pompous sermonising.
fields.body:
An unfortunate corollary of the increased tolerance of pornography (ie the erotica of one's intellectual inferiors), of which Jonathan Freedland complains (Comment, May 10), is the parallel increase in pompous sermonising.

Mr Freedland tells us that sex "should be a private, even spiritual part of the human experience". Does he consider the spiritual aspect of the Goldberg Variations to be impaired by their being performed at the Wigmore Hall? After all, we know that Bach created the work for two people in a bedroom - Goldberg playing for Kayserling.

It's a waste of time trying to persuade the rest of us that visual excitement is not exciting, and that true connoisseurs of erotica read The Song of Solomon or, if feeling really naughty, those exchanges between Miss Bennett and Mr Darcy one always felt should have been printed in Latin for the protection of one's wife or servants.
Robin Dow,
Sheffield

 So repression still rules in Cool Britannia! Congratulations Delia Morris (Letters, May 12), another person on the brink of adolescence believing sex is dirty, shameful and guilt-ridden. At least your son won't come home pregnant in a few years because he was too ashamed and frightened to tell you he didn't have a clue.
Louise Chase,
Croydon

fields.headline: Tate of things to come
fields.trailText: Reporting the opening of Tate Modern (Tate and style, May 12) you quote a contemporary sculptor who welcomes "... a great tempest of cultural energy which will blow away all the old certainties, all the traditional hierarchy of law, money and God".
fields.body:
Reporting the opening of Tate Modern (Tate and style, May 12) you quote a contemporary sculptor who welcomes "... a great tempest of cultural energy which will blow away all the old certainties, all the traditional hierarchy of law, money and God".

But it seems the gallery is happy to have its place in the hierarchy of public institutions registered by the presence of the Queen, while as for law, "... the streets outside were peppered with police officers reportedly anxious about the threat of anarchist protests". As for money, modern art is clearly very expensive. And as for God, who can say?
Donald Fairhall ,
Derby

 The prime minister has not "suddenly developed an interest in art" and Tate Modern (Diary, May 12). The government's support for the project has been crucial - granting Tate additional annual subsidy of £6m so that the gallery can be free for everyone.

Mr Blair has also shown considerable personal interest in the project, making time in his busy schedule to contribute to a video which helped the gallery raise interest and funding from abroad.

Tate's trustees were delighted that the Queen accepted their invitation to open Tate Modern, a building that she visited in 1962 when it was still Bankside power station. The prime minister neither asked for nor was given a private tour of the gallery prior to its opening. The fact that he agreed to attend the launch party gave tremendous pleasure to all those involved with the project.
Nicholas Serota,
Director,
Tate Gallery

fields.headline: Dome down
fields.trailText: Giving the Millennium Dome a further tranche of money will be throwing good money after bad (Dome asks for extra cash - again, May 12).
fields.body:
Giving the Millennium Dome a further tranche of money will be throwing good money after bad (Dome asks for extra cash - again, May 12).

Writing as a chair of school governors, in an area which has housing deprivation and a government-led underfunding (by both parties) of education and housing, I can tell you that just 1% of the money thrown at the dome could have helped my school and its environs far more to celebrate the millennium and make a positive statement for the future than the "tent" in Greenwich will ever do.

The same benefits could have been extended throughout the country - benefits extending long after the dome has outlived its usefulness. Enough is enough - close it now and spend the money more wisely.
Liz Rorison,
London

fields.headline: Out of the picture
fields.trailText: Your comment (Leader, May 11) that the BMA is backtracking on revalidation is totally incorrect.
fields.body:
Your comment (Leader, May 11) that the BMA is backtracking on revalidation is totally incorrect. The medical profession as a whole fully supports revalidation and the idea that doctors must be able to show they remain competent to practise.

Back in 1994, our conference of GPs called for a system of revalidation to be introduced. We are now working hard with the royal colleges to produce acceptable systems.

Our concern is that procedures must be simple enough to be workable. We would like to see a system of revalidation under way next year.
Dr Ian Bogle
Chairman of council, British Medical Association

fields.headline: The wrong diagnosis
fields.trailText: However tragic the individual case, the issue of Mr Harley's cancer (Doctors told to listen, May 12) is not one of how or why the doctors "got it wrong". It is that there is an unrealistically high expectation that doctors will get it right every time.
fields.body:
However tragic the individual case, the issue of Mr Harley's cancer (Doctors told to listen, May 12) is not one of how or why the doctors "got it wrong". It is that there is an unrealistically high expectation that doctors will get it right every time.

Not all diseases have symptoms, not all symptoms relate to diseases and any symptom has a number of causes. "Diagnostic" tests can be falsely negative or falsely positive.

The experience Mr Harley demonstrates this - from what I've read, he was taken seriously and was repeatedly re-examined and reinvestigated by experts.

Ultimately, as a doctor, you have to weigh up the odds and make an educated guess. We can't get it right every time. We do our best, but in the end, doctors are human. And even if we get the correct diagnosis, it doesn't necessarily follow that you will live longer or suffer less as a result.
Dr Ben Fox,
Northwick Park Hospital, Harrow

 It is sad that the poor doctors never seem to get a chance to give their point of view. Perhaps they are all too demoralised, jaded and tired. Successive governments are too ready to condemn inefficiency within the NHS rather than address the real problem, which is gross underfunding for many years.

When GPs are consulting at a rate of one every 7-10 minutes and seeing in excess of 40 patients a day, it is no surprise that there isn't much time to get every diagnosis correct. The same is true of hospital out-patient consultations - simply not enough time to be a human being and treat the patients simillarly. The equation is simple: too many patients and not enough carers, which requires a lot more money.

Give a thought to those dedicated carers within the NHS who are working all hours trying to provide some kind of service despite the most enormous pressures. No one is infallible. Let us look behind the tragic scenarios we see on our screens and ask, is it really the doctors who are to blame, or is it the system they have had to work under for so many years?
Anthony Walker,
Bristol

 The comments of the chief executive of Barnsley district hospital will give hope and inspiration to all patients. They can be assured they will receive exactly the same care and attention that Steve Harley received, as well as the understanding of managers about the impact of throat cancer. If they are still able to talk, they can also nip along to their GP for a friendly chat. It beggars belief.
Pat Carthy,
Salisbury

fields.headline: We don't admit snobbery
fields.trailText: Mr Blunkett's rant at admissions tutors (Blunkett rounds on 'snobbish' universities, May 11) betrays the poverty of thought in the upper echelons of government.
fields.body:
Mr Blunkett's rant at admissions tutors (Blunkett rounds on 'snobbish' universities, May 11) betrays the poverty of thought in the upper echelons of government. I am an admissions tutor, involved in a selection process that is informed; based on the assessment of individuals as individuals; and one that attempts to be completely fair to all of the high-calibre individuals who care to apply. At my own college, an individual's chance of success is exactly the same - irrespective of their gender, background, social class, accent, or whatever.

It is sad and deeply insulting for Mr Blunkett to suggest that snobbery plays any role in university selection. Even more sad is that he appears unaware that it is his own government - through the introduction of tuition fees and the severance of the final vestiges of state support for student maintenance - that has reversed recent and continuing efforts to broaden access to higher education.
Dr David Pyle,
St Catharine's College, Cambridge
dmp11@esc.cam.ac.uk

 The secretary of state misses the point when he asserts that the social background of admissions tutors is prejudicing the chances of working-class students entering university. Our research shows that applicants from the immediate areas surrounding this university (which are largely working-class) have practically the same chance of receiving an offer for entry as students from high-income families and middle-class suburban areas. Our difficulty is persuading the brightest working class students to apply to us in the first place and to accept our offers. This is where we aim to have impact with our aspiration-raising work and summer school.

(I am from an ex-mining town near Barnsley, educated at the local comprehensive and FE college, and a Durham graduate.)
Richard Taylor,
Head of schools liaison, University of Durham
R.S.Taylor@durham.ac.uk

 There is one simple reason why I and many other working-class children of my generation were able to attend university. We received mandatory local authority grants that were sufficient to enable us to live without the need for economic support from our parents. If Mr Blunkett seriously wishes to see an increase in the number of working-class children entering universities, he should reflect on that instead of conjuring up silly fantasies about snobbish admissions officers.
Dr Dave King,
University of Liverpool
d.king@liverpool.ac.uk

 The publicity over the introduction of tuition fees masked the even more damaging abolition of maintenance grants. It is becoming very rare for my students to go anywhere other than their home town universities. £1,000 bursaries may be a help, Mr Blunkett, but do you know it costs around £6,500 to keep a student at university for 30 weeks?

Being in the first cohort of parents to pay two lots of tuition fees, I therefore need to earn around £21,000 gross just to finance their education. Luckily I earn more than the average wage and can therefore send my comprehensive-school educated daughters to "snobbish" universities. A large proportion of my students are not so fortunate. The changes were sold as funding an expansion in higher education. Sadly this means making it more difficult for working-class students to attend "top" universities.
Geoff Poole ,
Prescot, Merseyside
Gpoole@btinternet.com

 Isn't this the same Mr Blunkett who, only the other day, was blaming the poor performance of the poor on failing teachers and failing schools?
James Murphy,
University of Lancaster
j.murphy@lancaster.ac.uk

fields.headline: Deportation reprieve for hunger striker
fields.standfirst: Refugees in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: The Home Office has held off deporting an Iranian asylum seeker who has been on hunger strike for more than a month in Rochester prison, Kent, it was announced last night.
fields.body:
The Home Office has held off deporting an Iranian asylum seeker who has been on hunger strike for more than a month in Rochester prison, Kent, it was announced last night.

He was to be sent back to Germany on Monday, despite a protest by a charity supporting victims of torture that has called for his release.

A court application for the man, who has not been named, to be released on bail was rejected yesterday after he was certified by hospital doctors as fit to travel.

But the Medical Foundation for the Care of Victims of Torture said the man was showing signs of shellshock and severe depression, and that ministers should reconsider his case.

The charity's director, Helen Bamber, said it would be inhumane for him to remain in detention or be deported.

The man's lawyer, Kash Beh bahani, said yesterday that his client had told him he would rather die than be sent back to Germany, where he believed he would be deported to Iran.

The man has been on hunger strike for more than 39 days, and was transferred for a second time to Medway Maritime hospital.

The immigration authorities said he should be sent back to Germany on "safe third country" grounds. He had fled from Iran via Germany, and that was where his asylum application should be decided.

His removal is believed to have been postponed after the German authorities requested more information about his medical condition.

Doctors acting for the medical foundation believe he is in a highly disturbed state and unfit to travel.

A second Iranian is also in hospital after going on hunger strike more than 30 days ago at Rochester prison.

fields.headline: Warning shots
fields.standfirst:
Royal Armouries exhibits art of violence

Gun violence in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: The Royal Armouries is to court controversy with an exhibition of the art of violence, portraying shootings, real and simulated deaths, and a gun club for children as young as eight which was disbanded after the Dunblane massacre.
fields.body:
The Royal Armouries is to court controversy with an exhibition of the art of violence, portraying shootings, real and simulated deaths, and a gun club for children as young as eight which was disbanded after the Dunblane massacre.

The "deliberately provocative" collection of paintings and video installations marks a new development for the Leeds museum, whose trustees are also considering reducing the entrance charge to £1 a head to stimulate visitor numbers.

Museum experts have collaborated with the Contemporary Art Society to build a "disturbing" collection of artwork on the use and perceptions of violence. The exhibition, entitled Warning Shots, will show 22 unrestrained pieces over four months, starting in June.

Vaughan Allen, curator of the exhibition which includes a soundtrack of gunfire and photographs of victims of the Balkan war, said: "We live in violent times. Our minds are fed with a constant barrage of horror. The damage must be immeasurable."

Two of the exhibits evoke deliberate memories of Dunblane, which overshadowed the royal opening of the £43.5m armouries in March 1996, the day after the tragedy.

The Quickening, the Lightening, the Crowning by Christine Borland, who was shortlisted for the 1997 Turner Prize, overlays foetal heartbeats with shots from pistols handed in during the post-Dunblane amnesty.

A continuous film loop called Strip, by the video artist Monika Oechsler, will show girls aged eight to 14 stripping down and reassembling handguns in the only British gun club licensed to give membership to such young children. Disbanded due to post-Dunblane legislation, the club's activities are set to an endlessly repeated nursery rhyme.

Other exhibits pursuing the theme include a young child with a gun, and pictures of weapons which another artist, Graham Fagen, claims to have made as a boy, including a petrol bomb and a crossbow.

The armouries acknowl edged yesterday that the exhibition was likely to meet with criticism, and visitors will be given written warnings that they may find some of the images upsetting. But the master of the armouries, Guy Wilson, said the subject was central to the museum's academic work.

"It is part of an innovative approach we are taking to covering all aspects of our subject, arms and armour," he said.

fields.headline: Antun Bauer
fields.trailText: Perhaps the greatest achievement of the great collector Antun Bauer, who has died aged 88, was the founding of   the museum documentation centre in Zagreb in 1955, where the contents of Croatia's museums were recorded. The value of this was proved in the past decade when so many of the country's museums were bombed and had to assess their losses.
fields.body:
Perhaps the greatest achievement of the great collector Antun Bauer, who has died aged 88, was the founding of the museum documentation centre in Zagreb in 1955, where the contents of Croatia's museums were recorded. The value of this was proved in the past decade when so many of the country's museums were bombed and had to assess their losses.

Bauer was the founder of modern museology in Croatia. The museums he founded, and sometimes furnished through gifts from his own collections, are now his memorial. His fields included numismatics and the ethnography of his native country, but his most important treasures, the "Bauer Collections" of more than 1,300 works of 19th and 20th century Croatian artists, were donated to the town museum of Vukovar in 1941. During the Balkans conflict these, and the building's other contents, were carried off by the Yugoslav army to Belgrade where, despite interventions from the United Nations's cultural body Unesco, and the Council of Europe, they remain.

Bauer was born in Vukovar, and after a degree in the history of art and archaeology, took a doctorate at Zagreb University. He entered the museum world in 1931 and rose to be the founder/director of Zagreb's Gipsoteka (the museum of casts of works of sculpture and architecture). He also became director of the Croatian school museum, and of his museum documentation centre (1955-78). He founded a postgraduate museology course at Zagreb University, developed the artists archive register and the civic art gallery of Osijek, and helped organise the Croatian academy of arts and sciences' archives.

The professor took part in many archaeological explorations, especially around Osijek, Vukovar and llok, and was responsible for the discovery of the prehistoric "Vucedol Dove", a vessel in the emblematic form of a dove, found at Vucedol (Vukovar). He contributed to Croatian and international journals and lectured regularly at European universities.

Bauer will also be remembered with gratitude in Croatia for an act of personal heroism, the rescue and preservation of the Austrian sculptor Anton Dominik Fernkorn's 19th century bronze equestrian portrait statue of Ban Josip Jelacic.

The monument, installed in Zagreb's main square in 1866, was dismantled by the new communist regime in 1947, but under cover of night Bauer took the parts away and concealed them in the Gipsoteka. In 1990, on the brink of Croatia's declaration of independence, the equestrian group was restored to its original site.

 Antun Bauer, museologist and collector, born April 18 1911; died April 9 2000

fields.headline: Sidney Hutchison
fields.standfirst: A carpenter's son whose love of art led to half a century of outstanding work for the Royal Academy
fields.trailText: Sidney Hutchison, who has died aged 88, was a key figure in the art world, where his influence will continue to be felt. He worked for the Royal Academy for 52 years and his time as its secretary, 1968-82, was a crucial period for the institution he was passionate about.
fields.body:
Sidney Hutchison, who has died aged 88, was a key figure in the art world, where his influence will continue to be felt. He worked for the Royal Academy for 52 years and his time as its secretary, 1968-82, was a crucial period for the institution he was passionate about.

He commanded respect for what he did, but was also loved for his own qualities. He was honest in a way rare today and, if that meant being blunt, sensible men listened. Equally he was persistent and many of those who had first disagreed with him, in the end came round.

Hutchison's years as secretary of the RA coincided with its changing almost beyond recognition. Raising vast sums of money became an obsession; in the process the Academy nearly lost its soul. That it did not wholly do so was, in considerable measure, thanks to him.

Sadly, since he retired as secretary, the Academy's once magisterial place in the life of the nation and its role in shaping the visual arts have both declined. The high principles of the RA's first president, Sir Joshua Reynolds, have too often been forgotten. Hutchison was never guilty of that.

His values were recorded in his The History of the Royal Academy (1968), the standard work on the subject, which was enlarged and updated in 1986. Its central lesson has to do with the role of the RA in the life of the nation and, just as surely, with the possibility of the arts exerting a benign influence.

Because he understood these things can be complementary, Hutchison had an enormously fruitful relationship with the RA's last great president, Sir Thomas Monnington. Good art in the summer exhibition; a superb series of loan exhibitions; and academy banquets at which the great and the good mingled - rather than, as has too often been the case in recent years, the great and the ambitious - were the tangible indications of a flourishing institution.

It will need a history as balanced as his own to establish how much Hutchison, who received honours from here and other European countries, had to do with those good years.

His achievements were remarkable for a man whose father was a London carpenter and whose mother died when he was a month old. Very early though, Sidney showed his mettle at Holloway school, displaying a deep feeling for music; from 1933 to 1937 he was organist and choirmaster of St Matthew's, Westminster.

When the second world war began, he entered the Royal Navy and finished up as a lieutenant-commander; he was in charge of one of the first detachments to retake Hong Kong in 1945. These years left their mark on him. They stood him in good stead when, in 1946, he went back to the RA, which he had joined when only 17.

Hutchison was a little man who combined the qualities of the cockney with the authority of a naval officer. He knew all about good housekeeping. Indeed, beside running the RA so well, he was a general commissioner of taxes (1972-87), a governor of Holloway school (1969-81), and served on many committees and funds ranging from being a trustee of the Chantrey Bequest to president of the Southgate Society of Arts.

At the same time, at the RA he was responsible for organising exhibitions as memorable as those devoted to Pompeii, The Horses of San Marco and the 1981-82 exhibition of Japanese art.

Incisiveness and a quick, determined manner was combined with patent sincerity. Hutchison peering directly through his thick-rimmed glasses inspired confidence. That he was shrewd and efficient was obvious, but everyone soon discovered that he was also fair and kind.

Nor should it be forgotten how from 1949 until 1968, when he became secretary, he was also the RA's librarian. It was in recognition of the work he did then, besides his history of the RA and his other publications, including articles for the Walpole Society, the Museums Journal and the Dictionary of National Biography, that in 1955 he was made a fellow of the Society of Antiquaries.

His wife Nan, whom he married in 1937, and who died in 1985, was particularly proud of the fact. She was right. In electing Sidney Hutchison as a fellow, the Antiquaries were recognising his special combination of scholarship, efficiency, decency and a lifelong desire to defend values. What was so remarkable was that these qualities were exercised by a man who was also a splendid storyteller and knew how to influence others.

 Sidney Charles Hutchison, art historian and administrator, born March 26 1912; died April 22 2000

His values were recorded in his The History of the Royal Academy (1968), the standard work on the subject, which was enlarged and updated in 1986. Its central lesson has to do with the role of the RA in the life of the nation and, just as surely, with the possibility of the arts exerting a benign influence. Because he understood these things can be complementary, Hutchison had an enormously fruitful relationship with the RA's last great president, Sir Thomas Monnington. Good art in the summer exhibition; a superb series of loan exhibitions; and academy banquets at which the great and the good mingled - rather than, as has too often been the case in recent years, the great and the ambitious - were the tangible indications of a flourishing institution. It will need a history as balanced as his own to establish how much Hutchison, who received honours from here and other European countries, had to do with those good years. His achievements were remarkable for a man whose father was a London carpenter and whose mother died when he was a month old. Very early though, Sidney showed his mettle at Holloway school, displaying a deep feeling for music; from 1933 to 1937 he was organist and choirmaster of St Matthew's, Westminster. When the second world war began, he entered the Royal Navy and finished up as a lieutenant-commander; he was in charge of one of the first detachments to retake Hong Kong in 1945. These years left their mark on him. They stood him in good stead when, in 1946, he went back to the RA, which he had joined when only 17. Hutchison was a little man who combined the qualities of the cockney with the authority of a naval officer. He knew all about good housekeeping. Indeed, beside running the RA so well, he was a general commissioner of taxes (1972-87), a governor of Holloway school (1969-81), and served on many committees and funds ranging from being a trustee of the Chantrey Bequest to president of the Southgate Society of Arts. At the same time, at the RA he was responsible for organising exhibitions as memorable as those devoted to Pompeii, The Horses of San Marco and the 1981-82 exhibition of Japanese art. Incisiveness and a quick, determined manner was combined with patent sincerity. Hutchison peering directly through his thick-rimmed glasses inspired confidence. That he was shrewd and efficient was obvious, but everyone soon discovered that he was also fair and kind. Nor should it be forgotten how from 1949 until 1968, when he became secretary, he was also the RA's librarian. It was in recognition of the work he did then, besides his history of the RA and his other publications, including articles for the Walpole Society, the Museums Journal and the Dictionary of National Biography, that in 1955 he was made a fellow of the Society of Antiquaries. His wife Nan, whom he married in 1937, and who died in 1985, was particularly proud of the fact. She was right. In electing Sidney Hutchison as a fellow, the Antiquaries were recognising his special combination of scholarship, efficiency, decency and a lifelong desire to defend values. What was so remarkable was that these qualities were exercised by a man who was also a splendid storyteller and knew how to influence others.  Sidney Charles Hutchison, art historian and administrator, born March 26 1912; died April 22 2000

fields.headline: Bearded Lady
fields.standfirst: 'Sordid' Lowry work for sale
fields.trailText: The painting shows a woman with a beard - "an able and intelligent woman, completely alone and isolated behind her deformity," noted the artist LS Lowry.
fields.body:
The painting shows a woman with a beard - "an able and intelligent woman, completely alone and isolated behind her deformity," noted the artist LS Lowry.

There was, he added, "no way of reaching her". He felt compassion for her. But he still painted her, though he admitted that people he knew felt this was sordid.

"But I am very fond of sordid pictures," he told his friend, the Southport businessman Monty Bloom. "You are, too, very fond of them."

Yesterday it emerged that the art world, and its buyers and investors, is also very fond of them. Lowry's The Bearded Lady, done from a sketch made with some embarrassment and shame on a train journey from Manchester to Paddington, is rated as "the star lot" by the auctioneers, Christie's, at a London sale next month.

It is estimated to fetch £200,000 to £300,000 for Bloom's heirs in a sale of part of the world's largest Lowry collection, which Bloom amassed through his bond with the solitary artist.

Bloom once bought six "sordid" Lowrys for £90.

In his account of the journey to London, Lowry, who was 70 at the time, told him: "She had a very nice face and quite a long beard.

"Well sir, I just couldn't let such an opportunity pass, so I began almost at once to make a little drawing of her on a piece of paper.

"She was sitting right opposite me. After a while, she asked, rather nervously, what I was doing. I blushed like a Dublin Bay prawn and showed her my sketch - the one from which I later made my painting of her.

"At first she was greatly troubled. But we talked and by the time the train had reached Paddington we were the best of friends. We even shook hands on the platform."

Lowry, a recluse who called even those he knew well "sir", felt an echo of his own loneliness in the woman.

Their train trip was in 1957, when little treatment existed for unsightly hair growths, decades before their removal became a multi-billion pound drug and cosmetic industry.

The condition is often caused by excess male hormones in the body or through taking steroids and sometimes by polycystic ovaries, birth control pills or a disorder of the adrenal gland.

The painting is one of 20 Lowrys from Bloom's collection expected to fetch a total of up to £1.3m on June 9.

webTitle: Doctor's family gets £1m in asbestos case

fields.headline: Doctor's family gets £1m in asbestos case
fields.trailText: The family of a plastic surgeon who died of an asbestos-linked lung disease more than 20 years after he unwittingly inhaled blue asbestos dust in hospital corridors had a £1.15m settlement approved at the high court yesterday.
fields.body:
The family of a plastic surgeon who died of an asbestos-linked lung disease more than 20 years after he unwittingly inhaled blue asbestos dust in hospital corridors had a £1.15m settlement approved at the high court yesterday.

James Emerson, a consultant at the Northern general hospital in Sheffield, was 47 when he died of mesothelioma in August 1995.

He had contracted the disease from exposure to asbestos when he was a medical student at the Middlesex hospital in London between 1966 and 1970, and a junior doctor there in 1972-73.

When Mr Emerson - who left a widow, Vanessa, and three daughters, Isabel, Lydia and Jessica, now 17, 15 and 10 - became ill he was at a loss to know where he had been exposed to the killer dust.

Investigations brought to light a Guardian article written in 1977 which stated that "parts of the underground area of one of London's major teaching hospitals, the Middlesex, have been closed down, and the stores kept there removed and decontaminated, because of the presence of blue asbestos in pipe lagging".

Under the hospital were underground passages carrying a network of cables and pipes covered with asbestos lagging.

The passages were used by staff and students to travel between buildings, especially the main hospital and the medical school.

Evidence from witnesses collected by the family's lawyers, Irwin Mitchell, confirmed that at the time some of the pipes had been lagged with asbestos insulation material and that the lagging was in poor repair and had been damaged in parts by passing trolleys.

Mr Emerson remembered that he had walked through the passages several times a day.

His lawyers argued that the predecessor of Camden and Islington health authority, which employed Mr Emerson, should have known by 1966 that even low levels of exposure to asbestos could cause mesothelioma. But the health authority only started to consider the safety implications around 1977.

Shortly before the case was due to go to trial in November 1998, Camden and Islington admitted liability.

Mrs Emerson, a 49-year-old GP who lives in Sheffield with her daughters, was at the high court in London yesterday to hear her counsel, Andrew Spink, tell Mr Justice Eady that her husband had been a notable and very successful surgeon.

Approving the settlement, the judge said it was a tragic case and Mr Emerson had died at the height of his career.

He noted that Mr Emerson's three daughters were thriving and doing well at school, due to the devoted care of their mother.

fields.headline: Lewis Allen
fields.standfirst: British director who forged a new career in television after a mixed bag of Hollywood movies
fields.trailText: It is 41 years since Lewis Allen, who has died aged 94, directed his last feature film; after that he disappeared into television at a time when the traffic was mostly the other way. His name probably rang a few bells when it came up on the small screen after "anonymously" directed episodes of The Big Valley, Perry Mason, The Fugitive, Mission Impossible and Bonanza.
fields.body:
It is 41 years since Lewis Allen, who has died aged 94, directed his last feature film; after that he disappeared into television at a time when the traffic was mostly the other way. His name probably rang a few bells when it came up on the small screen after "anonymously" directed episodes of The Big Valley, Perry Mason, The Fugitive, Mission Impossible and Bonanza.

Yet it was the same Lewis Allen who made several interesting films in the 1940s and 1950s, including a number of shockers, in both senses of the word. His first feature, and arguably his best, was The Uninvited (1943), a supernatural thriller about a brother (Ray Milland) and sister (Ruth Hussey) who rent a haunted house on the Cornish coast and get a young medium (Gail Russell) to exorcise the spirit. Allen brilliantly creates an intangible presence of evil, effectively suggesting horror rather than depicting it. The critic James Agee wrote: "It seems to me harder to get a fright than a laugh, and I experienced 35 first-class jolts, not to mention a well-calculated texture of minor frissons." The Uninvited was that rare species, a serious Hollywood ghost movie, rather than the usual comic thriller. It also had a haunting hit theme song, Stella by Starlight.

Two years later, Allen tried to repeat its success with another old-dark-house picture, The Unseen, again starring the dark-haired beauty Gail Russell. Unfortunately, the film was haunted by its predecessor, and the title described its fate.

There followed a few movies in which Allen displayed a lighter touch, such as Those Endearing Young Charms (1945), a wartime romance that depended on the charms of Laraine Day and Robert Young. But, of all Allen's films, the most interesting and the most preposterous was Desert Fury (1947), in which there is more than a hint of homosexuality. In this garishly Technicolored melodrama, Lizabeth Scott falls for gambler John Hodiak, who is obsessed by her mother (Mary Astor, at her vixenish best), while his sidekick (Wendell Corey) is obsessed by him.

Allen shot his next film, So Evil My Love (1948), starring Ray Milland and based on a Victorian murder case, in England, the country of his birth.

Allen was a Shropshire lad, the son of a clothing manufacturer. After serving four years in the British Merchant Service, he became an actor and then a theatrical manager, first for Raymond Massey and then for the Gilbert Miller Organisation. He eventually took to directing plays in London and New York, including the first US production of JB Priestley's I Have Been Here Before (1938).

In 1941, after directing a London production of The Women, Clare Boothe's all- female play of love and bitchery, he settled in Los Angeles, where Paramount put him under contract, allowing him to become an apprentice film director for three years before The Uninvited.

Most of his 18 pictures were made for Paramount, two of which featured the studio's resident star Alan Ladd, in conventional heroic mode in Chicago Deadline (1949) and Appointment with Danger (1951), the latter co-starring Phyllis Calvert as a nun, in one of her very few Hollywood roles.

One of Allen's absolute duds was Valentino (1951), which was even more fictionalised than Ken Russell's 1977 version of the life of the supreme Latin lover of the silent screen. Not only was it shaky on period detail, but Anthony Dexter, who was chosen from 2,000 actors, while bearing a resemblance to the star, had no charisma, and had to utter lines such as: "Love is a language spoken by the heart not the tongue."

Allen's talent was better displayed in Suddenly (1954), with Frank Sinatra playing a cold-blooded psychopathic killer hired to assassinate the US president as he is passing through a sleepy Californian town. Allen kept the tension mounting until the believ able but predictable climax. Because of the subject, the film was withdrawn from US screens for some years after the Kennedy assassination.

For A Bullet for Joey (1955), Allen brought two of the cinema's most notorious gangsters face to face. However, Edward G Robinson was on the side of the law this time, while George Raft gave his well-worn interpretation of a tough guy. But both stars were past their best; the only unfamiliar thing about the film was the Canadian setting.

For his penultimate movie, Allen returned to Cornwall, the setting of his first triumph, with Another Time, Another Place (1958), this time actually filmed on location. It starred an overwrought Lana Turner suffering a nervous breakdown after her married lover (Sean Connery) is killed. Television claimed Allen after Whirlpool (1959), a made-in-Germany drama with Juliette Greco, then at her peak.

Allen, whose first wife Dorothy Skinner, a London literary agent, died in 1969, is survived by his second wife, Trudy, and a son.

 Lewis Allen, stage, film and television director, born December 25 1905; died May 3 2000

webTitle: Minister enters fray over future of 'toxic' Tyneside waste plant

fields.headline: Minister enters fray over future of 'toxic' Tyneside waste plant
fields.trailText: The row over the government's plans to increase incinerator capacity in Britain took a new turn yesterday when a cabinet minister sought safety assurances over the operation of an energy from waste plant in his constituency.
fields.body:
The row over the government's plans to increase incinerator capacity in Britain took a new turn yesterday when a cabinet minister sought safety assurances over the operation of an energy from waste plant in his constituency.

Nick Brown, agriculture minister, has demanded assurances from the environment agency, the directors of public health at Newcastle upon Tyne council and the local health authority that the Byker waste plant poses no danger to public health.

His intervention yesterday came after the Guardian reported on alarm in Newcastle about toxic ash being spread on public paths and allotments.

The council has already ordered the removal of 2,000 tonnes of poisoned ash, which has been found to have high levels of mercury, cadmium and lead, from footpaths and allotments. As a precautionary measure the health authority has ruled that no children under the age of two should play in the 27 affected allotments and that no eggs or poultry reared there should be eaten.

The waste plant is already the centre of controversy because the company which operates it wants to double its capacity.

The plan includes burning tyres which are known to include heavy pollutants. Mr Brown released a letter sent to all three authorities saying: "I am writing to you to ask for your views on the current operation of the plant. Specifically can I have your clear view as to whether the present operations carried out at the plant pose a real threat to human health?"

Mr Brown, a former Newcastle councillor, opposed the building of the waste plant.

Now he wants to know whether the existing plant, at present burning coal, is safe, and particularly whether the emissions from the chimney stack could pose a health risk. Both the environment agency and the council are to publish reports shortly.

Mr Brown's intervention comes as the government has delayed publishing its national waste strategy after Downing Street intervened in the controversy over landfill tax scams revealed by the Guardian and Channel 4's Dispatches programme.

fields.headline: Banned lorry boss seeks licence
fields.trailText: Relatives of six people killed by a defective lorry yesterday expressed horror that the haulage company's owner has applied for a licence to run heavy goods vehicles.
fields.body:
Relatives of six people killed by a defective lorry yesterday expressed horror that the haulage company's owner has applied for a licence to run heavy goods vehicles.

Tony Eyers was banned from running a business for five years by the traffic commissioner because of his firm's cavalier disregard for road safety.

In September 1993 one of his defective lorries ploughed into a van, passersby and a terrace of shops on a steep hill in Sowerby Bridge, West Yorkshire, killing three women, two men, and a two-year-old girl.

The 30-tonne lorry had defective brakes on all eight of its wheels.

It later emerged that Mr Eyers, who was managing director of Skipton-based Fewston Transport, had burned company records after the crash. An inquest ruled that the six people had been unlawfully killed.

After a three-year campaign by the victims' relatives, the company's former transport manager was charged with manslaughter, but the charges were dropped when a judge ruled that he would be unable to get a fair trial.

Mr Eyers has now applied for a licence to operate six vehicles for North Riding Waste at Tockwith, near York.

But the relatives of some of the victims who died in the accident expressed concern about his application.

Glenn Rooke, whose wife Angela was killed by the lorry, said he hoped that the public inquiry would look at Mr Eyers's previous safety record.

"I don't have a lot of confidence in the system these days," he said. "If it was up to me, there is no way he would get a licence. But unfortunately it's not. Mr Eyers has never shown any sign of remorse or regret to us about the accident. It is seven years ago now and for me it is something which never goes away."

Lorraine Stott, whose husband Peter died in the crash, said the public inquiry would stir up memories for the victims' families. But she said an inquiry was the lesser of two evils.

Alice Mahon, MP for Halifax, said she would be contacting the traffic commissioner about the public inquiry.

"I would be very, very surprised if he was granted a licence, and I am sure the authority will take into account everything that has happened in the past," she said.

"I would be deeply, deeply shocked if the events of that tragic day were not a major concern for the authorities."

A spokesman for the Department of the Environment, Transport and Regions said it was not unprecedented for the traffic commissioner to decide that a public inquiry is necessary for a licence application. A date has not yet been fixed for the hearing in Leeds.

Mr Eyers was unavailable for comment yesterday.

After the accident, heavy lorries of more than 17 tonnes were banned from using roads through Sowerby Bridge, which used to be a notorious shortcut for traffic from the M62.

The victims of the accident were the lorry driver, Derek Waterworth, 63, of Bradford, van driver Peter Stott, 42, of Luddendenfoot, near Halifax, and pedestrians Angela Rooke, 38, Beryl Rose, 49, Ann Crossley, 32, and her two-year-old daughter Karen, all from Sowerby Bridge.

webTitle: Another organ error at Alder Hey

fields.headline: Another organ error at Alder Hey
fields.trailText: Alder Hey children's hospital on Merseyside yesterday admitted another mistake arising from the removal of body organs without consent.
fields.body:
Alder Hey children's hospital on Merseyside yesterday admitted another mistake arising from the removal of body organs without consent.

A second family had to be told that, contrary to the information they were given in February, the organs of their daughter, Simone Robinson, three, had been accidentally destroyed. In March a mother cancelled a second funeral for her son on being told his organs had been lost. She had earlier been assured they had been kept.

The hospital has set up a project board to deal with the problems arising from the 851 cases in which organs were removed from children's bodies without permission.

Kate Jackson, the board's director, visited the parents of Simone Robinson on Thursday to break the news. In a statement the hospital trust said it had expressed deep regret over the anguish to the family.

Ed Bradley, spokesman for a families' support group, Pity II, said: "Each day seems to bring another blunder by the old administration at the hospital. At least the new team is being open this time."

Alder Hey's acting chief executive, Tony Bell, who took over in April, said the project board would try to find out what had happened, in the case, to be certain that all information given about organ retention was accurate and to avoid further distress to families.
Press Association
