fields.headline: Diva's delight
fields.standfirst: Home of 19th-century soprano for sale
fields.trailText: A Victorian castle once owned by the 19th-century opera star, Adelina Patti, has been put on sale.
fields.body:
A Victorian castle once owned by the 19th-century opera star, Adelina Patti, has been put on sale.

Craig Y Nos, which dates back to the early 1840s, was home to the celebrated soprano for more than 40 years until her death at the age of 76 in 1919.

Among the extensive alterations carried out during her ownership was the constructions of a 150-seat theatre, which opened in 1891 and remains in use.

The grade 1 listed building, which has a mechanical floor-lifting device, is said to be a miniature copy of the Bayreuth opera house. The curtain drop depicts Madame Patti in the role of Semiramide in Rossini's opera of the same name.

Set in nine acres of ground on the banks of the river Tawe near the village of Penycae in the upper Swansea valley, the castle was sold to the Welsh National Memorial Trust on Madame Patti's death and operated as a hospital until the 1980s when it was sold into private ownership.

Agents Knight Frank are seeking offers of around £700,000 for the property.

webTitle: Meacher: shark's fin soup is off

fields.headline: Meacher: shark's fin soup is off
fields.trailText: Britain is fighting to limit trade in shark fins for soup as part of a battle to save the world's second largest fish.
fields.body:
Britain is fighting to limit trade in shark fins for soup as part of a battle to save the world's second largest fish.

Michael Meacher, the environment minister, believes international demand from far eastern restaurants for the highly prized fin of the basking shark is endangering the future of the harmless 30ft fish, which makes frequent visits to British waters.

It is not only Asian tastebuds that pose a threat. Flesh from the fish was sold in Scottish fish and chip shops less than 10 years ago and consumers in eastern Europe enjoy sharkmeat caught by Norwegian fishing boats.

But steeply rising prices for fins means it is unlikely that many Britons are supping on basking shark in Chinese restaurants here. Far cheaper alternatives are now on offer.

The basking shark has complete or partial protection in British, US and New Zealand coastal waters, and should soon be safe in the Mediterranean too. But with dried fins being sold to top restaurants in Beijing for up to £17,000, Mr Meacher wants to remove the temptation to fishermen who can make up to £1,000 a fish.

"I am certain that the demand for basking shark fins poses a real threat and I am determined that this harmless and mysterious creature is given the protection it needs," he said.

He wants other countries to help to restrict trade in products derived from the fish, which is believed to be in serious decline.

He is pressing for more information on the scale of the problem so that controls, though not a total ban, can be introduced at the next convention on international trade in endangered species in 2002.

webTitle: Oh. My. God. It's Clerkenwell Friends

fields.headline: Oh. My. God. It's Clerkenwell Friends
fields.trailText: It's difficult, isn't it, to get a seat in a crowded pub. And yet, in the fantasy land of television, there is always a nice empty clutch of seats in front of the camera. I am not confusing reality with fiction, but just pointing out that such lacunae in realistic depictions of everyday scenes on television militate against viewers taking them as they are intended and, in a particularly poignant twist, make us aspire to do better things with our pub furniture arrangements, and perhaps even with our disappointing selves. It would be nice to be beautiful, wouldn't it, to waft across the floor of a voguish basement bar with attractive friends and stylish drinks, and to sit on something decorous.
fields.body:
It's difficult, isn't it, to get a seat in a crowded pub. And yet, in the fantasy land of television, there is always a nice empty clutch of seats in front of the camera. I am not confusing reality with fiction, but just pointing out that such lacunae in realistic depictions of everyday scenes on television militate against viewers taking them as they are intended and, in a particularly poignant twist, make us aspire to do better things with our pub furniture arrangements, and perhaps even with our disappointing selves. It would be nice to be beautiful, wouldn't it, to waft across the floor of a voguish basement bar with attractive friends and stylish drinks, and to sit on something decorous.

In Coupling (BBC2), the cunning and well-scripted new sitcom by Steve Moffatt, two women came from a crowded bar in the background to the red sofa near the camera. This sequence, and not just for the reasons rehearsed in the last paragraph, was ripe with suggestion. Time was when a sofa in a British pub, especially a well-designed one swathed in virginal velour, was an aberration. Time was when, if the pub flooring was not a heavily stained and smelly carpet, it could not be pub flooring.

Then the fantasy land of television interposed itself between ourselves and that unpleasant reality. In Friends, there was a sofa forever vacant when Joey, Chandler, Ross, Monica, Rachel and Phoebe arrived at Central Perk. The floor was sanded and thus, for those of us who have smellyvision (a tiny elite to which the likes of you will never belong), did not reek repulsively as floors did in pub scenes of British television past (Coronation Street, Minder, Only Fools and Horses, EastEnders etc). Pub and cafe designers of cool Britannia looked at the mise-en-scène of Friends and realised this could be imported wholesale to the delight of TV viewers who saw their fantasies brought from televisual New York to real Britain.

And so it was. Except that these hang-outs are in reality so crammed that anyone fortunate enough to get a seat on their sofas will occupy them all day and all night, in the manner of street car parking in central London: once you get a spot there is nothing to do but occupy it, perhaps forever.

Coupling is doubly derivative of Friends. The pilot episode was chiefly set in a buffed, sanded and newly upholstered basement bar in Clerkenwell (that apparently fashionable district of London where the Guardian, incongruously, is produced). The setting was thus a televisual simulation of a real type of new central London bar that is derivative of Friends' Central Perk (which may itself be a televisual simulation of the real central New York bar, though perhaps not).

Coupling was further derivative because its comedy involved six sexually cross-fertilising young men and women, all implausibly good looking, all stupendously banal, just like Friends. At one point the character played by Jack Davenport said "Oh. My. God," as though he was David Schwimmer - which in a sense, he was. There was even a running gag about men being turned on by lesbian sex fantasies, just as there is in Friends. As the series goes on, no doubt, Coupling will embrace Friends' incestuous sexual politics. Steve will have sex with Jane who will have sex with Patrick who will have sex with Susan who will have sex with Jeff who will be unexpectedly rejected by Sally. And any one of the sextet who has sex with anyone outside this ronde will be deserving of contempt and their extra- curricular partner will be written out with extreme prejudice, so that the six can get on with the real business of their lives, seducing and dumping each other.

Admittedly, Coupling was not wholly derivative. In Friends, Ross and Rachel never had sex in a stall of the ladies loo, as Steve and Jane did (the hotsy-totsy simulation of Schwimmer and Aniston performed here by Davenport and Gina Bellman, whose strip in the cubicle unwontedly recalled her performance in Dennis Potter's Blackeyes). And Coupling was much ruder in its put downs: "Mary Kelly thinks you're an idiot." "Then why does she keep looking at my arse?" "She's lip reading."

The comedy was much more to British tastes, in that it was fraught with anxiety. One woman who had just turned 30 realised this imposed a set of personal responsibilities: "I have had to put a daily limit on facial expression. Nowadays, I only smile at single men. I can justify the use of elasticity." Shame she had to smile so much to her girlfriend when she said this, since it totally undermined the joke.

Ageing, though, that twentysomething terror, was well deployed by Moffatt: "Has it never occurred to you that age brings wisdom and greater confidence?" said naive twentysomething. "All age brings is more to shave," retorted sardonic thirtysomething.

Better, Davenport and Bellman played out a droll comedy of rejection. He wanted to dump her, but she was having none of it. "I don't accept that," she told him. "Don't I get a say in it?" he asked. "Of course you don't." No wonder Susan Faludi wrote a book about the crisis for men called Stiffed if this sort of dialogue realistically depicts the new power relationship between men and women.

Will this series take like a chain of buffed West End boozers? The answer was in the lyrics of the ill-advisedly retro Doris Day theme tune. Perhaps. Perhaps. Perhaps. Perhaps.

fields.headline: Disgraced bishop is welcomed back
fields.trailText: France's most troublesome priest, Jacques Gaillot, has been forgiven by the French Catholic church, five years after his appointment as Bishop of Evreux was revoked
fields.body:
France's most troublesome priest, Jacques Gaillot, has been forgiven by the French Catholic church, five years after his appointment as Bishop of Evreux was revoked because the Vatican disapproved of his media-driven campaigns in favour of the poor, illegal immigrants and the jobless.

The Vatican was so angry at his social crusades, including support for homosexuals, that he was given the contemptuous title of Bishop of Partenia, a non-existent diocese in north Africa.

But his expulsion from Evreux was marked by the presence of thousands of Catholics at his last mass in the cathedral.

Monsignor Gaillot, who caused public rows with his calls to overturn the Vatican's ban on contraceptives, to stop the spread of Aids, and his support for the ordination of married priests, was already the country's best known cleric.

Easily recognisable with his striking blue eyes and small stature, he has marched in dozens of demonstrations in defence of illegal immigrants, or better housing for the poor.

Although there is no indication whether Pope John Paul has forgiven Mgr Gaillot for condemning some of the Vatican's teachings on contemporary social questions, the head of the French hierarchy, Louis-Marie Billé, Archbishop of Lyon, has publicly invited him to return to the fold as a "brother".

To mark the reconciliation, he has been invited to an ecumenical gathering tomorrow where he will sit with all the senior members of the French church

Archbishop Billé said that the decision to make peace with Mgr Gaillot was made by all the French hierarchy.

"It is important that Catholics, and public opinion in general, are aware that the communion that links us as brothers is real, even when it is lived out in a special fashion," Archbishop Billé said.

"What happened five years ago remains a wound even for those who don't necessarily share Mgr Gaillot's opinions."

In a letter to Mgr Gaillot, Archbishop Billé said all members of the Catholic church were committed to serving the poor, and accepted that he had the right to carry out his mission "in a way different from the rest of us".

Friends of Mgr Gaillot said he was told that his work for the poor and minorities was to be publicly recognised by French bishops.

"The Vatican had no part in this initiative even though it was decided in the context of Jubilee 2000," a friend said.

"There will be no pressure to reinstate Mgr Gaillot as Bishop of Evreux, nor to seek another episcopal function. The essential point is that his mission among the socially excluded has been officially recognised."

fields.headline: Insurers reject Nazi survivors' claims
fields.trailText: Criticism of several of Europe's leading insurance companies mounted yesterday following the disclosure that they have rejected three-quarters of all compensation claims submitted to them by Holocaust survivors and their relatives.
fields.body:
Criticism of several of Europe's leading insurance companies mounted yesterday following the disclosure that they have rejected three-quarters of all compensation claims submitted to them by Holocaust survivors and their relatives.

A report by the international commission on Holocaust-era insurance claims says the German, Italian, Swiss and French companies have settled only 124 out of 909 claims submitted, and rejected nearly 400.

The dispute is the latest to bedevil survivors' attempts to reclaim their property, following their long struggle to obtain compensation two years ago from Swiss banks, which held on to concentration camp victims' accounts for more than 50 years, despite documentary claims by relatives.

In a further move, the organisers of a fund to compensate former slave labourers forced to work for the Nazis, say they will name German companies which have not yet contributed to that scheme.

Last year the German government and companies which used forced labour offered to contribute £3.25bn to the fund, but so far only a quarter of that amount has been handed over.

Deborah Senn, a US state insurance commissioner, was quoted in the Jewish Chronicle as saying: "I am seriously concerned about how the companies have participated in this process. They are turning down claims even when they are well documented."

The companies have failed to release all the names of their policy holders during the Nazi era, leaving the relatives unclear as to whether they are entitled to compensation.

The companies are Allianz AG of Germany, Assicurazioni Generali of Italy, the French company Axa and Winterthur and Zurich of Switzerland.

webTitle: Fetes worse than death and other seasonal delights

fields.headline: Fetes worse than death and other seasonal delights
fields.trailText: Tales from the riverside | The joys of monolingualism
fields.body:
After last Thursday's elections debacle, all Labour MPs got an email, no doubt from some little squirt at Millbank, informing them: "This has been a disaster for William Hague." This magnificently on-message message was greeted with hilarity by almost everyone who received it. But it's a sign of terminal decadence in any institution, I suspect, when instead of just lying to us - we expect that - they think they can get away with lying to themselves.

 Thanks for your letters about the worst of Britain. Kris Wardle of Brighton nominates the village fete: "miserable weather, puny little stalls filled with tiny pots of jam, old scratched vinyl records, books with pages missing, the dreaded tombola, the ubiquitous, hideous bouncy castle, all against a background of harassed parents, whingeing children, dark skies, drizzle and a biting wind - and that's just in the summer".

But at least a fete is put on for a good or goodish cause. It's not usually run by cynical greedheads. What I dislike most are all those enterprises designed to extract as much of our money as possible, while loudly proclaiming how lucky we are to have them. High street electrical chains, where young men who spend too much time grooming their hair sell you overpriced goods which would cost half as much in New York, while flogging you an unnecessary insurance policy which costs a third as much again. Chain hotels, where the only human being you meet during your entire stay is the reception clerk, who says: "Welcome to the Droitwich Journey's End!", prints off your credit card, then loses all interest in you.

Lap-dancing clubs (I haven't been to one in Britain, but I can guess). British films made with lottery money, which go straight to video, then straight into the waste bin. Virgin trains (I won't go on about these, but Branson's hopeless service took the edge off an otherwise very pleasant visit to the West Midlands the other day. I felt sorriest for the young couple next to me who'd been told at Birmingham that the train would make a special stop at Watford, and were told just as firmly on board that it wouldn't. It did, but they were ready to stand at the window waving frantically at her father, waiting for them on the platform. Most London west end theatres and musicals, charging New York prices for an experience which would have folk grumbling at a North country rep. I won't go on; it's too depressing.

 To the cellars of Berry Brothers in St James Street, for the launch of the Landmark Trust's fund-raising drive and "open doors weekend" which starts a week today. (Details from 01628 825925). The Trust is the opposite of bad, being run by dedicated people who care deeply about their work of renovating and preserving superb old buildings. But we had a reminder of the truly awful from the actor Timothy West, who made the keynote speech. While on tour he tries to stay in Landmarks (renting restored buildings) after grisly experiences "in places with names like the Tamworth Dragonara". The last straw had come at a big, expensive hotel, where he'd arrived at around 10 and had been pleased to see that cold meat salad was featured on the room service 24-hour menu. When he phoned, a voice said, "No, yer can't have that, the 24-hour menu doesn't start till 11.30."

One of the best features of a Landmark is the log book, in which visitors describe their stays. It's fascinating to trace in some how ghost stories begin and circulate. One visitor jokily describes hearing a creaky noise on a windless night. A fortnight later someone hears a low moaning from the belfry. Soon you have a full-blown haunting, and everyone has some weird and eerie experience to contribute. Among ghost-infested Landmarks are Woodford Castle and Wolverton Gatehouse, where a monk is supposed to drag his ball and chain around. Though as Landmark's director, my fellow-sceptic Peter Pearce, asks, "why on earth would a monk come equipped with a ball and chain?"

 Another thing that's not at all bad involves sitting on the terrace of the House of Commons on a warm summer evening. The view from the Thames has been improving steadily over the past few years, with Tate Modern, the new footbridge and the Millennium Wheel offering the eye alternatives to the ghastly rectangular blocks - Shell House, St Thomas's hospital and the unspeakable Portcullis House. Walking past County Hall the other day, I spotted a yellow tourist bus curiously shaped like a boat with wheels. The surrealist air was heightened by the courier, who wore a neckpiece showing a smiling toad. That night I had a few drinks on the terrace with MPs, some of whom were preparing to vote against the government's plans to half-privatise air traffic control. "We opt for the Canadian model," one told me. "The planes fall out of the sky much more slowly."

Another is a member of the Northern Ireland committee and was just back from a trip to Belfast. "At one point we had to walk down a railway line," he said, "and they made us wear safety jackets. And I suddenly realised, there we all were, the whole committee, marching along in broad daylight, in Belfast, all wearing bright orange."

At this point I looked at the river and rubbed my eyes, because there was the yellow bus churning its way upstream. It clearly offers an amphibious sightseeing experience. The name, I noted, was Frog Tours, though I believe that people of any nationality can buy a ticket.

 Should we British learn more foreign languages? Of course we should, but which? France is near us, Germany is the main economic power in Europe, Japan the second in the world, Russia and China soon to become hugely important. It's an easy decision for every non-Anglophone country, and even Americans have Spanish as the obvious choice.

The march of English is so relentless, accelerating every year (Renault board meetings in Paris are now conducted in English), that to most schoolchildren here foreign languages will soon seem pointless. They may come to live on as a secret code, just as people in North Wales use Welsh to abuse English tourists in pubs.

There's a scene in David Lodge's Nice Work in which German manufacturers try to swindle a Birmingham businessman by - the cheating Hun - talking in front of him in their own language. But we can't learn them all; they, on the other hand, can learn the only one that matters.
fields.bodyText: After last Thursday's elections debacle, all Labour MPs got an email, no doubt from some little squirt at Millbank, informing them: "This has been a disaster for William Hague." This magnificently on-message message was greeted with hilarity by almost everyone who received it. But it's a sign of terminal decadence in any institution, I suspect, when instead of just lying to us - we expect that - they think they can get away with lying to themselves.  Thanks for your letters about the worst of Britain. Kris Wardle of Brighton nominates the village fete: "miserable weather, puny little stalls filled with tiny pots of jam, old scratched vinyl records, books with pages missing, the dreaded tombola, the ubiquitous, hideous bouncy castle, all against a background of harassed parents, whingeing children, dark skies, drizzle and a biting wind - and that's just in the summer". But at least a fete is put on for a good or goodish cause. It's not usually run by cynical greedheads. What I dislike most are all those enterprises designed to extract as much of our money as possible, while loudly proclaiming how lucky we are to have them. High street electrical chains, where young men who spend too much time grooming their hair sell you overpriced goods which would cost half as much in New York, while flogging you an unnecessary insurance policy which costs a third as much again. Chain hotels, where the only human being you meet during your entire stay is the reception clerk, who says: "Welcome to the Droitwich Journey's End!", prints off your credit card, then loses all interest in you. Lap-dancing clubs (I haven't been to one in Britain, but I can guess). British films made with lottery money, which go straight to video, then straight into the waste bin. Virgin trains (I won't go on about these, but Branson's hopeless service took the edge off an otherwise very pleasant visit to the West Midlands the other day. I felt sorriest for the young couple next to me who'd been told at Birmingham that the train would make a special stop at Watford, and were told just as firmly on board that it wouldn't. It did, but they were ready to stand at the window waving frantically at her father, waiting for them on the platform. Most London west end theatres and musicals, charging New York prices for an experience which would have folk grumbling at a North country rep. I won't go on; it's too depressing.  To the cellars of Berry Brothers in St James Street, for the launch of the Landmark Trust's fund-raising drive and "open doors weekend" which starts a week today. (Details from 01628 825925). The Trust is the opposite of bad, being run by dedicated people who care deeply about their work of renovating and preserving superb old buildings. But we had a reminder of the truly awful from the actor Timothy West, who made the keynote speech. While on tour he tries to stay in Landmarks (renting restored buildings) after grisly experiences "in places with names like the Tamworth Dragonara". The last straw had come at a big, expensive hotel, where he'd arrived at around 10 and had been pleased to see that cold meat salad was featured on the room service 24-hour menu. When he phoned, a voice said, "No, yer can't have that, the 24-hour menu doesn't start till 11.30." One of the best features of a Landmark is the log book, in which visitors describe their stays. It's fascinating to trace in some how ghost stories begin and circulate. One visitor jokily describes hearing a creaky noise on a windless night. A fortnight later someone hears a low moaning from the belfry. Soon you have a full-blown haunting, and everyone has some weird and eerie experience to contribute. Among ghost-infested Landmarks are Woodford Castle and Wolverton Gatehouse, where a monk is supposed to drag his ball and chain around. Though as Landmark's director, my fellow-sceptic Peter Pearce, asks, "why on earth would a monk come equipped with a ball and chain?"  Another thing that's not at all bad involves sitting on the terrace of the House of Commons on a warm summer evening. The view from the Thames has been improving steadily over the past few years, with Tate Modern, the new footbridge and the Millennium Wheel offering the eye alternatives to the ghastly rectangular blocks - Shell House, St Thomas's hospital and the unspeakable Portcullis House. Walking past County Hall the other day, I spotted a yellow tourist bus curiously shaped like a boat with wheels. The surrealist air was heightened by the courier, who wore a neckpiece showing a smiling toad. That night I had a few drinks on the terrace with MPs, some of whom were preparing to vote against the government's plans to half-privatise air traffic control. "We opt for the Canadian model," one told me. "The planes fall out of the sky much more slowly." Another is a member of the Northern Ireland committee and was just back from a trip to Belfast. "At one point we had to walk down a railway line," he said, "and they made us wear safety jackets. And I suddenly realised, there we all were, the whole committee, marching along in broad daylight, in Belfast, all wearing bright orange." At this point I looked at the river and rubbed my eyes, because there was the yellow bus churning its way upstream. It clearly offers an amphibious sightseeing experience. The name, I noted, was Frog Tours, though I believe that people of any nationality can buy a ticket.  Should we British learn more foreign languages? Of course we should, but which? France is near us, Germany is the main economic power in Europe, Japan the second in the world, Russia and China soon to become hugely important. It's an easy decision for every non-Anglophone country, and even Americans have Spanish as the obvious choice. The march of English is so relentless, accelerating every year (Renault board meetings in Paris are now conducted in English), that to most schoolchildren here foreign languages will soon seem pointless. They may come to live on as a secret code, just as people in North Wales use Welsh to abuse English tourists in pubs. There's a scene in David Lodge's Nice Work in which German manufacturers try to swindle a Birmingham businessman by - the cheating Hun - talking in front of him in their own language. But we can't learn them all; they, on the other hand, can learn the only one that matters.

fields.headline: Scary masks and sausages
fields.standfirst: Jonathan Jones explores the cruder side of art at Carnivalesque
fields.trailText: Jonathan Jones explores the cruder side of art at Carnivalesque
fields.body:
Art has been a religion ever since modern art galleries began in the late 18th century. But religion implies blasphemy, and the underside of aesthetics rears its grossly distorted head in Carnivalesque, an exhibition sprawling like a fat drunk across several venues in Brighton. It demonstrates that for every noble aspiration we have to contemplate the finer things, we have an equal and opposite urge to gorge, puke, screw and fart our way to the bottom of the barrel.

Today we talk about our divided nature in the language of the unconscious, but in the middle ages it was imagined in extravagant mythological terms as the War of Carnival and Lent. This was a Lenten world ruled by Christianity and poverty, but once a year each town would stage its carnival and the world would explode in a shower of sausages, long noses, big bottoms and immense turds.

Carnivalesque traces the way carnival has manifested itself in art from the middle ages to today. Here, Paul McCarthy's Spaghetti Man (1993) - a lifesize plastic man wearing an animal head, with his penis transformed into several metres of flaccid, flesh-coloured rubber hose - is set in the same art historical space as a Flemish diptych from circa 1520. This opens up to reveal not - as a pious person of the time would have expected - a religious image, but a painting of a huge hairy spotty arse pricked by a bunch of thistles. You only have yourself to blame. On the outside of the diptych is painted a warning not to open it; inside, opposite the raddled arse, it says in so many words "told you so". Its parody of Christian art seems very subversive, but Philip II of Spain, a Lenten monarch if ever there was one, loved to look at a similar object as a relief from persecuting heretics.

In the 1930s the Russian literary critic Mikhail Bakhtin, the inspiration for this show as well as dozens of academic theories about the "carnivalesque", argued that "carnival laughter" is "the laughter of all the people" and an assault on all hierarchical order. Bakhtin was living in internal exile in Kazakhstan when he wrote this and was obviously thinking of Stalin when he claimed in his classic study Rabelais and His World (not published until 1965) that "no dogma, no authoritarianism, no narrow-minded seriousness" can co-exist with carnival.

But the imagination is a frightening place and the carnival world this exhibition explores is anything but a jolly libertarian paradise. It is a scary place where people you know suddenly put on huge hairy wooden masks and turn themselves into monsters. Some of the most unsettling pictures here are James Ensor's masked nocturnal invaders in early 20th century Belgium. Even nastier are Philip Guston's Ku Klux Klansmen, reduced to pairs of beady black eyes and pointed masks. You see the Klan through Guston as a version of European carnival; the infamous white garb is a vicious form of the masquerade outfits in Tiepolo's paintings and drawings of 18th-century Pulcinellas at the Verona carnival.

Carnival can be cruel. This exhibition demonstrates that its structure persists across centuries: the same masks, the same bottom jokes, a shared stock of images. What you have to conclude is that our personal desires or terrors are not private but shared. Carnival is an aesthetic phenomenon manifesting our need to look at the ugly as well as the beautiful. It is the inversion of the classical idea of perfection. If we will always take pleasure in straight lines we will also always laugh at someone showing their arse.

What is so clever about this exhibition is that it resists the temptation to stick in any old bum or sausage. It keeps its fools and masked pranksters firmly under control and because of this precision it is able to tell an alternative history of art. Carnival has seeped up into high art from Goya to Louise Bourgeois, whose stumpy voodoo doll made of pink quilting is repellent yet mesmerising. Just when you think those pancake-eating Bruegel peasants are a bit quaint you recognise this world of upside-down folly, boozing, gorging and beating each other with sticks, as our own. As Robert Crumb says, looking in a mirror on the cover of Self-Loathing Comics, "Is that me? My god, it is!"

In contemporary art the classical notion of beauty has been almost entirely eclipsed by abjection; carnival has won. The man in a fool's cap presenting us with a turd on a plate in a 16th-century engraving by Peter Flötner turns up again in Paul McCarthy's video Bossy Burger. "Ha, ha, ha," says McCarthy, wearing a blood-spattered chef's hat and a mask based on Mad magazine's grinning kid, "Ho, ho, ho."

 Carnivalesque is at the Brighton Museum and Art Gallery and other Brighton venues till July 2. Details: 01273 290900.

fields.headline: Looking for the personal touch
fields.standfirst: The Diaghilev series ended on a muted note, says  Andrew Clements
fields.trailText: The Diaghilev series ended on a muted note, says Andrew Clements
fields.body:
The Diaghilev Series, Valery Gergiev's week-long tour through the scores associated with the Ballets Russes, began with two concerts from his own Kirov Orchestra and ended with a pair from the Philharmonia. The Kirov's programmes had been devoted exclusively to Russian music, but at London's Royal Festival Hall the Philharmonia's ranged more widely: Stravinsky appeared in both of them, as well as works by Debussy, Ravel, Borodin and Rimsky-Korsakov, masterpieces every one of them.

In his youth Diaghilev had ambitions to be a composer himself; his musical instincts rarely failed him later. Some of the pieces, of course, were just appropriated for dance rather than commissioned. The Polovtsian Dances from Borodin's opera Prince Igor were featured in his company's debut Paris season in 1909, which brought Nijinsky, Pavlova and Karsavina to the West for the first time. Rimsky's Sheherazade entered their repertory the following year. Much to the impresario's satisfaction, the explicit sexuality of Nijinsky's choreography of Debussy's Prélude à l'après-midi d'un faune scandalised all of Paris (including the composer himself) when it was unveiled in 1912, 18 years after the piece itself was premiered in the same city.

Stravinsky's The Firebird (Gergiev conducted the 1911 suite) and Ravel's Daphnis et Chloé, however, owed their existence to Diaghilev's sponsorship, while the former's Apollo was first staged in Europe under the Ballets Russes's auspices. Each work was a milestone in its composer's development. In the history of musical modernism Diaghilev was one of the most significant catalysts of all; his carefully superintended commissions almost always encouraged composers to extend their creative horizons.

On the threshold of his international career with The Firebird, Stravinsky needed no encouragement to kick over the traces, but when he came to write Apollo two decades later he used the opportunity to push his neoclassical style in a new direction. Meanwhile in Daphnis, the reticent Ravel was pushed into displaying his orchestral mastery with greater virtuosity than ever before.

That kind of white-hot inspiration usually brings the best out of Gergiev; in the right works his conducting has a visceral quality that is unique among conductors today. But in his pair of Philharmonia concerts he seemed more concerned with other things, with instrumental detail and beauty of tone, with dynamic contrasts (some of the orchestra's quietest playing was breathtaking) and long-limbed phrasing, as if intent on pointing up the difference between this British orchestra and his Russian one. Though he has made enormous strides at the Kirov in ridding the orchestra of its less desirable characteristics - the days of vibrato-laden brass and soupy woodwind are long gone - it is still a band that is at its best when being assertive, while the Philharmonia prides itself on its finesse.

There was still the never-fail adrenalin-rush that Gergiev brings to big moments: the final Bacchanale of Daphnis was stupendous, while the climax of the last section of Sheherazade seemed to pull together all the threads of the preceding movements in an absolutely conclusive way, but these were the predictable high points. Much more of a surprise was his neutral approach to both Prélude à l'aprés-midi, which relied entirely on the beauty of the Philharmonia's woodwind to make its points in sweeping curves, and to the way in which he presented the strings-only Apollo. He played down the energy of the athletic numbers in favour of the grandeur of those intended to be danced by Apollo himself, and made the pas de deux between Apollo and Terpsichore the emotional heart of the work. Sheherazade began in that way too: broadly paced, moulded rather than driven, and only really dramatic in the last movement.

There were passages in which the conducting seemed to be relying on auto-pilot, as if Gergiev was not engaged with what he was doing, or had not established a personal slant on the music - hardly surprising, perhaps, considering these were his third and fourth orchestral programmes within seven days and he was working with an orchestra that he conducts relatively rarely. Of course he pushes himself too hard: that is part and parcel of his character as a musician, and the Kirov would not have survived as magnificently as it has down without his selfless energy. But sometimes it shows, and these two concerts, for all their splendour, did not quite live up to expectations.

fields.headline: Distinctive chuckle in the cacophony
fields.trailText: Alarms, phones, pagers and radio: the soundscape is now so insistent and cacophonous that nothing is distinctive. Most of the radio we hear becomes a succession of half-recalled moments in an effluence of noise.
fields.body:
Alarms, phones, pagers and radio: the soundscape is now so insistent and cacophonous that nothing is distinctive. Most of the radio we hear becomes a succession of half-recalled moments in an effluence of noise.

Johnnie Walker (Radio 2) interviewed old rocker Ian Hunter of 70s band Mott the Hoople in his clumsy-adulatory fashion. (I can't help thinking that a coked-up Walker might be sharper.) Hunter lives an unreconstructed English working-class life in the middle of America, still hooked on the Daily Mail and the football results.

Bam Bam, London station Kiss 100's Sony-award winning breakfast show host, promised on Tuesday to reveal the next day what men do that women don't know about. But I forgot to tune in on Wednesday so I still don't know. Bam Bam's endearing show is like eavesdropping on the pub talk of 23-year-old men.

Radio 5 Live's Sony-award winning Late Night Live had a coolly instructive appraisal of what the new owners of BMW have to do to turn it around, including taking the inside of other makes of car and putting their own outside on it. This is what a lot of current radio programmes do to other radio programmes.

Why does Terry Wogan (Radio 2) chuckle so much? Is it to show how urbane and ironic he is, or because he thinks he is witty?

The Way He Was, the first in Thomas Lynch's series of Radio 4 Colloquies, was one of the few programmes to do an Ancient Mariner, coercing one to listen intently. Lynch is an American undertaker and poet who can make poetry out of death. The Way He Was began as a commentary on the bereaved's wish to restore their loved ones to some previous, tolerable state, but swiftly metamorphosed into a chilling account of his own alcoholism. A single parent, Bushmilled out of his mind, he noticed the look on his nine-year-old son's face - "he is afraid of me, and my anger" - and got himself some help.

Just when one presumed that this would be the edifying tale of drying-out, it shifted again into a remarkable parental lament: that nine-year-old himself turned into a 14-year-old alcoholic.

Disclosure can easily become exhibitionism, self-revelation is often narcissistic, and speaking publicly about family members remains ethically problematic. Yet none of this is relevant to Lynch because of his eloquent humanity. In a great cry of despair he charts his son's decline, his own attempt to wish it away - thinking, after a first stint in rehab, that it was fixed - and his realisation that "the only victory is the admission of defeat".

This was not so much stream of consciousness as softly-spoken anguish. It was also a facing-up, where some sort of accommodation must be made with horrible truths. I have rarely heard anything so powerful as Lynch's recalled speech trying to persuade his son back to rehab, or his Zen-like adoption of gratitude for life's struggles. Like a thriller, you hung on, praying that the boy would not die at the end of the piece. He didn't.

Finally, the first in the new series of Nature (Radio 4) travelled to Lake Eyre North, a desert in the Australian outback suddenly transformed by extraordinary rains into the 13th largest lake in the world. This was nature up to its tricks again, allowing a fascinating programme to demonstrate the complexity of its ecological equilibrium. Most intriguing was the revelation that masses of beautiful birds, normally resident 2,000km away, within weeks had mysteriously become appraised of these new breeding wetlands and had flown there. All without phone, pager, and email. How do they do it ?

fields.headline: The last word on... Complexity
fields.standfirst: There's no limit to how complicated things can get, on account of one thing always leading to another . - EB White
fields.trailText: There's no limit to how complicated things can get, on account of one thing always leading to another . - EB White
fields.body:
As a rule, whatever is simple, easy or neat is preferable to what is complicated, difficult or messy. Most would rather deal with a straightforward person, an easy subject of study, or an uncluttered room, than with their opposites. Yet it is highly interesting that the world, and practically everything in it, is complex. But what is complexity? Instead of trying to avoid it, perhaps we should do the next best thing - have a theory about it.

In recent years that is just what some scientists have been doing: investigating it in a determined effort to understand complicated phenomena like the weather, turbulence around aircraft, and crowd behaviour. Randomness is defined as the state something is in when a description of it is no less complex than the system itself. For very complicated systems, therefore, it is impossible to distinguish complexity from chaos.

Another suggested definition exploits the fact that a system becomes complex by developing from simpler stages. The more complex the system, the longer or at least the more involved must its evolution have been. One therefore defines complexity as the amount of input it takes for nature to produce a given system; perhaps, the amount of free energy required to organise the system into its complex state. This measure of complexity is called " depth".

These definitions have been artistically illustrated by the Nobel physicist Murray Gell-Mann. A minimalist painting - say, a black square - has low algorithmic complexity because it does not take much to describe, and low depth complexity because it did not take much to produce.

A Jackson Pollock drip painting has high algorithmic complexity; it is indeed close to randomness. But it has low depth complexity because it involved relatively little evolution. For example: it is the Bosch's developmental depth which makes a description of it long.

If we do not take this into account, how shall we explain the seeming paradox just posed - that some things are more complex than others because they are simpler?

fields.headline: Body language
fields.standfirst: Political passion or bourgeois boredom?  Michael Billington sees two plays with radically different motives for murder
fields.trailText: Political passion or bourgeois boredom? Michael Billington sees two plays with radically different motives for murder
fields.body:
Murder is in the air this week. At the Almeida Theatre The Novice, adapted by Richard Eyre from Jean-Paul Sartre, debates the ethics of assassination. And in David Gieselmann's Mr Kolpert at the Royal Court an affluent young couple "entertain" their guests with the idea that there is a corpse in the living-room trunk. Both plays are European; both use the thriller format; both feature bourgeois protagonists. But what is fascinating is that Gieselmann's sardonic comedy seems much more lethally political than Sartre's heavyweight melodrama.

I am wary of calling Sartre's play dated, simply because it was written in 1948. As John Lahr once wrote, "all drama is dated, the product of a particular moment". And nothing is dafter than to attack plays simply because they don't conform to our own values and circumstances. We don't believe in divine monarchy, but Richard II is still a potent analysis of the fallibility of power. Venereal disease may now be curable, but it doesn't stop Ibsen's Ghosts being a powerful attack on inherited guilt. All good plays exist in a dual time-frame: they embody their own period while expressing eternal truths.

Eyre's tactical error in The Novice is to abstract Sartre's play from its times. He gives us bags of 40s film noirish atmosphere. But, in a play that is all about a bourgeois rebel assigned to kill a compromising communist, he deletes all reference to the Soviet Union. This strikes me as bizarre, since the whole play is about the tentacles of Moscow's power.

In Eyre's version the hero, having committed the murder, is baldly told by his minder, "we've changed our policy". In Sartre's original it is spelt out clearly: contact with the USSR was interrupted by war and the local party chose to pursue its own line, whereas in the postwar world it has to kow-tow to Moscow orthodoxy. Eyre excises the specifics, leaving Sartre's play floating in political limbo.

But Sartre's form also looks suspect. There was a time when I found his mix of melodrama and politics exciting. What strikes me now is that he tries to spice up his ideas with desultory sex. Sartre gives his hero a glam wife who oscillates between coy flirt, frigid ice-maiden and romantic victim: she is simply used as top-dressing - or sometimes undressing - for the political debates. My hunch is that, if you are going to revive the play today, you have two choices: either acknowledge its strengths and weaknesses and do it as all-out dialectical debate, or, as Frank Castorf does in his jazzy version at the Berlin Volksbuhne, treat it as rampant expressionism. What you can't do is strip it of all context.

Ironically, Gieselmann's Mr Kolpert, although seemingly apolitical, has much more social content. Like Sartre's play it is about the morality of murder. The well-heeled Ralf and Sarah entertain married guests and tease them with the idea that there may be a dead body in the trunk. But the key moment comes when Sarah explains, in David Tushingham's translation, the affluent vacancy of their lives: "Ralf and I kept seeing people our age dancing, trying hard to pretend they'd just left school a few weeks ago and that emotions and all that stuff are just a bit of a laugh. But beneath all that they were really human beings. Then we realised we weren't aware of emotions any more either. All we wanted to do was feel something again."

If that strikes a chord it is with the world of Sarah Kane and with Mark Ravenhill's Shopping and Fucking and Some Explicit Polaroids. What all these German and British writers seem to have spotted is that the real danger in modern society is of a sawn-off sensibility and a detachment from feeling. A shrewd academic pointed out to me this week that there is nothing new in this: Wordsworth was making the same complaint in his Preface to the Lyrical Ballads. But what modern dramatists have detected is that we now seek dangerous substitutes - chemical substances or, in extreme cases, killing - to compensate for our emotional void.

That is why I would call Mr Kolpert a deeply political play. It suggests valueless affluence leads to desperation. In Sartre's world people kill for a cause; in Gieselmann's they murder, or toy with it, out of ennui. Sartre warns us against the dangers of excess idealism: Gieselmann against a total lack of it. Fifty years separate the two plays which together paint a graphic picture of modern Europe. If I find Gieselmann's infinitely more terrifying it is because it suggests we now live in a world where violence is the product less of political passion than of bourgeois boredom. How on earth do we counter that?

 The Novice is at the Almeida Theatre, London N1 (020 7359 4404) till June 17; Mr Kolpert is at the Royal Court, London SW6 (020 7565 5000) till May 20.

fields.headline: Young Manics depressive
fields.standfirst: Nihilism and pop make a poor drama, says  Lyn Gardner
fields.trailText: Nihilism and pop make a poor drama, says Lyn Gardner
fields.body:
A recent spate of theatre work emanating from Wales has taken a jaundiced view of life in the valleys, and Patrick Jones's play, enlivened by a soundtrack from the Manic Street Preachers, Catatonia and others, is no different. Cindy, Pip and Curtis live in a small Caerphilly town; for them, life is barren, New Labour is a bad joke, and the best they can hope for is a poxy job assembling cheap computers in the local factory. Heroin is a more appealing way to die.

Statistics in the programme point to Caerphilly's deprivation: its 8.1 per cent unemployment rate, the 29 per cent of its residents who have no educational qualifications. Unfortunately, these speak more eloquently about life in Wales than Jones's overwrought and self-consciously poetic script.

The first half of the evening isn't so much a call to the barricades as one long whine. Things buck up a bit in the second half, as Jones tells the story of the distraught A, who decides to terrorise the human resources manager who casually sacked his father. This scene is the best in the play: it has some real dramatic tension and, more importantly, it doesn't preach about but shows the gulf in Wales, between the haves and the have-nots, the workers and the enforced idle, the young and the middle-aged. The manager seals his fate by calling A "sonny".

Jones's play and Phil Clark's strident production have a youth audience in mind, but they have learned little from the innovative Volcano or Frantic Assembly, until recently both Welsh-based, and still with a huge under-25 following. This a stuttering, old-fashioned piece of theatre that merely pumps up the volume and throws in some tricksy visuals. The gutsy cast is way too old.

But it is the play's nihilism, the way it is so quick to applaud despair and suggests that feeling is better than thinking, that is so deeply depressing.

 Everything Must Go is at the Lyric Hammersmith, London W6 (020-8741 2311), till May 27.

fields.headline: Plain tales from the royals
fields.standfirst: What could revive the ailing 500-year-old travelling theatre of Assam? Modern morality plays, reports  Saira Shah, based on stories of the Titanic, Princess Diana, and aircraft hijacking
fields.trailText: What could revive the ailing 500-year-old travelling theatre of Assam? Modern morality plays, reports Saira Shah, based on stories of the Titanic, Princess Diana, and aircraft hijacking
fields.body:
Princess Diana glides closer to her faithful retainer James Hewitt and begs him to give her the affection that her playboy husband Charles cannot. Hewitt, resplendent in naval uniform, is moved. Heavy black liner accentuates the torment in his eyes and his breast quivers. "No Diana!" he protests. Violins in the orchestra pit strike up. Under a shaky chandelier, the loyal lover embraces his beloved. The couple clinch. The audience goes wild.

This is not a made-for-TV dramatisation of the life of a late member of the British royal family. It is a theatrical event that has enraptured villagers in one of India's remotest regions. The Diana myth has, in just a few months, transformed the seemingly doomed fortunes of a five-century old travelling theatre tradition in Assam. Many in the audience have never heard of Diana, but the theatre group claims her story has an important message about marital fidelity for the humblest villager.

"Princess Diana's story is a morality play," says Mukib Ahmed, who plays Prince Charles. "Even in Assam we have cases of husbands who are unfaithful to their wives. In Diana's case, it ended in tragedy. We can learn from her life."

The travelling theatre began with the efforts of a 15th century moralist and religious reformer, Shankar Deb, to educate the Assamese away from the brutal practices of Tantric Hinduism. In a new book, To the Elephant's Graveyard, Tarquin Hall describes a popular method of divination: examining a nine-month foetus cut from the body of its mother. Appalled, Shankar Deb founded Vashnavite Hinduism, prevalent in Assam to this day.

To spread his new values of decency and uprightness, his followers travelled from village to village performing yatra, morality plays. In an area starved for entertainment, these soon became immensely popular. Today, the painted lorries heralding the troupe's arrival are greeted rapturously by villagers. Daily chores cease, and an impromptu four-day carnival begins. Stalls selling sweetmeats and snacks spring up. Village youths lounge outside the tent on their motorcycles, hoping some of the glamour of theatre will be sprinkled on them. As dusk falls, the entire community converges upon the theatre. Many have walked for miles. The bamboo stage is enormous and the tent seats 2,000. There is a portable generator so plays may be performed in villages with no electricity.

It is an expensive business. There are about 100 people in the troupe, including cast, costume and make-up personnel, a full orchestra, engineers and cooks. Travelling theatre has survived because Assam's remoteness meant little competition. The region has largely resisted the lure of Bollywood films in Hindi. But the recent growth of cinema in Assamese is a greater threat. So large is the appetite for these films, with their lurid plots featuring sex and violence, that fights for tickets have exploded outside the mobile cinemas that tour the villages.

The Abahan Theatrical group decided to fight back by staging blockbusters with an added moral dimension. Its first experiment last year was a production of Titanic, based on the plot of James Cameron's film. It was a success, and this year the group launched into its most ambitious project, a locally-scripted version of the life and death of Diana. The play is an unlikely triumph, with distance lending an intriguing cultural twist. A team of researchers sifted through contemporary writing about the late princess, including biographies and back copies of Hello! magazine.

The challenges are amazing. "I have seen still pictures of Camilla," says Likuma Sharma, who plays the woman referred to in the play as Camilla Parker-Bowels, "but I have never had a chance to see film or video of her. That is very important for an actress to get a chance to see how she talks, how she moves. I had to guess all that and I have managed very well."

Details are slightly askew. Charles is glamorous, given to disco dancing. Likuma, who once played basketball for Assam, portrays Camilla as a young nymph. Diana is a poor girl from a humble family and James Hewitt is the unlikely hero. The Queen and her press officer meet outside the gates of Buckingham Palace, where the Queen laments Diana's lack of breeding, intending to have the girl live in the palace where she can be taught etiquette. The press officer suggests that she be dispatched to Kensington Palace instead, where Hewitt can mould her into a member of the family.

On the deck of the royal yacht Britannia, Diana bemoans that they have passed "Gibraltar, Sicily, the Suez Canal and Algeria" and yet still the press follow: as indeed they do, bobbing in a rowing boat on the muslin sea. Charles, meanwhile, openly consorts with Camilla. The day after his wedding to Diana he gives his mistress a necklace proclaiming: "Diana may be Princess of Buckingham Palace, but you are Queen of my heart."

The production is remarkable for its meticulous detail: the props include a Mercedes, motorcycles for the paparazzi, a helicopter that flies around the stage and a scale model of Britannia. The finale is the crash in the Paris underpass. "I've never seen pictures of the accident, but I'd heard about it," said Rajen Shah, technical engineer in charge of sets. "I thought surely we could re-create it. I hope I haven't made any mistakes."

The director refused to stage the play until he had searched Assam for the perfect Diana lookalike. The brunette, buxom Jubilee Rajkumari (she adopted the name Jubilee in honour of the part) bears little similarity to Diana, but on stage, with white makeup, her sideways glance under lowered lashes seemed oddly familiar.

The production is two and a half hours long and, even to non-Assamese speakers, absorbing. Dialogue is interspersed with musical numbers and farce, such as the scene in which Diana is smuggled out of Buckingham Palace gates in a black Islamic veil, or when the paparazzi bribe Palace guards for an interview.

Not all critics approve of it. "The ancient art of yatra has been trivialised by the adoption of western themes, such as Titanic and Diana," the Indian film actress Moon Moon Sen says. "It may allow the theatre to survive, but the religious art itself is dead." The play shows how, less than three years after her death, Diana is a legend, with the power of myth even for the villagers of Assam, most of them tea-growers. One man queuing patiently for tickets to the show says: "I earn 10,000 rupees a month. One ticket costs 1,000 rupees, so to afford tickets for all my family, I had to save for many weeks. But we all want to learn about Princess Diana. She cared about the common people. She is like Mother Teresa."

The play's success has guaranteed the Abahan group's immediate survival, and prolonged the artform into the 21st century. There is even talk of bringing the production to Britain. The company is already planning next year's play, based on the recent hijacking of the Indian Airlines jumbo jet by Kashmiri separatists.

 Saira Shah's film about Assam may be seen on Channel 4 News tomorrow, 7.30pm. To the Elephant's Graveyard by Tarquin Hall, John Murray, £16.99.

The brunette, buxom Jubilee Rajkumari (she adopted the name Jubilee in honour of the part) bears little similarity to Diana, but on stage, with white makeup, her sideways glance under lowered lashes seemed oddly familiar. The production is two and a half hours long and, even to non-Assamese speakers, absorbing. Dialogue is interspersed with musical numbers and farce, such as the scene in which Diana is smuggled out of Buckingham Palace gates in a black Islamic veil, or when the paparazzi bribe Palace guards for an interview. Not all critics approve of it. "The ancient art of yatra has been trivialised by the adoption of western themes, such as Titanic and Diana," the Indian film actress Moon Moon Sen says. "It may allow the theatre to survive, but the religious art itself is dead." The play shows how, less than three years after her death, Diana is a legend, with the power of myth even for the villagers of Assam, most of them tea-growers. One man queuing patiently for tickets to the show says: "I earn 10,000 rupees a month. One ticket costs 1,000 rupees, so to afford tickets for all my family, I had to save for many weeks. But we all want to learn about Princess Diana. She cared about the common people. She is like Mother Teresa." The play's success has guaranteed the Abahan group's immediate survival, and prolonged the artform into the 21st century. There is even talk of bringing the production to Britain. The company is already planning next year's play, based on the recent hijacking of the Indian Airlines jumbo jet by Kashmiri separatists.  Saira Shah's film about Assam may be seen on Channel 4 News tomorrow, 7.30pm. To the Elephant's Graveyard by Tarquin Hall, John Murray, £16.99.

fields.headline: Word play
fields.standfirst: 'It is extraordinary how important words remain, especially as they are used so sloppily nowadays. But sloppiness also has its uses'
fields.trailText: 'It is extraordinary how important words remain, especially as they are used so sloppily nowadays. But sloppiness also has its uses'
fields.body:
Words, words, words: they govern our lives, they determine our destiny; the world is ruled by them. Hopes for a permanent end to the bloodshed in Northern Ireland rest on finding words that are acceptable to both Unionists and Republicans. The IRA refuses to "disarm", it refuses to "decommission", but it is willing to put its weapons "beyond use". Will the Unionists agree to that? Lives depend on it. Lives also depend on the words used to describe the province's police force. It cannot continue to be called the Royal Ulster Constabulary, because the Republicans won't accept that, but is there some way of defining it under its new name, the Police Service of Northern Ireland, with words that the Unionists can accept? Everyone is frantically looking for one.

I have just read an article about gay marriage in the Washington weekly magazine, the New Republic. Its author, Andrew Sullivan, will accept nothing less than "marriage" as the word to describe a permanent partnership between a gay or a lesbian couple. The state of Vermont has just decided to create a new institution for gay couples called "civil union". This will accord them all of the rights and responsibilities of a civil marriage between a man and a woman. It is a great victory for gay rights in the United States.

But Sullivan finds it totally unacceptable. "Civil union essentially creates a two-tiered system, with one marriage model clearly superior to the other," he writes. "There are no arguments for civil union that do not apply equally to marriage. To endorse one, but not the other, to concede the substance of the matter while withholding the name and form of the relationship, is to engage in an act of pure stigmatisation." For Mr Sullivan, there can be no complete equality of rights between homosexuals and heterosexuals unless the same time-honoured word, "marriage", is applied to all legally-recognised partnerships. In a similar way, members of the Royal Ulster Constabulary feel stigmatised by their insipid new title.

It is extraordinary how important words remain, especially as they are used so sloppily nowadays. But sloppiness also has its uses when the purpose, as it often is, is to obfuscate. Elisabeth Murdoch, in an interview with the Guardian this week, was at pains not to reveal too much about her reasons for resigning from BskyB - her father Rupert's TV network - to start up her own company. Why did she decide to do it? "I think it was a catalyst for me to be like, 'Okay, I am someone who can do this. And I also thought that it was a good time from the perspective of where Sky is at the moment," she said. You couldn't put it unclearer than that - unless, of course, you are Prince Andrew and the Duchess of York.

Interviewed in the current issue of the Tatler magazine, the prince was asked whether he would consider re-marrying his former wife. "I don't rule re-marriage out, and I certainly don't rule it in," he said. "If ever the opportunity arose, I don't know what I'd do, as it isn't in the plan." Replying to the same question, Fergie said, "I simply say that if it should happen, great. It is not in, nor is it ruled out." Almost impenetrable as these answers are, they are intriguing all the same.

Although Andrew and Fergie have clearly agreed on the same "neither-in-nor-out" formula in discussing the possibility of re-marriage, it would appear that she is rather keener on the idea than he is. Unlike him, she says it would be "great" if it happened, and she reverses the sequence of the formula to make it sound more important that it is not ruled out than that it is not ruled in. The prince, by contrast, says that while he doesn't rule it out, he "certainly" doesn't rule it in, which tips the balance the other way.

According to him, there are also a couple of prerequisites for them getting married for a second time, both of which are puzzling. One is that the "opportunity" must first arise, and the other is that there will first have to be a change in "the plan". What "opportunity"? What "plan"? They are both living in the same house and could decide to re-marry at any time, unless they are being denied the opportunity by someone else - the Queen, perhaps. As for the "plan", whatever it may be, it doesn't presently include the possibility of re-marriage, but could apparently be amended to do so.

Obfuscation is irritating, but at least it represents a desire not to lie. Ken Livingstone was commendably clear in his repeated declarations that he would not, under any circumstances, stand as an independent for mayor of London, but then it turned out he didn't mean any of it. Words cannot be more dangerously misused than that.

webTitle: Only a straight girl could look so butch

fields.headline: Only a straight girl could look so butch
fields.standfirst: 'Lesbianism has become a party to which the world - especially the male half - must be invited if it is to be deemed acceptable'
fields.trailText: Lesbianism has become a party to which the world - especially the male half - must be invited if it is to be deemed acceptable
fields.body:
When I was a chicklet, I liked nothing more of a shimmering 70s Saturday morning than to settle down with a copy of Judy or Bunty, and read comic strips about young gels of humble origin, who, due to their incredible resemblance to the deposed Princess of Tsaratanla, were plucked from the schoolroom and dressed in the finest silks and drippingest diamonds in order to thwart the dastardly efforts of a band of brigands who planned to snatch the princess and hold her for some huge ransom. That the subtext of these stories was quite filthy - the life of royalty obviously mattering much more than the life of a dirty commoner - never bothered me. I thought they were fab and, as a freckled, skinny, blonde child (I know - stop sniggering at the back), wondered whether I could one day be of similar use to my heroine, Hayley Mills.

So, when I saw the photographs of the smiling blonde with the soft bob, long fringe and pouty, baby-pink, lip-glossed lips in the latest issue of OK!, I was relieved that my favourite Spice, Baby, had had the foresight to arrange such a doppelgänger for herself. But, on closer inspection, what were those big biceps doing there? And those dirty great tattoos ? Realisation dawned: it wasn't a stand-in for my beloved Baby, but Sporty! Bitch, stealing Baby's look! Serve her right if she was found throttled with Baby's favourite pink scrunchy. But, according to OK!, the transformation arose from necessity rather than spite. Poor Sporty had been forced to "cast off her tomboy image of kung-fu kicks to an ultra-feminine new one" after becoming "the target of a lot of criticism after less-than-flattering pictures were published of her on holiday with her friend and personal assistant, Chai Ying Yau". This is the same Ying Yau, trivia-hounds might recall, who recently shared a bed in Barbados with Sporty for a whole week, and who was widely mooted by the tabloids as the real Spice love interest. Denials came thick and fast from the Sporty camp, none of which was helped by the fact that a) with her money, such a move on grounds of economy cuts little ice; and b) Ying Yau's very name sounds like the sort of noise a girl might make after a lengthy bout of good cunnilingus.

Personally, I've never thought that Sporty was gay. In my experience, only straight girls dare to look that butch. Your actual 21st-century lesbian tends to stagger about in strappy platform sandals, blind with mascara and dumb with lippy. People with an extreme interest in football often misread cultural signifiers, and a tracksuit and trainers no more make Sporty a dyke than a sarong and scanties make Becks a bender.

What is fascinating isn't whether Sporty does or doesn't, but why she felt she had to go to the lengths of changing her image in order to shake off the rumours. The outing of Stephen Gately makes the Sporty make-over even stranger, for Boyzone are full-on heartthrobs, marketed to appeal to an almost exclusively female audience. It's a long time since the Spice Girls were marketed as pin-up girls for adolescent boys. Indeed, their appeal has always been primarily to very young girls. And George Michael and Elton John: coming out really ruined their careers, didn't it?

But this new tolerance does not seem to extend to lesbians. The career of Ellen DeGeneres - and that of her girlfriend, actress Anne Heche, whom many studios now regard as a non-starter for romantic leads due to public knowledge of her lack of interest in men - remains a warning to all. In the UK, poor old Hufty from The Word was obviously a royal pain, but was she more so than Terry Christian, who is still hanging on in there? And, while Mandelson and Chris Smith strut about in robes of office, Angela Eagle MP is something less than a household name. This would be annoying and illogical under any circumstances, but in tandem with the current vogue for Thespian Lesbianism - lad-mag babes stripping off and cuddling up to each other for the delectation of the nation's onanists - it is downright nasty. Lesbianism, it seems, has become a party to which the world, especially the male half, must be invited if it is to be acceptable. When it is done for the satisfaction of the participants rather than for the viewers, it reverts to its former status of neighbourhood threat and moral evil. Oh, you and your girlfriend want to make love behind closed doors, do you? Bloody spoilsports! And, by the way, you're fired. There is no such Peeping Tom pressure on gay men - imagine how odd we would find it if magazines for young women routinely featured photographs of pretty boys in their underwear snogging. It's no accident that DeGeneres is only now making a comeback by stripping off for a TV sex scene with Sharon Stone. That's more like it: give the boys a thrill!

Perhaps this is just a variation on my old riff of the modern habit of rewarding people who pretend to do a thing with far more approval and money than the people who actually do it (compare the money paid to doctors and nurses with the money paid to actors pretending to be doctors and nurses). But it is far more likely that, while it has always been socially acceptable for a man to make himself unavailable to women (which gay men do in extremis, and which straight men do in various ways all the time), it is still not acceptable for a woman to make herself unavailable to men, which is what lesbians, by their nature, do. One of the creepiest expressions of this double standard is the current vogue for films in which a sad straight woman clings to her gay male best friend. Imagine a rash of films in which a sad straight man pined after his lesbian best friend - it just wouldn't work, because, post-Bridget Jones, we are so used to the lie that women are inherently masochistic in emotional matters, and rejection by men their natural lot, that being with a man who doesn't want you is pretty much par for the course. The straight man/lesbian friend scenario would only ever be acceptable if, in the end, she renounced her sexuality and fell into his arms.

In the very same copy of OK!, by the way, Julian Clary could be seen as the guest of honour at the Wills Bowls Club, Swindon, of which his parents are club captains this year. In a dark suit and discreet make-up, this campest of comics bathed in the smiles and approval of the club's elderly and, one might venture, conservative-with-a-small-c members. At a time when female members of golf clubs, most of them married, routinely receive sexually-oriented hate-mail accusing them of being "dykes" if they request the same access to their own club's greens as male golfers, this seemed a poignant reminder of how, even within the realms of "deviancy", men have the upper hand. Who can blame poor Sporty for dragging up?

webTitle: How to tell the time without a watch

fields.headline: How to tell the time without a watch
fields.trailText: Some people have a perfect in-built clock - they could be held hostage for 13 years underground and know when they come out that they're just in time for Coronation Street. Others haven't - they'll be the person for whom you spend hours waiting in the rain, wondering whether they've actually been taken hostage.
fields.body:
Some people have a perfect in-built clock - they could be held hostage for 13 years underground and know when they come out that they're just in time for Coronation Street. Others haven't - they'll be the person for whom you spend hours waiting in the rain, wondering whether they've actually been taken hostage.

People without internal clocks are always surprised when their alarm goes off at 7.30am on a work day. They would be much more comfortable with an alarm that went off an hour-and-a-half after they set it, and then made a pathetic excuse. These are the people who operate on NMT+30, which is Normal Meeting Time plus 30 minutes. It doesn't matter if you turn up half-an-hour later than planned, because they are always 30 minutes behind you.

You can, of course, tell the time by the sun. If you work out the height of the sun relative to the horizon, you can work out that it's exactly the time you need to rush to the eye hospital to have your retinas replaced.

You can also work out the time from the position of the stars. When they are directly above you, it's time to stop drinking because you have fallen over.

Animals are also natural clocks. Cocks are the first thing to wake up in the morning (stop it), and they tend, like most early risers, to crow about it. Exactly three minutes afterwards, your dog bounds into the room and jumps on your groin. After that, the animal clock isn't very useful. You can work until the cows come home, but by all accounts they tend to work late. On the other hand, if you hear an owl at your desk, you can be sure it's time to go home or else delete your RSPB screensaver.

Turning the television on will always give you a clue: if the first thing you see is something odd in a foreign language or a programme with explicit biological content, you can be pretty sure it's either Channel 4 in the early hours or the Open University in the shockingly early hours.

Your stomach has an extremely sophisticated clock. The big hand will always know exactly when it's time for you to stop for lunch, while the little hand will always say it's time to stop for a quick chocolate Hobnob. Finally, you can look at the contents of your wallet: when there's nothing in it, it's time to stop shopping and go to work.

fields.headline: The knowledge
fields.standfirst: Garlic, the raw facts, part 1
fields.trailText: Garlic, the raw facts, part 1
fields.body:
The subject
Allium sativum - the fragrant, indispensable bulb.

The basics
Looking at a clove of garlic, you wouldn't dream what was inside it. To wit: vitamins (A, B and C), a number of other trace elements, and sulphur compounds - some 75 in all. The sulphur is what makes garlic garlic. Compound in chief: allicin, formed by enzymatic action when a clove is cut or crushed. Allicin gives garlic its aroma and flavour. More cell-thumping = more allicin. In other words: cut, don't crush, if you want a milder effect.

The details
Garlic is the most mythologised foodstuff on earth - Bulby The Vampire Slayer. A medicine, according to some ancient writers. A toxin, according to others. Possessor of antiseptic properties, according to doctors, who used it to cleanse wounds (and treat typhus and dysentery) during the first world war. An antimicrobial agent, according to Israeli studies of the mid-90s. A putative protector against cancer (antioxidant properties) and cardiovascular disease (supposedly lowers cholesterol and triglycerides, and prevents atherosclerosis). Reasons to use it? No. Sound evidence is hard to come by, and many researchers don't believe any of it. Even worse, the best 'medicinal' garlic may be supplements rather than fresh cloves; and the fresh stuff is what the Knowledge knows to be best for eating. Regard the health benefits, if any, as an incidental gain.

Where to buy
Anywhere. How to buy: look for rock-hardness, smooth husks (that is, the papery skins shouldn't be in a general state of disrepair), and no trace of green shoots sprouting out of the top of the bulb. What to buy: white-skinned garlic generally has the strongest taste; pink-tinged Mediterranean varieties are tops for delicacy; fist-sized elephant garlic has its fans, possibly for curiosity value. New season's garlic, now appearing on our shelves, is sweet, delicate, and a pain to peel.

The easy way out
All will be revealed next week in Garlic 2: The Cook Strikes Back.
