"There are lots of different things - old tracks, alignments between sites, astronomical alignments, and so on - which could all come under the ley lines umbrella. Watkins, at the end, was saying that there were different classes of alignments. What was he really seeing?" The more convincing alignments, Sullivan believes, were probably corpse ways or funeral paths. These designated paths by which the dead were carried to their place of burial have been documented all over Europe, frequently showing up on medieval maps and sometimes surviving into this century in the form of local folklore. Some were deliberately crooked - in order, perhaps, that the spirit of the deceased might not return to haunt the living. But others were straight, and clearly sighted on the towers of churches. "In China," says Sullivan, "evil spirits were thought to travel in straight lines, so the route had to be blocked with a wall containing a charm. In Ireland, 'fairy passes' ran between places of ancient sanctity. In Bolivia, straight lines run from hilltops, where spirits were thought to live, directly into towns and churches. In South America and the south-west US, where these things are still on the ground, they conform uncannily to Watkins's original ideas. Yet they are on another continent and belong to a completely different culture, which suggests that there's something going on that is universal." The common thread, it seems, is the widespread belief that spirits, ghosts and fairies all travel in straight lines - a notion that Devereux thinks might derive from the sensations experienced in all places and at all times by humans in those altered states of consciousness known to be induced by shamanic rituals or the use of hallucinogens. Shamanism? Hallucinogens? At first glance, it's a far cry from the stiff-collared, sepia world of Alfred Watkins. And yet there's another common thread running through all of this - a thread that links the first ley-hunters with their most modern counterparts. I refer not to any out-of-body experience, but to the simple out-of-car experience that Lionel Stanbrook describes. "It can be left to a coterie of hardened intellectuals to discuss the whys and wherefores of shamanism or whatever," he says. "But for me, it's about getting people off the sofa and into the open air. It's about being excited by our own heritage and about climbing to the tops of hills and admiring the view with a sense of adventure and of mystery and imagination."  Ley Lines - A Comprehensive Guide To Alignments, by Danny Sullivan, is published by Piatkus Books, priced £16.99. For details about the Society Of Ley Hunters, which was due to hold its inaugural meeting in Hassocks, West Sussex, last Saturday, write to PO Box 1634, Hassocks BN6 8BZ.

fields.headline: Take no prisoners
fields.standfirst: Andrea Dworkin is famous for her uncompromising feminism. But why has she now turned her attention to Israel? And how did that lead to such a surprising - and shocking - conclusion?
fields.trailText: Andrea Dworkin is famous for her uncompromising feminism. But why has she now turned her attention to Israel? And how did that lead to such a surprising - and shocking - conclusion?
fields.body:
At the age of 10, Andrea Dworkin would travel from her suburban home to attend Hebrew school in the city. One day, she arrived to find the school closed, so she went to her cousin's house to call her mother. She found her cousin going crazy. "She was bouncing off the walls, I mean, I'd never seen anything like it," said Dworkin. "It was April, and she said that every April she remembered." Passover, which usually occurs in April, is the time when Jews remember the Holocaust. The Warsaw Ghetto uprising began on the eve of Passover. Remembering is a big Jewish thing.

Dworkin's cousin was doing more than remembering. "She was having what we now call flashbacks. At that point [in 1956] the Jewish community was not talking about the Holocaust, and the survivors were not talking about it, so I had the incredible experience - not of being there, but of really seeing the viscera of somebody who had been there. I had no intellectual defence for this. I could see what she was describing to me, even now, and I would say something fairly stupid, like, but why did they do that? She described the babies being used as targets by the guy that Ralph Fiennes played in Schindler's List and eventually we called my mother and she came and got me and did something to help her, I'm not sure what."

Dworkin's cousin had been in the Krakow ghetto, then Plaszow, Auschwitz-Birkenau and Buchenwald. Finally, she had survived a death march. When Dworkin got to college, years later, the first thing she did was to "sit down in the library with the Nuremberg trials and read them, volumes of them. I've been very involved in trying to learn about the Holocaust and trying to understand it, which is probably pointless. I have read Holocaust material, you might say compulsively, over a lifetime. I might go through six months when I won't read it and a few months when I will and I have been doing that since I was a kid."

Dworkin is, in the popular imagination, the spearhead of radical feminism, of anti-pornography. Her books (with titles such as Woman Hating, Pornography: Men Possessing Women, and Life And Death: Unapologetic Writings On The Continuing War Against Women) are filled with descriptions of what she considers the inherent violence of heterosexual relations, and the sadism that permeates the sex industry. The common view is that Dworkin began to write about porn because of her own traumatic marriage, in which being beaten and kicked wasn't an occasional incident, but the everyday. But now it turns out she is a woman who, for almost all her life, has been drawn to horror. Since she first sat down in the college library to find out what her cousin was raving about, she has been reading about sadism. Fascism, misogyny, they're all the same to her. The exposure began at an impressionable age.

And now she has published what she believes to be her life's work, nine years in the making; not another assault on gender relations or the sex industry but a polemical account of modern Israel and the lessons it holds for women. It is a book which many Zionists, non-Zionists, Palestinians, scholars of the Holocaust, pacifists, the left, women, men, are bound to find offensive. Scapegoat: The Jews, Israel And Women's Liberation, sparked by a visit to Israel in 1988, is a critique of Middle East politics which sees the whole situation as a product of wounded and then enraged testosterone. It is an analysis of the Holocaust and Israel through the eye of gender relations, drawing together strands of Zionism, feminism and Holocaust studies to produce a radical new thesis: that the Jews, downtrodden, had to fight back; and that women, downtrodden, must do the same.

I jumped at the chance to meet Andrea Dworkin. Why? Because she is Andrea Dworkin. Many people think she is totally crazy, and indeed she seems to have turned her own life's experience, as an abused wife, into a universal principle. But she remains, for me, the woman who showed us the dark core of pornography, the punishing hatred of women that pervades it. There is nothing erotic about being sexually sold, she told us. The sex industry is founded on factories which turn human beings very quickly into waste material. Often people found her work unbearable to read, they couldn't understand why she wanted to go grubbing around in such filth. We didn't want to know. Like the Holocaust back in the 50s, porn was not something you talked about; and anyway, we were anti-censorship, weren't we? She made us face up to the reality of porn.

At first she wanted me to meet her at her local Starbucks, but I protested against the noise. Reluctantly, she agreed to let me meet her at her house but asked a young friend round to answer the door and sit in on the interview. She told me certain very innocuous things, which she said were off the record, though I've no idea why. I was warned that she is "a very private person". I had to come at night because that is when she is awake. Early evening is morning for her. She lives in a sombre brownstone in Brooklyn with her friend and partner, the writer John Stoltenberg. The house is all dark wood floors, a dark wooden staircase and the walls a murky pink, where they can be seen at all beneath shelves and shelves and shelves of books, many of them about the evil things that go on in this world of ours. The light fittings are original, from the turn of the century, except for a few, which are duplicates she found in second-hand shops.

We sat in the kitchen. She was wearing round her neck a small piece of jewellery, a star of David. She is a very Jewish Jew. "I have been reading about Jewish history all of my life," she said. "I had a very strong Jewish education, and Jewish scholarship taught me scholarship, that's how I learnt to think analytically." When our time was up and I was waiting for my taxi, when the tape was off and she seemed to relax because I was going, we talked about how we had both grown up in traditional Jewish homes, where the women went to the synagogue and sat in the ladies gallery watching the men below get on with the business of the religion. Her mother was, she says, "all surfaces". I described how I had watched my father being "called up", the moment of great honour when a man of the congregation gets to go and read aloud from the holiest of Jewish texts and how when he had finished he would walk along the rows of seats while eager hands reached out to shake his, to congratulate him on this mitzvah. "And I wanted to do that but I couldn't because I was a woman," I said. "Well," Dworkin replied, "I wanted to be the rabbi."

She was a good Jewish girl in a pro-Israel home: "And all of my remaining family are, I would say, Zionist zealots." She remains a supporter of Israel's right to exist, of the Jewish right to have their own state and the Jewish right to fight back against those who tried and still try to kill them; just as she thinks that women have the right to fight back, even kill, the men who have abused them. "I've been a pacifist all of my life, currently lapsed, and maybe before I die I'll go back to my religion, which is pacifism," she said.

She begins her book with a torrent of rage against anti-Semitism. After what was done to the Jews, how could they not arm themselves, she asks? This book, like the others on misogyny and pornography, spares the reader nothing in its gruelling accounts of what actually happened during 2,000 years of Jew hating. Page after page peers into the dark abyss: state-sponsored pogroms, death camps, Jews with their skin flayed off and thrown to the dogs. She writes about things hardly ever spoken of before: the role women played in the wartime Resistance that history seems to have ignored; the fabled heroes of the Warsaw Ghetto uprising who, during the height of their defiance against the Nazis, rounded up three Jewish women and used them as prostitutes; and most chillingly, the activities of Irma Grese, the camp guard at Auschwitz-Birkenau and Bergen-Belsen who reached orgasm by whipping women to death.

Unlike many on the Left, including the Jewish Left, Dworkin was never anti-Israel. She attributed to the country ideas about socialism and equality which were indeed part of the founding vision, right up to the Declaration of Independence. So that 1988 visit, her first, came as a big shock: "I was devastated by the situation of women, so the obvious thing for me to ask was, why are Jewish women so subordinated and treated so badly, have so few rights? I met with a lot of activists, feminists, and I came back to the United States really, really angry that feminists who had been to Israel a whole lot more than I had, had basically been keeping all this stuff secret. It enraged me. And I couldn't shake it. And that's why I started writing."

What she found in Israel was a male- dominated, militaristic society. Okay, women did compulsory military service but not in combat roles. The rabbis had to declare Golda Meir an honorary male before they could recognise her as prime minister. She understood why Israeli men were such tough nuts but was furious at the effect on society. "Pacifism was dead, killed by the Nazis along with the six million," she writes. "There would be no more feminised, gentle, Jewish males, no more 'Yid'." With the death of the bookish "nebbish" - the Woody Allen type - the new, tough Jews emerged, not victims but the invincible Israeli army. Jewish machismo turned the 1948 Israeli Declaration of Independence, which specifically spoke of equality and women's rights, into a travesty - "Debased men need to degrade women . . . Once debased, men become powerful men, the degrading of women becomes a state protected right."

Moreover, she found that Israel was a country built on a form of "near apartheid" against Palestinians and Arab Israelis. The Israeli army tortured Palestinian men and then went home to masturbate to Holocaust-themed pornography (the army's use of torture "eliminates ethical Judaism from the boundaries of the Israeli state and state action," she writes); Israeli soldiers clandestinely took photographs of Palestinian women in shop changing-rooms to blackmail them into collaborating. Dworkin sees the whole of post-war history as a game of consequences, with women always the losers: the Nazis emasculated the Jews, the Jews took it out on the Palestinians and Jewish women; and the Palestinians, emasculated in turn by the Jews, vented their loss of masculinity on the only people left who were weaker than themselves - Palestinian women. "For certain Israel is a nation state," she writes. "For certain no one kicks sand in the face of the Israeli men; for certain hatred of Arabs is useful in sustaining male rage and a willingness to injure and kill; for certain, militarist heroes do not get bashed by the international community or Amnesty International or human rights groups for beating their wives or for killing them."

Seeing Israel through the lens of gender instead of race or religion or geopolitics cuts through much of the heated ideology that surrounds any attempt to find some kind of just solution to the two sets of victims in the Middle East. I have very little patience with the question asked by some non-Jews, "How could the Jews, who went through the Holocaust, behave like that?" Because, as Dworkin writes, inflict pain on someone and they'll inflict pain on someone else. We know this from the psychology of sexual abuse when the abused themselves may become an abuser. But the Palestinians - abused by the abused - are not let off lightly in this book: she claims that the Arab world maintains the refugee camps at Gaza to further their own political ends; that the Palestinians fall for Holocaust denial to undermine Israel's right to exist; that many Arab feminists romanticise freedom fighters who, in the name of religion and nationalism, abuse women. But most of all, Dworkin is enraged with Israeli men for betraying what she regards as elemental Jewish morality and values - the ones she held dear when she dreamed of being a rabbi and a scholar.

Back home in America, she has been berated for criticising Israel from a comfortable distance. "People always say to me, the Israelis are there, they're the ones whose lives are at stake. It's not me that's going to die if somebody thinks I'm right and they end up with a bullet in their brain. But I must say that looking at the situation of women suggests to me that the Israelis need enemies. I see the consistency of women being an internal enemy in virtually every country I look at, and certainly throughout the Middle East. Israel is not an exception. If there weren't the Palestinians, who are they going to shoot? Who are they going to define themselves against? They had to prove that they were virile. After the Holocaust, every Jewish man had to prove that he had not been castrated and nobody could come and take him away, and the Israeli army became the form for doing that."

Dworkin hasn't been back to Israel since the 1988 visit and Scapegoat is very far from being a book of reportage. It is an analysis of source material - of scholarly works, diaries, letters, survivor testimony, eye witness accounts; there is little contemporary detail. No mention is made, for instance, of Dana International, the transsexual who was Israel's official entry to the Eurovision Song Contest two years ago. When I asked why, I was completely astounded to discover that Dworkin had never heard of her. Okay, Eurovision may not be shown on American television but if you are engaged in a nine-year study of Israel and gender you'd have thought that a sex-change diva singing to 500 million people would not have escaped your attention. Dana International is the Israel of the new millennium - not just the gay community's heroine but representing the young people of Tel Aviv's Shenkin Street, for whom the army is an unwelcome interruption between high school and the hippie trail to Goa and Thailand.

Dworkin remained unimpressed. She's not interested in gay men, she's interested in women. "It's almost always a mistake to take tokenism as real movement. When I was there I found that there was only one lesbian who was prepared to come out. John and I watched a movie called Trick before you arrived, and it's about a young man looking for love and he somehow finds it with this ideal-looking other man - but the whole thing was built on hatred of women, it was absolutely extraordinary. So you can have those permutations of masculinity, which look like a big change, but they don't actually change the machismo factor. I do it as much as anybody else, looking for social change and thinking okay, at least that has moved a little bit but it usually is really a very little bit, I think."

Scapegoat displays a kind of love-hate relationship with Israel. Dworkin loves the idea of Jews fighting in, and for, a Jewish state; hates the fact that misogyny and violence are the result of it. At the end of the book's longest chapter, which makes a link between Zionism and women's liberation, she asks an extremely pertinent question: "What will women do? Is there a plan? And if not, why not?" When one wonders how the Jews managed to create a country, and why they managed to defend it despite being overwhelmingly outnumbered, the answer is - there was a plan. There was a strategy, there were tactics. If the Jews knew anything it was how to organise, how to maintain discipline, how to be tough and how to be single-minded in their goals. As for feminism, there no longer seems to be any plan at all, no political organisation, no goals, no strategy.

"It's been the biggest breach between me and other feminists," Dworkin says, "that I believe that the women's movement is a political movement and a political movement has aims and strategies and makes advances and sometimes suffers defeat but then goes on. I had two really interesting experiences. One was talking to Emile Habiby, a very fine Palestinian writer and the first Arab to be given the Israel Prize [for literature]. He's been a left radical for a long time. He was blown away by Mercy [Dworkin's 1990 novel, about sexual abuse] but he said to me at one point, 'I have the feeling that you mean it' and I said to him, 'Yes, I do.' And I had the same experience in the Republic of Ireland where some very tired, corrupt IRA person was talking with me. And he said, 'Wait a minute, you intend to win' and I said 'Yes'. This is a political struggle, it's not a social movement for a different kind of clothes, it's not a lifestyle movement. I think that's where all of our trouble is. Great numbers of women felt very happy in finding out things that they had not known before about women's history and women's lives but were not prepared to do what the Jews did. We were not prepared to decide strategically what do we need to do, what do we want and how do we get it."

So now we come to what Andrea Dworkin wants and it is this: she wants women to have their own country. But that's mad, I said to her. Why bother discussing it? It isn't going to happen. To which she has a reply - didn't they say that about Israel? And didn't the world think that Theodor Herzl, the founder of the Zionist movement, was a crank? The Jews got a country because they had been persecuted, said that enough was enough, decided what they wanted and went out and fought for it. Women should do the same. And if you don't want to live in Womenland, so what? Not all Jews live in Israel, but it is there, a place of potential refuge if persecution comes to call. Furthermore, Dworkin says, as the Jews fought for Israel so women have the right to execute - that's right, execute - rapists and the state should not intervene. I couldn't really believe she was serious, but she is.

"The last chapter - that's my favourite chapter," she said, regarding the section of her book proposing a nation state for women, and her face lit up when I referred to it. "The first time I thought about this, strangely enough, was when I was reading for my book on pornography and I read half a dozen books on the Marquis de Sade and it occurred to me that if his first victim had shot him, all the other victims wouldn't have happened, and I think - I really believe - that a woman has the right to execute a man who has raped her. If a woman is raped she has a right to retaliate and the state doesn't have a right to intervene."

But that's not going to happen, I protested, again. "It might happen, it could happen," she said. Then we began to talk about this women's country. Wouldn't it wind up exactly like Israel itself - a utopian dream which like all utopias, inevitably turns out not quite as expected? "No, I don't think it would be an ideal place," Dworkin agreed. "Women tried to establish co-ops and communes throughout the 70s and a lot of them broke down, not because of outside pressure but because of internal politics. I'm not saying that's the only solution but I'm saying it's an incredible thing to overlook as a possibility. We've never dealt with the issue of sovereignty and I think that's because we've never understood that what we want we can only get through a really serious political movement. It would have many parts, it would have to; it would have the ladies, it would have the girls, it would have everybody and all different shades of politics would be necessary."

And the female sadists? Would a woman's state have the Irma Greses, the Rosemary Wests, the Myra Hindleys? What distinguishes Dworkin from many of her contemporaries is that she has never swallowed any of the guff about women having all that nurturing caring gentleness encoded within the DNA. "In the last five or 10 years I've got sick of this endless 'Women can be bad, too, women can commit crimes'," she says. "Look at these women who were the guards at Birkenau and other camps as well. Maybe what the Nazis created was a celebration for sadists and maybe in other circumstances that sadist would have stayed at home and beaten her children, I don't know. But there is no question about whether women can be evil, it's not a question. The only place where hate really plays a role in my life is around the Nazis, I really hate them and I really hate those women."

Perhaps there is something prurient about Dworkin's interest both in fascism and in pornography - George Steiner once wrote that the problem with this stuff is that it flatters the attention. Sometimes Dworkin almost seems to be too fascinated as she extracts yet another atrocity - against Jews, against women - from the shadows. Rape or pogrom, snuff movie or death camp, what's the difference? On the other hand, Steiner also speaks of the "sheer incapacity of the 'normal' mind to imagine and hence give active belief to the enormities of the circumstance". And perhaps Dworkin does not have a normal mind and so can do what the rest of us cannot do: go on reading when anyone with any sense would say, "Enough. I know what happened. I don't need to know everything that happened." But maybe someone has to know, read, catalogue all the horrors. As Gloria Steinem said, "In every century, there are a handful of writers who help the human race evolve. Andrea is one of them."

Is she mad? Not in the sense of those American feminists such as Kate Millett and Shulamith Firestone, who really did lose their minds. Millett lives in poverty in New England, selling Christmas trees on the street. Firestone, says Dworkin, is "poor and crazy. She rents a room in a house and fills it with junk, then gets kicked out and moves into another room and fills that with junk."

Dworkin lives in a nice, comfortable house in a middle-class Brooklyn neighbourhood. People pay attention to what she says. To Dworkin, herself, everything she says and thinks and writes has its logic and she can't understand why others don't always see it. In her book, Intercourse, she argued that every act of penetrative sex is potentially an act of rape. It wasn't a metaphor. She is always literal. I went to see her with a million questions - "How can you think this? It's not practical! It doesn't make sense!" But she will not be deflected.

In person she is not angry. She is calm. She gets up and feeds the cat. She pours cranberry juice mixed with seltzer. She only wants you to know what she knows and if you did, then how could you not draw the same conclusions as she does? And you have to say this about her: she has survived to go on writing long after many of her contemporaries in the women's movement - Ti-Grace Atkinson, Robin Morgan, Mary Daly - are names known only within a dwindling circle. But, whomever I talked to, male or female, when I said I was going to meet Andrea Dworkin they knew exactly who she was and they all asked the same thing. Is she crazy? What's she like? Does she really mean all that stuff?

Well, yes, she does

Dworkin: What I believe

I am an enemy of nationalism and male domination. This means that I repudiate all nationalism except my own and reject the dominance of all men except those I love. In this I am like every other woman, a pretender to rebellion because to break with patriarchy I would need to betray my own: the ones with whom I share a group identity, in this case Jewish, and a presumed history, in this case Jewish men. They have not hesitated to betray me through assertions of superiority intended to hurt my human rights and my human dignity. In this, too, I am like every other woman. Feminists try hard to fight for women at the same time maintaining special loyalties to sub-groups of men. How could we not? I have grown sick of those loyalties, which protect brutal acts as if they were heroic.

The line between self-defence and aggression has been breached by my particular ethnic group represented by the Israeli government; the line itself is often not self-evident in that violent acts sometimes serve to head off enemy attack and are arguably a form of self-defence. I believe that threatened peoples and individuals have a right to self-defence.

This goes against the pacifism that has been instrumental in my political life. My pacifism was first challenged when, working on my book on pornography in the late 70s, Pornography: Men Possessing Women, I read a half-dozen biographies of the Marquis de Sade. A life of rape and sexual violence, including kidnapping and possibly murder, would have been stopped short if his first (known) victim, Jeanne Testard, had killed him. I will say here what I have never said before: my pacifism was not challenged by the beating and torture I experienced in marriage some 30 years ago; I finally got away not because I knew that he would kill me, but because I thought I would kill him.

Understand: this is true generally of women - his life meant more to me than my own; but also I was not willing to kill, even to escape beating and his own promise, which I believed, that he would kill me. Once having had the serious and true thought that one of his victims should have offed the good Marquis, it was impossible not to apply that insight to the widespread, contemporary beatings and rapes that women sustain. Especially, I have seen a legal system designed to protect male privilege work to do just that. I have seen a generation of anti-rape activists and anti-battery activists sit through trials of guilty men who almost always walk. Like those advocates, I have seen rapists acquitted, batterers put back in the home, child-rapers given custody of the incested child. The legal system is so genuinely perverse that women rarely report crimes involving either rape or battery.

I am, as a result, a lapsed pacifist. I truly abhor violence, and I believe that both nationalism and male dominance are systems that promote and produce violence. With extreme difficulty and reluctance, I have come to believe that women have to be literate in both strategic violence and the violence of self-defence. It is one thing to choose not to kill; it is quite another to be defenceless by virtue of ignorance and socialisation. Women have mastered the articulation of violence on behalf of national liberation movements, including the Jewish liberation movement called Zionism, the claim of a material right to land and sovereignty in the ancient territory of Palestine.

For a couple of thousand years - after the destruction of the second Temple in 70 CE - Jews, including Jewish men, were seen as inherently pacifistic, genetically pacifistic, as are women; the existence of the 20th-century Jewish state and its defence suggest that this pacifism was socially constructed and had no relationship at all to any particle of DNA or to testosterone or any other inevitable hormone or biological fact. The perceived gentleness of Jewish men before the establishment of the state never suggested to anyone that men as a whole could live the way that Jewish men had lived: which is to say, without publicly committed violence. Rather, this perception encouraged group violence against Jews in pogroms and in the Holocaust.

Is it the same with women? I have been trying to grasp the Holocaust since I was 10 years old and had Auschwitz-Birkenau told to me by a survivor who was having unbearable flashbacks. In 1988, I went to Israel. I had the honour (as had happened in Northern Ireland in 1983) of meeting a great number of women activists (in Israel both Jewish and Arab) in a very short time. There was no small talk. I was distressed by what I found, including Holocaust-themed pornography and battered and raped women. Why would I expect it to be different? The answer is simple: because the Israelis are my guys, a miracle of self-determination and courage. Well, they took the land; but they had to. I continue to believe that they (we) had to; but brutality has become institutionalised in Israel as expressions of male dominance and state sovereignty - over Jewish/Israeli women as well as over Palestinian men and women.

Would I be so troubled if Jewish women were not among the conquered? Yes, but: I think that women are the internal enemy regardless of the ethnic or racial or nationalist status of the group's men; and that Israel is a perfect example of how male dominance grows in a new state - it needs the subordination of one's own women and the subordination of a racial or ethnic other: it needs internal and external scapegoats. Israel both embodies and protects male Jews; but the Jewish women inside the state have been disarmed - the pattern for women in liberation struggles that succeed.

Yet across the ethnic conflict, Israeli and Palestinian women, often motivated by feminist ambitions and feminist ideas, have found ways to work together. This is a fact more hopeful than the outcome of any election or provisional dictatorship. Cooperation is the female equivalent of male conflict, a way of operating in a world filled with injury and hate. This is a social, not a biological, point. In the nine-year course of writing this book, I have become certain of one thing: that women cannot be free of male dominance without challenging the men of one's own ethnic group and destroying their authority. This is a willed betrayal, as any assault on male dominance must be.

 Scapegoat: Jews, Israel And Women's Liberation, by Andrea Dworkin, is published by Virago on June 8, priced £22.50. I've been very involved in trying to learn about the Holocaust and trying to understand it, which is probably pointless. I have read Holocaust material, you might say compulsively, over a lifetime. I might go through six months when I won't read it and a few months when I will and I have been doing that since I was a kid." Dworkin is, in the popular imagination, the spearhead of radical feminism, of anti-pornography. Her books (with titles such as Woman Hating, Pornography: Men Possessing Women, and Life And Death: Unapologetic Writings On The Continuing War Against Women) are filled with descriptions of what she considers the inherent violence of heterosexual relations, and the sadism that permeates the sex industry. The common view is that Dworkin began to write about porn because of her own traumatic marriage, in which being beaten and kicked wasn't an occasional incident, but the everyday. But now it turns out she is a woman who, for almost all her life, has been drawn to horror. Since she first sat down in the college library to find out what her cousin was raving about, she has been reading about sadism. Fascism, misogyny, they're all the same to her. The exposure began at an impressionable age. And now she has published what she believes to be her life's work, nine years in the making; not another assault on gender relations or the sex industry but a polemical account of modern Israel and the lessons it holds for women. It is a book which many Zionists, non-Zionists, Palestinians, scholars of the Holocaust, pacifists, the left, women, men, are bound to find offensive. Scapegoat: The Jews, Israel And Women's Liberation, sparked by a visit to Israel in 1988, is a critique of Middle East politics which sees the whole situation as a product of wounded and then enraged testosterone. It is an analysis of the Holocaust and Israel through the eye of gender relations, drawing together strands of Zionism, feminism and Holocaust studies to produce a radical new thesis: that the Jews, downtrodden, had to fight back; and that women, downtrodden, must do the same. I jumped at the chance to meet Andrea Dworkin. Why? Because she is Andrea Dworkin. Many people think she is totally crazy, and indeed she seems to have turned her own life's experience, as an abused wife, into a universal principle. But she remains, for me, the woman who showed us the dark core of pornography, the punishing hatred of women that pervades it. There is nothing erotic about being sexually sold, she told us. The sex industry is founded on factories which turn human beings very quickly into waste material. Often people found her work unbearable to read, they couldn't understand why she wanted to go grubbing around in such filth. We didn't want to know. Like the Holocaust back in the 50s, porn was not something you talked about; and anyway, we were anti-censorship, weren't we? She made us face up to the reality of porn. At first she wanted me to meet her at her local Starbucks, but I protested against the noise. Reluctantly, she agreed to let me meet her at her house but asked a young friend round to answer the door and sit in on the interview. She told me certain very innocuous things, which she said were off the record, though I've no idea why. I was warned that she is "a very private person". I had to come at night because that is when she is awake. Early evening is morning for her. She lives in a sombre brownstone in Brooklyn with her friend and partner, the writer John Stoltenberg. The house is all dark wood floors, a dark wooden staircase and the walls a murky pink, where they can be seen at all beneath shelves and shelves and shelves of books, many of them about the evil things that go on in this world of ours. The light fittings are original, from the turn of the century, except for a few, which are duplicates she found in second-hand shops. We sat in the kitchen. She was wearing round her neck a small piece of jewellery, a star of David. She is a very Jewish Jew. "I have been reading about Jewish history all of my life," she said. "I had a very strong Jewish education, and Jewish scholarship taught me scholarship, that's how I learnt to think analytically." When our time was up and I was waiting for my taxi, when the tape was off and she seemed to relax because I was going, we talked about how we had both grown up in traditional Jewish homes, where the women went to the synagogue and sat in the ladies gallery watching the men below get on with the business of the religion. Her mother was, she says, "all surfaces". I described how I had watched my father being "called up", the moment of great honour when a man of the congregation gets to go and read aloud from the holiest of Jewish texts and how when he had finished he would walk along the rows of seats while eager hands reached out to shake his, to congratulate him on this mitzvah. "And I wanted to do that but I couldn't because I was a woman," I said. "Well," Dworkin replied, "I wanted to be the rabbi." She was a good Jewish girl in a pro-Israel home: "And all of my remaining family are, I would say, Zionist zealots." She remains a supporter of Israel's right to exist, of the Jewish right to have their own state and the Jewish right to fight back against those who tried and still try to kill them; just as she thinks that women have the right to fight back, even kill, the men who have abused them. "I've been a pacifist all of my life, currently lapsed, and maybe before I die I'll go back to my religion, which is pacifism," she said. She begins her book with a torrent of rage against anti-Semitism. After what was done to the Jews, how could they not arm themselves, she asks? This book, like the others on misogyny and pornography, spares the reader nothing in its gruelling accounts of what actually happened during 2,000 years of Jew hating. Page after page peers into the dark abyss: state-sponsored pogroms, death camps, Jews with their skin flayed off and thrown to the dogs. She writes about things hardly ever spoken of before: the role women played in the wartime Resistance that history seems to have ignored; the fabled heroes of the Warsaw Ghetto uprising who, during the height of their defiance against the Nazis, rounded up three Jewish women and used them as prostitutes; and most chillingly, the activities of Irma Grese, the camp guard at Auschwitz-Birkenau and Bergen-Belsen who reached orgasm by whipping women to death. Unlike many on the Left, including the Jewish Left, Dworkin was never anti-Israel. She attributed to the country ideas about socialism and equality which were indeed part of the founding vision, right up to the Declaration of Independence. So that 1988 visit, her first, came as a big shock: "I was devastated by the situation of women, so the obvious thing for me to ask was, why are Jewish women so subordinated and treated so badly, have so few rights? I met with a lot of activists, feminists, and I came back to the United States really, really angry that feminists who had been to Israel a whole lot more than I had, had basically been keeping all this stuff secret. It enraged me. And I couldn't shake it. And that's why I started writing." What she found in Israel was a male- dominated, militaristic society. Okay, women did compulsory military service but not in combat roles. The rabbis had to declare Golda Meir an honorary male before they could recognise her as prime minister. She understood why Israeli men were such tough nuts but was furious at the effect on society. "Pacifism was dead, killed by the Nazis along with the six million," she writes. "There would be no more feminised, gentle, Jewish males, no more 'Yid'." With the death of the bookish "nebbish" - the Woody Allen type - the new, tough Jews emerged, not victims but the invincible Israeli army. Jewish machismo turned the 1948 Israeli Declaration of Independence, which specifically spoke of equality and women's rights, into a travesty - "Debased men need to degrade women . . . Once debased, men become powerful men, the degrading of women becomes a state protected right." Moreover, she found that Israel was a country built on a form of "near apartheid" against Palestinians and Arab Israelis. The Israeli army tortured Palestinian men and then went home to masturbate to Holocaust-themed pornography (the army's use of torture "eliminates ethical Judaism from the boundaries of the Israeli state and state action," she writes); Israeli soldiers clandestinely took photographs of Palestinian women in shop changing-rooms to blackmail them into collaborating. Dworkin sees the whole of post-war history as a game of consequences, with women always the losers: the Nazis emasculated the Jews, the Jews took it out on the Palestinians and Jewish women; and the Palestinians, emasculated in turn by the Jews, vented their loss of masculinity on the only people left who were weaker than themselves - Palestinian women. "For certain Israel is a nation state," she writes. "For certain no one kicks sand in the face of the Israeli men; for certain hatred of Arabs is useful in sustaining male rage and a willingness to injure and kill; for certain, militarist heroes do not get bashed by the international community or Amnesty International or human rights groups for beating their wives or for killing them." Seeing Israel through the lens of gender instead of race or religion or geopolitics cuts through much of the heated ideology that surrounds any attempt to find some kind of just solution to the two sets of victims in the Middle East. I have very little patience with the question asked by some non-Jews, "How could the Jews, who went through the Holocaust, behave like that?" Because, as Dworkin writes, inflict pain on someone and they'll inflict pain on someone else. We know this from the psychology of sexual abuse when the abused themselves may become an abuser. But the Palestinians - abused by the abused - are not let off lightly in this book: she claims that the Arab world maintains the refugee camps at Gaza to further their own political ends; that the Palestinians fall for Holocaust denial to undermine Israel's right to exist; that many Arab feminists romanticise freedom fighters who, in the name of religion and nationalism, abuse women. But most of all, Dworkin is enraged with Israeli men for betraying what she regards as elemental Jewish morality and values - the ones she held dear when she dreamed of being a rabbi and a scholar. Back home in America, she has been berated for criticising Israel from a comfortable distance. "People always say to me, the Israelis are there, they're the ones whose lives are at stake. It's not me that's going to die if somebody thinks I'm right and they end up with a bullet in their brain. But I must say that looking at the situation of women suggests to me that the Israelis need enemies. I see the consistency of women being an internal enemy in virtually every country I look at, and certainly throughout the Middle East. Israel is not an exception. If there weren't the Palestinians, who are they going to shoot? Who are they going to define themselves against? They had to prove that they were virile. After the Holocaust, every Jewish man had to prove that he had not been castrated and nobody could come and take him away, and the Israeli army became the form for doing that." Dworkin hasn't been back to Israel since the 1988 visit and Scapegoat is very far from being a book of reportage. It is an analysis of source material - of scholarly works, diaries, letters, survivor testimony, eye witness accounts; there is little contemporary detail. No mention is made, for instance, of Dana International, the transsexual who was Israel's official entry to the Eurovision Song Contest two years ago. When I asked why, I was completely astounded to discover that Dworkin had never heard of her. Okay, Eurovision may not be shown on American television but if you are engaged in a nine-year study of Israel and gender you'd have thought that a sex-change diva singing to 500 million people would not have escaped your attention. Dana International is the Israel of the new millennium - not just the gay community's heroine but representing the young people of Tel Aviv's Shenkin Street, for whom the army is an unwelcome interruption between high school and the hippie trail to Goa and Thailand. Dworkin remained unimpressed. She's not interested in gay men, she's interested in women. "It's almost always a mistake to take tokenism as real movement. When I was there I found that there was only one lesbian who was prepared to come out. John and I watched a movie called Trick before you arrived, and it's about a young man looking for love and he somehow finds it with this ideal-looking other man - but the whole thing was built on hatred of women, it was absolutely extraordinary. So you can have those permutations of masculinity, which look like a big change, but they don't actually change the machismo factor. I do it as much as anybody else, looking for social change and thinking okay, at least that has moved a little bit but it usually is really a very little bit, I think." Scapegoat displays a kind of love-hate relationship with Israel. Dworkin loves the idea of Jews fighting in, and for, a Jewish state; hates the fact that misogyny and violence are the result of it. At the end of the book's longest chapter, which makes a link between Zionism and women's liberation, she asks an extremely pertinent question: "What will women do? Is there a plan? And if not, why not?" When one wonders how the Jews managed to create a country, and why they managed to defend it despite being overwhelmingly outnumbered, the answer is - there was a plan. There was a strategy, there were tactics. If the Jews knew anything it was how to organise, how to maintain discipline, how to be tough and how to be single-minded in their goals. As for feminism, there no longer seems to be any plan at all, no political organisation, no goals, no strategy. "It's been the biggest breach between me and other feminists," Dworkin says, "that I believe that the women's movement is a political movement and a political movement has aims and strategies and makes advances and sometimes suffers defeat but then goes on. I had two really interesting experiences. One was talking to Emile Habiby, a very fine Palestinian writer and the first Arab to be given the Israel Prize [for literature]. He's been a left radical for a long time. He was blown away by Mercy [Dworkin's 1990 novel, about sexual abuse] but he said to me at one point, 'I have the feeling that you mean it' and I said to him, 'Yes, I do.' And I had the same experience in the Republic of Ireland where some very tired, corrupt IRA person was talking with me. And he said, 'Wait a minute, you intend to win' and I said 'Yes'. This is a political struggle, it's not a social movement for a different kind of clothes, it's not a lifestyle movement. I think that's where all of our trouble is. Great numbers of women felt very happy in finding out things that they had not known before about women's history and women's lives but were not prepared to do what the Jews did. We were not prepared to decide strategically what do we need to do, what do we want and how do we get it." So now we come to what Andrea Dworkin wants and it is this: she wants women to have their own country. But that's mad, I said to her. Why bother discussing it? It isn't going to happen. To which she has a reply - didn't they say that about Israel? And didn't the world think that Theodor Herzl, the founder of the Zionist movement, was a crank? The Jews got a country because they had been persecuted, said that enough was enough, decided what they wanted and went out and fought for it. Women should do the same. And if you don't want to live in Womenland, so what? Not all Jews live in Israel, but it is there, a place of potential refuge if persecution comes to call. Furthermore, Dworkin says, as the Jews fought for Israel so women have the right to execute - that's right, execute - rapists and the state should not intervene. I couldn't really believe she was serious, but she is. "The last chapter - that's my favourite chapter," she said, regarding the section of her book proposing a nation state for women, and her face lit up when I referred to it. "The first time I thought about this, strangely enough, was when I was reading for my book on pornography and I read half a dozen books on the Marquis de Sade and it occurred to me that if his first victim had shot him, all the other victims wouldn't have happened, and I think - I really believe - that a woman has the right to execute a man who has raped her. If a woman is raped she has a right to retaliate and the state doesn't have a right to intervene." But that's not going to happen, I protested, again. "It might happen, it could happen," she said. Then we began to talk about this women's country. Wouldn't it wind up exactly like Israel itself - a utopian dream which like all utopias, inevitably turns out not quite as expected? "No, I don't think it would be an ideal place," Dworkin agreed. "Women tried to establish co-ops and communes throughout the 70s and a lot of them broke down, not because of outside pressure but because of internal politics. I'm not saying that's the only solution but I'm saying it's an incredible thing to overlook as a possibility. We've never dealt with the issue of sovereignty and I think that's because we've never understood that what we want we can only get through a really serious political movement. It would have many parts, it would have to; it would have the ladies, it would have the girls, it would have everybody and all different shades of politics would be necessary." And the female sadists? Would a woman's state have the Irma Greses, the Rosemary Wests, the Myra Hindleys? What distinguishes Dworkin from many of her contemporaries is that she has never swallowed any of the guff about women having all that nurturing caring gentleness encoded within the DNA. "In the last five or 10 years I've got sick of this endless 'Women can be bad, too, women can commit crimes'," she says. "Look at these women who were the guards at Birkenau and other camps as well. Maybe what the Nazis created was a celebration for sadists and maybe in other circumstances that sadist would have stayed at home and beaten her children, I don't know. But there is no question about whether women can be evil, it's not a question. The only place where hate really plays a role in my life is around the Nazis, I really hate them and I really hate those women." Perhaps there is something prurient about Dworkin's interest both in fascism and in pornography - George Steiner once wrote that the problem with this stuff is that it flatters the attention. Sometimes Dworkin almost seems to be too fascinated as she extracts yet another atrocity - against Jews, against women - from the shadows. Rape or pogrom, snuff movie or death camp, what's the difference? On the other hand, Steiner also speaks of the "sheer incapacity of the 'normal' mind to imagine and hence give active belief to the enormities of the circumstance". And perhaps Dworkin does not have a normal mind and so can do what the rest of us cannot do: go on reading when anyone with any sense would say, "Enough. I know what happened. I don't need to know everything that happened." But maybe someone has to know, read, catalogue all the horrors. As Gloria Steinem said, "In every century, there are a handful of writers who help the human race evolve. Andrea is one of them." Is she mad? Not in the sense of those American feminists such as Kate Millett and Shulamith Firestone, who really did lose their minds. Millett lives in poverty in New England, selling Christmas trees on the street. Firestone, says Dworkin, is "poor and crazy. She rents a room in a house and fills it with junk, then gets kicked out and moves into another room and fills that with junk." Dworkin lives in a nice, comfortable house in a middle-class Brooklyn neighbourhood. People pay attention to what she says. To Dworkin, herself, everything she says and thinks and writes has its logic and she can't understand why others don't always see it. In her book, Intercourse, she argued that every act of penetrative sex is potentially an act of rape. It wasn't a metaphor. She is always literal. I went to see her with a million questions - "How can you think this? It's not practical! It doesn't make sense!" But she will not be deflected. In person she is not angry. She is calm. She gets up and feeds the cat. She pours cranberry juice mixed with seltzer. She only wants you to know what she knows and if you did, then how could you not draw the same conclusions as she does? And you have to say this about her: she has survived to go on writing long after many of her contemporaries in the women's movement - Ti-Grace Atkinson, Robin Morgan, Mary Daly - are names known only within a dwindling circle. But, whomever I talked to, male or female, when I said I was going to meet Andrea Dworkin they knew exactly who she was and they all asked the same thing. Is she crazy? What's she like? Does she really mean all that stuff? Well, yes, she does Dworkin: What I believe I am an enemy of nationalism and male domination. This means that I repudiate all nationalism except my own and reject the dominance of all men except those I love. In this I am like every other woman, a pretender to rebellion because to break with patriarchy I would need to betray my own: the ones with whom I share a group identity, in this case Jewish, and a presumed history, in this case Jewish men. They have not hesitated to betray me through assertions of superiority intended to hurt my human rights and my human dignity. In this, too, I am like every other woman. Feminists try hard to fight for women at the same time maintaining special loyalties to sub-groups of men. How could we not? I have grown sick of those loyalties, which protect brutal acts as if they were heroic. The line between self-defence and aggression has been breached by my particular ethnic group represented by the Israeli government; the line itself is often not self-evident in that violent acts sometimes serve to head off enemy attack and are arguably a form of self-defence. I believe that threatened peoples and individuals have a right to self-defence. This goes against the pacifism that has been instrumental in my political life. My pacifism was first challenged when, working on my book on pornography in the late 70s, Pornography: Men Possessing Women, I read a half-dozen biographies of the Marquis de Sade. A life of rape and sexual violence, including kidnapping and possibly murder, would have been stopped short if his first (known) victim, Jeanne Testard, had killed him. I will say here what I have never said before: my pacifism was not challenged by the beating and torture I experienced in marriage some 30 years ago; I finally got away not because I knew that he would kill me, but because I thought I would kill him. Understand: this is true generally of women - his life meant more to me than my own; but also I was not willing to kill, even to escape beating and his own promise, which I believed, that he would kill me. Once having had the serious and true thought that one of his victims should have offed the good Marquis, it was impossible not to apply that insight to the widespread, contemporary beatings and rapes that women sustain. Especially, I have seen a legal system designed to protect male privilege work to do just that. I have seen a generation of anti-rape activists and anti-battery activists sit through trials of guilty men who almost always walk. Like those advocates, I have seen rapists acquitted, batterers put back in the home, child-rapers given custody of the incested child. The legal system is so genuinely perverse that women rarely report crimes involving either rape or battery. I am, as a result, a lapsed pacifist. I truly abhor violence, and I believe that both nationalism and male dominance are systems that promote and produce violence. With extreme difficulty and reluctance, I have come to believe that women have to be literate in both strategic violence and the violence of self-defence. It is one thing to choose not to kill; it is quite another to be defenceless by virtue of ignorance and socialisation. Women have mastered the articulation of violence on behalf of national liberation movements, including the Jewish liberation movement called Zionism, the claim of a material right to land and sovereignty in the ancient territory of Palestine. For a couple of thousand years - after the destruction of the second Temple in 70 CE - Jews, including Jewish men, were seen as inherently pacifistic, genetically pacifistic, as are women; the existence of the 20th-century Jewish state and its defence suggest that this pacifism was socially constructed and had no relationship at all to any particle of DNA or to testosterone or any other inevitable hormone or biological fact. The perceived gentleness of Jewish men before the establishment of the state never suggested to anyone that men as a whole could live the way that Jewish men had lived: which is to say, without publicly committed violence. Rather, this perception encouraged group violence against Jews in pogroms and in the Holocaust. Is it the same with women? I have been trying to grasp the Holocaust since I was 10 years old and had Auschwitz-Birkenau told to me by a survivor who was having unbearable flashbacks. In 1988, I went to Israel. I had the honour (as had happened in Northern Ireland in 1983) of meeting a great number of women activists (in Israel both Jewish and Arab) in a very short time. There was no small talk. I was distressed by what I found, including Holocaust-themed pornography and battered and raped women. Why would I expect it to be different? The answer is simple: because the Israelis are my guys, a miracle of self-determination and courage. Well, they took the land; but they had to. I continue to believe that they (we) had to; but brutality has become institutionalised in Israel as expressions of male dominance and state sovereignty - over Jewish/Israeli women as well as over Palestinian men and women. Would I be so troubled if Jewish women were not among the conquered? Yes, but: I think that women are the internal enemy regardless of the ethnic or racial or nationalist status of the group's men; and that Israel is a perfect example of how male dominance grows in a new state - it needs the subordination of one's own women and the subordination of a racial or ethnic other: it needs internal and external scapegoats. Israel both embodies and protects male Jews; but the Jewish women inside the state have been disarmed - the pattern for women in liberation struggles that succeed. Yet across the ethnic conflict, Israeli and Palestinian women, often motivated by feminist ambitions and feminist ideas, have found ways to work together. This is a fact more hopeful than the outcome of any election or provisional dictatorship. Cooperation is the female equivalent of male conflict, a way of operating in a world filled with injury and hate. This is a social, not a biological, point. In the nine-year course of writing this book, I have become certain of one thing: that women cannot be free of male dominance without challenging the men of one's own ethnic group and destroying their authority. This is a willed betrayal, as any assault on male dominance must be.  Scapegoat: Jews, Israel And Women's Liberation, by Andrea Dworkin, is published by Virago on June 8, priced £22.50. To order a copy at the special price of £19.50 (plus 99p UK p&p), freephone CultureShop on 0800 316 6102. Linda Grant's latest novel, When I Lived In Modern Times (Granta), has been shortlisted for the Orange Prize.

fields.headline: Dear Weekend
fields.trailText: John Sulston says he's against the 'morally wrong' monopolisation of the human gene sequence for personal gain (DNA: It's war, May 6). Why then go on to say: 'We want competition on the products [arising from free data], not on the information itself'? Such products will inevitably be patented to make and protect profits, and therefore monopolisation will still occur. The poorest, unable to buy them, will be denied their benefits.
fields.body:
John Sulston says he's against the 'morally wrong' monopolisation of the human gene sequence for personal gain (DNA: It's war, May 6). Why then go on to say: 'We want competition on the products [arising from free data], not on the information itself'? Such products will inevitably be patented to make and protect profits, and therefore monopolisation will still occur. The poorest, unable to buy them, will be denied their benefits.

Does this producing-for-sale not contradict one of Sulston's other statements: 'The only thing I have retained from my upbringing . . . is the idea that you do not do things for money'?
Max Hess
Folkestone, Kent

I'll believe Kevin Toolis's portrayal of a genetic utopia the day I get my too-cheap-to-meter nuclear electricity.
Dr Peter Quaife
Erdington, Birmingham

Is the theoretical eradication of Reagan supposed to be a dilemma; and if Sulston was wearing 'instead of a Rolex . . . a pair of old leather sandals', as Toolis asserts, how do they look on his wrist, and do they keep good time?

On a more serious note, I would like answers to the following: is a genetic predisposition for being gay actually proven; is there an alternative to capitalist competition to reproduce the urgency which has reduced the time to the completion of the Human Genome Project by almost 10 years; and if I were to write a patent on the structure of H <->2 O, would I then be able to charge everyone for using water?

Surely merely describing that which already exists in nature cannot confer any right of ownership.
Ed Barrett
London NW11

Do I detect double standards in Joanna Blythman's rather dismal assessment of the British restaurant curry (Food, May 6)? The very things she criticises are precisely those that would normally win her approbation. It is of unique ethno-geographic distribution, it has the capacity to re-invent itself, it has adapted to the local climate, and it even has 'traditional' status with the locals, to the point of being revered by those who don't know béarnaise from hollandaise.
Christopher Lambton
Broughton, Biggar, S Lanarks

Just a tiny question regarding Elizabeth Wurtzel's great stuff - her advice was much more positive, workable, forgiving and up-to-date than the original Rules (A Bad Girl's Code, April 29) That is, she suggests we 'Have a cleaning person come in as often as you can afford.' Is a professional cleaner expected to hire another, or are cleaners just too low in the chain to count when it comes to The Bitch Rules?
Julie Slater
Macclesfield

Rarely has a letter provoked two such forceful and opposite feelings in me as Alan Rankin's (Dear Weekend, May 6). Serif 'I'? We are one in our infuriation. Burchill? He couldn't be more wrong.
Tom Hawkins
Heaton Moor, Stockport

When Julie Burchill quotes other people (at increasing length, as she has done these past few weeks), does she still get paid by the word? Nice work if you can get it.
Sean O'Neil
London E14

Guardian Weekend, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER. Email: weekend@theguardian.com. Fax: 020-7239 9935. A postal address must be supplied. Letters should reach us by Tuesday afternoon for inclusion on Saturday, and may be edited.

webTitle: How to source the best asparagus

fields.headline: How to source the best asparagus
fields.standfirst: England has some fantastic raw ingredients, but few can match the star quality of home-grown asparagus. Claire Phipps finds out why
fields.trailText: England has some fantastic raw ingredients, but few can match the star quality of home-grown asparagus. Claire Phipps finds out why. Recipes by Jeremy Lee
fields.body:
There are many reasons to berate the wet weather this spring, not least because it delayed the start of the asparagus-cutting season. Even in a good year, English asparagus graces our tables for just two months, and growers usually begin their annual harvest in mid-April. But two weeks ago, Paul Hayden at the Birlingham Nursery, in Pershore, Worcestershire (01386 750668) had barely begun cutting (that is, hand-slicing the shoots from the soil).

Still, when you've waited four years for the plant to mature sufficiently to yield the best crop, what's a few weeks more? Those who bemoan the expense of the English spear should be aware that these tender greens, which are at their best for only a few days, are the end result of a very long toil. "You have to be constantly looking a long way ahead," Hayden explains. "The problem with growing asparagus is that you should always have started five years ago."

The life of an asparagus grower is indeed lived in the slow lane. First, the seeds (at Birlingham, they use Dutch hybrids) are sown. Then, after maybe two years, you can if you want start to cut a little. But if it's the really fine stuff you're after - the fleshy, thick stems of a typical English asparagus yield - then you'll be waiting a good four years.

Only then - and for just two short months, May and June, to boot - you can call the cutters in. And there's no point trying to bend the rules. "If you continue cutting after mid-June," says Hayden, "it doesn't allow energy back into the crown, so there'll be no crop the next year. You must say, 'No more.'"

Fortunately, Hayden has a retail nursery to keep him busy for the 10 months when his asparagus is doing little more than recovering its strength for next season's spurt. It is eight years since he committed to asparagus, although the location of the nursery - in the heart of the Vale of Evesham, that fertile basin between the Cotswolds and the Malvern and Bredon Hills - made the choice rather straightforward: "I was aware that asparagus was historically grown in the area, and it did spring to mind because of that."

The Birlingham operation is not entirely traditional, however. Unusually among growers, part of this crop is cultivated under glass, so this year's late cutting has not meant a lazy spring for Hayden and his two co-workers. The indoor asparagus was deemed ready for cutting on March 5, when it reached peak condition - compact heads, good green colour (unlike the white asparagus that is grown under the soil and that is so favoured on the continent, especially in the Low Countries, our stuff is allowed to see what sun we have). Every day since, Hayden and co have been busy cutting, grading and packing, all by hand.

As anyone who has ever cooked or eaten asparagus will insist on telling you, it is essential that the spears are eaten as soon after cutting as is possible. Hayden is particularly proud of the fact that around one third of his crop is sold directly to the public from the Birlingham shop. "It's the one edible crop that people are willing to drive a distance for," he says. "We've tried tomatoes and other vegetables, too, but they just didn't pull people in in the same way. And people are happy to pay maybe two or three times more than they would for the Spanish, because it's so much better."

Ah yes, the price - if there's one thing that stops people from cheerfully bunging a couple of bundles into their weekly shopping basket, it's the expense. Hayden, who sells his crop for £2.95 per round (about 1lb in weight) in his own shop, blames the short season and the high level of imports.

Asparagus, which traditionally grew wild on the banks of the Nile and elsewhere in the eastern Mediterranean region, is now cultivated in the unlikeliest of places across the world. Peru, the US and Spain are the biggest producers, and it's those names that you're most likely to find on the supermarket labels. Talk of seasonal availability can sound suspiciously like conspiracy when bright green shoots can be bought all year round.

"The only way English asparagus can sell is on quality," says Hayden. Good thing, too. Asparagus always has been a treasured vegetable - it is, after all, a member of the fashionable lily family. Some cultures praised its medicinal qualities - it has been credited with curing everything from gout to toothache to bee stings, while Native Americans used it to treat bladder infections (indeed, few texts on the subject fail to mention the effect asparagus has on the odour of urine, and, in the interests of conformity, nor will this - it's all to do with the body's inability to break down aspergin). It was the Romans, however, who hit the nail on the head when they took a shine to Asparagus officinalis for just one reason: its taste. So keen were they that they even set up designated asparagus fleets for ferrying the freshest spears to the emperor's dining table.

There's no need for such decadence to get hold of the finest English asparagus, however. Hayden is toying with the idea of selling it via mail order, and the advent of a rival growing region, East Anglia (which is perfect for more than just its light soils: "Asparagus is happy near the sea," says Hayden), should ensure a ready supply of English stems, for the early summer months at least. A food fit for emperors, maybe, but there's enough for all of us.

fields.headline: Four delicious asparagus recipes
fields.standfirst: Rice with asparagus, asparagus with scrambled eggs on toast, asparagus with hot anchovy dip and asparagus in onions, garlic, lemon and herbs. Jeremy Lee shares some of his favourite recipes
fields.trailText: Rice with asparagus, asparagus with scrambled eggs on toast, asparagus with hot anchovy dip and asparagus in onions, garlic, lemon and herbs. Jeremy Lee shares some of his favourite recipes
fields.body:
All recipes serve six.

Rice with asparagus

450g very fresh asparagus

Water

60g unsalted butter

1 medium onion, finely chopped

450g carnaroli or arborio rice

1 big chunk good Parmesan

1 small handful flat-leaf parsley

Test the stalks of the asparagus and snap them where they yield. Peel them if their skin seems tough. Fill a deep, wide pan with water, enough to generously to cover the asparagus, though not so much that the flavour of the vegetable will be diluted; add a little salt, and bring to the boil. Lay in the spears, and boil for three to four minutes only. Transfer the asparagus to a draining rack, to allow it to cool slightly, tip the cooking liquor into a large jug or somesuch, and wipe dry the pot.

Add the butter to the dried pot, melt over a medium flame, then add the onion and cook until it is soft and pale. Pour in the rice, stir for a minute or two to coat the grains, then add a ladle of the cooking water and stir until it is absorbed by the rice. Repeat thus until all the rice is plumped and cooked - about 15-20 minutes - with each grain remaining intact. The consistency should err towards the liquid. Finely chop the parsley, add to the rice, stir in as much freshly-grated Parmesan as you like, remove from the heat, gently stir in the asparagus and serve at once.

Asparagus with scrambled eggs on toast

One of the simplest yet most sublime combinations of egg and asparagus.

36 very fresh asparagus spears

6 thick slices bread (preferably from a pan loaf)

12 eggs

A little double cream

1 tbsp Dijon mustard

100g unsalted butter

Sea salt and milled pepper

Heat the grill. Set a big pot of water on to boil. Peel the asparagus, cut the spears in half and keep only the tips (the stalks can be used in a soup). Crack the eggs into a large bowl and beat them together. When the water is beginning to boil, add the mustard to the eggs, along with a generous splash of cream, salt and pepper. Over a low heat, melt 50g of the butter in a heavy-based pot.

Put the asparagus into the boiling water, and cover at once so that it returns to the boil quickly. When the butter has melted in the pan, put the bread under the grill and tip the eggs into the butter pan. Stir the eggs slowly but constantly until large curds form.

Generously butter the toasted bread, and place the slices on the plates in readiness. When the eggs are cooked but still soft, spoon them over the toast. Drain the asparagus, place a spear or two atop each egg and serve immediately.

Asparagus with hot anchovy dip

The dipping sauce of Piedmont, bagna cada, is traditionally served in winter, but an exception is made for asparagus.

36 very fresh asparagus spears

2 cloves garlic, chopped fine

40g unsalted butter

180ml very good olive oil

10 finest anchovy fillets

Trim and peel the asparagus. Set a large pot of salted water on to boil. In a small pan, warm the oil and butter until a foam forms. Fry the garlic without letting it colour, then add the anchovies and stir. Cook slowly, stirring frequently, until the fish have dissolved into a paste. Add a little salt, if required, and transfer to the table. Plunge the spears into the boiling water and cook until just tender. Drain, put upon a plate and serve swiftly.

Asparagus in onions, garlic, lemon and herbs

Aka, asperges marinées à la Niçoise - Julia Child had the original recipe from Jacques Mèdecin, who recommends wild asparagus 'as thin as little pencils that grow in the crooked feet of the olive tree in the month of April and whose taste is absolutely inimitable'. My search for such asparagus was fruitless, but the more familiar green stuff works a treat anyway.

2 medium onions, sliced thin

5 cloves garlic, sliced thin

1 lemons, zested and cut into fine strips

7-8 tbsp excellent olive oil

12 black peppercorns

150ml white wine

6 tbsp lemon juice

600ml water

1 tsp sea salt

36 very fresh asparagus spears

1 sprig thyme

1 bayleaf

1 small handful flat-leaf parsley

Warm a big, heavy pot and cook the onion, garlic and lemon slowly in the olive oil. Once softened, add the peppercorns, wine, lemon juice, water and salt, and simmer for 20 minutes.

Peel the asparagus and put into the simmering marinade. Add a little water if the marinade has reduced while cooking. Cover the pot and simmer very slowly for 20 minutes until the asparagus is tender. Remove the spears to a handsome plate, and turn up the heat under the pan. Reduce the marinade until it is the consistency of syrup and spoon over the asparagus. Serve hot or cold, strewn with chopped parsley

 Jeremy Lee is the chef at Blue Print Cafe, London SE1.
