fields.headline: Atom bomb
fields.standfirst: Alex Clark  thrills to Michel Houellebecq's depraved apocalypse, Atomised
fields.trailText: Alex Clark thrills to Michel Houellebecq's depraved apocalypse, Atomised
fields.body:
Atomised
Michel Houellebecq, translated by Frank Wynne
Heinemann, £12.99, 379pp
Buy it at BOL

We are all going to die, but not before we rot slowly from the inside, make ourselves and others unbearably miserable, and become the patsies of a cynical society in thrall to the false gods of materialism and individualism. Occasionally, by some miracle of self-deception, certain of us might believe ourselves to be saved by love, but ultimately this cannot rescue us. The moment we part company with our youth, we are doomed; from then on, we are simply waiting to die, marooned in a world that no longer has the remotest faith in any life after death - and not a great deal in life before it.

To describe Michel Houellebecq's extraordinary novel as nihilistic would be a grave understatement. On its publication in France as Les Particules Elémentaires, it shot up the bestseller charts while provoking outrage for its strands of homophobia, racism and misogyny, not to mention explicit and frequently voyeuristic sex and violence. Houellebecq, now based in Ireland, found himself the subject of countless newspaper articles and the pariah of the literary journal Perpendiculaire, which he had helped to found.

His novel deals with a crisis that ostensibly originates in the west but has ramifications for the entire human race. The only remedy for humanity's predicament is the extinction of the species, and this chilling development is plausibly consigned to the category of "metaphysical mutation". These mutations have happened before - the rise of Christianity, the cult of the individual - and the death of the human, hastened by the inexorable logic of scientific advance, might well be another.

In Atomised, that futuristic fantasy is played out in the lives of two grotesque half-brothers, Michel and Bruno. Interspersed with an account of their woeful progress through the decades are the cool observations of a dispassionate narrator on the crises and failures of contemporary society, the rise of science and the decline of religion, the animalistic nature of sexual desire and the inability of the liberal western intellect to come up with any coherent response to the disasters that enfold it.

The circumstances of his characters' births present Houellebecq with an opportunity to tether his philosophy to a specific social malfunction. This might be termed the permissive society, but can also be viewed as an unavoidable consequence of an obsession with free will. Their mother, a shiftless pleasure-seeker, abandons them to different grandmothers without batting an eyelid. At the fag end of the 1950s she takes off for California, where "something radical" is happening, and joins a commune headed by an Aldous Huxley-inspired, sex-obsessed charlatan. The result of her absence affects her sons in opposite but equally disabling ways.

Bruno, the elder, is a sexual inadequate whose life is consumed by the pursuit of women. His "adventures" are chronicled with gallows humour, moving from childhood depravity to bleak, self-knowing middle-age. Early on we encounter a teenage Bruno sneaking into his mother's bedroom, kneeling reverentially in front of her vagina, and then masturbating outside before stoving a cat's head in with a rock.

Later on, after decades of prostitutes, unreliable erections and premature ejaculation, Bruno finds something approximating love with the sexually liberated anti-feminist Christiane. It's no great surprise - nor any great pity, for Houellebecq's characters are not built to last - that she ends up collapsing while being penetrated from behind in a night-club; a short time later, trapped in a wheelchair by her rotting coccyx, she hurls herself down a stairwell.

Michel has no inclination towards sex, despite an intense childhood relationship with the saintly Annabelle. She, by the way, also commits suicide, after an unhappy life and a short struggle with cancer; but it would be spurious to point out that all the women in this novel meet their deaths as victims. After all, nobody exactly has a ball. Michel in particular is afflicted by sadness, his hyper-intelligence condemning him to all too frank an apprehension of the way things are going. A physicist turned molecular biologist, his findings on mutations in DNA provide the foundations of the new "metaphysical mutation" that closes the book. A reluctant prophet, his intellect ruthlessly shuts down our options until there is, literally, no point to human life.

This is an anti-novel in the sense that it consistently diminishes any sense of its own possibilities. It lurches from misanthropic farce to dissociated tragedy, from philosophical speculation to sarcastic sideswipes at the luminaries of recent French thought. The situationist Debord appears merely in a reference to his suicide, committed for no other reason than that he could not bear the thought of his own physical decline, while Gilles Deleuze inspires "lengthy intellectual justifications of porn" from a minor blue-movie starlet.

Much of Houellebecq's barely concealed rage is directed towards the incapacity of those in the ivory towers to deal with the big questions: religion, sex and death. Tellingly, the reclusive Michel plucks a Christian tract out of a rubbish bin and, after casually perusing it, turns instead to a shopping catalogue, in which he finds "a more thoughtful, historically informed insight into Europe's current malaise". But while Michel is simultaneously repelled and attracted by the blandishments of consumer society, his creator offers the reader no corresponding solace. His vision of a post-existentialist, rationalist world, in which any attempts at human happiness are not only doomed but risibly beside the point, is completely without mitigation.

Do we take Houellebecq seriously? Atomised is so complex in its subject matter, and yet so excessively repulsive in its execution, that it verges, at times, on adolescent foot-stamping. It allows little room for the reader to take issue with it, so defiantly pessimistic are its parameters and its conclusions. And although it is a novel of evident stature, which immediately invites comparison with writers such as Celine, Beckett and Camus, it also deliberately situates itself outside any such canon.

There is little so radical or reductive that it can't be absorbed into the mainstream, which underlines Houellebecq's various points about the velvet jackboot of consumerism. And yet, finishing this book, one is genuinely excited by its author's daring and conviction, even when that conviction reads like an elaborate practical joke. One hesitates to say that Houellebecq is the Next Big Thing, but he may be the best we see for a long time.

This is an anti-novel in the sense that it consistently diminishes any sense of its own possibilities. It lurches from misanthropic farce to dissociated tragedy, from philosophical speculation to sarcastic sideswipes at the luminaries of recent French thought. The situationist Debord appears merely in a reference to his suicide, committed for no other reason than that he could not bear the thought of his own physical decline, while Gilles Deleuze inspires "lengthy intellectual justifications of porn" from a minor blue-movie starlet. Much of Houellebecq's barely concealed rage is directed towards the incapacity of those in the ivory towers to deal with the big questions: religion, sex and death. Tellingly, the reclusive Michel plucks a Christian tract out of a rubbish bin and, after casually perusing it, turns instead to a shopping catalogue, in which he finds "a more thoughtful, historically informed insight into Europe's current malaise". But while Michel is simultaneously repelled and attracted by the blandishments of consumer society, his creator offers the reader no corresponding solace. His vision of a post-existentialist, rationalist world, in which any attempts at human happiness are not only doomed but risibly beside the point, is completely without mitigation. Do we take Houellebecq seriously? Atomised is so complex in its subject matter, and yet so excessively repulsive in its execution, that it verges, at times, on adolescent foot-stamping. It allows little room for the reader to take issue with it, so defiantly pessimistic are its parameters and its conclusions. And although it is a novel of evident stature, which immediately invites comparison with writers such as Celine, Beckett and Camus, it also deliberately situates itself outside any such canon. There is little so radical or reductive that it can't be absorbed into the mainstream, which underlines Houellebecq's various points about the velvet jackboot of consumerism. And yet, finishing this book, one is genuinely excited by its author's daring and conviction, even when that conviction reads like an elaborate practical joke. One hesitates to say that Houellebecq is the Next Big Thing, but he may be the best we see for a long time.

fields.headline: David Trimble, sketched
fields.trailText:
His face more head than face

as if straitlaced he's wearing

a permanent hard hat...
fields.body:
His face more head than face

as if straitlaced he's wearing

a permanent hard hat

except for men in blue suits

a hard hat is an item

of temporary headgear

and a bluesuited man with such

a bakelite hat he

looks always slightly daft

- anxious ill at ease

not much swearing

and somewhere deep down in a tremble

unlike a man in a donkey jacket

or vest - a man

who's not just visiting the site

but is part of the mess

the whole works all that shite

- he knows how to hack it

as here and now we wait

for more deadlines more dates

and that access of authority

which every site foreman

has got to possess

- I see mud pallets of breezeblocks

and bricks wrapped in stretched cellophane

stacks upon stacks upon stacks

above them a longlegged crane

(not a fly)

that might just stumble

© Tom Paulin 2000

fields.headline: Gothic succour
fields.standfirst: Steven Poole  on monstrous elixirs of Federico Andahazi's The Merciful Women
fields.trailText: Steven Poole on monstrous elixirs of Federico Andahazi's The Merciful Women
fields.body:
The Merciful Women
Federico Andahazi
Doubleday, £12.99, 188pp
Buy it at BOL

It is a dark and stormy afternoon in 1816. Braving violent gusts of pathetic fallacy, five people disembark from a boat on a Swiss lake. They are Byron, Shelley, Mary Shelley, Claire Clairmont and Byron's secretary, John Polidori. Staying at the Villa Diodati, they will embark on the famous yarn-spinning contest that leads to the composition of Frankenstein.

Polidori is wracked by literary envy of his master, so the group is amazed when he reads them his brilliant entry, The Vampyre. But the novel has been written by a monstrous crone, Annette Legrand, who, with her two sisters, travels the world drinking semen in order to survive. Polidori must pay for the manuscript with his own tasty seed.

This dark lady explains her predicament in a series of letters. She began life as a slimy, ratlike adjunct to the birth of two beautiful sisters. When it became clear that if one were to die, they all would, she was allowed to flee, and grew up underground cultivating her remarkable literary powers in the usual manner, by eating books.

The story unfolds through a mixture of mannered narration of life with the holidaying poets and epistolary Gothic pastiche, as Annette softens up the secretary for her demands on his testicles. It is translated from Spanish by the estimable Alberto Manguel, and the result is a superficial, velvety elegance, but Manguel cannot do much with the jarring cliches of Andahazi's characterisation - Shelley is "graceful as a gazelle"; Byron is given to "sulky brooding".

There is a desultory interpolation of suspense as a young man is murdered on the lake, but otherwise the narrative proceeds with a lazy, becalmed inevitability. And the skeletal pastiche sadly fails to play by the rules it has chosen. It is framed with a fictional foreword by a modern scholar who has found some hitherto undiscovered documents, thanks to a helpful eccentric who calls himself a "teratologist", a taxonomist of monsters. But The Merciful Women fails as a contribution to the teratological imagination because Annette remains defiantly unmonstrous. We are constantly reassured that she is covered with hair and weeping pustules, but that wouldn't get her an entry into a Pokémon game, let alone a bestiary of the abominable.

What she can do is write books in return for manly elixir. But why are such bargains struck for certain men when her siblings have taken to killing other victims after milking them dry? The sisters' mercy is merely an arbitrary fix that allows the writer to get his story onto the page. The best horror fiction works to a relentless calculus of cause and effect: the axioms may be fantastical, but they combine in consistent ways. The Merciful Women therefore fails as horror, and the reader of this comically gynophobic confection is left, as presumably are its titular antiheroines, with a faintly sour taste in the mouth.

fields.headline: Audio
fields.trailText: This is no botanical record, but a homage to 60 big, ancient beauties from Britain and Ireland with "strong personalities".
fields.body:
Meeting With Remarkable Trees
Thomas Pakenham
(Orion, £8.99, 190 mn)
Buy it at BOL

Bill Paterson, blessed with one of thespdom's most wonderful voices, prefaces this gem with some reassurance: this is no botanical record, but a homage to 60 big, ancient beauties from Britain and Ireland with "strong personalities".

The arboreal facts are fascinating. Britain and Ireland, it turns out, enjoy a richer heritage of big old trees than anywhere else in western Europe. But we've got nothing to be complacent about in our neglect for oak, beech, ash, birch, yew and Scots pine trees, which makes a mockery of current interest in the environment.

Old trees both emphasise the brevity of human life and offer vivid links with the past. The Celts possibly stuck enemies' heads on the branches of a yew still going strong in Tandridge, Surrey, and it will doubtless see man reach Mars. Perfect in-car listening to raise respect for those passing plants that so shape our surroundings.

fields.headline: What's selling in politics
fields.trailText: The postmayoral daze has given a belated boost at Politico's, the Westminster bookshop, to John Carvel's update of his book on Ken Livingstone.
fields.body:
The postmayoral daze has given a belated boost at Politico's, the Westminster bookshop, to John Carvel's update of his book on Ken Livingstone. Can't you just see all those MPs scuttling off to gen up on the cuckoo in their nest?

Had they given it more attention when it was first published last autumn, they might have had a better idea of the type of operator they were dealing with. Carvel, after all, was the first to predict that, if pushed, Ken would stand independently.

The oddball in the pack is Ann Widdecombe's doom-laden novel, The Clematis Tree. Though not exactly a joker, it's certainly less embarrassing than Edwina Currie's steamy Chasing Men, with which it shares the shelves. Jonathan Aitken's tear-stained confessional is extorting the sympathy vote (publishers HarperCollins have sent out nearly 10,000 copies), while the huddle of sturdy memoirs is enlivened by Max Hastings's strikingly readable account of his wars gone by.

fields.headline: Non-fiction
fields.trailText: The subject for which the Ellipsis 105mm-square format might have been intended, plus Flint Architecture of East Anglia
fields.body:
Japan, the Informal Contained
Christopher Tadgell
(Ellipsis, £8)

The subject for which the Ellipsis 105mm-square format might have been intended: a miniature history of Japanese architecture from pithouses - elegant, minimalist pits, of course - to 1912, with Himeji castle's awesome timbers diagrammed at matchbook scale, and Nikko's shrines shown so tiny that their precious-box quality is more evident even than it is on-site. Pix hardly bigger than slides, yet the right musty-paper darkness shades the rooms, and the great green trees thresh beyond the Zen garden walls. The text is properly serious, clear but with no concessions to the novelty of the enterprise - we own far heavier works on the subject that are less weighty.

Flint Architecture of East Anglia
Stephen Hart
(DLM, £19.19)
Buy it at BOL

Flint, knapped and chipped, cobbled and rubbled, galletted with pebble and quoined with Roman tile-brick: the language of these Saxon-to-Victorian churches, and of William Kent's rusticated triumphal arch at Holkham Hall, crunches in the mouth. The thereness of there then is intense - these buildings were created from what were considered ignoble materials, just local geological junk. But sombre ingenuity made of them dignified (sometimes witty) towers and cottages. How beautiful is the human passion for order and pattern, especially when it makes a fine something of nothing much. Scrupulous text, too.

fields.headline: Fiction
fields.trailText: David Dabydeen takes on Hogarth's 18th-century London and makes it his own, plus The Face Maker And The Muse, Mother London and Starcrossed
fields.body:
A Harlot's Progress
David Dabydeen
(Vintage, £6.99)
Buy it at BOL

As historical fiction, Dabydeen's novel is satisfying on many levels. Take a good idea - putting flesh on Hogarth prints - and sharpen up with victimhood, slavery and exploitation. Many a writer would be content with this heritage picaresque, but Dabydeen is a sly debunker. London's oldest black inhabitant, Mungo, becomes the object of the Abolitionists' campaigning voyeurism and of their charity. He refuses to trade his autobiography for a crust of bread, instead conjuring his own fiction full of myth, poetry and strangeness. Dabydeen, unlike so many who help themselves to history, takes on Hogarth's 18th-century London and makes it his own.

The Face Maker And The Muse
Leonid Latynin
(Glas, £8.99)
Buy it at BOL

Pick up this dystopian Russian novel, which had to wait until communism crumbled before publication, and it is easy to slot Latynin into the canon of Kafka, Zamyatin and Orwell. The city where worth is measured by a person's likeness to the Image, and survival depends on being chosen to be remade by a Face Maker according to arbitrary rules, is an over-determined allegory of Soviet society. But Latynin's novel works for any era. A society where youth is prized above all and adaptation is the only way to survive is a fitting metaphor for today. The Face Maker And The Muse is not a polished read, but it resonates with beguiling ideas.

Mother London
Michael Moorcroft
(Scribner, £7.99)
Buy it at BOL

In 1988, when Moorcroft was nominated for the Whitbread for this novel, London as a fictional character was reborn. Now we are familiar with a city where buried rivers and neglected graveyards are treated as the bricks and mortar of myth; a city on which meaning can be hung by anyone open to its possibilities. A group therapy session in a north London suburb introduces us David Mummery, Mary Gasalee and Josef Kiss, whose experiences of London spread like a skein of unordered Underground lines. Moorcroft sets down their London stories humorously, and with the dusty tragedy of a mid-week afternoon at the end of the Northern Line.

Starcrossed
AA Gill
(Black Swan, £6.99)
Buy it at BOL

Winning the Literary Review's annual Bad Sex Award is the stuff of embarassment for most authors, AA Gill, you cannot help but suspect, probably wrote Starcrossed to beat off all other contenders. John is a bad poet who works in a bookshop and has dull sex with girlfriend Petra until he falls into bed with a literary superstar. Gill relishes describing sticky-bedsheet sex (it's hard to decide just which inexorably awful passage won the award) and plots a formulaic tale of a private life become public in Notting Hill mode. He can toss off a neat sentence or nice aphorism, but these are garnishes covering a very crude dish.

webTitle: The end of the WHSmith Award

fields.headline: The end of the WHSmith Award
fields.trailText: What's the difference between a Literary Award and a Book Prize? Mobile phones... no bragging and conspiracy theories
fields.body:
 To the rather grand Chapter House, by Westminster Abbey, for the annual WHSmith Literary Award, at which the Loafer catches sight of Doris Lessing. In the past, Lessing has called this her favourite prize, but what will she do for kicks next year? For the Award, it was announced over the petits fours, will cease to exist forthwith, mutating instead into the WHSmith Book Prize.

This newcomer will boast a range of categories - "lifestyle" being the most ominous - and, a WHS bod assured us, will be "relevant" to everyone, whatever their interests. If we had any doubt that this is social inclusion at work, the winners will be decided by polling the public, who will be able to vote through WHS shops, over the net, and (of course) by mobile telephone. This, we hear, will make the prize "less elitist".

 Who better to preside over these distinctly New Labour festivities (Ken Follett, by the way, was guest judge) than Alan Howarth MP, whom the Loafer last encountered at a fractious Arts Council dinner? Then, Howarth recommended the widespread display of poetry in hospitals and old peoples' homes, the better to distract them from their predicaments.

On this occasion, he was in somewhat more rarefied form, delivering a speech that included references to Chairman Mao, Edward Gibbon, Napoleon, the Marquis de Sade and Emerson. As the assembled company assented sagely, Howarth finally opened his buff envelope and announced Melvyn Bragg, that well-known New Labour peer, to be the winner.

 Bragg, it must be reported, made a notably gracious and mercifully brief acceptance speech, nodding gratefully at his publishers, Sceptre, and promising to genuflect every time he passed a branch of WHSmith in the future. Sceptre, as some unkind conspiracy theorists present were compelled to comment, is part of Hodder, who are owned by... er, WHSmith.

 Meanwhile, the losers were comporting themselves with good grace. Francis Wheen and Howard Jacobson saluted each other in the queue for the loos, and last year's winner, Beryl Bainbridge, had kind words for all. As we were ushered out, the Princess Royal arrived for a meeting of Crime Concern. No connection, of course.

fields.headline: Butch muse
fields.standfirst: Margaret Reynolds' The Sappho Companion covers 26 centuries of the mysterious, multi-faceted poet
fields.trailText: Margaret Reynolds' The Sappho Companion covers 26 centuries of the mysterious, multi-faceted poet
fields.body:
The Sappho Companion
edited by Margaret Reynolds
Chatto & Windus, £25, 432pp
Buy it at BOL

Two things tend to be known about Sappho, and it's hard to say these days which has made her more famous. Poet or lesbian: it's a tough call. At least we know that she was a poet, probably the greatest lyric poet of ancient Greece, and a native of the island of Lesbos, living around 600BC. That she was a lesbian is pure conjecture, based on some indisputably gendered grammar and scurrilous gossip about the cult of Aphrodite. But it's not easy to scotch a rumour that's been doing the rounds for 2,600 years - as many anxious gentleman scholars of Sappho have discovered.

Plato's "tenth Muse" has been enjoying something of a revival lately; the last few years have seen a rush of Sappho translations, editions and critical works, inspired in part by a new generation of scholarship in ancient Greek and in part by the growth industries of feminist studies and lesbian critical theory.

Margaret Reynolds's blockbuster anthology of Sapphorabilia, The Sappho Companion, clearly marks out its stake within this academic milieu, but has been designed to appeal well beyond the library. Lovingly researched and admirably readable, it is a book to return to at leisure rather than to plough through and reshelve.

As well as a fascinating narrative of the Sappho story, it includes a selection of the original fragments, a taste of the variety of their translations, and a kaleidoscopic catalogue of literary and artistic Sapphic reinventions through the ages. All of which show, argues Reynolds, that Sappho is at once whatever you want her to be and ultimately elusive: " 'Sappho' is not a name, much less a person. It is, rather, a space. A space for filling in the gaps, joining up the dots, making something out of nothing."

What has been made out of nothing really is quite something. Sappho has been reincarnated by other writers since as early as the fourth century BC, just 200 years after her death. Refracted through the looking glass of scholars, translators, poets, dramatists, librettists, artists, sculptors, suffragists and lesbian acolytes, she has been mother, muse, wife, predatory lesbian, victim of unrequited heterosexual love, prostitute, bluestocking, dominatrix, exile, philosophical ideal and tragic suicide.

In the first century BC, Catullus made her the quintessential poet of love. Not long after, Ovid bitchily reinvented her as a dowdy ex-lesbian. In the 18th century, Pope's even bitchier reworking of Ovid would be largely responsible for "Sappho" becoming a term of abuse directed at women writers.

The medieval intellectual Christine de Pisan made her an intellectual; the Elizabethan playwright John Lyly made her Elizabeth I; and John Donne made her himself, or himself her. Edmund Burke made her an icon of the sublime, while Madame de Staël made her Corinne, or Italy.

The Romantics invoked her; Christina Rossetti empathised with her; and Queen Christina of Sweden blamed her for arousing her passions with That Chambermaid. Baudelaire and Swinburne wanted both to be her and to possess her. Natalie Barney and Renée Vivien wanted both to be her and to dress up like her. Ezra Pound and HD wanted to strip her down and Virginia Woolf wanted to play her up. Monique Wittig and Judy Grahn wanted her to come out in violet. Pat Califia wanted her to come out in leather. Eventually, there was nowhere left for her just to sit still and be a poet.

Jeanette Winterson's Sappho wants to know, "WHAT HAVE YOU DONE WITH MY POEMS?" But the problem is that the poems are fiction, too. None of Sappho's work was written down during her lifetime, and all that remains of her lost nine books, beyond the snippets recorded by near-contemporaries after her death, are the famous fragments: dog-eared scraps of old papyrus, themselves fictions of quotation, memory and invention, dating from the second or third centuries AD and miraculously dug up from a rubbish dump in Egypt at the turn of the last century.

How could moonlight not always have been silvery, or desire a fire beneath the skin and a roaring in the ears?

Of course, Reynolds's muse - "difficult, diffuse, many-syllabled, many-minded, vigorous and hard" - is as revealing of its author as the fictions that precede it. Her Sappho - butch, proud and prone to silences - is not afraid of leaving gaps unfilled; of beckoning, bittersweet and hard to get, from the future. One of Sappho's fragments says simply: "Someone, I say to you, / will think of us / in some future time". She can have had no idea.

fields.headline: Of sceptres and the sea
fields.standfirst: Christopher Lee tells Peter Kingston about his love of books and boating
fields.trailText: Christopher Lee tells Peter Kingston about his love of books and boating
fields.body:
Christopher Lee must be the fastest-selling historian since Bede. Recordings of This Sceptred Isle, his history of Britain broadcast on Radio 4, have been leaping off the shelves. At last count, 600,000 CD and cassette packs had shifted, making a staggering £6.5 million.

The series - which can be bought in episodes or as a set, and is also available in book form - has become the surprise best-seller in the BBC audio catalogue, outstripping even Alan Bennett. It is a surprise, then, to find the man sitting in a modest house in the curiously named Somerset village of Queen Camel. Why not something a mite grander to show for such sales? "Perhaps I'm not a big cigar-and-mansion person," he says. He does own a 32-foot sloop. "But my boat is one of the oldest in yachting". And, he doesn't exactly use it to chill out with the Cowes set: this year Lee will moor Lara somewhere off the coast of Ireland and plug on with his work on a laptop.

He hints that he may not have got the best deal for This Sceptred Isle. But no one spotted the "big blockbuster" lurking in the manuscript. Once the book of the series had been done, he thought he had seen the end of it. After eight years, he would have time to catch up with the rest of his life. But no. He had been foolish enough to mention another idea - a history of England's most powerful families. So keen was the BBC that it is making the unprecedented move of releasing it as a book before committing to a broadcast version. Lee hints that there may not even be one.

This Sceptred Isle: Dynasties, will become the the third part of a trilogy which originally came in two parts - the Romans to Victoria, and the 20th century. It will cover the most formidable families in England, starting with the Godwins, a dynasty which ended when Harold was killed at the Battle of Hastings, and ending with the Murdochs. "These were the powers behind the throne, the people who really ran the country, " he explains.

"When I wake up I always say one thing: 'Still here'," he adds, maybe a touch pessimistically for a solid-looking fellow of 55, but understandably given his killer schedule. Quite apart from researching Dynasties, he has latterly spent part of the day wrapping up the first draft of his official biography of Lord Carrington. He has also been pushing ahead with The Tramp, a chronicle of one of the last working tramp steamers, based on the diaries he kept during the 19 months in his late teens that he worked on the vessel.

Reading three books at once is easy. It just takes a gadfly mind and an inability to see a task through. But what adoes it take to write three books at a time? Seventeen clear hours a day, six days a week to work unmolested, in Christopher Lee's case. He rises at 5.30am, and after a livener of tea, plunges into prose production.

This schedule has enabled him to produce 25 books and 50-odd plays for Radio 4, including six series of a political drama, The House. He has commissions for the next seven years, including a new radio comedy series.

One explanation for his prolific output is his remarkably rich hinterland of interests and careers: apart from historian, journalist (ex-BBC defence and foreign-affairs man) and merchant mariner, he has been a Cambridge don, a jazz trumpeter and a scriptwriter on the Archers. The books range across travel, cricket, military strategy, and a whodunnit trilogy called The Bath Detective.

His fascinations with history and boats stem from early childhood. "My father's family were Kent fishermen. I loved being on the water. I felt at home there." He grew up on the Erith marshes and, as a boy, learnt to sail in a small sailing skull in the creeks of the Thames. That was how he began to think in terms of time. "If somebody asked me: 'How far is Shoeburyness?' I'd reply: 'If you catch the top of the tide it's about four hours. I wouldn't know in miles'."

When the headmaster of the village school summoned Lee's father to tell him that his son ought to go to university, his dad replied that there was a place reserved for him at the machine-tool factory where his grandfather worked. Horrified at this prospect, the 16-year-old Lee ran away to sea.

He did eventually get to university, and - much later, after his career as a BBC correspondent - became a fellow at Emmanuel College, Cambridge, researching historical origins of political and strategic decision making.

It was while he was at Cambridge that he did a nine-month stint on the Archers, the result of a casual remark to the soap's then editor about fancying a turn at doing a script. "My writing for The Archers was the only thing that impressed them at Emmanuel."

Cambridge, he says, was "idyllic. But I didn't think I was making much contribution to the college." So he left.

How does he square his hectic work schedule with family life? His two daughters - an actress and a garden designer - are grown-up. His wife of 30 years lives in Sussex and runs a flourishing business. "We are really great chums. We love each other." But it is a relationship which thrives on periodic meetings, he says. "She came for Christmas and had the grace to go on Boxing Day."

fields.headline: Ghosts of the self
fields.standfirst: Nick Hasted  heralds the return of a master of horror, Peter Straub, with Mr X
fields.trailText: Nick Hasted heralds the return of a master of horror, Peter Straub, with Mr X
fields.body:
Mr X
Peter Straub
HarperCollins, £10.99, 482pp
Buy it at BOL

Peter Straub made his name in horror's gold-rush years with Ghost Story (1979), a fusion of honed literary style learned from classic supernatural fiction - Hawthorne, Poe - and the gaudy pop-culture revisionism of Stephen King. Its chill opening lines - "What was the worst thing you've ever done? I won't tell you that, but I'll tell you the worst thing that ever happened to me" - laid out the themes that have obsessed him since: the past as an unsevered, vengeful afterbirth to the present; the doubling and shadowing of characters; tales within tales; and the fracturing of reality as the protagonist - always a writer - falls into his fictional terrain.

Floating Dragon (1983) summed up the genre's apocalyptic tendencies at the time, while Koko (1988), a transitional work, let an ambiguously supernatural serial killer rise from an atrocity-haunted Vietnam past in a poetic riff on random violence. With The Throat (1993), Straub shucked his horror skin entirely. The themes he had sustained so resourcefully - the connections between history, fiction and personality, genre exploring its own place in the world - had been tackled to the ground. Could there be an encore?

Mr X leaves the answer unclear. His first four-square horror fiction since Floating Dragon, it is a variation on the doppelganger myth. Its narrator, Ned Dunstan, is a man who has lost his shadow, a supernatural twin he knows only as an absence. Returning to his midwest hometown, he's sucked into the lives of his outlandish relations and the secrets they harbour. There are frequent interjections from the malicious Mr X, who believes himself to be the spawn of the alien gods invented by 1930s horror writer HP Lovecraft.

It's business as usual, then, especially when Mr X's own bad Lovecraft tribute is excerpted: another tale within a tale. But this is repetition on a reduced scale; a micro-genre analysis where whole chunks of literature were gulped down before. Straub's voice seems clogged, as does a previously sound ear for dialogue; too many scenes ring soap-opera false. The social conservatism that King accused Straub of 20 years ago creeps out, making Mr X's sadistic impatience with niceties a constant relief.

But the cardboard blandness of the respectable citizens is undercut by the ferocity in the fog-shrouded, twisting back alleys where urchins linger, a 1930s pulp slip in time. The shadow theme is also explored in a fascinatingly subtle way: the Dunstans' ethnicity (they're black) is referred to only obliquely - a shadow-identity made troubling, like Ned's twin, almost entirely through absence. This is minor work by Straub's standards, but it has its own secrets.

fields.headline: Sacred geographies
fields.standfirst: William Dalrymple  hails John Keay's assured guide to India's disputed past
fields.trailText: William Dalrymple hails John Keay's assured guide to India's disputed past
fields.body:
India: A History
John Keay
HarperCollins, £24.99, 576pp

If in Britain academic history is sometimes perceived as the preserve of the specialist in the ivory tower, in India it is a very different story. In a region where even the most basic facts of history are disputed by rival parties, historians find themselves on the political frontline, their position and tenure open to direct political interference.

With the rise of the Hindu nationalist BJP in the last couple of years, the power balance among historians has now swung decisively towards the right. Soon after the new government was sworn in, two of the presiding deities of Indian historiography - Romila Thapar and Irfan Habib - were summarily removed from their positions both on the Indian Council for Historical Research (the Indian equivalent of the British Academy, which awards grants to students embarking on doctorates) and on the Prasar Bharati (where the two had overseen the historical content of what was broadcast on Indian television and radio).

They were replaced by a collection of extremely dubious figures from the lunatic fringe of the far right, one of whom, KS Lal, was later quoted as saying "People who were labelled communalist are now in power. Now it's our turn to write the history."

Lal had provided a figleaf of academic respectability for the fundamentalist World Hindu Council in its campaign to destroy the mosque at Ayodhya in 1992. While most historians correctly stated that there was no evidence that the mosque had been built over a pre-existing Hindu temple, still less that such a temple had marked the birthplace of the god Ram, Lal dissented from the majority view.

As the historians bickered, the three domes of the mosque fell like discarded symbols of India's once-vaunted traditions of democracy, secularism and tolerance. In the days that followed, mobs went on the rampage across India as Muslims were hunted down, burned alive in their homes, scalded by acid bombs or knifed in the streets. When the army was finally brought in, at least 1,400 had been slaughtered in Bombay alone.

Under the new BJP government, the rewriting of school textbooks has now begun in earnest, with India's Muslim rulers being depicted as little more than a stream of violent, barbarous and oppressive invaders. In Delhi I was recently shown one of these "history" books, in which it was written that the Taj Mahal and the Red Fort were built and commissioned by Hindus. The Moghuls, it claimed, were simply not capable of producing such buildings.

In an environment where every fact is infinitely malleable, every interpretation politicised, the need for clear, accessible and unbiased popular history is all the greater. It is hard to imagine anyone succeeding more gracefully in producing a balanced overview than John Keay has done in India: A History.

It is, of course, a massive task: 5,000 years of history covering an area much larger and more diverse than Europe. Yet, astonishingly, Keay has produced a book that is as fluent and readable as it is up-to-date and impartial. Hardly a page passes without some fascinating nugget or surprising fact. Whether dealing with the courtesans of ancient India (who, we learn, kept elephants for showering themselves with scent), Tipu Sultan's botanical interests (the Tiger of Mysore was an enthusiastic silk farmer) or Arundhati Roy's views on the "Hindu" bomb (very gloomy indeed), Keay manages to be both authoritative and accessible. This is a particular achievement in the early part of the book: it is one thing to be able to poke fun at the snobberies and dissimulations of that richly comical institution, the Raj, quite another to get good mileage out of Mahabarat-period pottery distributions.

The great Sanskritist Diana Eck once wrote that "Considering its long history, India has had but a few hours of political and administrative unity. Its unity as a nation, however, has been firmly constituted by the sacred geography it has held in common and revered: its mountains, forests, rivers, hilltop shrines." What has united India, in other words, is not so much its fragmented political past as its cultural and religious sense of itself as a place apart. For Keay, who aims to provide an unashamedly old-fashioned battles-and-dynasties account of Indian history, this provides a major challenge: when every region of India has its own complex story, how do you begin to create a single coherent narrative?

India has rarely been governed by one ruler; its history is made up of a rapid succession of regional dynasties, their war elephants and camel cavalry crossing the burning plains with the regularity of the summer monsoon. Trying to make sense of this rapidly changing dynastic kaleidoscope is never going to be easy, but it is essential if the story is to be properly told, and not simply presented as a series of patriotic attempts to unite India interrupted by long periods of "foreign rule" or "anarchy".

Yet, as Keay points out, there has been a conscious effort by India's postcolonial historians to subvert the truth of its disjointed past and suppress regional history as somehow anti-national: "Such today is Delhi's and Islamabad's paranoia about secessionist movements [that] the recollection of the regions' independent status is not much promoted... habitually disparaged as divisive, 'regional' history has few champions in the Senior Common Rooms of power."

Keay convincingly demonstrates that this is the reason why the achievements of culturally important regional dynasties have tended to be diminished in favour of those of their more militaristic pan-Indian rivals, who have (as the nationalist historiography would have it) "aroused the nation". Equally, nationalistic pride has led to the semi-deliberate neglect of some of India's most fascinating and productive periods when it was under "foreign" rule; so it is, for example, that the remarkable (but Central Asian and Buddhist) Kushans are routinely compared unfavourably with the homegrown and reassuringly Hindu "Golden" Guptas.

There has never been a lack of voices to argue for India's individuality; as the Arab scholar al-Biruni noted in the 11th century: "The Hindus believe that no country is like theirs, no nation like theirs, no king like theirs, no religion like theirs, no science like theirs." Yet if there is one abiding impression that one takes away from Keay's extraordinary panorama, it is the overwhelmingly cosmopolitan and pluralistic nature of Indian history.

The greatest moments, culturally speaking, took place when India was at its most open to foreign influence: when the Kushans traded and debated with Romans and Persians and produced the wonders of Indo-Hellenic Gandharan sculpture; when Nizamuddin brought Turk and Rajput together to create the mysticism of the Indian Sufi and the Indian Sufi's great love song, the Qawwali; when the Mughals mixed together the Hindu and Muslim architectural ideas that resulted in the Taj.

As a BJP-governed, nuclear India seems to be heading towards another period of inward-looking nationalism, and as pluralism is replaced - as it has been intermittently through Indian history - by a period of savage polarisation, one can only hope that John Keay's India will be widely read, and its lessons taken to heart.

In the days that followed, mobs went on the rampage across India as Muslims were hunted down, burned alive in their homes, scalded by acid bombs or knifed in the streets. When the army was finally brought in, at least 1,400 had been slaughtered in Bombay alone. Under the new BJP government, the rewriting of school textbooks has now begun in earnest, with India's Muslim rulers being depicted as little more than a stream of violent, barbarous and oppressive invaders. In Delhi I was recently shown one of these "history" books, in which it was written that the Taj Mahal and the Red Fort were built and commissioned by Hindus. The Moghuls, it claimed, were simply not capable of producing such buildings. In an environment where every fact is infinitely malleable, every interpretation politicised, the need for clear, accessible and unbiased popular history is all the greater. It is hard to imagine anyone succeeding more gracefully in producing a balanced overview than John Keay has done in India: A History. It is, of course, a massive task: 5,000 years of history covering an area much larger and more diverse than Europe. Yet, astonishingly, Keay has produced a book that is as fluent and readable as it is up-to-date and impartial. Hardly a page passes without some fascinating nugget or surprising fact. Whether dealing with the courtesans of ancient India (who, we learn, kept elephants for showering themselves with scent), Tipu Sultan's botanical interests (the Tiger of Mysore was an enthusiastic silk farmer) or Arundhati Roy's views on the "Hindu" bomb (very gloomy indeed), Keay manages to be both authoritative and accessible. This is a particular achievement in the early part of the book: it is one thing to be able to poke fun at the snobberies and dissimulations of that richly comical institution, the Raj, quite another to get good mileage out of Mahabarat-period pottery distributions. The great Sanskritist Diana Eck once wrote that "Considering its long history, India has had but a few hours of political and administrative unity. Its unity as a nation, however, has been firmly constituted by the sacred geography it has held in common and revered: its mountains, forests, rivers, hilltop shrines." What has united India, in other words, is not so much its fragmented political past as its cultural and religious sense of itself as a place apart. For Keay, who aims to provide an unashamedly old-fashioned battles-and-dynasties account of Indian history, this provides a major challenge: when every region of India has its own complex story, how do you begin to create a single coherent narrative? India has rarely been governed by one ruler; its history is made up of a rapid succession of regional dynasties, their war elephants and camel cavalry crossing the burning plains with the regularity of the summer monsoon. Trying to make sense of this rapidly changing dynastic kaleidoscope is never going to be easy, but it is essential if the story is to be properly told, and not simply presented as a series of patriotic attempts to unite India interrupted by long periods of "foreign rule" or "anarchy". Yet, as Keay points out, there has been a conscious effort by India's postcolonial historians to subvert the truth of its disjointed past and suppress regional history as somehow anti-national: "Such today is Delhi's and Islamabad's paranoia about secessionist movements [that] the recollection of the regions' independent status is not much promoted... habitually disparaged as divisive, 'regional' history has few champions in the Senior Common Rooms of power." Keay convincingly demonstrates that this is the reason why the achievements of culturally important regional dynasties have tended to be diminished in favour of those of their more militaristic pan-Indian rivals, who have (as the nationalist historiography would have it) "aroused the nation". Equally, nationalistic pride has led to the semi-deliberate neglect of some of India's most fascinating and productive periods when it was under "foreign" rule; so it is, for example, that the remarkable (but Central Asian and Buddhist) Kushans are routinely compared unfavourably with the homegrown and reassuringly Hindu "Golden" Guptas. There has never been a lack of voices to argue for India's individuality; as the Arab scholar al-Biruni noted in the 11th century: "The Hindus believe that no country is like theirs, no nation like theirs, no king like theirs, no religion like theirs, no science like theirs." Yet if there is one abiding impression that one takes away from Keay's extraordinary panorama, it is the overwhelmingly cosmopolitan and pluralistic nature of Indian history. The greatest moments, culturally speaking, took place when India was at its most open to foreign influence: when the Kushans traded and debated with Romans and Persians and produced the wonders of Indo-Hellenic Gandharan sculpture; when Nizamuddin brought Turk and Rajput together to create the mysticism of the Indian Sufi and the Indian Sufi's great love song, the Qawwali; when the Mughals mixed together the Hindu and Muslim architectural ideas that resulted in the Taj. As a BJP-governed, nuclear India seems to be heading towards another period of inward-looking nationalism, and as pluralism is replaced - as it has been intermittently through Indian history - by a period of savage polarisation, one can only hope that John Keay's India will be widely read, and its lessons taken to heart.

fields.headline: The making of Maggie
fields.standfirst: Luck, ambition, weedy opponents and spin:  John Campbell reveals the heady brew that forged the Iron Lady in Margaret Thatcher Volume One
fields.trailText: Luck, ambition, weedy opponents and spin: John Campbell reveals the heady brew that forged the Iron Lady in Margaret Thatcher Volume One
fields.body:
Margaret Thatcher Volume One: The Grocer's Daughter
John Campbell
Jonathan Cape, £25, 512pp

First, a brief exercise in what-if history. It is autumn 1978. Heartened by a clutch of broadly favourable opinion polls, and after a starring appearance at the TUC conference, James Callaghan decides to go to the country. The short, bitter election campaign that follows is dominated by some unexpectedly useful economic statistics and a serious Tory gaffe over immigration. The trades unions are cajoled into issuing a policy statement that could just be decoded as implying support for further wage restraint. In the end, Labour wins a small but workable majority.

Rattled by its third election defeat in four years, the Conservative Party implodes into civil war. Margaret Thatcher is pushed out by a cabal of grandees (Whitelaw, Pym, Gilmour et al) who then steer through, oh, I don't know, James Prior or Geoffrey Howe as a "unity" candidate. The Winter of Discontent, the Social Democratic Party and the Falklands don't happen, Labour wins a fourth election in a row and Thatcher - for the past three years an embittered backbench sybil surrounded by a dissident fringe - resigns her seat to run the Open University.

Now, none of this sounds especially plausible or even - let us be honest - desirable, does it? And yet Callaghan very nearly did go to the country late in 1978 (Melvyn Bragg wrote a novel about this phantom election, Autumn Manoeuvres). Had he done so, there was a fair chance of victory. Had he won, the break-up and reformation of the Old Left - a virtual guarantee of Thatcher's two subsequent landslides - would probably still have happened, but in a much less dramatic and more electorally manageable way.

All down to luck, then - a commodity with which Thatcher the politician, as John Campbell shows in the first half of a planned two-volume life, was almost effortlessly endowed. Her rise to the top of the Tories' greasy pole early in 1975 was, as he points out, achieved only by way of some swingeing strokes of good fortune.

Heath could have held on, had he immediately submitted himself for re-election after the October 1974 defeat, but he queered his pitch by petulance. Sir Keith Joseph, the Right's standard-bearer, blew it with an injudicious speech about the underclass. Edward du Cann, who could have had the leadership on a plate at one point, found that his business affairs wouldn't stand up to the inevitable public scrutiny. Helped by an astute campaign manager, Airey Neave, party-wide dislike of Heath and some particularly weedy opponents, Mrs Thatcher found herself borne aloft on a tide of grassroots adulation to the party throne.

Perhaps, on the other hand, the charmed political life that she led in the mid-1970s was merely a reward for early tenacity. While the account of her formative years in The Grocer's Daughter lacks something of the drama occasionally offered in the council-slum-to-Westminster biographies of one or two (but not many) Labour politicians, nobody should doubt the very real obstacles that the young Miss Roberts had to climb over in order to make something of her life.

Of course dad was a local politician-cum-shopkeeper (Mrs Roberts looks simply to have vanished from her daughter's memory), of course she made it to grammar school, but her adolescent life seems to have consisted of laborious progress along a path measured out in exacting toll-gates: schoolmistresses who doubted her ability (she enjoyed snubbing them on celebrity revisits); snooty, left-leaning dons who frankly despised the religious and conservative tradesman's daughter for not being "one of us".

Campbell's Oxford chapter is particularly revealing of a dogged, lonely girl, occupying time not spent in the labs with solitary walks and the John Wesley Society, and patronised rotten by her tutors. The retrospective verdicts pronounced by Somerville luminaries such as Janet Vaughan and Dorothy Hodgkin (sample: "She was a perfectly adequate chemist. I mean, nobody thought anything of her") seem peculiarly malicious, if only because of their skewed values - such Olympian academic standards used to judge a 19-year-old barely disguise the fact that the snub is a reward for present, not past, inadequacies.

What was the young Miss Roberts like? All Campbell's evidence, whether from college contemporaries, twenty-something onlookers or later political colleagues, tells the same story: fanatically hard-working, bursting with drive and enthusiasm, let down by a lack of "imagination". When given a task to accomplish - finals, bar exams, or, in 1950 and 1951, election campaigns in a hopeless Labour seat - she simply got on with it, won golden opinions and, occasionally, scared people with the intensity of her application.

The political ambitions, in place since college days, were boosted by what might be called her defining stroke of luck - marriage to the wealthy divorcé whose modest fortune effectively subsidised her ascent through the Tory hierarchy. Even then, though - even with Denis, the twins and their nannies - it was a struggle.

Safe Home Counties seats in the 1950s wanted decorous ex-public schoolboys. Once in parliament, on the 1959 Macmillan floodtide, she was a ripe target for cheery Labour chauvinism. Dispatch-box appearances in the role of pensions minister were punctuated by banter about "vital statistics". Showing the first hint of the unworldliness that characterised her political life, Thatcher often brought her own innuendoes to the chamber. "I have got a really hot figure..." she innocently proposed at one point.

As Campbell shows, the young parliamentarian was an isolated figure - spurned by the grandees, thought overly "suburban" by her peers. Her efficiency was undeniable, though, and the role of the party's 1960s "token woman" seemed to have been made for her. Heath put her in his 1970 cabinet as education secretary, and subsequently appointed her to the shadow Treasury team fighting the 1974 finance bill. In giving her the chance to shine in front of an appreciative Tory audience, he probably sealed his own doom.

Like his earlier life of Heath, Campbell's biography is brilliantly - and horribly - acute. With diligent research among the Conservative Central Office archives and a sharp eye for the amnesiac wool-pulling practised in the subject's own memoirs, he locates the roots of the Thatcher agenda - roll back the state, individual freedom, the whole updated Manchester liberal package - far back in her career. At the same time she was an enthusiastic trimmer when circumstances demanded it: chary of privatisation when the mid-1960s consensus frowned upon it, and as education secretary offering notably little resistance to the Croslandite reforms, outlined in circular 10/65, which secured the forward march of the comprehensive schools.

The book ends with its subject quoting Gide on the steps of Downing Street, already a markedly different creature from the woman with the mumsy hairstyle and splendiferous teeth who had won the leadership four years before. As Campbell winningly demonstrates, the spin doctors got hold of her at a relatively early stage, played up the lower-middle-class background (Denis's wealth was conveniently forgotten) and trammelled the rhetoric to produce a series of provocative but oddly insubstantial implications.

The 1978 immigration speeches were a classic example of hinting a great deal but saying remarkably little: Campbell shrewdly calls it a "measure of her political weakness... that she was obliged to hint at attitudes whose implications she could not fully expound, but a mark of her political skills that she was able to do so successfully".

How did she do it? Unlike the majority of left-wing critics of the past 20 years, who allowed their distaste for Thatcher to blind them to the nature of her appeal and the feebleness of her opponents, Campbell is in no doubt as to her allure for millions of exasperated middle-class voters in 1979. Exhausted state corporatism and self-aggrandising trades unions were no match for the values of the god-fearing, counter-jumping petit bourgeoisie. Like many another newly enfranchised 18-year-old, I voted Conservative in 1979. At the time it seemed a perfectly straightforward reaction to the stew of rubbish, lies and refusal to face facts that marked out the 1970s. As Campbell's second volume will no doubt show, the embarrassment - and the regret - came later.

fields.headline: The list
fields.trailText: Female? Confused? Worry no longer. Plus
fields.body:
The Bitch Rules
Elizabeth Wurtzel
(Quartet, £6)
Buy it at BOL
Read an extract

Female? Confused? Worry no longer. Wear men's Levi's, have a conversation with God every day, eat pudding voraciously, don't clear up after dinner, hire a cleaning lady, watch films and have political opinions. Poses as radical; is in fact deeply anti-feminist: most chapters end with lines like "Men, by the way, find this trait very attractive", and the most important rule is not to forget settling down with a man. So a bitch is a man-centred sex-kitten, after all. Approachable, not threatening. Which explains why the cover of the book is identical to that of Wurtzel's Bitch, except that she's no longer naked, and no longer giving us the finger. Obscurely disappointing.

The Beatles, Popular Music and Society: A Thousand Voices
ed Ian Inglis
(Macmillan, £12.99)
Buy it at BOL

Wonderfully mad symposium of academic essays on the fab four. Histograms showing the varying incidence of the words "I", "you" and "love" over the albums, hardcore musicological analysis (Lennon and McCartney "clearly favour complete major scales over major pentatonics and hexatonics"), and a round-up of dissenting voices in the 1960s.

The Fragile Absolute
Slavoj Zizek
(Verso, £16)

Righteously to battle the tsunami of postmodern spiritual mush, Zizek attempts a reconciliation between Marxism and Christianity, eccentrically (against Nietzsche) trying to recuperate St Paul for the radical Christian. The thudding psychoanalytic apparatus of Zizek's prose, and his chronic rhetoricism (favourite sentence construction: "Is not...?"), engender a rebarbative fog through which Zizek's many brilliant insights about the nature of culture and capital glimmer only darkly

fields.headline: Imaginary numbers
fields.standfirst: John McCrone  finds that Keith Devlin's argument in The Maths Gene doesn't add up
fields.trailText: John McCrone finds that Keith Devlin's argument in The Maths Gene doesn't add up
fields.body:
The Maths Gene: Why Everyone Has It, But Most People Don't Use It
Keith Devlin
Weidenfeld, £9.99, 320pp
Buy it at BOL

It's certainly a seductive premise. Anyone can do maths: we all have the gene, even if most of us never quite get round to using it. And who better to tell the story than Keith Devlin, the hyper-productive, award-winning author of 24 previous books on logic and mathematical thought? Sadly, the gene for factual accuracy seems to have passed Devlin by. Whether discussing neurology, human evolution or genetics - anything but maths itself - Devlin peppers The Maths Gene with the most basic howlers. The effect is to undermine what might otherwise have been a useful corrective to some popular misconceptions about mathematically inclined brains.

The first howler lies in the title. Devlin at least distances himself quickly from this, admitting that of course there can be no gene for "doing maths". Instead, what he wants to consider is how Homo sapiens became capable of mathematical thought. And his perfectly sensible thesis is that maths must have piggy-backed on the invention of language and the capacity for logical thought that resulted.

He begins with a concise account of what maths is all about. First, he agrees that it is a remarkably recent invention, appearing as a formal mode of thought only a couple of thousand years ago. Indeed, the bulk of mathematics is barely a century old. In 1900, he says, the whole lot could fit into just 80 textbooks; now, you would need 100,000.

Devlin is also clear on why maths is hard for most people. It is a uniquely abstract way of thinking, wherein "x"s and "y"s replace everyday concrete objects. The trick is to make these abstractions come alive - to create a mental world in which concepts such as pi or associative symmetry become as familiar as characters in a soap opera.

Mathematicians come to know instinctively the way the cast members interact, so find it easy to imagine how they might be spun into new plot lines. Anyone can learn to be a mathematician if they can get on first-name terms with the abstractions; it's just that schooling rarely inspires people to make the effort. So far, so good - and familiar territory to readers of Devlin's earlier works. Then comes his excursion into evolutionary psychology.

Devlin argues (along with many others) that all the higher mental faculties of humans, from self-awareness to rational thought, are connected with the development of language. The ability to construct grammatical sentences - cause-and-effect tales about who did what to whom - became the engine driving logical thought. It allowed for "off-line" thinking, making it possible for individuals to turn away from the here and now and think about the past and the future, the remembered and the imagined - and, for the suitably trained, the scientific and the mathematical.

Unfortunately, while Devlin has skimmed enough of the science to capture the gist of a currently fashionable argument, he comes alarmingly - even laughably - unstuck on many simple matters of fact. For example, attempting to illustrate the principles of evolution, he tells how birds developed out of small dinosaurs with cooling fins on their backs. The dinosaurs flapped their fins to increase the cooling effect; eventually, as these fins slid down the side of the body, they became wings. Which would be fine, except that bird wings are modified forelimbs, as anyone who has had a chicken dinner will know.

There are many other such errors. Most of them are fairly irrelevant to his wider story, but eventually the sloppy grasp of biology and human evolution begins to tell. For very tenuous reasons, Devlin becomes convinced that language must have emerged within a single generation. Either one lucky ancestor had a freak mutation and went on to spawn a crop of talking kids, or else the brains of a group of hominids somehow reached a critical juncture of complexity at the same moment and simply convulsed into the circuit arrangement needed for speech. At which point the old fin/wing story starts sounding almost plausible.

As a general account of the development of mathematical ability, Devlin just about puts two and two together. However, a lack of homework means his arguments have none of the logic or rigour one ought really to expect from a mathematically trained brain.

 John McCrone's guide to the science of consciousness

At which point the old fin/wing story starts sounding almost plausible. As a general account of the development of mathematical ability, Devlin just about puts two and two together. However, a lack of homework means his arguments have none of the logic or rigour one ought really to expect from a mathematically trained brain.  John McCrone's guide to the science of consciousness

fields.headline: The tide is with Trimble
fields.standfirst:
Hardliners say no, but his people say yes

Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Hope is such a fickle creature in Northern Ireland. It flutters into view, as it did last weekend, and then dives almost out of sight, as now. It is not that the optimism unleashed by the IRA's proposal - to open its arms dumps to outside inspection - was unfounded. Rather, that any move forward in Northern Ireland is almost always followed by a couple of steps back. And so it has been this week.
fields.body:
Hope is such a fickle creature in Northern Ireland. It flutters into view, as it did last weekend, and then dives almost out of sight, as now. It is not that the optimism unleashed by the IRA's proposal - to open its arms dumps to outside inspection - was unfounded. Rather, that any move forward in Northern Ireland is almost always followed by a couple of steps back. And so it has been this week.

For Ulster's rejectionists - the men who like to say no - were wrongfooted by the IRA move. They did not know how to reject it. Some were so surprised, they even let themselves welcome it; but they have quickly found their familiar feet. Thus John Taylor, deputy leader and weathervane of Ulster Unionism, who last weekend was positively statesmanlike in his response, has now reverted to type. He is back on the negative script, predicting trouble if David Trimble seeks to win approval for re-entering devolved government from the UUP's ruling council when it meets a week from today.

Even more dispiriting is the clear impression that Mr Taylor and others are searching not so much for an accommodation with nationalism and republicanism as for a way to prevent that ever happening. So just as the decommissioning issue had seemed on the brink of resolution, new obstacles have appeared to cast an extra shadow. The insistence that the Royal Ulster Constabulary be allowed to keep (some variation of) its name is growing: Mr Trimble will need to win some movement on this matter if he is to face down his hardliners. But Mr Taylor has also breathed fresh life into a pseudo-issue: flags. He wants to make sure the Union Jack flies from official buildings during public holidays. With self-serving gestures like this, which make life so much tougher for Mr Trimble and all those who seek peace, it is hard to believe that anything would ever be enough. The likes of Jeffrey Donaldson and Martin Smyth, Unionism's no-men, would surely reject even a white flag waved by Sinn Fein and the IRA - complaining that the republicans had not sung God Save the Queen as they offered their surrender.

Still, Mr Trimble and his fellow accommodationists ought not lose heart. BBC Northern Ireland this week conducted an admirably thorough survey of opinion in the province. It found that two in three UUP voters want the party to go back into the executive in time for the May 22 deadline. Even if the margin in the 858-member council will be much narrower than that, Mr Trimble need not fear for his political life nor the life of the peace process. For the hardliners in the council are not in step with the party's own electorate. According to the BBC poll, those Unionist voters are with their leader - and for peace.

fields.headline: Love, Labour won
fields.trailText: Why along with other Sunday papers were you so pessimistic about the effect of the result of the London mayoral election on Labour's fortunes (Comment, last week)? Far from being a disaster for Labour, the mayoral election was a triumph. The candidate chosen by the vast majority of members of the London Labour parties was elected with a substantial majority.
